title: Africa Calling
snippet: The continent, with the youngest population in the world, is increasingly influencing global culture. We looked at 12 people leading the way.
lead_paragraph: [This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.]

title: East Africa's Loss, South Africa's Gain
snippet: Tourism is picking up in South Africa after slowdown that followed Sept 11, but bookings are still way off in Kenya and Tanzania, where two American embassies were bombed four years ago; photo (M) (Special section, Vacation)
lead_paragraph: THE number of American visitors to South Africa dropped 13 percent in the months just after Sept. 11, the state tourism agency here says, but since then it has picked up and appears to be climbing. This is in contrast to countries like Kenya and Tanzania, where the bombings of two American embassies received considerable publicity four years ago. Travel agents are still reporting sharp declines in bookings in that region, as much as 25 percent in some cases. East Africa's tourist woes have meant more business for South Africa, which is increasingly viewed as a safe haven for people eager to glimpse the wildlife.

title: All of Africa’s a Stage
snippet: Alan Riding reviews book Assassinating Shakespeare: The True Confessions of a Bard in the Bush by Thomas Goltz; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ASSASSINATING SHAKESPEARE

title: AFRICAN GOLD DEAL
snippet: AngloGold Ltd of South Africa will pay $205 million for 50 percent stake in Tanzanian mine owned by Ashanti Goldfields Ltd of Ghana and will provide up to $130 million in financing for mine; deal will provide financial relief for Ashanti, which ha...
lead_paragraph: In a move to expand its operations into countries with lower operating costs, AngloGold Ltd. of South Africa, the world's biggest gold producer, will pay $205 million for a 50 percent stake in a Tanzanian mine owned by Ashanti Goldfields Ltd. of Ghana and will provide up to $130 million in financing for the mine. The deal will provide financial relief to Ashanti, which has been trying to stave off bankruptcy after its gamble on gold prices last year backfired. Henri E. Cauvin

title: South Africa's Gilding; South Africa
Out of Africa
snippet: Excerpts from previously published reviews of African restaurants in New York (Good Eating column) (M)
lead_paragraph: February, which is Black History Month, is a good time to explore the exotic foods at these often overlooked African restaurants.

title: ‘The African Desperate’ Review: Double Speak
snippet: Martine Syms’s whip-smart satire brings the invisible, everyday negotiations of a Black artist to startlingly visual life.
lead_paragraph: Martine Syms’s debut feature derives its title from a Freudian slip. In the opening scene, as Palace (Diamond Stingily), a sculptor at an upstate New York art school, describes her thesis project to an all-white faculty panel, she mispronounces “African diaspora” as “African desperate.” It sounds nonsensical, but no one bats an eye, and the professors continue with their jargon-riddled commentary. This is the art world, a place as open to absurdity as it is closed to diversity. Here, people say made-up terms with grave conviction yet are incredulous that a Black woman like Palace has made it to the Venice Biennale.

title: ‘Africa Rising’? ‘Africa Reeling’ May Be More Fitting Now
snippet: Protests, civil war and economic problems are undermining a recent belief that the African continent was in a period of strong economic growth.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — For decades Africa was eager for a new narrative, and in recent years it got a snappy one.

title: Africa Kine
snippet: A Senegalese restaurant reopens in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: A Senegalese restaurant reopens in Harlem.

title: Finding an Aesthetic in the ‘Year of Africa’
snippet: 17 African countries declared independence in 1960. Archival photographs capture the mood of the period 60 years later.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Affordable Trips to South Africa
snippet: Cape Town, Johannesburg and Cape Winelands are among the destinations travel companies are offering. Itineraries include game drives and city tours.
lead_paragraph: South Africa is a coveted destination this year for travelers from the United States: According to data from South African Tourism, the first quarter of 2017 saw a 6.3 percent increase in visitors from the United States to South Africa, compared with the first quarter of 2016. Also, the airfare prediction app Hopper saw a 36 percent increase in flight searches this spring for travel in the fall to South Africa from the United States, compared with the same period last year.

title: Made in Africa
snippet: From Ethiopia to Kenya, local manufacturers have partnered with Western brands to make stylish shoes produced and sourced entirely on the African continent.
lead_paragraph: From Ethiopia to Kenya, a flurry of local manufacturers and craftsmen have partnered with Western apparel brands to make stylish shoes produced and sourced entirely on the African continent. There are rubber-soled cotton canvas low-tops from Mombasa, suede tennis shoes from Addis Ababa and crepe-soled nubuck loafers that incorporate materials from Mauritius, Liberia and South Africa.

title: U.N. Court Hears Arguments From South Africa on Israel’s Push Into Rafah
snippet: South Africa asked the court to order Israel to immediately withdraw from the southern Gaza city, where more than a million Palestinians had sought shelter from the war.
lead_paragraph: South Africa on Thursday urged the judges of the United Nations’ top court to order Israel to end its ground assault on Rafah in southern Gaza, saying it put Palestinian life in the enclave at imminent risk of destruction.

title: Yoga in Africa
snippet: Robert Sturman, a California artist, traveled to Kenya to document the work of the Africa Yoga Project, a nonprofit group that teaches and employs yoga teachers and conducts free classes in institutions like prisons and orphanages.
lead_paragraph: The language of yoga is universal. That is the message of Robert Sturman, an artist from Santa Monica, Calif., who has traveled across the United States to capture the tranquillity and beauty of yoga. A month ago, Mr. Sturman traveled to Kenya to document the work of the Africa Yoga Project, a nonprofit organization that teaches and employs more than 70 local yoga teachers and conducts up to 300 free yoga classes for more than 5,000 people weekly in orphanages, prisons and other locales throughout the country.

title: 'Pride of Carthage': Africans Abroad
snippet: Susannah Meadows reviews book The Sea of Tears by Nani Power; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: PRIDE OF CARTHAGE A Novel of Hannibal. By David Anthony Durham. 568 pp. Doubleday. $26.95.

title: The Real Africa
snippet: The reaction to the Boko Haram atrocities in Nigeria is positive, yet indicative of a widespread misunderstanding of Africa.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Binyavanga Wainaina published a brilliantly sarcastic essay in Granta called “How to Write About Africa,” advising people on how to sound spiritual and compassionate while writing a book about the continent.

title: Lupita Nyong’o Shines a Light on Africa
snippet: Lupita Nyong’o, Danai Gurira and Liesl Tommy talk about their collaboration on “Eclipsed,” which begins previews at the Public on Sept. 29.
lead_paragraph: A few days after arriving at the Yale School of Drama from Kenya in 2009, Lupita Nyong’o found herself understudying in a professional production of “Eclipsed,” Danai Gurira’s harrowing play about women in the second Liberian civil war.

title: African Chronicles
snippet: Images from “Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Images from “Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A Festival at the Intersection of Amsterdam and Africa
snippet: Language, meaning, interpretation, translation: These themes resonate in William Kentridge and Faustin Linyekula’s Holland Festival programming.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — William Kentridge stood at a podium and waved a hand authoritatively. “Fumms bö wö tää zää Uu, pögiff, kwii Ee,” he said decisively. The audience at the Frascati Theater here laughed as Mr. Kentridge continued to speak the meaningless — yet somehow meaning-filled — nonwords that make up the 1932 sound poem, “Ursonate,” by the artist Kurt Schwitters.

title: After 40 Years of Dance, What Happens to a Dream Fulfilled?
snippet: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, who founded Urban Bush Women four decades ago, says goodbye to it with a final work.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the early 1980s, the choreographer Jawole Willa Jo Zollar had a life-changing dream. Her dead parents, Dot and Al, appeared in it along with other ancestors. They all ate at a table in the middle of the ocean, and her father sang of his failure, cautioning against chasing after outside approval, repeating the phrase “Success is not the test.” A wave crashed over them, and Zollar knew what she had to do.

lead_paragraph: OLD MIKAMBA HAD A FARM  Written and illustrated by Rachel Isadora.  40 pp. Nancy Paulsen. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

title: A New Danger to Africans
snippet: Africans may become susceptible to a type of malaria that they had long been thought to be immune to because the parasite appears to be evolving, scientists said last week.
lead_paragraph: Africans may become susceptible to a type of malaria that they had long been thought to be immune to because the parasite appears to be evolving, scientists said last week.

title: Rebranding Africa
snippet: The continent is entering the fashion arena, with the quality of its handwork, artistic creativity and its potential for economic growth at the center of the latest issue of Uomo Vogue.
lead_paragraph: Africa is in the news — but not just for the sad and familiar reasons of conflict and suffering. The continent is entering the fashion arena, with the quality of its handwork, artistic creativity and its potential for economic growth bringing Africa literally in vogue.

title: African Books for Western Eyes
snippet: The continent’s writers are being celebrated, but only for catering to Western tastes.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — MY close friend Mercy, when she heard about my novel, congratulated me: I had found out “what the white people wanted to read and given it to them.”

title: A ‘Sex and the City’ for African Viewers
snippet: “An African City,” the steamy Ghanaian web series about five young women looking for love, becomes a critique of both Western and African cultures.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way up front: “An African City,” the steamy Ghanaian web series about five young women looking for love in Accra, is an unabashed rip-off of “Sex and the City.” There are the ubiquitous five-inch strappy sandals, the scene-stealing dresses made of Fanti fabric and the bevy of men who hop in and out of the beds of Nana Yaa, Makena, Zainab and Sade. The women are as free and liberal about sex as their American HBO foremothers, with the exception of the fifth character, Ngozi, who is such a Charlotte.

title: Out of Africa
snippet: In a city in the Sahara, migrants assemble with hopes of escaping to a better life.
lead_paragraph: Agadez, NIGER — It’s Monday and that means it’s moving day in Agadez, the northern Niger desert crossroad that is the main launching pad for migrants out of West Africa. Fleeing devastated agriculture, overpopulation and unemployment, migrants from a dozen countries gather here in caravans every Monday night and make a mad dash through the Sahara to Libya, hoping to eventually hop across the Mediterranean to Europe.

title: Out in Africa
snippet: On gay rights, South Africa puts President Obama to shame.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG

title: African Masterpieces With the Grace of Kings
snippet: A show of royal crests from Cameroon brings you face to face (and soul to soul) with African sculpture.
lead_paragraph: If there was any silver lining to the recent announcement that the Metropolitan Museum of Art would begin charging a mandatory $25 admission fee to out-of-town visitors this spring, it was this: The charge includes admission to all special exhibitions too. Unlike the leading encyclopedic museums of London, Paris or Vienna, the Met will offer a single ticket for its permanent collection and its rotating displays. Bundling those together allows curators to present shows that may not always be easy crowdpleasers and whose importance cannot be assessed by foot traffic alone.

title: Powering Africa
snippet: President Obama’s plan to bring electricity to millions of Africans is promising, but the outcome depends on how it is carried out and whether it is sustained.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s “Power Africa” initiative, unveiled during his recent trip there, has the potential to make a major impact on a continent where millions of people — including more than two-thirds of those in the sub-Saharan region — live every day without reliable access to affordable electricity. But the outcome depends heavily on how the plan is designed and carried out and whether it is sustained.

title: In Brightest Africa
snippet: After relocating its African galleries, the Brooklyn Museum is presenting “African Innovations,” an effective new display in which works are set out with an easily graspable logic.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Museum is doing some territorial reshuffling on its first floor. What has long been the gift shop will soon be a new cafe, while the shop itself will move into a former exhibition gallery nearby. The change will give the museum’s two primary social and commercial attractions a gain in size or visibility, but in the process art is taking a bit of a hit.

title: An African Mermaid
snippet: “Mami Wata” at the National Museum of African Art in Washington is as rousing as a drum roll, as piquant as a samba. Holland Cotter reviews.
lead_paragraph: “Mami Wata” at the National Museum of African Art in Washington is as rousing as a drum roll, as piquant as a samba. Holland Cotter reviews.

title: Number of Africans Bound for South Africa Remains to Be Seen
snippet: Though South Africans have purchased more World Cup tickets than fans from any other country, few Africans outside the host country have had the opportunity to do so, and may not make the long, expensive trip this summer.
lead_paragraph: As the 32 national team managers evaluate players, consider injuries and plot strategy in preparation for the 2010 World Cup, millions of soccer fans around the world are completing their own plans for the  tournament.

title: Not Aiding Africa
snippet: Shoveling aid into Africa is increasingly seen to be counterproductive.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — Less than four years ago, on the back of Tony Blair’s Africa Commission recommendations, the Group of 8 summit meeting at Gleneagles agreed to write off Africa’s debt and to double aid by 2010. Aid, trumpeted the British prime minister and his fellow celebrity travelers from Bono to Bob Geldof, was the answer to Africa’s development woes.

title: The Future Is African
snippet: Afrofuturism, a genre that mixes science fiction with the culture, history and politics of the African diaspora, is driving a lot of contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: Afrofuturism, a genre that mixes science fiction with the culture, history and politics of the African diaspora, is as old as Sun Ra’s 1974 film “Space Is the Place” and as new as Janelle Monáe’s latest album. If you’ve been following artists like Wangechi Mutu, Sanford Biggers or Robert Pruitt, you probably already know that it’s driving a lot of contemporary art. “The Shadows Took Shape,” opening Thursday at the Studio Museum in Harlem, cements the trend with work by 29 artists, including the three mentioned above.

title: Not Aiding Africa
snippet: Shoveling aid into Africa is increasingly seen to be counterproductive.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — Less than four years ago, on the back of Tony Blair’s Africa Commission recommendations, the Group of 8 summit meeting at Gleneagles agreed to write off Africa’s debt and to double aid by 2010. Aid, trumpeted the British prime minister and his fellow celebrity travelers from Bono to Bob Geldof, was the answer to Africa’s development woes.

title: Black Farmers in Georgia Cool to Biden, Reflecting a Bigger Challenge
snippet: White farmers filed lawsuits to block a debt forgiveness initiative, but the Biden administration is still bearing the blame.
lead_paragraph: On a hot day in May, Andrew L. Smith Sr., a vegetable farmer from Ludowici, Ga., listened with skepticism as Tom Vilsack, the U.S. agriculture secretary, touted President Biden’s efforts to help Black farmers overcome decades of discrimination.

title: A School With 7 Students: Inside the ‘Microschools’ Movement
snippet: Parents, desperate for help, are turning to private schools with a half-dozen or so students. And they are getting a financial boost from taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: When Nathanael was in kindergarten, he told his mother, Diana Lopez, that he did not want to return to school — ever. His teacher yelled at him, he said. And when Ms. Lopez picked him up from school, he would often immediately start to cry.

title: The ‘Mad Men’ Era Is Long Over. Why Is Advertising Still So White?
snippet: Despite corporate promises and hiring campaigns, the ad industry is among New York City’s least diverse job sectors. It shows in the work, critics say.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, KFC ran advertisements in Canada featuring Black people eating fried chicken and licking their fingers, their faces reflected in unused silverware.

title: For This Playwright, Africa With Laughter, Not Tears
snippet: In works like “School Girls; or, the African Mean Girls Play,” Jocelyn Bioh aims to tell stories that buck expectation and defy stereotype.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the actress and playwright Jocelyn Bioh decided to write a play about African characters — a searing play, a brutal play, a play that theaters would finally produce. “I was going to write the ‘poverty porn,’ ” she said. “The play about African suffering.”

title: An African Journey
snippet: Pascal Maitre has spent more than three decades photographing events big and small in Africa. His images attest to a continent — and a photographer — constantly adapting.
lead_paragraph: Pascal Maitre has been in motion ever since he went to Africa as a budding photojournalist in 1979. Cast your glance anywhere on a map of the sprawling continent, and chances are Mr. Maitre has been there — from the shores of Dakar, across the Sahel to Chad, south through Rwanda’s lush forests and all the way eastward to Madagascar. And, like his locales, his topics are always changing — desertification in Niger, political turmoil in Somalia and Chad’s oil boom.

lead_paragraph: New books include Atinuke’s “Splash, Anna Hibiscus!,” about a young girl playing on the beach with her family.

title: Out of Africa
snippet: The new men's style director at Louis Vuitton takes his inspiration from his childhood in the wild.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Kim Jones has started his new role as men’s style director at Louis Vuitton  with a mission: to embrace, via the luxury label’s travel history, the craft and culture of Africa.

title: Stories That Explore Africa’s Resilient Spirit
snippet: The Kenyan writer Ngugi wa Thiong’o’s “Minutes of Glory” tackles the absurdities, injustices and fortitude of people testing new ways against the old.

title: Out of Africa
snippet: The sculpted, geometric shapes of Africa and its rich, spicy colors are the strongest forms of identity this season.
lead_paragraph: The masked face with its feathers of hair glares from the instep. And the savage hybrid of a shoe mixes python straps and a sky-high heel with beads, wooden pearls, a cord and a tassel.

title: The World: Into Africa; In Africa, Pricking The West's Conscience
lead_paragraph: THE problem, up to now, has been the absence of genocide.

title: The Midwest of Africa
snippet: Win a Trip with Nick 2010 winner Mitch Smith feels surprisingly at home as he wanders the friendly streets of Tchibanga, Gabon.
lead_paragraph: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick arrived Sunday in Gabon, Africa–his first time ever outside of the country.

title: D.I.Y. Africa
snippet: From a budget safari to an urban alternative to Cape Town, the Frugal Traveler cuts his own path through the southern part of the continent.
lead_paragraph: It was a daunting challenge for a lone traveler in the African bush: Using only a tiny $23-a-day Fiat and my wits, I had to sneak around the six sleeping lions blocking the gravelly road ahead.

title: Africa Reboots
snippet: A new alliance of activists and entrepreneurs is rewriting the rules on the continent.
lead_paragraph: I SPENT March with a delegation of activists, entrepreneurs and policy wonks roaming western, southern and eastern Africa trying very hard to listen — always hard for a big-mouthed Irishman. With duct tape over my gob, I was able to pick up some interesting melody lines everywhere from palace to pavement ...

title: Africans for Obama
snippet: A dozen women of West African descent who work at a hair salon next to the State Office Building in Harlem came to see the senator.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of eager Harlemites flocked to the State Office Building on 125th Street on Thursday, and many waited hours hoping to get a glimpse of Senator Barack Obama, who was scheduled to meet there with former President Bill Clinton. Among them were a dozen women of West African descent who work at the Unity African Hair Braiding salon, which is next door to the building.

title: Portraits of Africa
snippet: At the New Museum’s exhibit, David Goldblatt pairs understated, antisensational photographs of South Africa with spare labels to create an infectiously mournful beauty.
lead_paragraph: At the New Museum’s exhibit, David Goldblatt pairs understated, antisensational photographs of South Africa with spare labels to create an infectiously mournful beauty.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Musician Killed
snippet: Ben Shabalala, former member of Black Mambazo, South African a cappella group, is shot and killed in Durban (South Africa) (S)
lead_paragraph: A former member of the iconic South African a cappella group Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Ben Shabalala, was shot and killed in Durban on June 16, the band's business manager said. The police have not identified a suspect. Mr. Shabalala sang alto in the 10-member group from the late 1970's to 1993, when he left to start his own business. He was one of the singers who made a major contribution to the 1986 hit album ''Graceland,'' by the American singer Paul Simon, which critics say played a crucial role in introducing American listeners to international music. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Africa rising
West South Africa
snippet: Virtually every play Athol Fugard has written has been set in South Africa, mostly during the apartheid era; few writers are as closely identified with one place. So while resituating classic plays is nothing particularly new, it's notable that Mr...
lead_paragraph: Virtually every play Athol Fugard has written has been set in South Africa, mostly during the apartheid era; few writers are as closely identified with one place. So while resituating classic plays is nothing particularly new, it's notable that Mr. Fugard's 1969 work "People Are Living There" has been moved from Johannesburg to Elizabeth, N.J., in an Off Broadway production that opens Thursday. "I would be quite surprised if Athol has ever allowed this before," said Samuel Liff, Mr. Fugard's agent at the William Morris Agency. "I have never given anyone permission to do that. But because Suzanne has a special, longstanding relationship with Athol, it wouldn't surprise me if they had an agreement on their own."

title: The Year of Africa
lead_paragraph: This has been the year of Africa, and it’s coming to a fitting end with the naming by Time magazine of Bill and Melinda Gates, along with Bono, as the People of the Year. All three have done great things for Africa, with the contribution by the Gates Foundation to the combating of disease in Africa being magnificent. There have been others who might be mentioned, of course: Gordon Brown, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, has battled for debt relief – and achieved a great deal – and Bob Geldof has sung and talked himself hoarse to get people to pay attention to Africa’s suffering. These are all people who have made a real difference to the continent’s year.

title: Africa at the Summit
snippet: ''There can be no excuse, no defense, no justification for the plight of millions of our fellow human beings in Africa today. And there should be nothing that stands in our way in changing it.'' That ringing summons was issued by Britain's prime m...
lead_paragraph: "There can be no excuse, no defense, no justification for the plight of millions of our fellow human beings in Africa today. And there should be nothing that stands in our way in changing it." That ringing summons was issued by Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, earlier this year, when he presented the compelling findings and lucid recommendations of his Commission for Africa. Later this week, we will see whether President Bush has the vision and compassion to meet those challenges, and grasp a historic opportunity to radically improve the life prospects of millions of those fellow human beings.

title: Dialing Africa
snippet: Africa is the world's fastest-growing cellphone market, a boom that has taken the industry by surprise.
lead_paragraph: Africa is the world's fastest-growing cellphone market, a boom that has taken the industry by surprise.

title: Man Plotted Mass Shooting in Atlanta to Incite ‘Race War,’ Officials Say
snippet: Prosecutors said Mark Adams Prieto of Arizona planned to target Black concertgoers at an Atlanta venue. He was indicted on hate crime and firearm charges.
lead_paragraph: An Arizona man who planned to commit a mass shooting at an Atlanta rap concert as a way of inciting a “race war” has been indicted by a federal grand jury on hate crime and firearm charges.

title: Africa in the Balance
snippet: Eight men are about to decide the future of hundreds of millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa. The choices President Bush and his fellow leaders make this week in Scotland will help determine whether more than two million children under 5 will ...
lead_paragraph: Eight men are about to decide the future of hundreds of millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa. The choices President Bush and his fellow leaders make this week in Scotland will help determine whether more than two million children under 5 will keep dying every year of diseases that can be easily and cheaply treated, whether 40 million young people will still be unable to go to school and whether 300 million Africans will continue to lack access to clean water.

lead_paragraph: Ken in Washington D.C. writes:

title: Central African Republic: More Peacekeepers Accused
snippet: The United Nations is investigating two new suspected cases of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations is investigating two new suspected cases of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, one involving the possible rape of a 14-year-old girl by Burundian soldiers, a spokesman for Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Monday. The spokesman, Stéphane Dujarric, told reporters at a daily briefing that the peacekeeping mission in the country had received the allegations on Friday. The other case, he said, involved a Moroccan peacekeeper’s relationship with a woman. None of the suspects were identified. The Central African Republic, one of the world’s most dysfunctional countries, has become an epicenter of sexual abuse allegations against United Nations peacekeepers, an issue that has tarnished their image as protectors of the helpless. The latest allegations came to light two weeks after the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution endorsing toughened discipline proposed by Mr. Ban against violators, including repatriation of entire contingents implicated in systematic abuse.

title: Africa Unite!
snippet: In this lesson, students become familiar with the 54 countries of Africa by researching and presenting information on each, then identifying them on a map of the continent. To conclude, students create trivia questions on the countries and leaders...
lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: New African court : Justice for Africa, but only if it's not rushed
snippet: Sunday was a milestone in the history of Africa and the international protection of human rights. It marked the entry into force of the protocol for the establishment of the African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights. After Europe and the Americas...
lead_paragraph: Sunday was a milestone in the history of Africa and the international protection of human rights. It marked the entry into force of the protocol for the establishment of the African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights. After Europe and the Americas, Africa will be the third continent with a regional court to bindingly adjudicate human rights violations.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Protesting In Pajamas
snippet: Democratic Nurses Assn of South Africa members in North West Province protest low uniform allowance by reporting to work in pajamas and nightgowns; national Health Department has said changes in allowance are being planned (S)
lead_paragraph: Nurses in North West Province have begun wearing pajamas and nightgowns to work to protest what they regard as a paltry uniform allowance, leading the provincial health department to threaten severe penalties "against those who continue to confuse our patients and turn our facilities into bedrooms." Members of the Democratic Nurses Association of South Africa began the protest two weeks ago by wearing street clothes to work, then escalated to nightwear after demands for a higher allowance went unmet. The national Health Department has said that it plans to address the problem with a higher nationwide uniform allowance. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: The Fate of Africa
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Extremist Freed
snippet: South African white supremacist Eugene Terre'Blache, on day he was released from three years in prison for attempted murder of black security guard, appears riding black horse through Potschefstroom (South Africa); photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The notorious white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche rode a black horse through Potschefstroom, a center of white conservatism, after being released from a South African prison where he had spent three years for the attempted murder of a black security guard in 1996. Mr. TerreBlanche, 60, said he might seek to revive the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, which fought to preserve apartheid, as a right-wing political party. But he was greeted by only a handful of his movement's members and was trailed throughout his ride by a throng of black South Africans who sang songs of the anti-apartheid struggle. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Crumbs for Africa
snippet: Editorial reports that Pres Bush kept remarkably straight face as he told Prime Min Tony Blair and world that US will now get around to spending $674 million in emergency aid that Congress has already approved for needy countries, and not a penny ...
lead_paragraph: President Bush kept a remarkably straight face yesterday when he strode to the microphones with Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, and told the world that the United States would now get around to spending $674 million in emergency aid that Congress had already approved for needy countries. That's it. Not a penny more to buy treated mosquito nets to help save the thousands of children in Sierra Leone who die every year of preventable malaria. Nothing more to train and pay teachers so 11-year-old girls in Kenya may go to school. And not a cent more to help Ghana develop the programs it needs to get legions of young boys off the streets.

title: Out of Africa
snippet: The Nigerian novelist talks about the latest ethnic violence in his country.
lead_paragraph: Since its publication in 1958,  “Things Fall Apart,”  the story of a Nigerian yam farmer who is unable to accept the changes wrought by British colonialism, has become the best-selling novel ever written by an African.  Well, I hear such exaggerated comments. I just leave them alone.

title: Letter from Africa: With Africa in crisis, spotlight is on Nigeria
lead_paragraph: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — The week was a busy one for Olusegun Obasanjo. There the Nigerian president was Monday morning, Jan. 16, beaming as Liberia's new president took the oath of office, cementing a peace Obasanjo had worked to build. And here he was on Wednesday, perched on a settee and clasping the hand of the president of Ivory Coast, Laurent Gbagbo, trying to put out the flames engulfing that country, as militant youths rampaged against the United Nations and France.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 'No Decision' On Zimbabwe
snippet: South African officials deny that Pres Thabo Mbeki and Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo have decided to call for end to Zimbabwe's suspension from Commonwealth of Nations; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Government officials denied reports that President Thabo Mbeki, left, and the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, had decided to call for an end to Zimbabwe's suspension from the Commonwealth, a group of 54 nations, mostly former British colonies. Bheki Khumalo, a spokesman for Mr. Mbeki, said, ''There's no final decision on the matter.'' But African officials have long been sympathetic to Zimbabwe despite the government's crackdown on the opposition and its condoning of violence. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Asylum For Aristide
snippet: South African government grants asylum to deposed Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide (S)
lead_paragraph: The government said that it is granting asylum to Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's deposed president. A government spokesman characterized Mr. Aristide's stay as temporary, until ''the Haitian situation stabilizes and he and his family can return.'' A spokesman for Mr. Aristide said he could arrive in South Africa as early as next week. He is expected to live in Pretoria, the capital, under heavy security and at government expense. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: Africa Quandary
snippet: A tug of war over land in South Africa is pitting tens of thousands of white landowners against millions of nonwhites left landless by colonialism and apartheid.
lead_paragraph: A tug of war over land in South Africa is pitting tens of thousands of white landowners against millions of nonwhites left landless by colonialism and apartheid.

title: South Africa
snippet: GEOGRAPHY Location: southern Africa. Boundaries: Namibia to NW, Botswana, Zimbabwe to N, Mozambique to NE, Swaziland, Indian Ocean to E, Atlantic Ocean to W; Lesotho entirely surrounded by South African territory. Total area: 471,444 sq. mi. (1,22...
lead_paragraph: GEOGRAPHY Location: southern Africa. Boundaries: Namibia to NW, Botswana, Zimbabwe to N, Mozambique to NE, Swaziland, Indian Ocean to E, Atlantic Ocean to W; Lesotho entirely surrounded by South African territory. Total area: 471,444 sq. mi. (1,221,040 sq km). Coastline: 1,739 mi. (2,798 km). Comparative area: slighlty less than twice the size of Texas. Land use: 12% arable land; 1% permanent crops; 87% other. Major cities: (1991 census) Note: Figures are for metropolitan areas: Cape Town (legislative capital) 2,350,157; Pretoria (administrative capital) 1,080,187; Johannesburg 1,916,061; Durban 1,137,378; Port Elizabeth 853,205. PEOPLE Population: 42,768,678 (2003 est.). Nationality: noun—South African(s); adjective—South African. Ethnic groups: 75.2% black, 13.6% white, 2.6% Indian; 8.6% other. Languages: Afrikaans, English, Zulu, Xhosa, Sotho, Ndebele, Pedi, Swazi, Tsonga, Venda, Tswana (all official). Religions: 68% Christian (most whites and about 60% of blacks), 2% Muslim, 1.5% Hindu (60% of Indians), 28.5% traditional and animistic beliefs. GOVERNMENT Type: republic. Independence: May 31, 1910 (from U.K.). Constitution: signed Dec. 10, 1996 by then-President Mandela—being implemented in phases. National holiday: Freedom Day, Apr. 27. Head of Government: Thabo Mbeki, president (since June 1999). Structure: executive—president is head of govt. and chairman of cabinet; bicameral legislature—National Assembly, National Council of Provinces; judiciary—courts maintain substantial independence from government influence. ECONOMY Monetary unit: South African rand. Budget: (FY02/03 est.) income: $22.6 bil.; expend.: $24.7 bil. GDP: $432 bil., $10,000 per capita (2002 est.). Chief crops: corn, wheat, sugarcane, fruits, vegetables; beef, poultry, mutton, wool, dairy products. Natural resources: gold, chromium, antimony, coal, iron ore. Major industries: mining (world's largest producer of platinum, gold, chromium), automobile assembly, metalworking. Labor force: 17 mil. economically active (1997); 45% services, 30% agriculture, 25% industry and commerce; 37% unemployment (2001 est.). Exports: $31.8 bil. (f.o.b., 2002 est.); gold, minerals and metals, food, chemicals. Imports: $26.6 bil. (f.o.b., 2002 est.); machinery, chemicals, transport equipment. Major trading partners: exports: E.U., U.S., Japan; imports: E.U., U.S., Japan. South Africa was originally inhabited by San and related peoples. Bantu peoples, including the Zulu and Xhosa, migrated to the region beginning around the 15th century and established large native kingdoms. The Portuguese explorer Bartholomew Diaz discovered and named the Cape of Good Hope in 1488. The Dutch East India Company established a permanent settlement at Cape Town in 1652, which served as a supply and transshipment point for Dutch trade to the East Indies. It attracted Protestant settlers from throughout Western Europe. In a series of wars, the Xhosa people were expelled from the area under Dutch rule. Great Britain began to dispute Dutch control of the Cape of Good Hope region in the late 18th century. To escape increasing British hegemony, in 1836 many Dutch farmers undertook the Great Trek, a northward migration to lands not under the control of any European power. These Afrikaner pioneers later became known as Boers (farmers). They came into conflict with the Zulu kingdom that, under King Shaka, had recently widened its dominion in the South African interior. The Zulus were defeated at the Battle of Blood River in 1838, but they retained substantial power and territory for another 40 years. Great Britain formally took control of the Cape Colony in 1841 and annexed Natal in 1843. The other two Afrikaner provinces, the Orange Free State and the Transvaal, remained free of British control. But when diamonds were discovered in the Orange Free State in 1867 and gold in the Transvaal in 1886, an influx of British miners and entrepreneurs provoked Boer rebellions. In 1878 the Zulu Kingdom under its last great king, Cetewayo, rebelled against British rule in Natal. British troops attacked Zululand in 1878 and crushed the rebellion in 1879. The first Anglo-Boer War of 1881–82 led to total British victory. A renewed uprising led to the Boer War of 1899–1902, which was fought with great ferocity between British regular troops and Afrikaner guerrilla forces. The eventual British victory led to the establishment of British rule in all of South Africa and to the formation of the Union of South Africa in 1910. The union became a self-governing state within the British Empire in 1934. South African politics became dominated by friction between British and Afrikaner whites; no effective black participation in government was permitted. The United South African party, led by Jan C. Smuts, advocated cooperation between the two groups and led South Africa to join World War II on the Allied side, over the opposition of the pro-Afrikaner Nationalist party. After the war the Nationalists prevailed and won control of the government in 1948. Racial politics became the country's paramount concern, and the Nationalists introduced the policy of “apartheid” (separateness), under which racial groups were rigidly defined as white, black, Asian (primarily Indian), and colored (mixed ancestry). Each group was to be kept physically separate and develop its own political institutions within defined areas of residence; mixed neighborhoods, intermarriage, and other relations were prohibited. Blacks, in particular, were restricted by “pass laws” that allowed them only temporary access to white areas for employment. International condemnation of these policies began almost immediately, as India broke relations with South Africa in 1946 over discrimination against Asians, and South Africa became the focus of mounting protest, U.N. resolutions, and international sanctions beginning in the 1960's. On May 31, 1961, South Africa gave up its dominion status and became a republic; its application for membership in the British Commonwealth was withdrawn in the face of strong opposition. The African National Congress (ANC), organized in 1912, was banned by South African authorities. The imprisonment of its leader, Nelson Mandela, provided a focus for black political protest and nationalist aspirations. Homelands were established under the Promotion of Bantu Self-Government Act of 1959 to further the policy of apartheid by creating separate, but dependent, states for South Africa's blacks. Their form of government was set up in the Black Constitution Act of 1971. The South African government intended that the homelands be regarded as separate nations, but none was ever internationally recognized. The scattered homeland territories comprised only a tiny portion of the total area of South Africa, and tended to include marginal and underdeveloped lands. Residents of the homelands were not considered citizens of South Africa, but rather citizens only of their homeland. As such, they could be considered temporary migrant workers and were therefore ineligible for unemployment and other benefits. An uprising in Soweto in 1976 was put down by South African police and armed forces with the loss of hundreds of lives, providing a further focus of black protest. Pieter Willem Botha was elected president in 1978, pledging to uphold apartheid while seeking solutions to racial problems. In 1983, a majority of white voters approved a new constitution that provided for limited power sharing by coloreds and Asians. Blacks, however, continued to be excluded. In the early 1980's, South African troops intervened in civil wars in Angola and Mozambique and were deployed to counteract growing proindependence rebellions in Namibia. Within South Africa, terrorism and uprisings led by the African National Union grew in intensity in 1983–84. A state of emergency was declared in 1985, accompanied by renewed political and economic pressure from abroad. In 1986, Bishop Desmond Tutu, a leading black nationalist, addressed the United Nations and called for renewed sanctions. The Botha government announced an end to the pass laws and promised limited black participation in government. Fighting among black groups in 1986–87 further increased domestic tension. On May 19, 1986, South African troops conducted raids against ANC bases in Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Botswana. A new national state of emergency was declared as strikes and riots marked the 10th anniversary of the Soweto uprising. The U.S. announced measures designed to end American investment in South Africa. In early 1989, in anticipation of elections to be held in September, various proposals were put forward for constitutional reform. Most called for expanded power sharing but still within the context of defined racial groups. In July 1989 Pres. Botha had an unprecedented meeting with Nelson Mandela, amid strong suggestions that the white government was seeking an accommodation with the antiapartheid leadership. Botha's successor, F.W. de Klerk, continued that policy. A series of measures in 1989–90 resulted in the partial dismantling of apartheid, against the vehement opposition of the white right wing, but violence between supporters of the ANC and the Zulu Inkatha movement in Natal led to the declaration of a state of emergency in the province. Mandela was released from prison in the spring of 1990 and received a rapturous welcome from South Africa's blacks, and later made a triumphant tour of Western Europe and North America. His glory was short-lived, however, as the struggle for supremacy again erupted in murder and violence between Mandela's ANC and Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom party throughout the latter part of 1990 and 1991. At the same time, Pres. de Klerk and Parliament continued to move the nation toward the ending of apartheid by repealing 60 years of segregation in hospitals, libraries, schools, and other public institutions. The government also released other political prisoners and completely repealed the legal foundations of apartheid: the Land Acts of 1913 and 1936, the Group Areas Act, and the Population Registration Act. The United States and other countries began lifting trade sanctions against South Africa in the summer of 1991. In September 1991, de Klerk, Mandela, and Buthelezi, together with 20 smaller antiapartheid groups, signed an accord to end factional violence. De Klerk proposed a new constitution that would provide universal suffrage and create a two-chamber parliament open to all races. The new constitution abolished the black homelands, consolidating them into one large, multiracial South Africa. In March 1992 a referendum of white voters overwhelmingly approved a government proposal to dismantle all forms of apartheid and to conduct talks with black leaders designed to end white-only rule. The new constitution was approved on Nov. 17, 1993, by all of the country's major political parties, except for Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom party, which withheld its support until a week before the country's first-ever multiracial elections in April. More than 22 million voters cast ballots. An overwhelming majority chose the 75-year-old Mandela to lead a coalition government that included de Klerk's National party and Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom party. In May 1996 South Africa completed the transition to democracy when it approved a permanent constitution to replace the transitional one implemented three years earlier. It created a strong central government, an independent judiciary, and a bill of rights with one of the broadest guarantees of liberty in the world. In addition to freedom of speech, movement, and political activity, the South African Bill of Rights protects rights to adequate food, housing, water, education, and health care. The day after the new constitution was approved, de Klerk and his colleagues in the National party quit their cabinet posts, saying that the government was strong enough to handle “robust opposition.” In 1997 there were reminders that troubles remain: in February, riots in Johannesburg suburbs by coloreds against discrimination in favor of blacks and in March, a mass rally (which turned violent) in Johannesburg by still-unsatisfied Zulus. Bitter feelings between the Inkatha Freedom Party and Mandela's ANC surfaced again when the Truth and Reconciliation Committee reported testimony linking Inkatha leaders to assasination squads during the apartheid era. On June 2, 1999, South Africa held its second post-apartheid elections: the ANC won a gigantic victory, taking 266 seats in the 400-seat Assembly. An “alliance” with the one member of the (Indian) Minority Front gave ANC the 2/3 majority that permits it to amend the Constitution. Thabo Mbeki, who replaced Nelson Mandela as party chief in December, was elected unopposed to be his successor as South Africa's president as well. There has been subsequent slippage in ANC popularity. As inflation heats up strikes grow more frequent. In Dec. 2000 local elections the ANC took only 59 percent and a serious bribery scandal is developing over a 1999 $3.5 billion arms deal. And the government's own report of March 2001 highlighted the gravity of South Africa's AIDS crisis. South Africa has the continent's most highly developed economy; it is a fully-developed, capitalist industrial-commercial society with manufacturing, mining, agricultural, service, and other sectors. It remains the world's largest producer of gold, a key source of chromium and other strategic metals, and of gem-quality diamonds.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Religion Honor
snippet: Dr George F R Ellis, University of Cape Town (South Africa) theoretical cosmologist wins Templeton Prize honoring contributions to religion; announces that half of $1.4 million in prize money will go to help social causes in South Africa (S)
lead_paragraph: Dr. George F. R. Ellis, a theoretical cosmologist at the University of Cape Town in South Africa, is this year's winner of the Templeton Prize, which honors contributions to religion. While his physics research examines the earliest moments of the universe, including the possibility of multiple universes, Dr. Ellis, 64, has also written about ethics and the boundaries of physics and metaphysics. He said he would donate half of the $1.4 million prize money to social causes, including a campaign to establish a basic income grant for all South African citizens to alleviate poverty. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: African Opportunity
snippet: Editorial hopes Africa will get attention it deserves at Group of 8 summit meeting in Canada; says leaders also need to raise issues of corruption and human rights abuses, although Pres Bush seems to be only one inclined to do so
lead_paragraph: Africa has enjoyed too few of globalization's benefits and suffered too many of its costs. The continent's future should get the attention it deserves at this week's summit of Group of 8 democracies in Canada. On the table Thursday will be an African proposal for a new economic bargain that should push President Bush, the leaders of seven other industrialized nations and the presidents of South Africa, Nigeria, Senegal and possibly Algeria beyond the usual platitudes about cooperation.

title: African Idyll
snippet: The Times’s Helene Cooper fled a warring Liberia as a child. In this memoir, she returns to confront the ghosts of her past -- and to find a lost sister.
lead_paragraph: The skeletal remains of Africa’s numerous civil wars litter the continent, from the easternmost reaches of Somalia to the western shores of Liberia. It is there, overlooking the picturesque beaches of the Atlantic Ocean, that unknown numbers of human remains — victims of Samuel Doe’s reign of terror — haunt the earth. One building that serves as their communal headstone, itself a virtual skeleton, is physical testimony to the civil war that racked Liberia for nearly 25 years. This macabre marker is the house at Sugar Beach.

title: U.S. to Withdraw Troops From Chad, Dealing Another Blow to Africa Policy
snippet: The departure of U.S. military personnel in Chad and Niger comes as both countries are turning away from years of cooperation with the United States and forming partnerships with Russia.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon will withdraw dozens of Special Operations forces from Chad in the next few days, the second major blow in a week to American security and counterterrorism policy in a volatile swath of West and Central Africa, U.S. officials said on Thursday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Farms Report
snippet: South Africa's Human Rights Commission findings are met with criticism and support from farmers and laborers investigated; cite sweeping abuses against black farmers, but dismiss idea that white farmers have been likewise target of racially motiva...
lead_paragraph: Farmers and workers groups split over a report by the country's Human Rights Commission that alleged widespread rights abuses against black farm laborers but dismissed contentions that a spate of attacks on the nation's largely white farmers were racially motivated. Some 1,500 white farmers have died in attacks since apartheid ended a decade ago, and the deaths are under investigation by a government panel whose final report has been delayed. Some farmers acknowledged the poor working conditions cited in the report but said that ''the worst kind of human rights violation is to murder and maim'' farmers. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Assessing Africa
snippet: In this lesson, students research important issues in Africa and how the concerns are being addressed both nationally and internationally. They then prepare briefing presentations for the American President to influence concerns of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The African Front
snippet: Kenya’s remote north has become a battleground for rising Islamism and its pro-American opponents. Have aggressive post-9/11 policies fomented the very sectarianism they were meant to fight?
lead_paragraph: One hot, cloudless afternoon in October, I sat in the members’ salon of the Kenyan Parliament as the guest of Joseph Lekuton, an M.P. from the desolate bush country to the east of Lake Turkana. Around us a dozen other Kenyan politicians sat in comfortable armchairs, sipping tea from silver services and gliding from English to Swahili to tribal languages and back again. The décor  dark wood paneling, white concrete pillars and a flying-saucer-like brass-and-steel chandelier  suggested both the Soviet Politburo and a Las Vegas lounge in the Rat Pack era. Lekuton (pronounced LEH-koo-tone), an animated man in his late 30s, had dropped by to catch up on developments in the country’s election campaign. On Dec. 27, Kenyans are voting, for the first time since 2002, to choose a new president and Parliament; Lekuton was in the capital raising money and trying to decide whether to throw his lot in with the government coalition or with the main opposition party. (Kenya’s parties are fluid, and continuous maneuvering takes place during a campaign season.) Lekuton, a rising political star, was being wooed by both sides, which put his constituents in a state of considerable anxiety. The election, meanwhile, was promising to be the most democratic and unpredictable in Kenya’s history: polls showed President Mwai Kibaki slipping behind the challenger, Raila Odinga, a former political prisoner. The prospect of an incumbent president caught in a genuine electoral contest  a nearly unprecedented event in Africa  excited Lekuton. “There’s never been anything like this in Kenyan politics,” he told me.

title: ‘There Must Be More Room for Africa,’ Leader of African Union Says
snippet: President Macky Sall of Senegal, chairman of the bloc, said in an interview before the U.S.-Africa summit that it’s time for the continent to have more seats in global institutions.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Since he took the helm of the African Union, Macky Sall, who is also president of the West African nation of Senegal, has been making the argument that Africa does not have the influence it warrants in world affairs.

title: African, American
snippet: This first novel follows a group of exiles in a Washington neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The Alexandrian exile André Aciman used to linger in a tatty Upper West Side park just for the bittersweet pleasure of shadowing his surroundings with images from cities he’d known and lost, remaking the architecture of the present, as he put it, “so as not to write off the past.” Dinaw Mengestu’s first novel is a tale of just such a shadowing of two cities — Washington, where the narrator, Sepha Stephanos, lives in exile, and Addis Ababa, his city of memory and violent expulsion. As Stephanos wanders the half-known, half-remembered roads of America’s capital, he finds himself drawn into conversation with his dead father, murdered before his eyes during Ethiopia’s Red Terror.

title: A Steadying Force for the Africa Center Is Stepping Down
snippet: Uzodinma Iweala, chief executive of the Harlem institution, will leave at the end of 2024 after guiding it through pandemic years and securing funds.
lead_paragraph: After guiding The Africa Center through rocky pandemic years and securing a huge chunk of funding for a major construction project, the leader of the Harlem institution is stepping down.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: A Return To Court
snippet: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, ex-wife of former South African President Nelson Mandela, returns to court facing charges of theft and fraud; claims to have been duped into participating in scheme to obtain loans for non-existent employees of African N...
lead_paragraph: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela was back in court on charges of fraud and theft. A prosecutor told the court that Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, a leading figure in the country's struggle against apartheid and the ex-wife of the former South African president, Nelson Mandela, did not make a credible defense. ''Her evidence was so bad,'' the prosecutor, Jan Ferreira, said, it was as if ''she hadn't testified at all.'' Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, 64, is charged with fraud and theft in a scheme to obtain bank loans for nonexistent employees of the African National Congress Women's League, which she heads. She has called the state's evidence ''a pack of lies'' and testified that she had been duped into taking part in the scheme. If convicted, she could face 15 years in prison. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Out of Africa
snippet: Race can be a means for Barack Obama to talk about reconciliation — of America with its past, its ideals and the world.
lead_paragraph: ELMINA, Ghana

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Unhappy With Zimbabwe
snippet: South African bank governor Tito Mboweni lashes out at Pres Robert Mugabe and Zimbabwe government and demands orderly resolution of problems (S)
lead_paragraph: The South African Reserve Bank governor, Tito Mboweni, who has been outspoken in his criticism of Zimbabwe, lashed out again at the government of President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Mboweni, who has watched South Africa's currency slide as the situation in neighboring Zimbabwe worsened, said the country's problems must be resolved in an orderly, legal way. He criticized a leader of a small South African opposition party who expressed support for the chaotic land reform undertaken by Zimbabwe.

title: Democracy Struggles in Africa; A Victory in South Africa
lead_paragraph: South Africans of every color, haves as well as have-nots, have brought off a considerable political feat. They agreed this week to an interim constitution free of racist taint; for the first time it makes the black three-fourths of the population full citizens. It establishes a multiracial transition regime that will govern until April 27, when an elected parliament will give final form to the new system.

title: Blowback in Africa
lead_paragraph: Ever since Chad gained independence 46 years ago, it has been a world-class model of political dysfunction. In the 1970s, Chad's president, François Tombalbaye, compelled civil servants to renounce Western customs, undergo a tribal initiation rite known as yondo and profess belief in a nationalist creed he called Chaditude. He was executed in 1975.

title: African-American History Seen Through an African-American Lens
snippet: The photography collection at the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture aims to redefine not just history, but how it is presented.
lead_paragraph: The photography collection at the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture aims to redefine not just history, but how it is presented.

title: Mozambique: Africa's Rising Star
snippet: Joshua Kurlantzick travel article on Mozambique which, after years of civil wars, is emerging as one of Africa's most alluring and relaxing tourist destinations; describes visit to Maputo, Mozambique's capital; photos; map (L)
lead_paragraph: AS the heavy rain pelted the windows of the taxi, Julio, my regular driver in Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, hardly seemed worried. He calmly piloted the cab through the flooding streets, as water rose above sidewalks and spilled onto people's front lawns.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Prostitution Ruling
snippet: South Africa's High Court rules that prostitution should be decriminalized, sparking outcry among some churches; decision must be approved by Constitutional Court before it takes effect (S)
lead_paragraph: The High Court has ruled that prostitution should be decriminalized, ruling on an application filed by prostitutes who were challenging their arrests and convictions. The decision must be approved by the Constitutional Court before it takes effect, but it has already sparked an outcry among some churches. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: South Africa’s 2024 National Election: What to Know
snippet: The ruling African National Congress party could lose its parliamentary majority for the first time since the fall of apartheid 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: This year is the 30th anniversary of South Africa’s first democratic elections, but millions of people continue to suffer from economic challenges similar to those during apartheid.

title: Brian Africa, Michael Dwyer
snippet: The couple are married at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Brian Lo Africa and Michael Thomas Dwyer were married Nov. 12 at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Robert M. Marino, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: African Bloc Hoping to Do Better as the 'African Union'
snippet: Africa's current leaders want to create new Organization of African Unity that they pledge would redeem failures of its predcessor; on final day of OAU's last summit meeting, members endorse plan to retire OAU in next year and to transform it into...
lead_paragraph: Nearly four decades after Africa's newly independent nations created the Organization of African Unity in an effort to give a strong voice to the world's poorest lands, the continent's current leaders began burying that body today and creating a new one that they pledged would redeem the failures of its predecessor.

title: How to Plan an African Safari
snippet: Figure out how much you want to spend, stay in a simple camp to be closer to nature and decide what wildlife you want to see.
lead_paragraph: An African safari is a trip that should be on every traveler’s bucket list, according to Melissa Biggs Bradley, the founder of the luxury travel company Indagare and a 15-time safari veteran. “A safari taps into the primitive ways of humankind because you’re living in the wild and tracking animals the way hunters and gatherers once did,” she said. “It’s a transformative experience.”

title: Out Of Africa
snippet: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column contends that after watching Teresa Heinz Kerry in action at Hollywood fund-raiser, when she gave her whispery Out-of-Africa autobiographical speech, entertainment liberals are nervous about how she will handle her turn i...
lead_paragraph: As Republicans on the East Coast fret about Dick Cheney acting bonkers, Democrats on the West Coast fret about Teresa Heinz Kerry acting flaky.

title: Out of Africa
snippet: W Jeffrey Bolster reviews book The Diligent: A Voyage Through the Worlds of the Slave Trade by Robert Harms (M)
lead_paragraph: THE DILIGENT

title: John Edmonds and the Allure of Africa
snippet: The photographer’s show at the Brooklyn Museum explores collecting and photography as acts of possession and desire.
lead_paragraph: The young photographer John Edmonds traveled to Ghana last January, searching for something he couldn’t name. Having recently begun collecting and photographing African sculpture, he thought the trip would lead to a greater self-knowledge.

title: Blowback in Africa
snippet: EVER since Chad gained independence 46 years ago, it has been a world-class model of political dysfunction. In the 1970's, Chad's president, François Tombalbaye, compelled civil servants to renounce Western customs, undergo a tribal initiation rit...
lead_paragraph: EVER since Chad gained independence 46 years ago, it has been a world-class model of political dysfunction. In the 1970's, Chad's president, François Tombalbaye, compelled civil servants to renounce Western customs, undergo a tribal initiation rite known as yondo and profess belief in a nationalist creed he called Chaditude. He was executed in 1975. In the 1980's, a rebel leader named Hissène Habré led an army to the presidential palace and seized power. He became known as the "African Pinochet" and murderously pursued opponents for nearly a decade.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AIDS Ruling
snippet: South African Constitutional Court, upholding lower-court decision, rules that government must provide AIDS drugs to pregnant women infected with HIV to prevent transmission to unborn babies (S)
lead_paragraph: Upholding a lower-court decision, the Constitutional Court ruled that the government must provide AIDS drugs to pregnant women infected with H.I.V. to prevent its transmission to unborn babies. In April, government officials agreed to provide the drugs in public hospitals after months of wavering. But the court's decision was still cheered by advocates for AIDS patients. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: AFRICAN CEMENT MERGER TALKS
snippet: Pretoria Portland Cement, South Africa's largest cement maker, is in talks with Portland Holding, of Zimbabwe, regarding merger (S)
lead_paragraph: Pretoria Portland Cement, South Africa's biggest cement maker, is in talks with Portland Holding of Zimbabwe, and analysts said the discussions were likely to lead to a takeover of the Zimbabwean company, now 44 percent owned by Anglo American P.L.C. Buying Portland Holding would add about 750,000 tons of annual capacity to Pretoria Portland's 5.1 million tons.

title: Africa's prisons
LOOKING AT AFRICA THROUGH AN AFRICAN'S EYES
lead_paragraph: ''I myself am an example of Africa's triple heritage,'' said Ali A. Mazrui, the central personality both as writer and as narrator on camera of the controversial new documentary series ''The Africans,'' which begins this week on the Public Broadcasting Service. The initial hourlong chapter in the nine-part series - a co-production of WETA, the Washington member station, and the British Broadcasting Corporation - will be broadcast Thursday evening at 9 on WNET/ Channel 13 in New York and at the same hour, two days earlier, on most of the other 300 PBS stations around the country.

title: Broadcast in South Africa
lead_paragraph: South African television, which focuses on Government leaders and largely ignores their black opponents, provided viewers with a stunning sight tonight, broadcasting the release of Nelson Mandela and his emphatic speech before a huge rally on the steps of Cape Town City Hall.

title: Design Attracts Africa’s Young Watch Entrepreneurs
snippet: From Ghana to South Africa, new brands are inspired by the continent’s varied cultures.
lead_paragraph: As African designers grab the fashion spotlight, with Thebe Magugu of South Africa winning the 2019 LVMH Prize for emerging designers, the continent’s watch entrepreneurs have been rising too.

title: Into Africa: China’s Wild Rush
snippet: Africans are asking just what China’s billions in investment mean for their daily lives and political rights.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — For nearly a decade, as China made a historic push for business opportunities and expanded influence in Africa, most of the continent’s leaders were so thrilled at having a deep-pocketed partner willing to make big investments and start huge new projects that they rarely paused to consider whether they were getting a sound deal.

title: The African Migration Tragedy in Yemen
snippet: Teenagers fleeing poverty and hunger in Somalia and Ethiopia must pass through the aptly named “gateway of grief.”
lead_paragraph: The narrow strait that separates the Horn of Africa from the Arabian Peninsula is so treacherous it is called Bab el Mandeb — “gateway of grief.” It’s earned its miserable name lately as African migrants try to pass through war-torn Yemen to flee dire poverty and hunger and reach Saudi Arabia, and jobs.

title: ‘Refugee Boats’ and African Capitalism
snippet: Europe can best reduce the flow of migrants by encouraging market economies on the continent.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Until a few days ago, you could order “refugee boats” from Alibaba, the enormous Chinese e-marketplace. The Chinese-made rubber boats, available for a couple of hundred dollars, had “good capacity of anti-sinking,” the item’s order page claimed, even if “the boat is filled fully with water.”

title: CADBURY EXPANSION IN SOUTH AFRICA
lead_paragraph: In another move to consolidate control over its holdings in South Africa, Cadbury Schweppes, the British beverage and candy company, said it planned to acquire the outstanding 45 percent stake in its South African subsidiary for about $207 million. Cadbury said that Tempora Investments Ltd., which holds nearly half of the minority stake in the South African company, had agreed to the deal, which follows Cadbury's sale of its South African soft drink business last year to Coca-Cola. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: Che in Africa
snippet: Michela Wrong reviews book The African Dream: The Diaries of the Revolutionary War in the Congo by Ernesto Che Guevara (M)
lead_paragraph: THE AFRICAN DREAM

title: UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS IN SOUTH AFRICA
snippet: South Africa reports unemployment rate fell to 23.3 percent in Oct 1999 from year-earlier 25.2 percent, first drop since 1995; rate fell to 36.2 percent from 37.5 percent using expanded definition that includes people who have stopped looking for ...
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate fell for the first time since 1995, as growth in informal employment offset job cuts elsewhere. The unemployment rate fell to 23.3 percent in October 1999 from 25.2 percent a year earlier, Statistics South Africa said. The rate fell to 36.2 percent from 37.5 using an expanded definition that counts as unemployed people who have stopped looking for work. South Africa has shed jobs in recent years in industries like manufacturing and construction, as the end of apartheid has opened the economy to competition from abroad. Job creation in the informal market -- largely unregistered businesses often run from homes or street pavements -- are beginning to compensate.

title: Africa’s Slide Toward Disaster
snippet: A U.S.-Africa summit meeting needs to address how American policies have fostered a culture of abuse and rebellion.
lead_paragraph: A specter is haunting Africa — the specter of impunity. Many countries the United States considers allies are in the grip of corrupt, repressive tyrants; others are mired in endless conflict. As Washington prepares to host the first-ever U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit next week, American policy makers must acknowledge their contributions to this dismal situation. By lavishing billions of dollars in military and development aid on African states while failing to promote justice, democracy and the rule of law, American policies have fostered a culture of abuse and rebellion. This must change before the continent is so steeped in blood that there’s no way back.

title: SOUTH AFRICA INFLATION DROPS
snippet: Inflation in South Africa fell to 1.9 percent in September, its lowest level since 1968; drop in consumer price index, from 3.2 percent in August, was driven by sharp reduction in mortgage rates; core inflation rate was unchanged from year earlier...
lead_paragraph: Inflation in South Africa fell to 1.9 percent in September, its lowest level since 1968, when it stood at 1.7 percent. The drop in the consumer price index, from 3.2 percent in August, was driven largely by a sharp reduction in mortgage rates. The core inflation rate, which excludes mortgage rates, was unchanged from a year earlier at 7.9 percent.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: DIAMOND DISPUTE
snippet: Investors holding almost 10 percent of De Beers' stock say they will oppose plan of consortium led by Oppenheimer family and Anglo American to take company private; deal could collapse if 15 percent of minority shareholders oppose it (S)
lead_paragraph: Investors holding almost 10 percent of the diamond giant De Beers said they would oppose a plan to take the company private. The deal could collapse if 15 percent of minority shareholders oppose it. A consortium led by the Oppenheimer family and the mining colossus Anglo American offered the equivalent of $16.8 billion for De Beers in February. Brandes Investment Partners of San Diego, with 6 percent of De Beers, and Southeastern Asset Management, which is based in Memphis and has 3.8 percent, said they wanted a higher offer. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: EXPANSION BY SOUTH AFRICAN UTILITY
snippet: Eskom, South Africa's state-owned power utility, intends to acquire interests in electricity providers in other African countries, including neighboring Zimbabwe (S)
lead_paragraph: The chairman of Eskom, South Africa's state-owned power utility, said the company intended to acquire interests in electricity providers in other African countries, including neighboring Zimbabwe. Eskom, one of South Africa's biggest state-run enterprises, says it wants to be competitive in an energy industry that will soon be dominated by large multinationals. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Africa’s Lesson in Self-Reliance
snippet: The saga of Mali shows that the nations of Africa bear primary responsibility for the continent's problems and their solutions.
lead_paragraph: WUM, CAMEROON — The ongoing French military intervention in Mali has not only saved the defenseless West African nation from almost certain complete occupation by marauding foreign terrorists and jihadists, it has also rekindled a debate on the risks and costs of Africa’s dependence on international charity for survival.

title: South Africa’s Student Revolt
snippet: Extending access to higher education is not some socialist dream; it's a vital part of stabilizing the country.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Last Wednesday, I arrived at the University of the Witwatersrand, where I work, and couldn’t get inside. Some major entrances to the campus in the center of Johannesburg were locked. Others had been barricaded by students. The university had expected a docile, two-hour protest; instead, a week before exams, the campus was shut down by a crowd of 2,000. It’s been closed ever since.

title: Into Africa: 6 Vacation Ideas From Our Experts
snippet: We’ve asked current and former New York Times international news correspondents, with a collective 25 years reporting in Africa, to tell us what to do in the regions they’ve covered.
lead_paragraph: We’ve asked current and former New York Times international news correspondents, with a collective 25 years reporting in Africa, to tell us what to do in the regions they’ve covered.

title: In Africa, Seeking a License to Kill
snippet: African leaders must not be allowed to withdraw their countries from the International Criminal Court. It will only encourage greater government corruption.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — MEMBERS of the African Union will meet in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, today to discuss recent calls by some African leaders to withdraw from the International Criminal Court. These calls must be resisted. The continent has suffered the consequences of unaccountable governance for too long to disown the protections offered by the I.C.C.

title: Au Revoir, Africa
snippet: Lives column by Jason Hotalen, 16-year-old son of American missionaries in Africa, who describes what it was like to be student at school in Bouake in Ivory Coast when rebels attacked, using campus as shield from government soldiers; says he and o...
lead_paragraph: My parents are missionaries in the Congo Republic. They home-schooled me for a while, but for the last two years, they have sent me to the International Christian Academy near Bouaké in Ivory Coast. I'm 16. The school is 1st through 12th, and Nigerians, Liberians, Koreans, Dutch, and kids from other countries go there, but at least 70 percent of the students are Americans like me. It costs more if your parents aren't missionaries, so native families have to be pretty wealthy to send their kids. Over all, the school has a strong American identity. We used to play soccer and basketball with school teams and some clubs from Bouaké, but we didn't go off campus often. We had everything we needed. The school is a comfortable place. It's a little America in the middle of West Africa.

title: Out of Africa, Part III
snippet: In Senegal, a rap artist and a weatherman both worry for their nation’s future.
lead_paragraph: Dakar, SENEGAL — You can learn everything you need to know about the main challenges facing Africa today by talking to just two people in Senegal: the rapper and the weatherman. They’ve never met, but I could imagine them doing an amazing duet one day — words and weather predictions — on the future of Africa.

title: A Chokehold on South African Universities
snippet: Radical student protesters are shutting down South Africa’s universities to force the authorities to make higher education free.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — Summer break in December and January brought a much needed pause in the unrest at South Africa’s universities. Protests have been continuous here since March 9, 2015, when students demanded the removal of the statue of the British colonizer Cecil John Rhodes from the campus of the University of Cape Town, where I work.

title: South Africa’s Subprime Crisis
snippet: We largely avoided the 2007 crash but didn't learn from it. Now we're facing our own bailouts.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — When America’s housing bubble burst and the subprime loan market tanked in 2007, banks around the world found themselves exposed to subprime debt through an array of complex and opaque financial arrangements. But here in South Africa, financial institutions and government regulators puffed out their chests in pride.

title: Finding the Right African Safari
snippet: The new website Your African Safari helps travelers assess operators and itineraries.
lead_paragraph: Knowing how, when and where to book that first safari can be complicated, said Jennifer Goetz, a founder of Your African Safari, a new website dedicated to helping travelers research and locate a reliable safari company that’s right for them.

title: South Africa’s Party Game
snippet: It’s voters, not donors, who should make decisions that would significantly reshape the political landscape.
