lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — When it comes to regulating political party funding and spending, South African politicians are the proverbial foxes guarding the henhouse.

title: Measuring Africa’s Air Pollution
snippet: Air pollution in Africa is becoming a growing health concern as more people move to the cities, but few countries are taking serious action.
lead_paragraph: When Jenny Linden, an air quality scientist, tried to measure the pollution in Burkina Faso’s capital city, one of her instruments clogged up. It was designed for road dust in Arizona, but the dust in Ouagadougou far exceeded the machine’s limit, and it had to be sent to the United States for repair.

title: African Connection
snippet: Geoffrey Moorhouse reviews book The Atlantic Sound by Caryl Phillips; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: THE ATLANTIC SOUND

title: Recasting France’s Role in Africa
snippet: The Central African Republic is the newest focus of an effort by President François Hollande to revive his nation’s influence in Africa.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The imagery is likely to be the same as it has been for decades — foreign troops in battle fatigues lugging backpacks and assault rifles, confronting mayhem.

title: A Fierce Famine Stalks Africa
snippet: African women have been reducing meals, finding new trades, selling possessions, dispersing children before they ask the world for help.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Somalis traditionally did not number years but instead gave each a name that immortalized important events or crises.

title: Weaving by African Women at the Textile Museum
snippet: Most of the exhibition in Washington focuses on Kuba textiles, including skirts made from raffia, which have geometric motifs rendered in abstract ways.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone thinks of African art in terms of sculpture and masks that are made by men,” said Vanessa Drake Moraga, the curator of “Weaving Abstraction: Kuba Textiles and the Woven Art of Central Africa,” a show opening Saturday at the Textile Museum in Washington. “But textile and fiber arts are the domain of women.”

title: South Africa’s Parliamentary Revolution
snippet: New lawmakers are shunning decorum to hold the president accountable.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — The South African Parliament went on recess last month after a raucous final session saw sanctions handed down to representatives of the country’s newest and third-largest political party, the Economic Freedom Fighters. Twenty of the party’s representatives were found guilty of “conduct constituting contempt of Parliament” and some were suspended without pay for as long as 30 days. But if anyone has treated Parliament with contempt, it’s President Jacob Zuma and his African National Congress.

title: African-American Sites
lead_paragraph: Westchester is presenting its plans for a Heritage Trail of significant African-American historic sites to residents at public meetings this week.

title: Slipping Into Darkness in South Africa
snippet: “Sizwe Banzi Is Dead,” in Princeton, translates the repressive horror of apartheid into human terms through the use of easygoing humor in its early passages, then shifts into graver tones as the play progresses.
lead_paragraph: The Kafkaesque existence that millions of people suffered through under South Africa’s apartheid laws is rendered with powerful simplicity in “Sizwe Banzi Is Dead.”

title: KOREA CARMAKER FALTERS IN AFRICA
snippet: Southern Africa automotive sales operation of South Korea conglomerate Hyundai, Hyundai Motor Distributors, has been placed into liquidation after its banks halt lending to troubled dealership network, which owes more than $120 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The southern Africa automotive sales operation of the South Korean conglomerate Hyundai, Hyundai Motor Distributors, has been placed into liquidation after its banks halted lending to the troubled dealership network, which owes more than $120 million. The action by a high court in South Africa has left uncertain the future of the operation, its 1,000 employees and its new assembly plant in Botswana. With all 64 of the company's dealerships and all 32 of its service centers shuttered, at least for now, the thousands of Hyundai owners in the region are wondering who will service their cars.

title: The ICC, Out of Africa
snippet: Before African states began withdrawing from the court, the court was moving away from cases on the continent.
lead_paragraph: In just a few weeks, Burundi, South Africa and Gambia have announced that they would withdraw from the International Criminal Court, a permanent tribunal investigating war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity. Since its creation in 1998, the I.C.C. has been hobbled by the refusal of major countries like the United States, China and Russia to subject themselves to its jurisdiction. But the recent defections by member states, on grounds that the court is biased and undermines peace, seem like an unprecedented blow to its legitimacy.

title: DIAMONDS RETURN TO SOUTH AFRICA
lead_paragraph: The world's largest diamond producer, De Beers, is repatriating about $100 million worth of large South African-mined diamonds stockpiled in London. ''De Beers is in the process of bringing back large stones in the stockpile at the request of the Diamond Board'' of South Africa, a De Beers spokeswoman, Tracey Peterson, said. About $700 million worth of regular-sized diamonds will remain in London. The board's demand that the diamonds be returned was part of a dispute that delayed the export of De Beers's consignments twice this year.

title: An African Diaspora Show Asks: What Is Africanness? What Is Diaspora?
snippet: Holland Cotter reviews Looking Both Ways: Art of the Contemporary African Diaspora on view at Museum for African Art; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Diaspora -- the exile or emigration of a group of people from their homeland -- is an idea that probably has little immediate resonance in the New York art world. Why should it? The city may be multiethnic, but its main gallery neighborhoods remain tight enclaves of mostly British-American art.

title: The Next Africa?
snippet: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column says South America and Central America are victims of institutionalized Western neglect and indigenous despair, of tumbling living standards, of coups and civil wars and failed states; says per capita income in Arge...
lead_paragraph: While we're all focused on distant Iraq, our neighbor South America is quietly falling apart.

title: What Africa Brought to the Table
snippet: Jessica B. Harris writes about “the Africanizing of the Southern palate,” and ultimately of the American one.
lead_paragraph: “You hear a lot of jazz about soul food,” Eldridge Cleaver wrote in “Soul on Ice,” his 1968 prison memoir. Cleaver didn’t want that stuff on his plate every night. “The people in the ghetto want steaks. Beef steaks. I wish I had the power to see to it that the bourgeoisie really did have to make it on soul food.”

title: A Workout for Bustling Sounds of Africa
snippet: The African double bill at the Highline Ballroom was a night of triplets, scampering, chattering and barreling ahead in ways that could be dizzying.
lead_paragraph: The African double bill at the Highline Ballroom on Saturday was a night of triplets, scampering, chattering and barreling ahead in ways that could be dizzying. Vieux Farka Touré, a bandleader from Mali, and Blk Jks, a band from South Africa, arrive at their music from different directions: Mr. Touré by personalizing an inherited tradition, Blk Jks by global mix-and-match. But both play rock with rapid inner workings. Even songs with slower superstructures were bustling in triple time just under the surface.

title: South Africa’s Political Fires
snippet: With so many scandals to deal with, Zuma won't have time to grapple with the real challenges facing South Africa.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — Many a political obituary has been written for South Africa’s president, Jacob Zuma. Even as he began his second term last week in the Union Buildings, there were murmurs that he might not see it through, owing to the multitude of fires — many of them perilously close to home — that he’ll need to put out.

title: Shadow on Africa
lead_paragraph: For those hoping for peace in this vast, broken country in the heart of Africa, the news could not have come at a worse time.

title: Nigeria and Burkina Faso in Africa Final
snippet: Nigeria and Burkina Faso advanced to Sunday’s final of the Africa Cup of Nations in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Burkina Faso ousted Ghana in a penalty-kick shootout, 3-2, after playing to a 1-1 draw after 120 minutes, and Nigeria rolled over Mali, 4-1, in South Africa on Wednesday in the semifinals of the Africa Cup of Nations. On Sunday in Johannesburg, the two countries will play for the title and a berth in this year’s FIFA Confederation Cup in Brazil.

title: House Hunting in ... South Africa
snippet: The market in Cape Town’s affluent beachfront suburbs like Camps Bay and nearby Clifton has improved over the last year.
lead_paragraph: AN EIGHT-BEDROOM VILLA WITH SEA AND OCEAN VIEWS IN CAMPS BAY, CAPE TOWN

title: An African Pinochet
snippet: Editorial notes that Senegalese court has indicted exiled former dictator of Chad, Hissene Habre, on torture charges; holds that it is first time that former African head of state has been charged with human rights violations by court in another c...
lead_paragraph: Even as British courts ponder whether the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet should be excused from trial in Spain on human rights charges because he is medically unfit, the enduring legacy of his case has been demonstrated on another continent. Last week a Senegalese court indicted the exiled former dictator of Chad, Hissene Habre, on torture charges. It was the first time that a former African head of state had been charged with human rights violations by a court in another country, and it opens a welcome new chapter in the evolution of international criminal law.

title: African Opportunity
snippet: R W Apple Jr analysis state that Nigeria's pledge that it will release all political prisoners is most gratifying news from Africa since establishment of multiracial Government in South Africa under Nelson Mandela; notes that if Nigeria could take...
lead_paragraph: For the Western Governments that have watched with dismay for the last three decades as much of Africa suffered through chaos and bankruptcy, the news from Nigeria today is the most gratifying from that continent since the establishment of a multiracial Government in South Africa under Nelson Mandela.

title: South Africa’s Failing Grade
snippet: The dysfunctional education system offers bitter evidence that the country is still far from its post-apartheid promise.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — This year’s parliamentary elections in South Africa will be the first in which the first children born after the 1994 transition to democracy become eligible to vote. Glibly dubbed “born-frees,” these children have been dealt vastly different fates in the years since the dismantling of apartheid, calling into question South Africa’s constitutional promise of equality.

title: North Africa’s Next War
snippet: If the United Nations doesn’t step up, the long-simmering conflict in Western Sahara could soon boil over.
lead_paragraph: TIFARITI, Western Sahara — Uninhabited and less than three miles long, the rocky, flat area known as Guerguerat falls under no formal government rule. It lies near North Africa’s Atlantic coast, some 40 miles north of Nouadhibou, a thriving Mauritanian port city. The main industry — if you can call it that — is smuggling. And it could be the place where Africa’s next war begins.

title: South Africa: Warning on Violence
snippet: President Jacob Zuma condemned violent demonstrations against poor public services on Tuesday as a violation of the country’s history of protest.
lead_paragraph: President Jacob Zuma condemned violent demonstrations against poor public services on Tuesday as a violation of the country’s history of protest. “Burning down libraries, torching people’s houses and looting spaza shops do not build a strong nation,” he said. Spaza shops are unlicensed convenience stores.

title: The Exotic in the Eyes of African Beholders
snippet: An exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts conveys how Africans across centuries have viewed the European outsiders to their continent.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT  For centuries Euro-American eyes have been trained on Africa. We’ve scanned it from afar, surveyed it up close, put it behind glass; looked and looked, wonderingly, acquisitively, disdainfully, fearfully. But we rarely seem to be aware that during all that time Africans have been looking back at us  wonderingly, acquisitively, disdainfully, fearfully. A remarkable exhibition called “Through African Eyes: The European in African Art, 1500 to Present,” which opens Sunday at the Detroit Institute of Arts, gives a vivid hint of what they’ve seen.

title: China’s Wide Reach in Africa
snippet: In a new book, two journalists examine an economic partnership that has grown dramatically in recent years.
lead_paragraph: AMONG Westerners, the economic partnership between China and Africa is often overlooked. But in “China Safari: On the Trail of Beijing’s Expansion in Africa” (Nation Books, $27.50), Serge Michel and Michel Beuret examine the roots of this relationship  and argue that China is engaged in a conquest of Africa that will have worldwide economic implications.

title: Hearkening To Africa
snippet: Designer Linda Lindsay offers furniture line that seeks to combine American and African design; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THERE'S a new furniture designer on the block, and a new block on which to buy furniture. The Bench is Linda Lindsay's first design in a new collection, called Ethnic Essence. ''I am trying to combine American design with African design,'' Ms. Lindsay said.

title: The Man for South Africa's Future
lead_paragraph: In the final months of the 27 years he spent imprisoned for subversion, Nelson Mandela resided in a warden's bungalow at Victor Verster Prison outside Cape Town, recuperating from tuberculosis and meeting secretly with state visitors.

title: Trump, in Pitch to Black Voters in Detroit, Casts Biden as Anti-Black
snippet: Former President Donald J. Trump met with voters at a Black church in the critical battleground state, seeking to make a contrast with President Biden on the economy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, courting Black voters at a church on the west side of Detroit on Saturday, sought to harness animus toward migrants crossing the border, sanitized his track record on race and sold himself as the best president for Black Americans since Abraham Lincoln.

title: Crocodiles and Culture on a Cruise in West Africa
snippet: Views of wildlife, encounters with locals and connections with history are all part of a boat trip from Senegal through Gambia.
lead_paragraph: The radiant sun was starting its late-afternoon descent, leaving behind pleasantly warm air, and I was gliding on glassy water through a Gambian archipelago of tropical rain-forest islands in a brightly painted boat, a converted ferry with an upper deck and even a soft-drink bar. Propped against pillows with my feet up, I was as comfortable as Cleopatra on her royal barge. Suddenly, Assan, our guide, spotted our goal: a big, black chimpanzee sitting on the wet, brown shoreline, eating fruit. And then there was another one, with a baby chimp swinging from its belly, high up in the trees.

title: The Fencing in of Africa
snippet: Wildlife management has become a multimillion-dollar industry in the southern part of the African continent; animals are being herded onto ranches, auctioned for big money, and displayed for tourists; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: There is no more truly wild land in Africa. No matter how far you go into the scrubland of Botswana and Namibia, you will run into barbed-wire fences. No matter how deep you go into the Congo jungle, you will see dirt roads and airstrips. The pressure on wild game -- both from decreasing habitat and poachers -- is enormous, but salvation may be coming from an unexpected source. Crass and unromantic as it sounds, game ranching may be the best hope for many of Africa's threatened animals.

title: Rocker Joins Entourage in Africa
snippet: The rocker Bob Geldof, who has made ending poverty in Africa a personal cause, is convinced that President Bush has undergone some sort of epiphany about Africa.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia  The contingent of reporters accompanying President Bush on his trip to Africa was small, a reflection of how the press is turning its attention away from the current president and toward the race to succeed him. But in Rwanda this week, Mr. Bush had a celebrity journalist in his entourage: Bob Geldof, the Irish rock star.

title: South Africa: Jump in Robberies
snippet: Robbers struck South Africa’s 800 or so armored cars at the rate of more than one a day over the last 12 months, the largest number of cash-in-transit robberies recorded since current recordkeeping began in 1996, the Police Service reported. The 3...
lead_paragraph: Robbers struck South Africa’s 800 or so armored cars at the rate of more than one a day over the last 12 months, the largest number of cash-in-transit robberies recorded since current recordkeeping began in 1996, the Police Service reported. The 383 armored-car robberies marked an increase of nearly 75 percent from the previous 12-month period. Business robberies and car and truck hijackings also rose; with armored-car robberies, those crimes are often the work of large organized gangs.

title: African National Congress prepares for leadership vote in South Africa
lead_paragraph: POLOKWANE, South Africa — As he fought his deputy for leadership Sunday, President Thabo Mbeki said that corruption, abuse of power and bitter internal divisions were threatening to destroy the African National Congress, the governing party in South Africa.

title: The Guns of Africa
snippet: News analysis of planned cease-fire agreement in Congo; if opponents sign accord, they will be trying to bring closure to single event that has destabilized all of Central Africa: genocide in Rwanda; agreement calls for disarmament of Hutu militia...
lead_paragraph: If the opponents in Congo's 11-month war sign their planned cease-fire agreement, they will be trying to bring closure to the single event that has destabilized all of Central Africa: the genocide in Rwanda. It won't be easy.

title: South Africa: Renault to Build
snippet: Renault of France will start building cars in South Africa from 2009 to expand its share of sales in rapidly growing emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: Renault of France will start building cars in South Africa from 2009 to expand its share of sales in rapidly growing emerging markets. The company will assemble entry-level Sandero cars at a plant owned by its affiliate, Nissan Motor, north of Pretoria, Patrick Pelata, Renault’s vice president of Asia-Africa projects, told reporters in Johannesburg. Renault may export the car to other parts of Africa and to Europe. South Africa produced 590,000 vehicles last year, giving it a share of world production of just under 1 percent. The government encourages exports by giving carmakers discounts on imported vehicles and components. Renault’s chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, says he intends to increase the company’s total sales by 39 percent, to 3.33 million vehicles, in the next three years.

title: Reagan and Africa
Command for Africa Is Established by Pentagon
snippet: The new regional headquarters reflects a Pentagon push to coordinate security, aid and development in Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For decades, Africa was rarely more than an afterthought for the Pentagon.

title: Our Africa
snippet: The faded and sketchy map spread across the hood of the Jeep suggests that only 150 miles separate the Kenyan frontier town of Lokichokio from the Sudanese village of Chukudum. But there are no filling stations between here and Chukudum - there is...
lead_paragraph: The faded and sketchy map spread across the hood of the Jeep suggests that only 150 miles separate the Kenyan frontier town of Lokichokio from the Sudanese village of Chukudum. But there are no filling stations between here and Chukudum - there is nothing between here and Chukudum - wo we strap jerry-cans of gasoline to the roof of the Jeep, just in case. A Kenyan Army patrol arrives and escorts us to the border. The escort is meant to protect us from bandits and cattle raiders, who riddle the area. At the border, we are met by guerrillas of the Sudan People's Liberation Army. I am heading for a meeting with a commander of the S.P.L.A., and the guerrillas quickly pass us through the border, which is marked by a branch laid across the dirt road.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe Frees South African Spy
snippet: A South African intelligence agent arrested in Zimbabwe a year ago returned to Johannesburg, saying that his stay in custody there had been difficult but that he had emerged ''with all my limbs.'' The agent, Aubrey Welken, was apparently assigned ...
lead_paragraph: A South African intelligence agent arrested in Zimbabwe a year ago returned to Johannesburg, saying that his stay in custody there had been difficult but that he had emerged "with all my limbs." The agent, Aubrey Welken, was apparently assigned to gather details of dissent within the government of President Robert G. Mugabe. After his arrest, 15 leading Zimbabwean figures were implicated in supplying political intelligence to South Africa. Zimbabwe released Mr. Welken as a gesture of good will during the holiday season, South African officials said, adding that the spy scandal had not seriously damaged relations between the nations.

title: Loving Africa
snippet: Margot Livesey reviews book The Gravity of Sunlight by Rosa Shand (M)
lead_paragraph: THE GRAVITY OF SUNLIGHT

title: Out of Africa
snippet: By Design column notes that from safari jackets to tribal prints to beaded necklaces, African influence permeates fashion for spring; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: From safari jackets to tribal prints to beaded necklaces, the African influence permeates fashion for spring. Ralph Lauren's collection was totally inspired by Africa, and other designers dipped into the continent's design heritage.

title: On Southern Africa
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Aristide Welcome To Stay
snippet: South African Foreign Min Nkosazana Diamini-Zuma tells Parliament that deposed Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide is welcome to stay in exile in South Africa indefinitely; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The deposed Haitian president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is welcome to remain in exile in South Africa for as long as he likes, but neither he nor the South African government anticipates that he will stay forever, the foreign minister, Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, told Parliament. Mr. Aristide, left, who left Haiti in 2004, lives outside Pretoria in circumstances akin to those of a cabinet minister, she said. Critics have accused President Thabo Mbeki of according luxury accommodations to Mr. Aristide, who was widely accused of corruption and misrule. Ms. Dlamini-Zuma said, however, that Mr. Aristide's exile fit an international mandate to create peace and stability in Haiti.

title: An African Chief in Cabby’s Clothing
snippet: Isaac Osei, who owns a taxi fleet in New York City with his wife, is also a Ghanaian chief who wears a crown and oversees five towns.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE dawn, when most New Yorkers are fast asleep, Isaac and Elizabeth Osei have already been working for hours. On a recent morning, Mr. Osei drove his wife from New Jersey to the half-abandoned outer blocks of Midtown Manhattan to oversee the 4:30 a.m. transfer of their fleet of 50 taxis. With Ms. Osei leading the way and a sliver of moon still hanging in the sky, they scouted three square blocks to make sure all of their taxis had been picked up by drivers. Then, over the screeches emanating from auto-body shops and the smell of gasoline wafting from a Hess station crammed with cabs, they surveyed their troubled taxis just as sunlight faintly appeared over Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Arrest In Fake Marriages
snippet: Pretoria (South Africa) police arrest priest Hendrik Uys Jansen for participation in nationwide marriage scam primarily designed to provide residency benefits for illegal immigrants; many of those married had no knowledge of nuptials; at least 600...
lead_paragraph: The police in Pretoria arrested a 39-year-old priest on charges of illegally sanctioning at least 600 bogus marriages between foreign men and South African women who had no knowledge of the nuptials. The priest, Hendrik Uys Jansen, was thought to be part of a nationwide ring of marriage officers conducting sham marriages, largely on behalf of illegal immigrants who want the benefits of residency that marriage to a South African citizen brings. Thousands of women -- and some men -- have discovered recently that they had been married without their knowledge. The Home Affairs Ministry, which oversees immigration, has acknowledged that corrupt officials in its ranks have been aiding the schemes. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: African Safari
snippet: Through June 30, Far and Wide will allow three people to travel together for the price of two.
lead_paragraph: Through June 30, Far and Wide will allow three people to travel together for the price of two. The 12-day Southern Cross tour, with a three-day safari in Kruger National Park, along with visits to Cape Town, Johannesburg and Sun City, starts at $4,490 a person for the first two travelers. The 13-day Ultimate African Safari stops in Cape Town, Kroger, Sun City and Zululand, starting at $6,254 a person for two. Accommodations are in deluxe private game lodges. The prices include air fare from New York or Atlanta, all accommodations and sightseeing; the three travelers must share accommodations. For information: (800) 421-8907 or www.african travelinc.com .

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mandela Prison Letters
snippet: Excerpts from letters written by Nelson Mandela during his 27-year imprisonment are published in Johannesburg newspaper (S)
lead_paragraph: A Johannesburg newspaper published excerpts from drafts of some 70 letters by Nelson Mandela during his imprisonment by South Africa's apartheid government in which he wrote that "there are times when my heart almost stops beating, slowed down by heavy loads of longing" for freedom. The drafts, written between 1969 and 1971, also detail Mr. Mandela's pain at not being allowed to attend the funerals of his mother and eldest son, who died while he was jailed in 1968 and 1969. Mr. Mandela spent 18 years in the Robben Island prison, then nine more in other jails before being released in 1990. The drafts, in two notebooks, had been confiscated by a guard who returned them to Mr. Mandela two months ago, saying they were of historical importance. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Mostly African Scenes, All by Africans
lead_paragraph: Photography can be a deeply passionate medium, and a sense of that passion comes across in "In/sight: African Photographers, 1940 to the Present" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: A Stylish Rosé of South Africa
snippet: Mulderbosch’s floral 2006 cabernet sauvignon rosé from Stellenbosch, in the heart of South Africa’s wine industry, combines a white’s zip and a red’s oomph. Deeply chilled, this stylish pink rosé is a tangy aperitif.
lead_paragraph: Mulderbosch’s floral 2006 cabernet sauvignon rosé from Stellenbosch, in the heart of South Africa’s wine industry, combines a white’s zip and a red’s oomph. Deeply chilled, this stylish pink rosé is a tangy aperitif.

title: New Condos Inspired by Africa
snippet: The construction site on West 116th Street that will eventually be the Kalahari condominium complex is a kind of symbol for the social and economic forces shaping Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Speak-No-Panic Proposal
snippet: Angered by charges that its Pelindaba nuclear research site had leaked potentially dangerous radiation, South Africa's government said it would study whether to regulate public speech to ensure that people and groups ''speak responsibly on sensiti...
lead_paragraph: Angered by charges that its Pelindaba nuclear research site had leaked potentially dangerous radiation, South Africa's government said it would study whether to regulate public speech to ensure that people and groups "speak responsibly on sensitive matters." A spokeswoman for the Minerals and Energy Ministry told the Johannesburg newspaper Business Day that "anybody who would act irresponsibly, making utterances that seek to incite and get people to rise up in arms, causing panic, will be targeted." She said that the minister would work with the communications and justice ministries to study legislation. Critics said the proposal was uncomfortably close to the so-called anti-incitement laws that South Africa's apartheid government used to suppress protests by blacks. The Constitution guarantees freedom of expression. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: 85 in South-West Africa Killed by South Africans
Online Tunes, in Service to Africa
snippet: (RED), a nonprofit organization that arranges for companies to contribute a share of profits on certain products to fight AIDS in Africa, is starting a digital music service for that purpose.
lead_paragraph: The music business is known for supporting causes with events like the Live Aid and Live Earth concerts, which generate lots of money and publicity for a relatively short time. But on Monday (RED), a nonprofit organization that arranges for companies to contribute a share of profits on certain products to fight AIDS in Africa, is starting a digital music service for that purpose, and it plans to operate for the long haul. The new venture has already arranged to release new songs from U2, Bob Dylan, Elvis Costello, Elton John, Emmylou Harris and Death Cab for Cutie.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Icons? Check No. 19
snippet: The public television network SABC apologized for broadcasting the series ''Great South Africans,'' in which viewers' nominations and votes determined a list of the 100 greatest South Africans, after the poll conferred greatness on some unsavory c...
lead_paragraph: The public television network SABC apologized for broadcasting the series "Great South Africans," in which viewers' nominations and votes determined a list of the 100 greatest South Africans, after the poll conferred greatness on some unsavory characters, including white supremacists and a disgraced match-fixing cricket captain. The No.1 spot was given to Nelson Mandela, but viewers awarded the 19th spot on the list to Hendrik F. Verwoerd, the principal architect of apartheid who forced millions of blacks into so-called homelands. Eugene TerreBlanche, a self-proclaimed racist who recently completed a prison sentence for attempted murder, was voted No.25. Network officials said the series, modeled on a popular BBC program, had "no intention to hurt" but was flawed in its formulation. The series was pulled. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Ostrich Leather in South Africa
snippet: Foraging column on shopping for ostrich feathers and ostrich leather items in Oudtshoorn, South Africa; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Oudtshoorn is the ostrich capital of the world. The town built on feathers lies in the Little Karoo region of South Africa, 250 miles from Cape Town. Around the turn of the last century, when white ostrich plumes were as precious as gold, the feather barons of Oudtshoorn built great palaces. The feather crash of 1914 ended all that.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apology For Unprotected Sex
snippet: Newly acquitted of raping the daughter of a family friend, South Africa's former deputy president, Jacob G. Zuma, apologized for having unprotected sex with the H.I.V.-positive woman last November, saying he ''should have been more cautious and mo...
lead_paragraph: Newly acquitted of raping the daughter of a family friend, South Africa's former deputy president, Jacob G. Zuma, apologized for having unprotected sex with the H.I.V.-positive woman last November, saying he "should have been more cautious and more responsible." But he bristled at the widespread criticism of his statement during the trial that he had showered after sex to minimize the chance of contracting H.I.V. Mr. Zuma said he had not stated that showers prevent AIDS, explaining that his behavior was an "additional measure" to ward off infection, akin to washing one's hands after peeling an onion. Mr. Zuma's statements on H.I.V. and women's sexual behavior were assailed by women's and AIDS activists but supported by many in South Africa's large Zulu population. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: Back to Africa
snippet: Annette Kobak reviews book Still Waters in Niger by Kathleen Hill (S)
lead_paragraph: Still Waters in Niger

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apartheid Spy Inquiry
snippet: South African government-appointed commission meets to begin investigation into accusations that senior members of governing African National Congress party, including public prosecution director Bulelani Ngucka, spied for apartheid government; Ng...
lead_paragraph: A government-appointed commission convened briefly this week to investigate whether senior members of the governing political party, the African National Congress, spied for the former apartheid government. Two allies of the vice president, Jacob Zuma, have accused Bulelani Ngcuka, the director of public prosecutions, of spying for apartheid authorities. Mr. Ngucka denied the charges. Supporters of the African National Congress say the allegations are simply an attempt to draw attention away from the prosecutor's own investigation into whether Mr. Zuma accepted a $71,000 bribe from a French arms company. The commission will reconvene next month. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: No Jail For Winnie Mandela
snippet: Pretoria High Court dismisses convictions on 25 counts of theft against Winnie Madikizela-Mandala, activist and ex-wife of former Pres Nelson Mandela, completely suspending her 14-year prison sentence; it allows 43 fraud convictions to stand; she ...
lead_paragraph: The Pretoria High Court dismissed convictions on 25 counts of theft against Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, left, the activist and ex-wife of former President Nelson Mandela, but allowed 43 fraud convictions to stand. Although the judge completely suspended her four-year prison sentence, Ms. Madikizela-Mandela said she would appeal her conviction on the remaining charges, calling them ''completely wrong.'' She and a second defendant, a financial services broker named Addy Moolman, were convicted of obtaining loans for people whom they had fraudulently depicted as employees of the African National Congress Women's League, which Ms. Madikizela-Mandela had headed. Mr. Moolman also won dismissal of his theft convictions, and said he, too, would challenge the remaining fraud counts. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Seeking a Road to Peace in Southeast Africa
snippet: For Deborah Julio, the challenges are many: from religious conflicts to border disputes to forced childhood marriage.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Julio, 36, has a past that helped shape her role as an advocate for women’s rights and a conflict mediator between the southeast African nation of Malawi, where she lives, and neighboring Mozambique.

title: 'Out of Africa' Chair Right Out of Africa
lead_paragraph: WHEN the producers of ''Out of Africa'' were combing Kenya for period pieces that would give the movie the right look, they stumbled across some unpacked boxes in an antiques store not far from the home of Karen Blixen, who under her pen name, Isak Dinesen, wrote the book on which the movie was based.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Africans Reject Call To Condemn Mugabe
snippet: Days before its fifth annual summit meeting in Libya, the African Union rejected Western demands to condemn mass evictions of poor squatters in Zimbabwe, saying that the forced uprooting of several hundred thousand people was a domestic matter. ''...
lead_paragraph: Days before its fifth annual summit meeting in Libya, the African Union rejected Western demands to condemn mass evictions of poor squatters in Zimbabwe, saying that the forced uprooting of several hundred thousand people was a domestic matter. "If the government that they elected say they are restoring order by their actions, I don't think it would be proper for us to go interfering in their internal legislation," the group's spokesman, Desmond Orjiako, told the BBC. The Group of 8 industrialized nations urged African leaders this week to press President Robert G. Mugabe on observing human rights, saying that "until Africa's leaders as a whole recognize what is going on, take action not just to condemn but to deal with it, we are likely to be in for many more months of this kind of tyranny." Mr. Mugabe says the evictions are an attack on crime and urban decay. Critics say they are, among other things, a campaign to eradicate opposition to his rule. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Telecom Venture
snippet: South Africa's Allied Technologies and Econet Wireless, cellular provider in Johannesburg, have created $140 million joint venture; Allied, known as Altech and controlled by Allied Electronics Corp, will contribute $70 million in cash and Econet $...
lead_paragraph: A South African telecommunications and multimedia company, Allied Technologies, and Econet Wireless, a cellular provider in Johannesburg, said they had created a $140 million joint venture. Under the deal, which is subject to government approval, Allied, known as Altech and controlled by the Allied Electronics Corporation, also of Johannesburg, will contribute $70 million in cash and Econet $70 million in assets, including cellular and satellite interests in Botswana, Britain, Kenya, Lesotho, New Zealand and Nigeria. Econet's company listed in Zimbabwe and its international assets will not initially be part of the deal. The venture will expand Allied's cellular telephone reach and will be based in Johannesburg.

title: Next Stop, Africa
snippet: Suzy Menkes comments on African influence on this spring's fashions; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Move over, Takashi Murakami, I thought as I looked at an exhibition of contemporary African art. Ever since Murakami, a Tokyo artist, was taken up by Louis Vuitton, his graphic designs have been the fashion equivalent of fusion food. But here I was, in a tiny museum in Florence, looking at a silk scarf, its fiery red-and-white pattern so vibrant and artistic that it seemed a steal at $30. It was signed "Mandy's Meninwa," a Nigerian artist in the show "Africans in Africa." Why, after all these years, I wondered, was Africa still below the radar?

title: African Safaris
snippet: African safaris are exciting, but expensive. One way to make them more affordable is to shorten them, which is what United Touring Company has done. Rates start at $2,495 a person, based on double occupancy, for a 10-day trip that stops in Kenya a...
lead_paragraph: African safaris are exciting, but expensive. One way to make them more affordable is to shorten them, which is what United Touring Company has done. Rates start at $2,495 a person, based on double occupancy, for a 10-day trip that stops in Kenya and Tanzania; the price includes round-trip air fare from New York. A 12-day itinerary begins in Nairobi, then goes to the Great Rift Valley and the Masai Mara National Reserve. Other stops include Tarangire National Park in Tanzania and the Ngorongoro Crater. The price is $3,095 a person, including air fare from New York. When booking safari trips, be sure to check which months are best for wildlife viewing in the regions visited. Contact: (800) 223-6486 or www.unitedtouring.com .

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Thatcher's Son Protests
snippet: Mark Thatcher, 51, the son of the former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, appeared in a Cape Town court to contest South Africa's decision to allow prosecutors from Equatorial Guinea to question him about an alleged plot to overthrow that...
lead_paragraph: Mark Thatcher, 51, the son of the former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, appeared in a Cape Town court to contest South Africa's decision to allow prosecutors from Equatorial Guinea to question him about an alleged plot to overthrow that nation's government. South African prosecutors accuse Mr. Thatcher, 51, of helping finance the coup plot, which collapsed in March; his lawyers told the court that Mr. Thatcher was innocent and that allowing Equatorial Guinea officials to question him could prejudice his trial. Mr. Thatcher's hearing on the issue, the first court proceeding ever to be broadcast in South Africa, is expected to end today. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: African Art Is Donated to Museum
snippet: In a move that will expand a strapped museum's resources, the Walt Disney Company donated a 525-piece collection of mainly West African traditional art on Thursday to the Smithsonian Institution, with the works to go to its National Museum of Afri...
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - In a move that will expand a strapped museum's resources, the Walt Disney Company donated a 525-piece collection of mainly West African traditional art on Thursday to the Smithsonian Institution, with the works to go to its National Museum of African Art.

title: Africa and the Mediterranean: Solar Eclipse
snippet: There's nothing like a total solar eclipse to remind you that we're clinging to a rock floating in space. As the moon slips between Earth and Sun, a twilight neither night nor day settles across the landscape. The wrong stars appear in the sky, an...
lead_paragraph: There's nothing like a total solar eclipse to remind you that we're clinging to a rock floating in space. As the moon slips between Earth and Sun, a twilight neither night nor day settles across the landscape. The wrong stars appear in the sky, and the planets, their cover blown, peer down bemused. With its body blotted out by the moon, the Sun's corona comes into view. It's an experience that lasts just a few minutes, but that reverberates for a lifetime.

title: African Safaris
snippet: African safaris are exciting, but expensive. One way to make them more affordable is to shorten them, which is what United Touring Company has done. Rates start at $2,495 a person, based on double occupancy, for a 10-day trip that stops in Kenya a...
lead_paragraph: African safaris are exciting, but expensive. One way to make them more affordable is to shorten them, which is what United Touring Company has done. Rates start at $2,495 a person, based on double occupancy, for a 10-day trip that stops in Kenya and Tanzania; the price includes round-trip air fare from New York. A 12-day itinerary begins in Nairobi, then goes to the Great Rift Valley and the Masai Mara National Reserve. Other stops include Tarangire National Park in Tanzania and the Ngorongoro Crater.
