title: Scholarships and Steel; AFRICAN INVESTMENT; African Investment
lead_paragraph: It is a familiar white claim in South Africa that nowhere else on the continent are blacks better off, apartheid notwithstanding. But the claim ignores the exclusion of blacks from professional fields.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Zimbabwean Opposition Visits
snippet: The leader of Zimbabwe's political opposition, Morgan Tsvangirai, met with President Thabo Mbeki in Pretoria. It was Mr. Tsvangirai's first foreign trip since Zimbabwe officials seized his passport and charged him with treason 32 months ago; he wa...
lead_paragraph: The leader of Zimbabwe's political opposition, Morgan Tsvangirai, met with President Thabo Mbeki in Pretoria. It was Mr. Tsvangirai's first foreign trip since Zimbabwe officials seized his passport and charged him with treason 32 months ago; he was acquitted on Oct. 15. Mr. Mbeki has been working to open a dialogue between the opposition and President Robert Mugabe. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Inflation Slows
snippet: South Africa's inflation slows to 21-month low in August, fueling expectations that central bank will cut interest rates next month for fourth time since June as strong rand reduces prices of imports (S)
lead_paragraph: South Africa's inflation slowed to a 21-month low in August, fueling expectations that the central bank will cut interest rates next month for a fourth time since June as the strong rand reduces the prices of imports. The CPIX inflation rate, which excludes mortgages, fell to 6.3 percent from 6.6 percent in July. Prices rose 0.4 percent in the month. The central bank has cut rates three times since June 12 by a total of 3.5 percentage points as inflation slowed toward its 3 percent to 6 percent target.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: A Stake In Bank
snippet: World Business Briefing: South Africa: A Stake in Bank**
lead_paragraph: The Absa Group, a South African bank, has agreed to sell a 10 percent stake for as much as 5.05 billion rand ($795 million) to a group of black investors led by a wealthy black investor and former political prisoner, Tokyo Sexwale. Mr. Sexwale, left, who was imprisoned with former President Nelson Mandela, is one of South Africa's wealthiest blacks. He is on the board at Absa and is the head of Mvelaphanda Resources, the biggest black-owned mining company. Mvelaphanda also is in talks to buy 15 percent of the South African assets of Gold Fields, a gold producer. Absa is the first of the largest banks in South Africa to announce a stake sale to blacks. Financial services companies agreed last year to sell a quarter of their business to blacks to help make up for discrimination during South Africa's apartheid era that lasted from 1948 to 1994.

title: With New African Flavor, Pope Starts Tour in Africa
lead_paragraph: On Pope John Paul II's 11th visit to this continent, beginning in Cameroon today, each stop of his four-country tour will include African touches for church ceremonies that even five years ago would have seemed strongly out of place for a Roman Catholic event of this magnitude.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Vagrant Is Left To Die
snippet: South African Health Minister Manto Tshabalala-Msimang requests inquiry into death of homeless man who was allegedly left untreated by paramedics after he collapsed in downtown Johannesburg; security guards on scene hold that medics said man was t...
lead_paragraph: South Africa's health minister assailed what he called the appalling conduct of two Johannesburg paramedics who were videotaped by security cameras on Tuesday as they refused to treat a homeless man who had collapsed in a downtown street gutter. The man was found dead the next morning. The paramedics had propped him against a wall after reportedly telling security guards that he was too dirty to ride in their ambulance. The health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, called for an inquiry, saying the government "should ensure that such an incident never happens again in this country." A police spokesman said the unidentified man had died of natural causes but declined to elaborate. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: A Big Hand For Mugabe
snippet: Pre-inauguration party for South African President Thabo Mbeki is overshadowed by controversial presence of Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe (S)
lead_paragraph: Thabo Mbeki began his second five-year term as president of South Africa in a stately ceremony partly overshadowed by the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe. Mr. Mugabe, 80, an icon of African liberation struggles, received a standing ovation from thousands as he arrived for a pre-inauguration party. His attendance was easily the most debated aspect of the inauguration; some South African hotels refused him lodging to protest his increasingly authoritarian rule. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Rising Anger at Other Africans Fuels South Africa Attacks
snippet: Refugees from Zimbabwe, its deeply troubled neighbor, are easy targets.
lead_paragraph: POLOKWANE, South Africa  Men in Westenburg Township went hunting Zimbabweans. They prowled its dirt roads by the truckload as night fell recently, brandishing clubs and throwing stones.

title: Bringing Africa to the World
snippet: The new director of the National Museum of African Art talks about his passion for sharing the astonishing breadth of his parents’ continent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gus Casely-Hayford, of London, started as the director of the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African Art in February. He talks about his passion for sharing the astonishing breadth of his parents’ continent, the need to go global and digital, and his desire to renovate. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title:
FILM;
A Lively Look at Africa Through an African Lens
snippet: AT 3 A.M. IN OUAGADOUGOU, the heat and dust are just beginning to settle. Muddled loudspeakers broadcast prayers from a mosque. The timeless certitude of this voice is broken by the loud soukous music from a dance bar next door. The reconciliation...
lead_paragraph: AT 3 A.M. IN OUAGADOUGOU, the heat and dust are just beginning to settle. Muddled loudspeakers broadcast prayers from a mosque. The timeless certitude of this voice is broken by the loud soukous music from a dance bar next door. The reconciliation of these disparate sounds seems too much for a room, let alone a city, to sustain.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Had A Great Fall
snippet: Nicholas Du Plooy is reported in 'relatively good condition' after falling 19 stores from window of Ritz Hotel in Seapoint, South Africa (S)
lead_paragraph: Hospital officials in Cape Town said a man was ''in a relatively good condition, considering his ordeal'' after falling 19 stories from a hotel window in Sea Point, a fashionable suburb. The man, Nicholas Du Plooy, suffered two broken arms, a broken leg and an injured neck after falling at the Ritz Hotel but was otherwise uninjured. The police said they did not know why he fell, but did not suspect foul play. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Searching For White Militants
snippet: South African authorities search almost 100 rural homes and farms attempting to root out white separatist militants thought to be responsible for several recent anti-government bombings (S)
lead_paragraph: The authorities searched nearly 100 farms and houses in an effort to find white militants who are believed to be plotting to destabilize the country. More than a dozen white separatists have already been arrested on charges of plotting to overthrow the government. The police suspect the men are behind a series of bomb blasts. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: A Covid Mystery in Africa
snippet: Why coronavirus case and death rates have been so low in much of sub-Saharan Africa compared with the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: As countries have struggled with disease and death throughout the coronavirus pandemic, one part of the world seems to have been mostly spared: central and western Africa.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Aids Treatment Closer
snippet: South African officials begin plan to supply antiretroviral drugs to HIV positive individuals; estimated 5.3 million South Africans are HIV positive (S)
lead_paragraph: Officials belatedly rolled out a plan to supply antiretroviral drugs to the nation's 5.3 million H.I.V.-positive citizens, saying that nutritional supplements and anti-H.I.V. drugs would be made available at least one center in every health district within a year and in all towns within five years. The drugs will be warehoused in each of the nation's nine provinces, officials told Parliament, but supply constraints could be a problem because crucial ingredients would be imported from China and India, which have their own mounting H.I.V. problems. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Outcry After Speech
snippet: Opposition parties accuse South African Pres Thabo Mbeki of neglecting discussion on AIDS in his state of the nation speech (S)
lead_paragraph: Opposition parties accused President Thabo Mbeki of neglecting critical issues, including AIDS and South Africa's support for Zimbabwe, in his state of the nation speech. Last week, demonstrators marched through the streets of Cape Town to press the government to provide AIDS drugs in this country, which has more people infected with H.I.V. than any other country. In his speech, Mr. Mbeki did not announce any plans to widen access to the lifesaving medicines. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Election Date Announced
snippet: South African President Thabo Mbeki sets April 14 for general elections; governing African National Congress is expected to maintain control of Parliament, which would likely ensure re-election of Mbeki to second five-year term (S)
lead_paragraph: President Thabo Mbeki set April 14 for general elections, which are widely expected to give his African National Congress continued control of Parliament and most provincial legislatures. The congress holds about two-thirds of the seats in Parliament; retaining that control in April would all but ensure that the body would re-elect Mr. Mbeki to a second five-year term as president. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: The Future of South Africa
snippet: What are the biggest challenges that South Africa faces in its struggle to obtain Nelson Mandela's dream of a democratic nation?

title: On Being African in Europe
snippet: We lack inspiring symbols and leaders: our Martin Luther Kings, our Rosa Parkses, our Obamas.
lead_paragraph: ROME — While the recent spate of deadly police confrontations with black men in America has sparked a renewed debate about racism, the conversation in Europe about violence, social exclusion and immigration has studiously avoided the issue of race.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Land Grabbers Beware
snippet: South African government will toughen criminal penalties for people who illegally occupy private property, describing recent spate of land invasions as 'unacceptable' (S)
lead_paragraph: Describing the recent spate of land invasions as ''unacceptable,'' government officials said they would toughen the criminal penalties for people who illegally occupy private property. The proposed law would allow the government to prosecute people who organize land invasions in addition to the squatters who occupy the land. Officials here have repeatedly said they will not tolerate the type of land seizures that have racked neighboring Zimbabwe. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Bank Acquisition
snippet: South Africa's Nedcor Ltd agrees to buy rival BoE Ltd to become biggest bank in South Africa; bid is valued at 7.3 billion rand ($657 million) (S)
lead_paragraph: Nedcor Ltd., one of South Africa's largest banks, said that it had agreed to buy a rival, BoE Ltd., to become the biggest bank in the country. Nedcor agreed to pay 280 rand and 0.48 Nedcor shares per 100 BoE shares, valuing each BoE share at 3.43 rand, a 10 percent premium to Friday's closing price. The bid, which values BoE at 7.3 billion rand ($657 million), requires shareholder approval.

title: Realism In Africa
lead_paragraph: A quiet neighbor of South Africa, Botswana is in many ways a model of what the United States would like to see in Africa: a genuine democracy, non-racial, devoted to free enterprise. Its politics earn that prized American adjective, moderate.

title: Africa, a User's Guide
snippet: The first step in getting to know this diverse continent is to orient yourself. Here is a key to the many destinations that we covered in our Africa issue.
lead_paragraph: The first step in getting to know this diverse continent is to orient yourself. Here is a key to the many destinations that we covered in our Africa issue.

title: An African King in Bolivia
snippet: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in an isolated part of Bolivia, there is a royal family whose existence is as surprising as it is humble. Despite his title, King Don Julio I and his wife live in a small apartment atop a small store in Mururata, Bolivia, where he farms coca leaves and other crops.

title: Africa and the Chinese Way
snippet: A group of African leaders has emerged that openly declares its admiration for authoritarian government.
lead_paragraph: The Kamba people of Kenya claim they were warned about the evils of colonialism long before the first colonialist arrived. The legend goes that the prophet Syokimau, back in the early 19th century, told her people of “a long narrow snake spitting fire” that would make its way up from the East African Coast, bringing with it “red people” who would take away their land. She was right; it was the railroads more than anything else that enabled European colonialists to exploit Kenya’s people and extract its wealth during the first half of the 20th century.

title: In South Africa, Land Apartheid Lives On
snippet: The government's reform program is undermining instead of promoting black economic development.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Friday marks the 150th anniversary of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman’s famous field order to confiscate 400,000 acres of land from former slave-owners and distribute it to former slaves — the promise of 40 acres and mule that we so often hear about.

title: ‘Disguise,’ of Masks and Global African Art
snippet: The exhibition, at the Brooklyn Museum, features more than 25 contemporary artists from Africa and of African descent from around the world.
lead_paragraph: In New York at least, the Brooklyn Museum has been a leader in the curatorial practice of juxtaposing art from disparate times, places, media and cultures. Its latest foray, which opens Friday, April 29, is at once wide yet focused, as its title attests. “Disguise: Masks and Global African Art” expands upon a show organized by the Seattle Art Museum, featuring more than 25 contemporary artists from Africa and of African descent from around the world, often representing them with several works each — photography, installation, drawing, sculpture and video.

title: ‘Disguise,’ of Masks and Global African Art
snippet: The exhibition, at the Brooklyn Museum, features more than 25 contemporary artists from Africa and of African descent from around the world.
lead_paragraph: In New York at least, the Brooklyn Museum has been a leader in the curatorial practice of juxtaposing art from disparate times, places, media and cultures. Its latest foray, which opens Friday, April 29, is at once wide yet focused, as its title attests. “Disguise: Masks and Global African Art” expands upon a show organized by the Seattle Art Museum, featuring more than 25 contemporary artists from Africa and of African descent from around the world, often representing them with several works each — photography, installation, drawing, sculpture and video.

title: The Poisoning of Africa’s Vultures
snippet: The circling scavengers are the poachers’ worst enemy.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — IN July of last year, roughly 500 vultures died after they ate the pesticide-laced carcass of an elephant that had been killed by poachers in Namibia. It was an example of one poaching technique in Africa that seems to be on the rise: the poisoning of vultures so that authorities won’t be alerted to the location of the crime.

title: It’s Time for African Resistance, This Artist Says
snippet: In a new exhibition in London, Yinka Shonibare has collected works that challenge the resurgence of extreme right-wing politics and xenophobia.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Can political art be beautiful? Can beauty itself be a form of resistance? These are some of the questions posed by the British-Nigerian artist Yinka Shonibare in a new exhibition he has curated at Stephen Friedman Gallery in London.

title: Africa's Third Liberation
snippet: To ensure a new future with both jobs and development, African governments will have to embark on a path down which few have so far ventured.
lead_paragraph: The first years of this century have produced Africa’s best decade of economic expansion since the end of the colonial era, with many countries showing growth rates of 5 percent or more since the year 2000. Prospects are good that growth will remain at this level for the next few years.

title: An African’s Message for America
snippet: This short documentary profiles a Kenyan activist who asks American student volunteers: “Why do you want to help us? Help your own country.”
lead_paragraph: This short documentary profiles a Kenyan activist who asks American student volunteers: “Why do you want to help us? Help your own country.”

title: Inventing Africa
snippet:
IN MY FATHER'S HOUSE

Africa in the Philosophy of Culture.
By Kwame Anthony Appiah.
225 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $29.95.
lead_paragraph: IN MY FATHER'S HOUSE

title: Making South Africa Great Again
snippet: As in America, ‘exceptionalism’ can create dangerous myths about a country. But it can also inspire a powerful reform movement.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In 2012, as a fellow at Yale University, I met an earnest and articulate American graduate student. I found her guileless patriotism touching; she regularly used phrases to describe America as “the greatest democracy on earth,” with “the best political system on the planet.”

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Top Lawmaker Arrested
snippet: Tony Yengeni, chief whip in South Africa's Parliament for governing African National Congress, is arrested on corruption and fraud charges related to purchase of automobile at cut-rate price from defense contractor; denies wrongdoing (S)
lead_paragraph: The chief whip in Parliament for the governing African National Congress was arrested on corruption and fraud charges in connection with his cut-rate purchase of a Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle from a defense contractor seeking a piece of a multibillion-dollar arms deal. The deal is the subject of a sweeping government investigation. The lawmaker, Tony Yengeni, has denied wrongdoing in buying the vehicle from DaimlerChrysler Aerospace South Africa, now part of the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, which says it sold 30 vehicles at discount prices to key government officials.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Trouble For Winnie Mandela
snippet: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela is found guilty of violating Parliamentary code of conduct by failing to report additional income beyond her salary as legislator; she will be reprimanded and lose 15 days of pay; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela was found guilty of violating Parliament's code of conduct by failing to report additional income beyond her salary as a legislator. Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, the ex-wife of former President Nelson Mandela, is also on trial on charges of defrauding a bank. She said she had monthly expenses of $6,600 -- more than four times her salary as a member of Parliament -- and said she paid them with additional money from private donors. She will be reprimanded and lose 15 days of her pay. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Stop the Plunder of Africa
snippet: Africa has the wealth to combat poverty, but it needs help holding on to it.
lead_paragraph: With Africa’s economies riding the crest of the global commodities wave, there is an unprecedented opportunity to convert the region’s vast resource wealth into investments that could lift millions out of poverty, create jobs, and bring hope to future generations.

title: Africa’s Population Surge
snippet: At current growth rates, sub-Saharan Africa, which now makes up 12 percent of the world’s population, will account for more than a third by 2100.
lead_paragraph: At current growth rates, sub-Saharan Africa, which now makes up 12 percent of the world’s population, will account for more than a third by 2100.

title: The Clinton Foundation in Africa
snippet: A recent trip to Africa gave Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and a handful of donors and aides from the Clintons’ years in Arkansas and the White House a firsthand look at the philanthropic work of the Clinton Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A recent trip to Africa gave Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and a handful of donors and aides from the Clintons’ years in Arkansas and the White House a firsthand look at the philanthropic work of the Clinton Foundation.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Growth Slows
snippet: South Africa's economic growth slows to annualized 1.2 percent in third quarter, two-year low, as manufacturing and mining production slide because demand for exports falls and agricultural output declines (S)
lead_paragraph: South Africa's economic growth slowed to an annualized 1.2 percent in the third quarter, a two-year low, as manufacturing and mining production slid because demand for exports fell and agricultural output declined. Growth slowed from a revised 1.8 percent in the prior quarter and from 3.4 percent last year.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Acquittal For Apartheid Official
snippet: Dr Wouter Basson, head of chemical and biological weapons program under South Africa's former apartheid government, is acquitted of murder, drug dealing and fraud; judge rules prosecutors failed to prove that he conspired to supply deadly drugs to...
lead_paragraph: The head of the chemical and biological weapons program under the former apartheid government was acquitted of murder, drug dealing and fraud. A judge ruled that prosecutors had failed to prove the charges, including accusations that Dr. Wouter Basson had conspired to supply deadly drugs to the apartheid-era defense force to murder black activists. Testimony at the trial said the targets had included Nelson Mandela. Prosecutors, who spent more than two years trying the case, said they would appeal. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Surge In AIDS Orphans
snippet: South Africa predicts country will ahve more than two million AIDS orphans by 2010 (S)
lead_paragraph: South Africa will have more than two million AIDS orphans by 2010, a 13-fold increase, the Finance Ministry reported. The officials said the government must plan for the children, increase health spending and train more nurses and teachers to replace those killed by the disease. With 4.7 million people infected with the AIDS virus, South Africa has more people living with H.I.V. than any other country. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Suddenly, Hope in Africa
snippet: A new leader for the Central African Republic promises change.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine a country more miserable than the Central African Republic, a potentially wealthy land that for much of its short history has been looted by its presidents, emperor and warlords and battered by rebellions and sectarian wars, the latest of which has been raging since March. A million people — nearly a quarter of the population — have fled their homes, and more than 1,000 have been killed in the past six weeks alone. So, to the degree to which they can offer any hope for this broken-down state, the announcement of a new interim president, a decision by the European Union to send a peacekeeping force and a pledge of half-a-billion dollars in humanitarian aid are all good news.

title: Art for Africa's sake
snippet: A revival in restive Somalia's art scene, booming business for art in Ethiopia and the ever present demand for African art abroad. Joel Flynn reports.
lead_paragraph: A revival in restive Somalia's art scene, booming business for art in Ethiopia and the ever present demand for African art abroad. Joel Flynn reports.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Arrest In Brotherly Deal
snippet: Police in South Africa arrest Shabir Shaik, brother of Defense Dept's chief acquisitions officer, on charges of improperly obtaining classified documents that helped him win lucrative defense contract; acquisitions officer is found to have conflic...
lead_paragraph: The police arrested Shabir Shaik, the brother of the Defense Department's chief acquisitions officer, on charges of improperly obtaining classified documents that helped him win a lucrative defense contract. The chief acquisitions officer was also found to have had a conflict of interest in awarding the contract to his brother. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Lawmaker Resigns Post
snippet: Tony Yengeni resigns South African parliamentary post after being charged with fraud and corruption (S)
lead_paragraph: The chief parliamentary whip for the president's African National Congress Party has quit his leadership post after being charged with fraud and corruption. By stepping down, the lawmaker, Tony Yengeni, spares his party the burden of deciding whether to suspend him as the police press ahead with their investigation of a multibillion-dollar arms deal. Mr. Yengeni, who was chairman of a key parliamentary defense committee, is accused of promising to help a defense contractor in exchange for a low price on a Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle.

title: Central African Republic: Court Invalidates Legislative Election
snippet: The Central African Republic’s constitutional court scrapped results from a legislative election, citing irregularities like illegible ballots and poor training for election workers.
lead_paragraph: The Central African Republic’s constitutional court certified presidential election results Monday but separately scrapped results from a legislative election, citing irregularities like illegible ballots and poor training for election workers. The court’s validation sets the stage for a runoff for the presidential election that pits Anicet-Georges Dologuélé against Faustin Archange Touadera, two former prime ministers. They will face each other in a vote scheduled for no sooner than Feb. 7. Election observers said that redoing the legislative vote, which took place simultaneously with the presidential vote, would be costly. Candidates were puzzled by the court’s decision. “This is illogical,” said Lydie Nzengou, the communications officer for Karim Meckassoua, a presidential candidate. “Why would the results for the presidential vote be more credible than those of the legislative vote?”

title: Africa and the Power of the Pivot
snippet: Developing countries must avoid depending on one ally for security and prosperity. Africa shows the power of such resilience.
lead_paragraph: By now, nearly everyone has heard of the BRICS (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa). Less known are the CIVETS (Colombia, Indonesia, Vietnam, Egypt, Turkey and South Africa) and MIST (Mexico, Indonesia, South Korea and Turkey).

title: Africa's agricultural opportunities
snippet: As delegates get down to business at the WEF in Nigeria Melanie Ralph looks at the potential of the continent's agricultural sector and the problems they face.
lead_paragraph: As delegates get down to business at the WEF in Nigeria Melanie Ralph looks at the potential of the continent's agricultural sector and the problems they face.

title: World Business Briefing/Africa: South Africa: Anglogold Gains
snippet: Anglogold earned $42 million in first quarter, reversing year-earlier loss of $17 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The world's biggest producer of gold, Anglogold, said that it earned $42 million in the first quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss of $17 million. Excluding one-time items, profit rose to $54.8 million, an increase of 1.6 percent over a year earlier. The rise in profit was attributed to cost-cutting and higher gold prices, which were negotiated when the price of gold was higher. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: Africa: Aid or Harm?
snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column rejects arguments by AFL-CIO and Unite that they oppose a bill designed to provide sub-Saharan African countries with duty-free access to US for their textile and apparel imports because it would harm African workers...
lead_paragraph: I wrote recently in support of the African Growth and Opportunity Act, a bill designed to provide sub-Saharan African countries with duty-free access to the U.S. for their textile and apparel exports. The act, now being debated by Congress, is embarrassing for U.S. unions, such as the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and Unite, because they are opposing any duty-free access for Africa even though studies show it would create jobs in Africa and scarcely affect employment here.

title: Contemporary African Royals, in Regalia and Complexity
snippet: A new photography exhibition at London’s Tate Modern includes images of monarchs from across the continent, steering away from Western imagery.
lead_paragraph: On a wall of London’s Tate Modern, a large photo from 2012 depicts a seated Nigerian king, wearing a green beaded hat and a lavish robe with a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II printed on the front.

title: An African King in Bolivia
snippet: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.
lead_paragraph: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.

title: Tapping Into Africa's Expertise
snippet: Bantu Wax, a surfwear brand in Dakar, Senegal, mines its local designers and collaborators for ideas.
lead_paragraph: In July, the fashion entrepreneur Yodit Eklund did the unusual. She decided to restructure her four-year-old surfwear brand Bantu Wax, with the aim of reflecting and serving the African surf culture she grew up with.

title: America First, in Africa
snippet: The Trump administration has signaled that it also may soon cut back on humanitarian aid to Africa.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Handmaiden to Africa's Generals
snippet: Security in Africa can only be achieved by supporting diplomacy, democracy and development.
lead_paragraph: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — Security is a core concern of the American government’s Africa policy. This was made clear in May when President Obama proposed a $5 billion Counterterrorism Partnerships Fund to supplement programs the Pentagon already has in 35 countries. And it was made clear again at the recent U.S.-Africa summit in Washington, when Mr. Obama announced $110 million a year for an African Peacekeeping Rapid Response Partnership, a program to train and equip six African armies for peacekeeping operations.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Proposal For Poor Farmers
snippet: South African government study proposes minimum wage for farm workers (S)
lead_paragraph: A study by the labor department proposed a minimum wage for farm workers in an effort to improve the lot of the lowest-paid workers in the country's lowest-paying industry. While the average farm worker's wages -- about $63 a month -- fall in the proposed range of $46 to $87, a survey found that some workers are being paid as little as $6 a month, and it is those workers that the labor department says it wants to help. The proposal is part of a government effort to begin redressing the country's income inequality. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Is That Really South Africa?
lead_paragraph: Maybe one day Hollywood will make a movie set in South Africa that features some of the following:

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Arrests In Land Conflict
snippet: South African authorities arrest dozens of squatters on private- and government-owned land outside Johannesburg; photo; plots reportedly were sold illegally by local members of Pan Africanist Congress (S)
lead_paragraph: Saying they would not tolerate land invasions, the authorities arrested dozens of squatters who had erected shacks on vacant land just outside Johannesburg. The plots, which include government-owned and privately owned land, were said to have been sold to the poor by local members of the Pan Africanist Congress, a political party that strongly advocates land reform. The police action followed warnings from government officials that South Africa would not allow the kind of illegal land seizures that have swept neighboring Zimbabwe. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Chanel Goes to Africa
snippet: The French brand brought its Métiers d’Art show to Dakar.
lead_paragraph: It could have gone badly wrong. The optics of Chanel, one of the most haute of all European haute luxury brands, parachuting into Africa, a continent where they have no stores and no meaningful business, with a bells and whistles one-off fashion show, could have smacked, loudly, of colonialism.

title: Itchy African Buffalo
snippet: The African buffalo scratching an itch.
lead_paragraph: The African buffalo scratching an itch.

title: Africa's Fabric Is Dutch
snippet: The distinctive, double-sided, wax-print cottons so loved by elite Africans actually is produced in a small, rather nondescript town in southern Holland.
lead_paragraph: HELMOND, THE NETHERLANDS — Internet connectivity across much of Africa can be mind-numbingly slow and unreliable, but that hasn’t stopped about 9,000 young, affluent women from braving the sluggish system to discuss something that matters a great deal to them: the latest design trends from a luxury fabric brand called Vlisco.

title: A Milestone for Justice in Africa
snippet: The trial of the former president of Chad in a new court sends a message to other strongmen.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, a landmark trial began that could herald a new era of justice and accountability in Africa. The former president of Chad, Hissène Habré, is being tried over atrocities committed during his rule in a new court set up in Senegal under the legal principle of universal jurisdiction for crimes against humanity.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Fighting Continues
snippet: Government forces in Central African Republic launch big attack on rebel positions near capital (S)
lead_paragraph: The government recaptured a military camp and launched a big attack on rebel positions on the outskirts of the capital, Bangui, reportedly causing many deaths and injuries. The leader of a failed coup, Gen. André Kolingba, and his associates are said to be hiding in eastern areas of the city. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: The Child Migrants of Africa
snippet: The Italian government has largely kept reporters from entering the shelters and interviewing refugees.
lead_paragraph: The Italian government has largely kept reporters from entering the shelters and interviewing refugees.

title: Disputed African Artifacts Sell at Auction
snippet: A Princeton art history professor said the figures were stolen and called on Christie’s to halt the sale, but it went ahead in Paris on Monday.
lead_paragraph: “These artworks are stained with the blood of Biafra’s children,” wrote Chika Okeke-Agulu, an art history professor at Princeton, in an impassioned Instagram post three weeks ago calling for a halt to the sale of two wooden statues made by the Igbo people of Nigeria. Mr. Okeke-Agulu believes the items were looted in the late 1960s during the country’s brutal civil war.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Squatters Ordered Out
snippet: South African high court judge tells black squatters who have built shacks on vacant land near Johannesburg to leave within 48 hours or face forcible eviction; judge grants petition by government officials, who say squatters are illegally occupyin...
lead_paragraph: A high court judge told black squatters who have built shacks on vacant land near Johannesburg to leave within 48 hours or face forcible eviction. The judge was granting a petition filed by government officials, who said the squatters were illegally occupying the land, which is owned by two government agencies and a local farmer. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mbeki Backtracks On 'Plot'
snippet: South African Pres Thabo Mbeki says he has 'no reason to think' that three senior African National Congress members conspired to oust or harm him; says it may have been mistake to name three as suspects (S)
lead_paragraph: President Thabo Mbeki said in a televised interview that he had ''no reason to think'' that three senior African National Congress members seen as possible rivals were conspiring to oust him or threatening to harm him. He said it might have been a mistake to publicly name the men -- Cyril Ramaphosa, Tokyo Sexwale and Matthews Phosa -- as suspects. His remarks came a day after a spokesman for the party acknowledged that the police investigation of the men had damaged South Africa's image. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: The Wisdom of Africa
lead_paragraph: Black Africa has much to teach its former masters in Europe. This may surprise those who think the only news from Africa concerns famine, war, pestilence and tyranny. Those scourges exist, but Africa has managed to keep a fifth affliction, ethnic separatism, from shattering national boundaries. Black Africa offers a lesson on the wisdom of respecting the territorial integrity of all states, whatever the mix of peoples.

title: Clueless in South Africa
snippet: The opposition Democratic Alliance Students Organization offers a striking illustration of how not to beat the A.N.C.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Last week in South Africa, the youth wing of the main opposition, the Democratic Alliance Students Organization, distributed a poster featuring an image of a white man and a black woman in semi-naked embrace above a caption that reads, ‘‘In OUR future, you wouldn’t look twice.’’

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Boesak Leaves Prison
snippet: Former anti-apartheid campaigner and cleric Allan
lead_paragraph: The for-mer anti-apartheid campaigner and cleric Allan Boesak was released from prison after serving a year and seven days of a three-year sentence. Mr. Boesak, former head of the Geneva-based World Alliance of Reformed Churches, was convicted of stealing thousands of dollars given by foreign donors meant to help needy children and educate black voters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Winnie Mandela To Be Tried
lead_paragraph: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela will stand trial on fraud and theft charges next year, a judge decided. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, a prominent political leader and the former wife of Nelson Mandela, has been charged with defrauding a bank of more than $103,000. Officials say that Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, who is president of the African National Congress's Women's League, was involved in a scheme in which a codefendant obtained personal loans for fictitious Women's League employees by using her name and letterhead to support the fraudulent loan applications. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Ethnic Cleansing in Africa
snippet: The fear now is that the U.N. peacekeepers will arrive too late to prevent more displacements and deaths.
lead_paragraph: The sectarian violence between Christian and Muslim militias and civilian mobs that has plagued Central African Republic for the past several months has tipped into a full-fledged campaign of ethnic cleansing of Muslims from the capital Bangui and the southern part of the country. Efforts to stem the mayhem have so far failed, and the country is on the brink of a de facto partition as Muslims flee toward the country’s northern borders. With 2.2 million people in dire need of humanitarian assistance, donor countries must act quickly to finance the $274 million in emergency aid the United Nations says is urgently needed.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Foreign Aid
snippet: Central African Republic gets aid from Libya and rebel group in Congo to defeat mutinous soldiers hiding out near capital (S)
lead_paragraph: The government of Ange Félix Patasse received assistance from Libya and a rebel group in Congo to defeat a band of mutinous soldiers who nearly seized power early this week and are hiding in the outskirts of the capital, Bangui. André Kolingba, a former military ruler believed to be behind the coup attempt, told Radio France International that he had asked the soldiers to return to their barracks. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Africa and Its Legacy
snippet: Images from “The Global Africa Project” at the Museum of Arts & Design.
lead_paragraph: Images from “The Global Africa Project” at the Museum of Arts & Design.

title: What Happened to South African Democracy
snippet: Thanks to a corrupt political elite, life for millions of people is no better than it was under apartheid.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Most first-time visitors to Cape Town are mesmerized by the majesty of Table Mountain, and wowed by the vivacity of the Victorian-era waterfront. As a new visitor myself last month, I was captivated by both. But what has lodged most in my memory is something very different.

title: France’s Challenge in Africa
snippet: The Libyan revolution of 2011 brought lasting terrorist mayhem across a broad reach of Africa’s former French colonies. Now France needs its allies to help pacify the region — if that can be done.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — This is a war that escapes most radar screens. The French, whose troops have been fighting in the Sahel for seven years, ask few questions about their involvement. They should. In this crucible where Islamist insurgency, ancient local conflicts, fragile states, European hesitations and a shifting American strategy make an explosive mix, it is a war they may well be losing — or, in the best case, a war they may never win.

title: 'WOZA AFRICA!' SPOTLIGHTS BLACK SOUTH AFRICANS
lead_paragraph: The most prolonged exposure New York theatergoers have had to black people's lives in South Africa today, as seen by its black playwrights, will be offered in September at Lincoln Center.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AIDS Drug Sought
snippet: Treatment Action Campaign, group that lobbies on AIDS issues, asks High Court judge to order South African government to distribute AIDS drug, Nevirapine, widely to pregnant women; government has already begun small-scale distribution of drug, whi...
lead_paragraph: The Treatment Action Campaign, a group that lobbies on AIDS issues, asked a High Court judge to order the government to distribute the AIDS drug Nevirapine widely to pregnant women who are infected with H.I.V. The government has already begun small-scale distribution of the drug, which sharply reduces a pregnant woman's risk of transmitting the virus to her newborn. The Treatment Action Campaign says that the government program is too small and that officials have taken too long to get it running. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: ‘Revealing the African Presence’
snippet: Images from the exhibition at the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Images from the exhibition at the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore.

title: World Briefing/AFRICA: SOUTH AFRICA: MANDELA BACKS MBEKI
lead_paragraph: Former President Nelson Mandela said he believed that President Thabo Mbeki deserved a second term. Speaking in London, Mr. Mandela was addressing concerns about the South African government's decision to investigate three senior members of the African National Congress, the governing party, on charges of trying to oust Mr. Mbeki. The inquiry has been described as politically motivated because two of the three men are considered potential rivals of Mr. Mbeki. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: The Scourging of Africa
lead_paragraph: Take pity on the untimely sorrows of Africa. At a moment of undreamed-of political gains -- apartheid crumbling, wars ending and tyrannies tottering -- much of Africa is now beset by the worst drought in this century.

title: Economic Classes in Africa
snippet: There are more than twice as many people considered middle class in sub-Saharan Africa than there were 30 years ago. But in most countries, the poorer and richer classes grew as well, so income distributions have gone largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: There are more than twice as many people considered middle class in sub-Saharan Africa than there were 30 years ago. But in most countries, the poorer and richer classes grew as well, so income distributions have gone largely unchanged.

title: A New Approach to Africa
snippet: Obama should become more active across the continent in the time he has left in office.
lead_paragraph: In the twilight of his presidency, George W. Bush sought refuge in one of his foreign policy victories: Africa. Dogged by his global missteps and failures, Mr. Bush traveled abroad in Feb. 2008 to trumpet his legacy-building AIDS program. When President Barack Obama heads to Africa later this week, the focus won’t be on a signature success story. Instead, the trip will highlight his lack of attention to the continent.

title: Demonizing Gays in Africa
snippet: Nigeria is one of several countries on the continent whose policies hurt gays and all Africans.
lead_paragraph: As acceptance of gays and lesbians has grown in the United States and Europe, intolerance and persecution has been rising in other parts of the world. African nations are leaders in this cruel and dehumanizing trend.

title: The Giant of Africa Votes
snippet: Muhammadu Buhari returns to fight corruption. This time he should get it right.
lead_paragraph: When Muhammadu Buhari last became head of state in Nigeria, it was via a military coup in 1983, when he launched a nasty campaign against “indiscipline” and corruption in his vast African nation that earned him a reputation for brutality and disdain for human rights. Hundreds of politicians and businessmen were convicted by military courts, and minor offenses — like cheating on exams — were enough to send Nigerians to jail. Mr. Buhari was himself overthrown 20 months later, yet now, at age 72, he has returned to rule Nigeria — and, he vows, to continue the war on corruption. The difference is that he has returned through a democratic election.

title: South Africa to Withdraw Its Troops From Central African Republic
snippet: President Jacob Zuma is bringing his troops home after at least 13 soldiers were killed last month in a firefight with rebels who overthrew the Central African Republic’s president.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — However the chaotic situation in the Central African Republic plays out, it will do so without the South African troops who have been deployed there since 2007. After the troops suffered one of their deadliest days since the end of apartheid in 1994, President Jacob Zuma is bringing them home.

title: 1916: Terrorized in Africa
snippet: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Nigerian officer at war sends a dispatch in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The following extract from a report dated January 26, 1916, compiled by a Nigerian officer who was serving as an intelligence officer with the column operating in Northern and Central Kamerun under Brigadier-General Cunliffe, is issued for publication : — ‘‘Any natives who showed any sympathy with the Allied forces, and many of those who did not, were promptly murdered. Sex or age was no protection.

title: Rethinking ‘African-American’
snippet: Tuesday | Today’s idea: American-born blacks shouldn’t call themselves “African-American” because now there are many more people in the United States who were actually born in Africa, a black linguist and commentator says. [The New Republic]
lead_paragraph: Today’s idea: American-born blacks shouldn’t call themselves “African-American” because now there are many more people in the United States who were actually born in Africa, a black linguist and commentator says.

title: 'Imaging African Art'
snippet: Grace Glueck reviews African art at Yale University Art Gallery (S)
lead_paragraph: 'Documentation and Transformation'

title: United by African Music
snippet: A woman, her daughter and an elderly man, passengers in a taxi, related in different ways to the songs being played by the Senegalese driver.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

title: The Jokes Are on South Africans
snippet: I bring foreign visitors to South African comedy clubs not just to relax, but also for a quick introduction to my country’s problems.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — On Tuesday evening, as I walked into Metro, a trendy restaurant-cum-comedy club in a northern suburb of Johannesburg, my heart skipped a beat. I noticed that our table was close to the stage.  As an obsessive stand-up-comedy fan, I know that these actors love to pick on the front row. And South African comics are particularly cruel.

title: African Art Endowment
snippet: An African bank has announced an endowment for the Tate Modern museum in London.
lead_paragraph: An African bank has announced an endowment for the Tate Modern museum in London to promote African art. The bank, Guaranty Trust Bank, based in Lagos, Nigeria, will support the creation of an African art curator, an acquisition fund for African art, and an exchange project between Africa and London for collectors, institutions and young artists. The sum of the endowment was not announced. “This is the beginning of being able to give African art the focus it deserves with audiences around the world,” Chris Dercon, the director of the Tate, said in a statement.

Cultural taboos that hinder open discussion of H.I.V., cultural taboos that prevent the availability of contraceptives, cultural taboos that make abortions illegal in many African countries.

title: Slaughter of the African Elephants
snippet: Poachers in central Africa are pushing elephants to extinction.
lead_paragraph: THERE is nothing a mother elephant will not do for her infant, but even she cannot protect it from bullets. About a year ago, poachers attacked a family of forest elephants in central Africa. The biologist who witnessed the attack told us that wildlife guards were completely outgunned. In the end, an elephant mother, riddled with bullets and trumpeting with pain and fear, was left to use her enormous body to shield her baby. Her sacrifice was for naught; the baby was also killed.

So one recent afternoon I wrapped a piece of African cloth around my waist and entered a packed studio at the Alvin Ailey extension center in Manhattan.

lead_paragraph: To be the voice of a nation speaking to the wider world is a tough mission for any performer. To be the voice of an entire continent is exponentially more difficult. Both were mantles that the South African singer Miriam Makeba took on willingly and forcefully. Despite her lifelong claim that she was not a political singer, she became “Mama Africa” with an activist’s tenacity and a musician’s ear. She died Sunday, at 76, after a concert in Italy.

Each segment of their journey was carefully documented by thousands of reporters and photographers.

Now he is in jail in Conakry, the capital, charged with conducting illegal international trade in the very creatures he was responsible for protecting, including chimpanzees, gorillas and bonobos.

title: African Renaissance

lead_paragraph: After decades of unspeakable repression at the hands of authoritarian regimes, Africans stand at the threshold of a new epoch. Across the continent, millions are demanding freely elected legislatures, an independent judiciary and an accountable executive. This democratic renaissance cuts across linguistic lines and national borders, from Nigeria to Kenya, from Mali to Zaire.

The focus on mothers and cubs and the impulse to treat nature like a storybook should come as no surprise: the film is made by Disneynature.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Rarely has the European Union been caught so off guard. Two weeks after demonstrators forced the resignation of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, Tunisia’s long-serving president, the only response from the Union was a promise to help the country’s new political parties prepare for free elections.

title: AFRICA: Rail revival
lead_paragraph: The African rail network is currently attracting levels of investment unmatched at any time since the basic network was laid down between 1850 and 1920 by European colonial powers, in order to facilitate trade and resource extraction. While the colonial presence left Africa with a rail infrastructure that would not otherwise have existed, the continent nonetheless inherited a system that lacks geographic and physical coordination. These shortcomings were greatly accentuated by the widespread disrepair and dereliction into which the network descended following independence.

title: Overdoing the African Negatives?
lead_paragraph: The blog Zoo Station has an interesting post about aid and Africa, noting that at the recent TED conference a Ugandan journalist had attacked Bono and the foreign aid lobby. Bono was apparently rather taken aback, but it is indeed a point of view that you hear periodically from Africans. In Rwanda, President Kagame voiced a similar disquiet about aid to us, and Bill Easterly has taken it to great lengths in his book. I think the debate is useful but that more aid is still beneficial, and that health interventions in particular have a good record. To me, Paul Collier’s new book, “The Bottom Billion,” gets the balance exactly right.

title: CORN GLUT WORRIES IN SOUTH AFRICA

lead_paragraph: A surge in South Africa's corn production this year could soften prices of corn, a staple commodity, and threaten the survival of some of the country's farms. The nation, the world's fourth-largest producer of corn, is expected to reap 11.2 million tons this year, a 42 percent increase over last year's 7.9 million tons and the country's biggest harvest in six years, according to the Department of Agriculture. title: In Africa, the Goal Is the Thing
snippet: African soccer fans encourage — no, they demand – that their teams play an attractive, attacking game that results in lots of goals.
lead_paragraph: KUMASI, Ghana — African soccer fans love goals. This may seem self-evident — who doesn’t love goals? But Africans have a unique desire to see joyful, attacking soccer that leads to bunches of goals. And they dread a scoreless affair. Nil-nil, even if it is a good result for the team’s involved, is “very, very bad,” said Ato Mohamed, a former centerback with local club Olympics, after we watched Tunisia’s goalless draw with Angola.

title: For Africa, a godsend in cellphones
Africa’s Drug Problem
snippet: It doesn’t produce or consume much cocaine, but West Africa has become a critical hub for traffickers.
lead_paragraph: On the tarmac of Osvaldo Vieira, the international airport of the West African coastal country of Guinea-Bissau, sits a once-elegant Gulfstream jet, which in the normal course of events would have no reason to land in a country with no business opportunities and virtually no economy. In recent years, however, Guinea-Bissau has emerged as a nodal point in three-way cocaine-trafficking operations linking producers in South America with users in Europe; the value of the cocaine that transits this small and heartbreakingly impoverished country dwarfs its gross national product. The Gulfstream arrived unexpectedly from Venezuela on July 12, 2008, and taxied to a hangar at the adjacent military airbase — where soldiers formed a line and unloaded its contents. The contents, reportedly more than a half-ton of cocaine, vanished. The crew was arrested and released. The army permitted the government to impound the plane only after several days. Since then, the plane has sat in the harsh sun, a reminder of Guinea-Bissau’s helplessness before forces far more powerful than itself.

title: A Taste of Africa (and Beyond)
snippet: Merkato 55 is a bold but uneven adventure, ranging across Africa in search of rare and unusual dishes.
lead_paragraph: WITH the qualified exceptions of Morocco and Egypt, Africa hasn’t received much high-gloss treatment on the Manhattan restaurant scene. It has been denied the dubious courtesies extended to Europe, Asia, even Australia: the thumping music, the whimsically named special cocktails, the fashionably compartmentalized menus, the entrees in the $25 to $35 range.

title: Patron of African Misgovernment
snippet: If you run an African country and have some natural resources to put in long-term hock, you’ve got a friend in Beijing ready to write big checks with no embarrassing questions.

title: Mission From Africa
snippet: Missionaries from African churches are evangelizing around the globe. Can a Nigerian Pentecostal movement take root in American soil?
lead_paragraph: PASTOR DANIEL AJAYI-ADENIRAN is coming for your soul. It doesn’t matter if you are black or white, rich or poor, speak English or Spanish or Cantonese. He is on a mission to save you from eternal damnation. He realizes you may be skeptical, put off by his exotic name — he’s from Nigeria — or confused by his accent, the way he stretches his vowels and trills his R’s, giving his sermons a certain chain-saw rhythm. He suspects you may have some unfortunate preconceptions about Nigerians. But he is not deterred. He believes the Holy Spirit is working through him — aided by the awesome earthly power of demographics.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: More Lawmakers In Travel Fraud
snippet: Fourteen more current and former South African legislators plead guilty in ongoing corruption scandal related to vacation- and travel-related abuses; all receive fines or suspended sentences; ongoing investigation has connected one in five members...
lead_paragraph: A long-running corruption scandal netted 14 more guilty pleas from current and former members of Parliament, all of whom admitted to scheming with travel agents to book luxury trips at taxpayer expense and other travel-related abuses, including flying relatives on holidays for free. The 14 legislators, mostly from the governing party, the African National Congress, received fines or suspended prison sentences after plea bargaining in which they agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Five more legislators are expected to face charges in the so-called Travelgate scandal, which so far has snared roughly one in five members of the 450-member Parliament. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Pretoria Renames Itself Tshwane
snippet: Pretoria metropolitan council renames South Africa's capital city Tshwane after local river and chief of region before arrival of whites; Tshwane means we are all together; change must be approved by national Geographic Names Council, but is expec...
lead_paragraph: A metropolitan legislative council voted to rename South Africa's capital Tshwane, relegating the historic name, Pretoria, to a comparatively tiny part of the city's downtown that does not contain any major government offices. The long-debated and contentious change must still be approved by the national Geographic Names Council in October, but most consider that a foregone conclusion. Pretoria was named after Andreas Pretorius, an Afrikaner best known for the 1838 Battle of Blood River, so named because the river ran red with the blood of 3,000 Zulus killed by Voortrekkersettlers. Tshwane (pronounced t'SHWAN-ay) is the African name for another local river and for an Ndebele chief who ruled there before the arrival of whites. The city says the word means "we are all together." Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 5 Lawmakers Admit Fraud
snippet: Five lawmakers in South Africa's Parliament plead guilty to stealing public funds by converting government travel vouchers to cash, and more legislators' guilty pleas are anticipated in estimated $2.8 million scheme (S)
lead_paragraph: Five lawmakers in the 450-member Parliament pleaded guilty in Cape Town to stealing public funds by converting government travel vouchers to cash, and more legislators' guilty pleas were anticipated in an estimated $2.8 million scheme widely dubbed Travelgate. The five, all members of the governing African National Congress, received fines and suspended prison sentences for converting as much as $12,600 in travel vouchers into cash, but critics noted that the fines barely matched the amount that was stolen. African National Congress leaders said in a statement that the members would face discipline, but did not mention stripping them of their seats, a move demanded by many opposition parties that called the thefts a breach of public trust. Twenty-four Parliament members are implicated in the scandal; three more may enter pleas next week. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Puberty and Education in Africa
snippet:
A lack of girls-only latrines, water and sanitary napkins in schools throughout sub-Saharan Africa causes one in 10 school-age African girls to either
skip school during puberty or drop out entirely.
lead_paragraph:
A lack of girls-only latrines, water and sanitary napkins in schools throughout sub-Saharan Africa causes one in 10 school-age African girls to either
skip school during puberty or drop out entirely.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: $10 Million To Fertilize African Farms
snippet: More than 40 African nations met in Nigeria and agreed to lift all cross-border taxes and tariffs on fertilizers needed to replenish the continent's severely degraded soils. Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, committed $10 million to a fund t...
lead_paragraph: More than 40 African nations met in Nigeria and agreed to lift all cross-border taxes and tariffs on fertilizers needed to replenish the continent's severely degraded soils. Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, committed $10 million to a fund to finance wider use of fertilizers. Three-quarters of Africa's farmland is severely depleted of basic nutrients needed to grow crops. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Iscor To Raise Pay
snippet: Southn
lead_paragraph: Iscor, Africa's biggest steel maker, said it offered to raise pay by more than South Africa's annual inflation rate of 4.4 percent in an effort to end an impasse with labor unions. The National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa has demanded a raise of 8 percent for lower- grade workers and 5 percent for higher-paid workers. Iscor, a unit of LNM Holdings, is based in Pretoria.

title: The ‘Avon Ladies’ of Africa
snippet: Door-to-door sales and franchising are being used by a group called Living Goods to get needed health products to people in Africa.
lead_paragraph: What if every time people came up with a new product, they also had to devise a completely new way to sell it?   Imagine that we had no Amazons, eBays, Targets or Walmarts — no distribution chain at all, and no stores near potential buyers.  Nor is there a way for potential customers to learn about the product. Oh, and they can’t afford it anyway — they can’t afford much of anything.

title: A Connoisseur's African Choices
snippet: Roberta Smith reviews exhibition of African art collected by the French artist Arman, at the Museum for African Art; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The French artist Arman has always gloried in carefully arranged profusion. In the late 1950's, when his close friend Yves Klein mounted an exhibition that consisted of an empty art gallery, he countered by filling the same gallery with trash.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mbeki Deputy Denounces Press
snippet: A businessman was sentenced to 15 years in prison for paying $186,000 in bribes to South Africa's deputy president, Jacob Zuma. The case against the businessman, Schabir Shaik, has prompted calls for Mr. Zuma's dismissal and thrown open the questi...
lead_paragraph: A businessman was sentenced to 15 years in prison for paying $186,000 in bribes to South Africa's deputy president, Jacob Zuma. The case against the businessman, Schabir Shaik, has prompted calls for Mr. Zuma's dismissal and thrown open the question of who will succeed President Thabo Mbeki in 2007. Mr. Zuma denounced the media, saying he has been unfairly convicted by the press. It remains unclear whether prosecutors will seek to press charges against him. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: $16.5 Million Airport Caper
snippet: The government agency that runs South Africa's airports is being bombarded with criticism after up to 15 armed men stormed a South African Airways Boeing 747 jet on Saturday and looted it of a cash shipment reported to total $16.5 million. The mon...
lead_paragraph: The government agency that runs South Africa's airports is being bombarded with criticism after up to 15 armed men stormed a South African Airways Boeing 747 jet on Saturday and looted it of a cash shipment reported to total $16.5 million. The money, flown from Britain, was en route to Tanzania and another unidentified African nation when the gang, armed with AK-47 rifles, overpowered guards on an ostensibly secure apron at Johannesburg International Airport. Johannesburg's airport has been repeatedly hit by gangs targeting large hauls of cash and other valuables. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: New burdens for Africa
lead_paragraph: The United States and other wealthy nations have responded generously to the AIDS epidemic in Africa, both through country-to-country programs and through the United Nations Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Setback For Accused Coup Financier
snippet: Cape Town, South Africa, court rules that Mark Thatcher, who is son of former British Prime Min Margaret Thatcher, must answer questions by Equatorial Guinea prosecutors investigating failed coup attempt last March; Thatcher is accused of financin...
lead_paragraph: A Cape Town court rebuffed an attempt by Mark Thatcher, son of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain to avoid interrogation by Equatorial Guinea's prosecutors in a inquiry into an attempted coup in that West African nation last March. Mr. Thatcher has been accused by the South African authorities of helping to finance the coup, which collapsed when a planeload of accused mercenaries en route to Equatorial Guinea was arrested in Zimbabwe. Mr. Thatcher's lawyers said the interrogation would violate his right to silence, but the court ruled that he could still assert that right later. Equatorial Guinea has accused him of being a co-conspirator in the coup. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: New Funds For African Force In Darfur
snippet: The United States and the European Union pledged nearly $150 million at a conference in Brussels to shore up the overmatched and nearly broke African Union force in the Darfur region of Sudan. The money is a short-term fix intended to allow the 7,...
lead_paragraph: The United States and the European Union pledged nearly $150 million at a conference in Brussels to shore up the overmatched and nearly broke African Union force in the Darfur region of Sudan. The money is a short-term fix intended to allow the 7,000-member African force to keep operating until the end of the year. The African Union said at its recent summit meeting in Gambia that it could not continue to operate the Darfur peacekeeping mission and that it wanted to hand it over to the United Nations. The United Nations wants to take over the mission, but so far the Sudanese government has firmly refused to allow United Nations troops to deploy. The Darfur region has grown even more violent in recent months as the dispute over the United Nations force has dragged on. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

title: Africans’
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Organization of African Unity to expand its sports boycott to South Africa poses a serious threat to future sports relations between the United States and black African nations.

title: Review: A ‘Mother Courage’ Deployed to Africa
snippet: Kecia Lewis stars in the Classic Stage Company production, which shifts Brecht’s antiwar drama to the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: Bertolt Brecht’s Mother Courage doesn’t fit the mold of a conventional heroine, or even the mold of a conventional antiheroine. But Kecia Lewis, who plays the role in the Classic Stage Company’s terrific production of “Mother Courage and Her Children,” certainly deserves some sort of badge of honor. Ms. Lewis’s commanding performance would be impressive under any circumstances, but the drama surrounding her undertaking the part makes the achievement all the more remarkable.

title: Out of Africa, to Brooklyn
snippet: Geoffrey Good has not seen Africa in nearly 10 years, but the continent is never far from mind when driving his vintage Land Rover.
lead_paragraph: GEOFFREY GOOD has not seen Africa in nearly 10 years, but the continent where he spent many years as a boy is never far from mind. It is embedded in his life and in his work as a jewelry designer.

title: Our African dogs
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — All dogs are not born equal into this world. And nowhere on earth is this more true than in Africa, where an accident of birth lands one dog in the lap of luxury and condemns another to a life that is literally dog eat dog.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Deal for Phone Concern
snippet: MTN Group agrees to buy mobile telephone services provider Investcom for $5.5 billion; deal will give MTN 4.9 million customers; chief exectutive Phuthuma Nhleko comments (S)
lead_paragraph: The MTN Group, Africa's largest mobile phone company, agreed to buy Investcom, a provider of mobile telephone services in Africa, the Middle East and Europe, for $5.5 billion. The purchase will give MTN 4.9 million customers in markets, including Sudan and Syria, where fewer than one in 10 people owns a mobile phone, the chief executive, Phuthuma Nhleko, said in a conference call. MTN, based in Johannesburg, will pay $3.83 for each share of Investcom, which is based in Beirut. The takeover will give MTN access to 10 new markets for a total of 21 in Africa and the Middle East.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Poison Fruit Plot Described
snippet: Henk van Zyl testifies in Pretoria (South Africa) court that Boeremag, white-supremacist group, planned in 2002 to pepper streets of black township Soweto with poisoned oranges to kick off plan to overthrow South Africa's government; poisoning was...
lead_paragraph: The white-supremacist group Boeremag planned to poison blacks with tainted oranges as part of a broader plan to overthrow South Africa's government in late 2002, a defendant testified in the treason and terrorism trial of 22 Boeremag members in Pretoria. Henk van Zyl testified that the group's chaplain was in charge of the plot, which involved tossing poisoned oranges into the streets of Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg. The poisonings were to kick off a coup plan that included bombings of Johannesburg's airport and stock exchange and the seizure of radio stations and military bases, but the orange-throwing was called off in September 2002 when it became clear that the police knew about it. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Coup Case For Thatcher's Son
snippet: Legal representatives for Equatorial Guinea's government are reportedly seeking extradition of Mark Thatcher, former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's son, from South Africa; hold he aided in unsuccessful plot to overthrown Equatorial Gui...
lead_paragraph: Equatorial Guinea's legal counsel was quoted as saying that his government would seek to extradite Mark Thatcher, the son of Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister. Mr. Thatcher was arrested Wednesday in South Africa, and he is accused of aiding a failed plot to overthrow Equatorial Guinea's government. South African officials said they had yet to receive a formal request for Mr. Thatcher's extradition. An acquaintance of his, Simon Mann, a British military expert, has also been accused in the case. On Friday, Mr. Mann was convicted in Zimbabwe on charges of illegal arms dealing. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Road to South Africa
snippet: It is time to take a look as time runs short in the current cycle of World Cup qualifying with most teams around the world having two games left to play.
lead_paragraph: It is time to take a look as time runs short in the current cycle of World Cup qualifying, with most teams around the world having two games left to play.

title: Africa's longevity curse
World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: African Union Lacks Darfur Funds
snippet: The African Union said lack of money might force transfer of its peacekeeping mission in the Darfur region of Sudan to the United Nations. Alpha Omar Konare, chairman of the African Union Commission, said in a report that the 7,800 peacekeepers an...
lead_paragraph: The African Union said lack of money might force transfer of its peacekeeping mission in the Darfur region of Sudan to the United Nations. Alpha Omar Konare, chairman of the African Union Commission, said in a report that the 7,800 peacekeepers and observers in Darfur could not remain beyond March without more money, Agence France-Presse reported. The mission has cost about $17 million a month, most of it paid by Western governments. The African peacekeepers have struggled to contain the conflict, which broke out in early 2003 and has turned into one of the world's worst human crises. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: 3 Sentenced For Spying For South Africa
snippet: Peter Dzvario, Zimbabwe's ambassador to Mozambique, Itai Marchi, ZANU-PF party leader, and Harare banker Tandai Matambanadzo are convicted of spying on Zimbabwe for South Africa; three others will face trial on same charges (S)
lead_paragraph: A Zimbabwe court convicted three men of spying for South Africa, the first verdicts in a spying scandal that has led to the arrest of five men and caused a sixth suspect to flee capture. The court ruled that Peter Dzvario, Zimbabwe's ambassador-nominee to Mozambique; Itai Marchi, a senior official in the governing ZANU-PF party, and Tandai Matambanadzo, a Harare banker, had passed state secrets to a South African agent who is in Zimbabwean custody and who remains unidentified. Three others face charges, including a member of Parliament and a diplomat in Zimbabwe's Embassy in Switzerland who fled after word of the espionage case became public. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Bush, Blair and Africa
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Formal Recognition For Traditional Healers
snippet: South African Parliament passes law that establishes licensing and regulation of some traditional healers; law gives healer more rights and allows for insurance coverage for patients; law does not sanction healers to treat serious ailments (S)
lead_paragraph: Parliament approved legislation to license and regulate certain classes of traditional healers much as Western-style physicians are regulated, making healers' services and many of their remedies eligible for insurance reimbursements and granting them some powers once reserved for doctors. Supporters called the law long overdue recognition for valid African medical practices like herbal cures, dismissed by outsiders as quackery. Critics said the healers' reliance on consultation with spirits and other nonscientific practices makes licensing a fraud. In a bow to skeptics, the law forbids the healers to treat such serious ailments as cancer and AIDS. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Angry Commuters Burn Trains
snippet: Johannesburg commuters burn 19 train cars and 9 engines in Soweta area after breakdown in service; is third such incident since October as South Africa's commuter trains continue to be plagued by breakdowns (S)
lead_paragraph: Infuriated by a breakdown that halted local trains for 20 minutes, Johannesburg commuters set fire to 19 train cars and 9 engines at three Soweto-area stations on Wednesday, reducing some $6 million in equipment to cinders. A day earlier, commuters fed up with delays set fire to four commuter cars, and last month, 18 coaches and other railway carriages were destroyed. South Africa's commuter trains are riddled with breakdowns, partly because of poor maintenance and partly because of rampant thefts of critical electric cables by scavengers. No trains ran on the affected commuter line yesterday. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOUTH AFRICA: A Big Hand For Mugabe; WESTERN SAHARA: Morocco Rejects Sovereignty;.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AFRICA: A BIG HAND FOR MUGABE Thabo Mbeki began his second five-year term as president of South Africa in a stately ceremony partly overshadowed by the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe. Mr. Mugabe, 80, an icon of African liberation struggles, received a standing ovation from thousands as he arrived for a pre-inauguration party. His attendance was easily the most debated aspect of the inauguration; some South African hotels refused him lodging to protest his increasingly authoritarian rule.    Michael Wines (NYT)

title: South Africa's turnabout  - Africa & Middle East - International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Departing from years of indecision - and on occasion denial - South Africa's government is considering a sweeping new assault on an AIDS pandemic that already includes one in eight of the world's HIV infections, infects 1,000 more citizens each day, and kills an additional 800.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN JOINS WORLD BANK
snippet: World Business BriÔ
lead_paragraph: Dr. Mamphela Ramphele, the head of the University of Cape Town, was named a managing director of the World Bank, making her the first African to hold a senior post at the bank. A prominent black consciousness advocate, anthropologist and physician, Dr. Ramphele, 51, will direct the bank's efforts in health, education and social protection when she joins the Washington-based institution next year. As vice chancellor of the University of Cape Town since 1996, she has presided over the university's transition into the post-apartheid era, pressing forward with integration while trying to uphold standards. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Africa’s Young Brides
snippet:
In Africa’s rural patriarchies, many girls must leap straight from childhood to marriage at a word from
their fathers.
lead_paragraph:
In Africa’s rural patriarchies, many girls must leap straight from childhood to marriage at a word from
