their fathers.

title: Letters: Aid for Africa
AIDS Drugs for Africa
snippet: US awards $77-million contract to consortium that will manage flow of AIDS drugs to Africa (S)
lead_paragraph: The United States has awarded a $77 million contract to a consortium that will help manage the flow of AIDS drugs to Africa, American aid officials announced yesterday.

title: Tensions on the Horn of Africa
lead_paragraph: Eritrea and Ethiopia seem well on their way to starting yet another destructive war. Tensions between the two Horn of Africa countries have hovered near a boiling point ever since Eritrea wrenched its independence from Ethiopia. In the late 1990s, the two fought a vicious battle over an inconsequential border town that left 100,000 dead.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Crime-Fighting Gorilla Dies
snippet: Max, Johannesburg (South Africa) zoo gorilla who in 1997 beat up thief that entered his cage while trying to escape police, dies at 30 (S)
lead_paragraph: Johannesburg mourned the death of Max, a zoo gorilla who won fleeting global fame in 1997 when he suffered three gunshot wounds while beating up a thief who had entered his cage to evade the police. The thief was given 40 years in prison, 5 of them for assaulting Max, who emerged from surgery in good condition but with one bullet permanently lodged in his body. The crime-fighting gorilla, about 30 years old, died in his sleep, probably of old age. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Wider African Role In Darfur Rejected
snippet: African Union-led peace talks in Nigeria that are directed at ending Darfur (Sudan) conflict cannot find immediate solution to disarming government-backed militias; Sudan's Agriculture Minister Mazjoub al-Khalifa, who is government's chief negotia...
lead_paragraph: At the start of peace talks in Nigeria aimed at ending the conflict in the western Sudan region of Darfur, Sudan rejected an expanded role for African Union troops. The Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, the chairman of the African Union, suggested at the outset of the talks that African soldiers could play a role in disarming the government-backed militias that have run rampant in Darfur. But Mazjoub al-Khalifa, Sudan's agriculture minister and its top negotiator, rejected the idea. The government is negotiating with two rebel groups. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Polio Outbreak Spreads
snippet: World Health Organization reports case of polio in Central African Republic; case is first in country since 2000; virus is similar to one active in northern Nigeria (S)
lead_paragraph: The Central African Republic, polio-free since 2000, has confirmed a new case, the World Health Organization said. It said the virus was similar to the one circulating in northern Nigeria, where the disease is endemic and where attempts to carry out mass vaccinations have run into opposition from Muslim and political leaders. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: THE U.S. IN AFRICA
lead_paragraph: Dr. Nthato Motlana, an important spokesman for urban blacks in South Africa, was invited last year to speak at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. He accepted - subject to his getting a passport. The South African Government often takes the position now that blacks are citizens of a ''homeland'' and must go there for passports.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Stake Raised
snippet: World Business Briefing: South Africa
lead_paragraph: The mining company Anglo American said it now owned a 66.6 percent stake in Kumba Resources, a South African iron ore producer. Anglo owned 35 percent of the company before making an offer that closed Friday, and said it would accept partial sales. Anglo was compelled to make the offer by stock exchange rules even though it had previously agreed with the South African government that it would not exceed a 49 percent holding. The company said it would discuss a resolution with the government.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOUTH AFRICA: Guilty Plea In Organ Trafficking; NIGERIA: End TaylorS Refuge, Groups Urge;.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AFRICA: GUILTY PLEA IN ORGAN TRAFFICKING A South African man who was charged last Thursday with participating in a trans-Atlantic organ-trafficking network pleaded guilty in Durban to 38 counts of violating the South African law prohibiting the sale of human tissues. The man, Roderick F. Kimberly, had been identified as a potentially key figure in the ring, which linked poor Brazilians willing to sell their kidneys through middlemen to wealthy but desperately sick recipients in South African hospitals. Fourteen people, four of them Israelis, were arrested last week in South Africa and Brazil and charged with trafficking in human organs. The police have suggested that more arrests are imminent. Mr. Kimberly, 58, was fined $40,000 and given a six-year suspended prison sentence for his role in the ring.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: LIBERIA: Ex-President Sues Tribunal; SOUTH AFRICA: Religion Honor;.
lead_paragraph: LIBERIA: EX-PRESIDENT SUES TRIBUNAL A Liberian criminal court took up a lawsuit brought by former President Charles Taylor against the United Nations-based war crimes tribunal in Sierra Leone for what he alleged was an illegal search of his former residences. Mr. Taylor was indicted by the Sierra Leone tribunal in March 2003 on 17 counts of crimes against humanity for his suspected role in arming and training rebels in a decadelong conflict in Sierra Leone that left as many as 200,000 dead. He has been in exile in Nigeria since August. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Under African Skies
snippet: The story of Denys Finch Hatton, aristocrat, swashbuckling lion slayer and bewitcher of women.
lead_paragraph: It’s no wonder Karen Blixen fell madly in love with Denys Finch Hatton in 1918. He was arrestingly handsome, intelligent, athletic and courageous. He was a war hero, a pilot and a lover of opera. The younger son of the 13th Earl of Winchilsea (who was also the Eighth Earl of Nottingham), he was equally at ease in the African bush and on the country estate. Immortalized in “Out of Africa” (written under Blixen’s pen name, Isak Dinesen), he was her artistic muse, but before that he was her escape from the drudgery of a loveless marriage, a failing Kenyan farm and a debilitating bout of syphilis, thanks to her husband, a feckless baron. Who wouldn’t want a swashbuckling lion slayer stopping in between safaris to recite poems and embrace her under the mosquito netting?

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Guilty Plea In Organ Trafficking
snippet: South African Roderick F Kimberly pleads guilty to 38 counts of violating law prohibiting sale of human tissues; is thought to be key person in trans-Atlantic organ-trafficing network linking poor Brazilians with wealthy, ill South Africans (S)
lead_paragraph: A South African man who was charged last Thursday with participating in a trans-Atlantic organ-trafficking network pleaded guilty in Durban to 38 counts of violating the South African law prohibiting the sale of human tissues. The man, Roderick F. Kimberly, had been identified as a potentially key figure in the ring, which linked poor Brazilians willing to sell their kidneys through middlemen to wealthy but desperately sick recipients in South African hospitals. Fourteen people, four of them Israelis, were arrested last week in South Africa and Brazil and charged with trafficking in human organs. The police have suggested that more arrests are imminent. Mr. Kimberly, 58, was fined $40,000 and given a six-year suspended prison sentence for his role in the ring. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Tone Deaf on Africa
snippet: BONO, Jeffrey Sachs, Tony Blair, rock bands, finance ministers and aid agencies have been vowing to ''make poverty history'' in Africa as the Group of 8 summit meeting in Scotland begins this week. The proponents of a comprehensive plan to end Afr...
lead_paragraph: BONO, Jeffrey Sachs, Tony Blair, rock bands, finance ministers and aid agencies have been vowing to "make poverty history" in Africa as the Group of 8 summit meeting in Scotland begins this week. The proponents of a comprehensive plan to end Africa's poverty say the solutions are easy. For example, Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, says preventing the deaths of five million children over the next 10 years would cost just $3 more for each new mother in the world's poorest countries. All told, Tony Blair's Commission for Africa calls for $25 billion more in aid to Africa per year.

title: Africa’s Girl Power
snippet: A group called Camfed is bringing lasting social change to African countries by educating hundreds of thousands of girls.
lead_paragraph: Update: David Bornstein responded to readers in the comments below.

title: Saving Lives in Africa
snippet: Editorial welcomes Pres Bush's pledge of $1.2 billion for five-year campaign against malaria in Africa
lead_paragraph: With President Bush's announcement yesterday of $1.2 billion for a five-year campaign against malaria in Africa, this mosquito-borne disease is finally getting the high-level attention it deserves. The wonder is that it took so long. This ancient scourge is so deadly and pervasive, and effective remedies are so cheap, that there is no justification for the world's past indifference.

title: African Genocide Averted
snippet: Kenya’s remarkable power-sharing outcome can serve as a model: Call it the Nairobi paradigm or Kofi Annan’s R2P marker.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: BENIN: Toll In Crash Rises To 113; CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: 29 Die Of Measles;.
lead_paragraph: BENIN: TOLL IN CRASH RISES TO 113 Foreign Minister Rogatien Biaou put the death toll in the crash of a UTA Boeing 727 on Thursday at 113, up from 82. Twenty-two people were injured, leaving 26 of the 151 passengers and 10 crew members unaccounted for. The pilot, a Libyan, survived. The plane failed to become airborne on take-off and skidded down the runway, smashing into a building before tumbling nose down into the Gulf of Guinea. Aviation officials suggested the plane was overloaded or unbalanced. UTA had been denied a license to register the plane in Lebanon because it did not fulfill "technical requirements," said the Lebanese transport minister, Najib Mikati. Instead the plane was registered in Guinea. But Guinea's transport minister, Cellou Dalein Diallo, said that after "all the customary checks, nothing prevented the delivery of an airworthiness certificate." (Agence France-Presse)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Miners Rescued After Quakes
snippet: A series of earthquakes collapsed shafts deep within a huge gold mine, owned by DRDGold Limited, 100 miles southwest of Johannesburg, initially trapping 42 miners. Rescue workers tunneled through fallen rock to reach the workers and later saved al...
lead_paragraph: A series of earthquakes collapsed shafts deep within a huge gold mine, owned by DRDGold Limited, 100 miles southwest of Johannesburg, initially trapping 42 miners. Rescue workers tunneled through fallen rock to reach the workers and later saved all but one of them, Reuters reported. The body of the miner who died was recovered. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Letter from Africa: Africa looks back on its pioneering leaders
lead_paragraph: KASUNGU, Malawi — A surprising exercise in revisionism is taking place in this quiet country, a southern African democracy tucked away in an obscure corner of Africa's Rift Valley that is not generally known for surprises or, for that matter, news.

title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
snippet: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Silvia Moreno-Garcia, Elliot Page, Binyavanga Wainaina and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Silvia Moreno-Garcia, Elliot Page, Binyavanga Wainaina and more.

title: Setback In Africa
lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration's attempt to reverse gears in southern Africa is moving us backward. Delegates from 30 African countries made that clear at the African-American Institute's conference here.

title: African youths are missing
World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Managing Job Losses
snippet: The government of South Africa will draft a plan with mining companies and labor unions to manage job losses in the gold-mining industry, which has shed 8,000 jobs in 18 months, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, the mining minister, left, said. ''South Afri...
lead_paragraph: The government of South Africa will draft a plan with mining companies and labor unions to manage job losses in the gold-mining industry, which has shed 8,000 jobs in 18 months, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, the mining minister, left, said. "South Africa requires a business model which does not solve the problem of lower profits by first retrenching workers," Ms. Mlambo-Ngcuka said. The South African rand has gained 87 percent against the dollar since the end of 2001, crimping profits of miners who pay costs in rand and sell their output for dollars. The chief executive of the Harmony Gold Mining Company, Z. Bernard Swanepoel, announced plans to lay off 11,780 people, or a quarter of its 45,000-member work force, to stem losses.

title: Africa's AIDS Orphans
snippet: The U.N. Children's Fund estimated in a report that 11 million children under 15 in sub-Saharan Africa have lost at least one parent to AIDS.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. Children's Fund estimated in a report that 11 million children under 15 in sub-Saharan Africa have lost at least one parent to AIDS.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Homes Burned In Witch Hunt
snippet: Police in Limpopo Province, South Africa, arrest 90 youths after rampage in which 39 homes were burned to ground in fruitless hunt for witch (S)
lead_paragraph: The police in northeastern Limpopo Province arrested 90 youths and said more arrests were likely after a rampage in which 39 homes were burned to the ground, apparently in a fruitless hunt for a witch. The burnings began early Thursday around the village of Giyani and continued until the youths were arrested yesterday. One died in a gunfight after officers tried to stop the crowd from burning one house. Moatshe Ngoepe, the police superintendent in the provincial capital, Polokwane, said the homeowners included traditional healers, traditional leaders and church officials, all apparently denounced as witches before the gang set their homes afire. "We thought this kind of thing was in the past," the South Africa Press Association quoted Mr. Ngoepe as saying. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Through Africa with hope
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — There was, last week, a glimmer of hope in the world food crisis. Expecting a bumper harvest, Ukraine relaxed restrictions on exports. Overnight, global wheat prices fell by 10 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Investing Plan For Blacks
snippet: Standard Bank Group, Old Mutual and other South African banks and insurers pledge to transfer quarter of their ownership to black investors by 2010 as part of 75-billion-rand ($10.7 billion) plan to loosen white control of country's economy (S)
lead_paragraph: The Standard Bank Group, Old Mutual and other South African banks and insurers pledged to transfer a quarter of their ownership to black investors by 2010 as part of a 75-billion-rand ($10.7 billion) plan to loosen white control of the country's economy. The financial services charter program, includes targets for employment and training of blacks, banking services and investment in poor areas and procurement of goods and services from black-owned companies.

title: AIDS: Africa's doctors
World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: African Leaders Urge U.N. Role; KENYA: Mau Mau Group Recognized; MOROCCO: An Agency To Tackle Illegal Migration;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: AFRICAN LEADERS URGE U.N. ROLE West African heads of state urged the United Nations to consider deploying peacekeepers in war-divided Ivory Coast to reinforce and eventually replace a stretched regional force. The leaders' appeal was issued after a one-day summit meeting in Ghana meant to ease regional tensions aggravated by the civil war that exploded in Ivory Coast after a failed rebel uprising last year. The leaders of Burkina Faso, Togo and Ivory Coast took part in the meeting, along with the presidents of Nigeria, Benin, Niger and Ghana. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SUDAN: Plea For Aid;.
lead_paragraph: SUDAN: PLEA FOR AID Foreign donors have delivered less than half the $170 million pledged as aid, the director of the government's aid commission said. The official, Sulafaldin Salih, said the money could promote peace efforts between the government and southern rebels and assist rehabilitation of war-ravaged areas. Rebels have been fighting for greater autonomy for the mostly animist and Christian south from successive Islamist governments since 1983.    (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SUDAN: Greatest Humanitarian Crisis; SWAZILAND: Topping The World In Aids Infection; UGANDA: American Missionary Couple Shot Dead;.
lead_paragraph: SUDAN: `GREATEST HUMANITARIAN CRISIS' A senior United Nations official said fighting in western Sudan had intensified and accused Arab militia of systematically attacking villages and raping women. Mukesh Kapila, the United Nations resident coordinator for Sudan, said attacks against tribes in the Darfur region were "close to the definition of ethnic cleansing." He said: "In my view, this is the world's greatest humanitarian crisis and possibly the world's greatest humanitarian catastrophe. There has been systematic burning of villages and displacement of the population." In one attack, on Feb. 27, more than 100 women were raped in the northern town of Tawilaa, Mr. Kapila said. Fighting has raged across Darfur since February 2003, when rebels took up arms. They accuse President Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir's Islamic government of arming and supporting the Arab militia. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Miner Forecasts Profit
snippet: Anglo American Platinum Corp says its income, rose 25 percent in 2004; will report profit of 2.6 billion rand ($430 million) on Feb 14 (S)
lead_paragraph: The Anglo American Platinum Corporation, the world's largest platinum producer, said its income, excluding one-time items and good-will amortization, rose 25 percent last year as metal prices rose. Anglo American will report a profit of 2.6 billion rand ($430 million) on Feb. 14, the company said in a statement to the Johannesburg stock exchange. The forecast was at the low end of analysts' expectations, and stock in the company, which is based in Johannesburg, fell 1.5 rand, or 0.7 percent, to 226.50 rand ($37.50) a share.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ETHIOPIA: Premier Sees 'Ghastly' Famine'; SOUTH AFRICA: More Whites Sought In Bombings;.
lead_paragraph: ETHIOPIA: PREMIER SEES `GHASTLY' FAMINE Prime Minister Meles Zenawi issued an urgent call for international aid to prevent a potential famine from affecting 15 million people, almost a third of the country's population. "The disaster we had 1984-85, the number involved was roughly a third to one-half of the number of people involved now," he told BBC radio in an interview. "So if that was a nightmare, this will be too ghastly to contemplate." The World Food Program, a United Nations agency, warned this month that it could run out of food for the drought-stricken country as early as next month unless governments increased their donations. But Mr. Zenawi's calls for assistance were far more dire than those issued by the United Nations, which has estimated that some six million Ethiopians are threatened by the drought. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ETHIOPIA: Food Shortages Worsen; SUDAN: Tribal Violence;.
lead_paragraph: ETHIOPIA: FOOD SHORTAGES WORSEN Ethiopia's worst drought in nearly two decades is hitting even harder than initial estimates showed, the government said, with one million more people now facing severe food shortages. The drought, which began in 2001, has devastated sorghum and maize crops. A senior Ethiopian relief official said 12.6 million people now required emergency food aid. He appealed for an additional 79,122 tons of food supplies for this year, urging donors to deliver their pledges quickly. He said so far less than half of the total food aid pledged had been delivered. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOUTH AFRICA: Man Guilty Of Killing Ex-First Lady; ZIMBABWE: Protesters Arrested; SIERRA LEONE: U.N. Prosecutor Demands Body;.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AFRICA: MAN GUILTY OF KILLING EX-FIRST LADY A security guard was found guilty of the 2001 murder of Marike de Klerk, the former wife of F. W. de Klerk, the last president in South Africa's era of apartheid. Mrs. de Klerk, 64, who was married to the former president for 39 years before their divorce in 1998, was stabbed and strangled in her luxury apartment near Cape Town. The guard, Luyanda Mboniswa, 23, who worked at the apartment complex, was convicted by the Cape High Court of murder and house breaking with aggravating circumstances. Sentencing is expected on Thursday. (Reuters)

title: Pan-African Treasures
Africa’s Next Slaughter
snippet: Unless a major international effort is mounted to avert it, a new conflict in southern Sudan will probably resemble Darfur but be carried out on a much wider scale.
lead_paragraph: ABYEI, Sudan

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: An Interest Rate Cut
snippet: South Africa's central bank reduces its benchmark lending rate by one percentage point, after surge in value of currency pushed manufacturing into recession and economy slid to its slowest growth rate in nearly five years; cut follows 1.5 percenta...
lead_paragraph: The central bank of South Africa reduced its benchmark lending rate by one percentage point, after a surge in the value of the currency pushed manufacturing into a recession and the economy slid to its slowest growth rate in nearly five years. The cut follows a 1.5 percentage-point reduction in June, and a 1 percentage-point cut in August.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOUTH AFRICA: Outcry After Speech; BURUNDI: Planning A Peace Force;.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AFRICA: OUTCRY AFTER SPEECH Opposition parties accused President Thabo Mbeki of neglecting critical issues, including AIDS and South Africa's support for Zimbabwe, in his state of the nation speech. Last week, demonstrators marched through the streets of Cape Town to press the government to provide AIDS drugs in this country, which has more people infected with H.I.V. than any other country. In his speech, Mr. Mbeki did not announce any plans to widen access to the lifesaving medicines.    Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Bush's Africa Trip
snippet: President Bush visited five African nations to address issues from AIDS to democracy.
lead_paragraph: President Bush visited five African nations to address issues from AIDS to democracy.

title: Evolution of an African Republic
snippet: Liberia's history noted; nation, Africa's first independent republic, was formed to repatriate free blacks from United States (S)
lead_paragraph: Liberia was founded early in the 19th century by the American Colonization Society, which was itself largely the creation of Robert Finley, a New Jersey minister who believed that blacks would never achieve equality in America and should, therefore, be returned to Africa.

title: An Aria for Post-Apartheid Africa
snippet: Article on first Zulu opera, Princess Magogo KaDinuzulu, commissioned by Sandra de Villiers, founder of Opera Africa in Durban, South Africa, where work had premiere performance in 2002; opera will open 100th-anniversary season at Ravinia Festival...
lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SEYCHELLES: Leader Calls It Quits; SUDAN: Cease-Fire Monitors;.
lead_paragraph: SEYCHELLES: LEADER CALLS IT QUITS James Michel, the longtime vice president, was sworn in as president of the Indian Ocean archipelago of 90,000 people, replacing France Albert René, who seized power in a 1977 coup. Mr. René, one of Africa's longest-serving leaders, announced his retirement last year but said he would remain chairman of the governing Seychelles Peoples Progressive Front. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Africa's Homeless Widows
snippet: Editorial on improving plight of women in Africa, including reforming inheritance practices so that widows and their children are not left homeless and destitute, at mercy of husband's relatives
lead_paragraph: Women feed Africa. They grow 80 percent of the continent's food, yet the land they cultivate is not theirs. Women own only 1 percent of the land in sub-Saharan Africa. Tradition says that when a man dies, his property passes to his adult sons or brothers. The widow and her children are often evicted and left destitute.

title: Central African Republic
snippet: GEOGRAPHY Location: landlocked country in central Africa. Boundaries: Chad to N, Sudan to E, Zaire, Congo to S, Cameroon to W. Total land area: 240,533 sq. mi. (622,980 sq km). Coastline: none. Comparative area: slightly smaller than Texas. Land u...
lead_paragraph: GEOGRAPHY Location: landlocked country in central Africa. Boundaries: Chad to N, Sudan to E, Zaire, Congo to S, Cameroon to W. Total land area: 240,533 sq. mi. (622,980 sq km). Coastline: none. Comparative area: slightly smaller than Texas. Land use: 3% arable land; negl. % permanent crops; 97% other. Major cities: (1988) Bangui (capital) 451,690; Berbérati 41,891; Bouar 39,676. PEOPLE Population: 3,683,538 (July 2003 est.). Nationality: noun—Central African(s); adjective— Central African. Ethnic groups: 33% Baya, 27% Banda, 13% Mandija, 10% Sara, 7% Mboum, 4% M'Baka; 2% other. Languages: French (official), Sangho (lingua franca and national language), tribal languages. Religions: 35% indigenous beliefs, 25% Protestant, 25% Roman Catholic, 15% Muslim; indigenous beliefs and practices strongly influence Christian majority. GOVERNMENT Type: republic. Independence: Aug. 13, 1960 (from France). Constitution: Adopted Jan. 7, 1995. National holiday: Republic Day, Dec. 1. Heads of Government: François Bozize, head of state (since March 31, 2003); Abel Goumba, prime minister (since March 31, 2003). Structure: executive; unicameral legislature; judiciary. ECONOMY Monetary unit: Communauté Financière Africaine (CFA) franc. Budget: (1994 est.) income: $638 mil.; expend.: $1.9 bil. GDP: $4.7 bil., $1,300 per capita (2002 est.). Chief crops: cotton, coffee, tobacco. Natural resources: diamonds, uranium, timber, gold, oil. Major industries: sawmills, breweries, diamond mining. Labor force: 775,413 (1986 est.); 85% agriculture, 9% commerce and services. Exports: $134 mil. (f.o.b., 2002 est.); diamonds, timber, cotton, coffee, tobacco. Imports: $102 mil. (f.o.b., 2002); food, textiles, petroleum products, machinery, electrical equipment, motor vehicles. Major trading partners: exports: 53% Belgium, Kazakhstan, Spain; imports: 26% France, Cameroon, Spain. A landlocked country in Africa's central region, the Central African Republic is one of the least-developed countries in the world. Most of its people are farmers, and the nation has little manufacturing, few reliable roads, and no railroad. Europeans first came to the area in the early 1800's in their search for slaves, but it was not until 1889 that the French established an outpost as the current capital city of Bangui. The region was organized as the territory of Ubangi-Shari five years later. In 1910 it was incorporated into French Equitorial Africa along with what are now the countries of Chad, the Congo, and Gabon. The country was granted internal selfgovernment by the French under its present name in 1958 and became a member of the French Overseas Community. Independence was achieved on Aug. 13, 1960. The first prime minister, Barthelemy Boganda, was killed in an airplane crash in 1959 and was succeeded by his nephew, David Dacko. Dacko was elected to a seven-year term in January 1964, but an army coup in 1966 overthrew his government. The head of the army, Jean-Bedel Bokassa, was installed as president. Named president for life in 1972, in 1976 Bokassa declared himself emperor and changed the name of the country to the Central African Empire. Dacko returned to power in 1979, however, and Bokassa went into exile in France. The name of the country was changed back to the Central African Republic. A multiparty political system was reinstated in March 1981, but army officers threw Dacko out of office again six months later and banned all political parties. Opposition parties were legalized in 1991, and Bokassa was released shortly before elections in 1993, elections that made Ange Félix Patassé president. He tried to reduce the army's power but has been met with several rebellions requiring the intervention of peacekeepers from neighboring states. After surviving numerous coup attempts, Patassé was overturned in March 2003 by fired army head General Francois Bozize who suspended the constitution and proclaimed himself president.

title: Liberia Seen as Icon of World's Neglect of Africa
snippet: Letter From Africa on Liberia as portrait of international neglect that stands in sharp contrast to neighboring Sierra Leone, where tens of thousands of foreigners are working to restore peace and donating aid; in Liberia, World Food Program canno...
lead_paragraph: At a popular restaurant here on the water's edge, the dinner menu offers a rare item: a vegetarian version of the traditional West African groundnut stew. Vegetarianism is anathema in this part of the world. But adjustments have had to be made in Sierra Leone because the world is here.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ex-Deputy Facing Charges
snippet: The national prosecutor said he would charge the nation's recently fired deputy president, Jacob Zuma, with two counts of official corruption stemming from his ties to Schabir Shaik, a financial adviser convicted on fraud and bribery charges this ...
lead_paragraph: The national prosecutor said he would charge the nation's recently fired deputy president, Jacob Zuma, with two counts of official corruption stemming from his ties to Schabir Shaik, a financial adviser convicted on fraud and bribery charges this month. President Thabo Mbeki fired Mr. Zuma after a Durban court concluded that Mr. Shaik had paid him bribes for several years, apparently in exchange for political influence on government contracts. Mr. Zuma has denied wrongdoing. His supporters applauded the prosecutor's decision, arguing that the Shaik conviction unfairly tainted him and that a separate trial would offer Mr. Zuma a chance to clear his name. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apartheid Victims Sue Banks
snippet: Class action lawsuit is filed in US District Court in New York against Citigroup and Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse Group and UBS, on behalf of four South African victims of apartheid (S)
lead_paragraph: A class action lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court in the Southern District of New York against Citigroup Inc., and Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse Group and UBS, on behalf of four South African victims of apartheid. Lawyers argue that the banks' financial dealings prolonged the white-only rule in violation of international law. They are seeking about $50 billion from the banks on behalf of as many as hundreds of thousands of clients. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apartheid Victims Sue Banks
snippet: Class action lawsuit is filed in US District Court in New York against Citigroup and Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse Group and UBS, on behalf of four South African victims of apartheid (S)
lead_paragraph: A class action lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court in the Southern District of New York against Citigroup Inc., and Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse Group and UBS, on behalf of four South African victims of apartheid. Lawyers argue that the banks' financial dealings prolonged the white-only rule in violation of international law. They are seeking about $50 billion from the banks on behalf of as many as hundreds of thousands of clients. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: In Search of a Lost Africa
snippet: Her idyllic childhood was shattered by a violent civil war. Her return from exile revealed what she had, and had not, left behind.
lead_paragraph: AS I LOOKED DOWN FROM MY FLIGHT onto the dense green rain forest that surrounds Robertsfield airport, all I could see was bush. From the air, Liberia looked lush and completely uninhabited. Fierce waves from the Atlantic hurled at the shoreline.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Radioactive Material Is Missing; SOUTH AFRICA: Playwright Announces He Is H.I.V.-Positive; KENYA: Chief Justice Is Investigated;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL IS MISSING Nigerian authorities said they were searching for highly radioactive material used in the oil industry that had disappeared in the oil-producing Niger Delta. The Nigerian Nuclear Regulatory Authority, in a public notice broadcast on radio and television, warned people to avoid contact with the "highly radioactive, dangerous material," but would not identify the exact substance. An oil engineer in the country said it was probably either cesium 137 or sodium iodide, used in oil-well-mapping operations, and that "two parcels" of the material disappeared around Dec. 3.   (Reuters)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 3 Cleared Of Coup Accusation
snippet: Cyril Ramaphosa, Tokyo Sexwale and Matthews Phosa, senior members of South Africa's governing African National Congress, are cleared of charges they plotted to oust Pres Thabo Mbeki; accuser, Min Steve Tshwete, apologizes (S)
lead_paragraph: Three of the country's leading black businessmen, all central figures in the anti-apartheid struggle and senior members of the governing African National Congress, have been cleared of accusations that they were plotting to oust President Thabo Mbeki. The accusations against Cyril Ramaphosa, Tokyo Sexwale and Matthews Phosa were widely denounced as absurd and dangerous when they were made in April. In announcing the results of the investigation, Minister of Safety and Security Steve Tshwete, who first accused the men, expressed his ''profound apologies'' to them and their families. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: The East Africa Times
snippet: In this lesson, students work in teams as editors to design the front page of a newspaper covering a country in east Africa. They then individually research and write articles that define modern life for the country’s citizens.
lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Africans in Early Virginia
lead_paragraph: The Jamestown Settlement in Williamsburg, Va., is commemorating 375 years of African-American culture with a special program on Saturday, Aug. 20. In observance of the arrival in 1619 of the first people of African origin in British North America, the museum plans a symbolic arrival ceremony and several programs about African-American traditions and experiences and their influence on American culture.

title: Africa's New Realism
snippet: Op-Ed article by South African Pres Thabo Mbeki says upcoming Group of 8 economic summit in Canada is chance for developed countries to make sound investment in Africa and help break cycle of African underdevelopment; says it is possible to revive...
lead_paragraph: A great moment is at hand: a chance for developed countries to make a sound investment while helping to break the cycle of African underdevelopment. This prospect now seems as obvious as it was previously elusive.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Baby-Rape Charges Dropped
snippet: Prosecutors in South Africa withdraw charges against six men accused of raping baby girl, citing lack of sufficient evidence (S)
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors withdrew charges against six men accused of raping a baby girl, saying they had insufficient evidence against the men. The police had said earlier that they believed only one of the men was responsible for the attack on the infant. Investigators, who feared outraged citizens might try to beat or kill the men, promised to continue searching for the baby's attackers. The baby was less than a year old when she was raped.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOUTH AFRICA: A Plot To Kill Mandela?; IVORY COAST: Red Cross Workers Slain;.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AFRICA: A PLOT TO KILL MANDELA? A group of white right-wing South Africans who face many charges of terrorism and treason were accused yesterday of plotting to assassinate former President Nelson Mandela. Paul Fick, a prosecutor, told reporters that 23 Afrikaner members of an organization called Boeremag had planned to blow up Mr. Mandela's car in October. In recent days, the police reported that Boeremag was still intent on violently overthrowing South Africa's black-led government. The group was blamed last year for planting several bombs, including nine in the black township of Soweto, which killed one person and prompted fears of a mass racial backlash. A lawyer for 13 of the accused told reporters that his clients' human rights had been "grossly violated" by the police.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Diamond Sales Rise
snippet: South African diamond mining company De Beers says sales in first half of year rose 2.7 percent to $2.92 billion and it expects sales for full year to exceed those of 2002; managing director Gary M Ralfe says company raised prices in January and F...
lead_paragraph: The diamond mining company De Beers said sales in the first half of the year rose 2.7 percent to $2.92 billion and that it expected sales for the full year to exceed those of 2002. The company raised prices in January and May, the managing director, Gary M. Ralfe, said on a conference call. Further increases will depend on retail sales in the fourth quarter, which accounts for about 40 percent of diamond jewelry sales, Mr. Ralfe said.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Land To Cameroon; RWANDA: More Judges For Genocide Court;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: LAND TO CAMEROON Nigeria said it would transfer 33 northeastern villages near Lake Chad to Cameroon by the end of the year, in line with a ruling by the International Court of Justice in The Hague. The countries have been locked in a dispute over a number of areas on their border, including territory rich in oil and fish. (Reuters)

title: African Sculptures at Yale
lead_paragraph: THE first exposure of ''Evocative Images'' took place two years ago at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. There, the show numbered 84 works of African art lent by the University Museum of the University of Pennsylvania and it celebrated that museum's centenary.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: Trade Surplus
snippet: South Africa posts its biggest trade surplus in 18 months in December, reversing deficit in November; surplus is put at 6.1 billion rand ($707 million) (S)
lead_paragraph: South Africa posted its biggest trade surplus in 18 months in December, reversing a deficit in November, after imports of oil and machinery slumped, the Revenue Service reported. The larger-than-expected surplus of 6.1 billion rand ($707 million) was in contrast to a deficit of 605 million rand in November and the average analysts' forecast of a 2.1 billion rand surplus.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: March For Shariah; NIGERIA: Death Row Review;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: MARCH FOR SHARIAH Hundreds of Nigerian Muslims marched in the city of Kano to press for a stricter enforcement of the Shariah Islamic penal code. Members of the Kadariyya group said they were worried that alcohol was still sold and prostitution practiced in Nigeria's second largest city four years after the state adopted the new legal code and three years after hundreds died in Muslim-Christian riots there. Kano is one of 12 northern states that adopted Shariah in 1999. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: Government And Rebels Meet; TRIBUNAL TRIES TO MEND RIFT WITH RWANDA;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: GOVERNMENT AND REBELS MEET Government officials and rebels held their first face-to-face talks in a bid to end more than five weeks of violent unrest in the West African country. Participants in the talks, in Lomé, the capital of Togo, said they had focused on rebel demands for changes in the armed forces and on the government's demand that the rebels disarm. The rebels — mainly soldiers and former soldiers — also want new elections, saying that the election in 2000 that brought President Laurent Gbagbo to power was marred by violence and that the disqualification of the opposition leader, Alassane Ouattara, was unjust.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: Warning On Food Shortages; SOUTH AFRICA: Searching For White Militants;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: WARNING ON FOOD SHORTAGES The World Food Program warned that food shortages were spreading throughout the country as imports by the government and aid groups fall short. The United Nations agency reported that more than six million people — about half the population — will need food aid by the end of March. It issued an appeal to donors, saying it has yet to meet its target of feeding three million people. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: An African Dumping Ground
snippet: Without strict, and strictly enforced, international rules on waste disposal, dangerous cargoes will find the course of least resistance, least cost, and least regulation.
lead_paragraph: Globalization brings wealth and opportunity to many people around the world. But to poor slum dwellers in the failing state of Ivory Coast, it has brought horrible sickness and death after hazardous waste, shipped nearly halfway around the world, was stealthily dumped in backyards around Abidjan. This need not and should not have happened.

title: Africa Braces for Coronavirus, but Slowly
snippet: The virus has not yet hit most of the African continent hard, and neither has social distancing.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Commuters on bicycles and motorbikes wove through traffic in this West African city wearing face masks to protect their lungs — but not against coronavirus. They were protecting themselves from the fine dust blowing in from the Sahara.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SUDAN: Aid Worker Dies In Fighting; ZIMBABWE: Journalists Challenge Law;.
lead_paragraph: SUDAN: AID WORKER DIES IN FIGHTING Sudanese government-backed forces launched a major offensive against rebel-held positions, just one week after the two sides reached an agreement that was hailed as a major step toward ending Africa's longest-running war. One aid worker was killed in the government offensive in the village of Waat and three others were reported missing. The government and the southern rebels agreed last week to allow residents in southern Sudan to vote within six years on whether to break off into a separate country. The two sides, however, did not agree on a cease-fire. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: Africa ZIMBABWE: Black Squatters Face Eviction; MALI: Ex-general Appears To Win Election.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: BLACK SQUATTERS FACE EVICTION The government said it would begin evicting thousands of black squatters from white-owned farms that are not scheduled to be be acquired under a land redistribution program. Foreign diplomats and regional leaders have been urging the government to take the step for months. Officials say they would start by evicting about 12,000 families from farms in the southern part of the country, a move that was welcomed by white farmers.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: U.N. Rushes To Evacuate 60,000 Liberians; NIGERIA: Date Set For Elections; SOUTH AFRICA: Comeback For Winnie Mandela;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: U.N. RUSHES TO EVACUATE LIBERIANS The United Nations refugee agency said it was urgently trying to move 60,000 Liberian refugees trapped in fighting in western Ivory Coast to safety along the southern coast. Kamel Morjane, assistant United Nations high commissioner for refugees, also said the United Nations was negotiating with other West African states to take in the Liberians if the situation worsened in Ivory Coast.   (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: MOROCCO: King Has An Heir And Frees 9,000 Prisoners; SOUTH AFRICA: U.S. Envoy Welcomes Zimbabwe Effort;.
lead_paragraph: MOROCCO: KING HAS AN HEIR AND FREES 9,000 PRISONERS King Mohammed VI celebrated the birth of a son and heir by ordering the release of more than 9,000 prisoners from Morocco's crowded jails, one of the biggest royal pardons in the country's history. In neighboring Algeria, the state radio said that President Abdelaziz Bouteflika had commemorated the forthcoming birthday of the prophet Muhammad by pardoning 5,000 inmates. The Moroccan baby, named Hassan after his grandfather Hassan II, is the first child of the king and his wife, Princess Salma Bennani. King Mohammed also reduced the jail sentences of more than 38,000 inmates. (Reuters)

title: Drought Deepens South Africa’s Malaise
snippet: The full impact of the drought and resulting poor harvests will be felt only in the months ahead, but they have already left 29 million people without reliable access to food, the U.N. says.
lead_paragraph: SETLAGOLE, South Africa — Under a midmorning sun that augured punishing heat later in the day, a handful of cows stood still inside a small pen, their ribs protruding. Too weak to reach the nearest grassy field some miles away, some munched on tall grass that their owner had cut from a strip of land along the highway, in a desperate attempt to save his cattle from the drought afflicting the land.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mbeki Pledges Leadership On Aids
snippet: Pres Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, who has questioned safety of commonly prescribed AIDS drugs and causes of the disease, says he is prepared to provide greater leadership on issue and urges people to practice safe sex to help combat country's lead...
lead_paragraph: President Thabo Mbeki, who has questioned the safety of commonly prescribed AIDS drugs and the causes of the disease, said he was prepared to provide greater leadership on the issue and urged people to practice safe sex to help combat the country's deadly epidemic. His remarks came a week after his cabinet announced that it would offer AIDS drugs to all H.I.V.-infected pregnant women at public hospitals to prevent the transmission of the AIDS virus to unborn babies. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOUTH AFRICA: State Funeral Ordered For Sisulu; CONGO: Key Rebel Joins Government;.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AFRICA: STATE FUNERAL ORDERED FOR SISULU The government decided to grant a state funeral to Walter Sisulu, who led the decades-long campaign against apartheid alongside Nelson Mandela. Mr. Sisulu, 90, died on Monday. The state funeral will be on May 17 in the Johannesburg township of Soweto. An official state funeral means the government will bear some of the costs, members of the South African military will participate, and flags will be flown at half-staff during a period of mourning.   (Agence France-Presse)

title: Africans — Naive No Longer
lead_paragraph: The reasons for the Americans’ 2-1 loss to Ghana Thursday and their three-and-out elimination from the World Cup are obvious enough: an inability to attack creatively (witness the dozens of hopeful long balls hoofed uselessly right to the Ghanaian defense); a poor tactical set-up (a 4-5-1 when it had already been proven that the Americans cannot score with a lone striker); a lack of highly skilled players (the Yanks have no field player who comes close to matching Essien, Appiah, Rosicky, Nedved, Del Piero or Gattuso); and poor preparation that depended on excessive secrecy and that somehow left the players psychologically overwhelmed. The blame spreads around evenly among the players, the coach and the federation — though it does seem as if the man most responsible for the missteps in preparation and tactics, Bruce Arena, bears the biggest share of that blame.

title: Jacob Zuma and the Theft of South Africa
snippet: The A.N.C. needs to move away from the president’s corrupt politics and look for solutions not based on crude nationalism and racial essentialism.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s ruling African National Congress will meet on Dec. 16 to elect a new party president. It will do so in the throes of a debilitating crisis. A decade of President Jacob Zuma’s leadership has seen Africa’s oldest liberation movement become a caricature of corruption and factionalism.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: RWANDA: Genocide Suspect Pleads Not Guilty; SOUTH AFRICA: Arrests In Land Protests;.
lead_paragraph: RWANDA: GENOCIDE SUSPECT PLEADS NOT GUILTY Augustin Bizimungu, a former Rwandan military commander considered one of the architects of the 1994 killing frenzy, pleaded not guilty at the United Nations tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania. Mr. Bizimungu, who was chief of staff of the army, was arrested last week in Angola. He faces 10 counts of genocide and crimes against humanity after being accused of leading the killing of 800,000 people, mostly members of the Tutsi ethnic group.

title: Reopening for Juneteenth, a Museum Celebrating a Black Inventor
snippet: Lewis Howard Latimer worked for Thomas Edison and drew patent diagrams for Alexander Graham Bell. A museum in Queens displays his work.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

title: The Amazon Is on Fire. So Is Central Africa.
snippet: Among the regions at risk is the Congo Basin forest, the world’s second-largest tropical rain forest, mostly in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — As images of wildfires in South America’s Amazon region draw global attention, a large and potentially devastating series of fires is raging in Central Africa and parts of Southern Africa.

title: Engineering Food for Africans
snippet: Africa has been developing genetically modified foods with help of countries like United States; scientists at front lines of Africa's biotechnology revolution, in Kenya, South Africa and Egypt, say they believe their lab work will eventually help...
lead_paragraph: A barbed-wire fence encloses a field full of vegetables, and security guards protect the perimeter of what is clearly not an ordinary garden. At harvest time, this well-guarded produce, instead of going to market, goes into a bonfire.

title: The Making of an African Petrostate
snippet: Chad, among poorest countries in Africa, is now its newest petrostate, with $3.7-billion underground pipeline carrying crude oil 670 miles from Doba Basin Oil fields through Cameroon to Atlantic coast; photos; map; huge economic and cultural impli...
lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Wider Availability Of Aids Drug
snippet: Officials in Gauteng Province, which includes Johannesburg, say they will provide AIDS drug nevirapine in public hospitals to prevent women from transmitting HIV to their babies during birth (S)
lead_paragraph: Officials in Gauteng Province, which includes Johannesburg, said they would provide the AIDS drug nevirapine in public hospitals to prevent women from transmitting H.I.V. to their babies during birth. The decision comes weeks after the leader of KwaZulu-Natal Province made a similar announcement. The national government, which has been reluctant to expand its pilot program for pregnant women infected with H.I.V., has decided to allow the nevirapine program to extend to provinces with hospitals and clinics that have enough staff members and supplies. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Seeking More Aids Drugs; TOGO: Leader Is A Candidate Again;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: SEEKING MORE AIDS DRUGS The government announced plans to sharply increase the availability of crucial anti-AIDS drugs by 2005. Kenya has about 2.2 million H.I.V. and AIDS patients, but only 7,000 receive life-prolonging anti-retroviral drugs. The government has asked the Health Ministry to raise that number to 40,000 by mid-2005, said Kenneth Chebet, director of the national program for control of AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases. The treatment will cost more than $14.6 million per year.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: Regional Official Meets Rebels; KENYA: President Dissolves Parliament; CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Gunfire In Capital;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: REGIONAL OFFICIAL MEETS REBELS The chief of the 15-member Economic Community of West African States met with Ivory Coast rebel leaders in their central headquarters in Bouaké to work out details of imminent talks with the government. "They are ready to discuss together and we are optimistic because we think it can happen very soon," the official, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, said in the capital, Yamoussoukro, shortly after returning. Leaders of the economic group met in Abidjan to lay the groundwork for a force from its member countries to monitor the fragile cease-fire agreed reached Oct. 17.   (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SENEGAL: Embassy Takeover; LIBERIA: Inmates To Go Free;.
lead_paragraph: SENEGAL: EMBASSY TAKEOVER More than 100 Gabonese students have taken over their embassy in Dakar, trapping three diplomats overnight to protest unpaid scholarships, the police said. The students invaded the embassy on Monday and have refused to allow the diplomats to leave. The Senegalese police say they will not try to enter the embassy because it is considered Gabonese territory. The students say they are owed stipends of $289 for rent, food and other expenses for the past academic term. About 2,000 Gabonese are students in Senegal. Of them, about half get government support. (AP)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: MOROCCO: Quake Survivors Protest; IVORY COAST: Polio Case Confirmed;.
lead_paragraph: MOROCCO: QUAKE SURVIVORS PROTEST A day after an earthquake hit northern Morocco, dozens of homeless survivors protested what they said was a lack of government aid. "We spent the night under the rain, in the cold," one man said. "We want building material, bricks, cement, iron to rebuild our homes." Nearly 600 people were killed and thousands were left homeless. Rescue teams continued to search for survivors in the rubble, but hopes were dim. (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mining Law Is Signed
snippet: Pres Thabo Mbeki signs into law transfer of ownership of South Africa's mineral deposits to state from companies; says proposed legislation to increase black participation in mining is complete; says owners of assets that are sold will receive 'fa...
lead_paragraph: South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, signed into law the transfer of ownership of mineral deposits to the state from companies and said proposed legislation to increase black participation in mining was complete. The transfer of the world's biggest gold, platinum and chrome deposits to the state is part of the government's plan to increase black participation in the nation's biggest export industry. The targets for black participation in mining will be made public Wednesday, President Mbeki said. This is ''a very satisfactory compromise between the political ambitions of the government and commercial considerations,'' said Barry Davison, chief of Anglo American Platinum and president of South Africa's Chamber of Mines. President Mbeki said that owners of assets that are sold would be paid ''fair market value'' and that there would be no nationalization of assets.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: OFFICIALS MEET U.S. TRADE ENVOY; IVORY COAST: Rebel Factions Sign Truce;.
lead_paragraph: OFFICIALS MEET U.S. TRADE ENVOY Officials from several southern African nations met in South Africa with the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, to discuss setting up a free trade agreement with the United States. Formal negotiations between the Southern African Customs Union and American officials are expected to start next month and officials hope an agreement will be signed in 2004.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Officers Blamed In Dog Attack
snippet: Witnesses testify in court that two white South African police officers ordered their dogs to attack three black Mozambique immigrants as part of animal training exercise; attack, in which six officers were involved, was videotaped and created nat...
lead_paragraph: Witnesses in a racially charged trial testified that two white police officers deliberately ordered their dogs to attack three black illegal aliens from Mozambique in 1998 as part of a dog-training exercise. The attack, which was videotaped, shocked the nation when it was broadcast on national television three years ago. Four police officers have pleaded guilty in the case and are serving prison sentences. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: For Kwanzaa, A Celebration of Africa
lead_paragraph: Hall of Ocean Life, American Museum of Natural History, Dec. 28.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AngloGold Profit Drops
snippet: AngloGold says that second-quarter profit fell 19 percent after rand and other currencies gain against dollar; net income dorps to 444 million rand ($60 million) (S)
lead_paragraph: AngloGold said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 19 percent after the rand and other currencies gained against the dollar, cutting margins at many of its mines. Net income dropped to 444 million rand ($60 million), or 1.99 rand a share, from 547 million rand, or 2.46 rand, in the fourth quarter, AngloGold said.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: LIBERIA: Swiss Freeze Leader'S Assets; DJIBOUTI: Errant Bombs Killed Marine;.
lead_paragraph: LIBERIA: SWISS FREEZE LEADER'S ASSETS Switzerland announced that it had taken steps to freeze the bank accounts in that country of Liberia's president, Charles Taylor. The Swiss Federal Office of Justice said it had acted on a request from a United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal, which has accused Mr. Taylor of crimes against humanity in connection with the civil war in Sierra Leone.    Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Aveng Shares Plunge
snippet: Shares
lead_paragraph: Shares of Aveng Ltd., the construction company, had their biggest drop in more than nine months after the company said first-half profit might fall as much as 30 percent. The stock dropped 49 cents, or 5.4 percent, to 8.51 rand ($1.30), its biggest fall since March 24. It earlier dropped as much as 10 percent. ''Shareholders are advised that the interim results for the period to Dec. 31 are expected to be materially lower than that of the corresponding period,'' the company said in a statement. Aveng said on Oct. 31 that the appreciation of the rand and weaker revenue from projects abroad would weigh on earnings. The company, based in Johannesburg, gets 40 percent of its sales from abroad. The currency climbed by 28 percent against the dollar last year. The company will report first-half earnings on March 8.

title: An African Dumping Ground
snippet: Editorial deplores stealth dumping of tankerload of petrochemical waste and caustic soda in backyards around Abidjan, Ivory Coast; says that without strict, and strictly enforced, international rules on waste disposal, dangerous cargos will find t...
lead_paragraph: Globalization brings wealth and opportunity to many people around the world. But to poor slum dwellers in the failing state of Ivory Coast, it has brought horrible sickness and death after hazardous waste, shipped nearly halfway around the world, was stealthily dumped in backyards around Abidjan. This need not and should not have happened.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: Africa ANGOLA: Amnesty For Rebels; RWANDA: Genocide Defendants Boycott Trial; CONGO: Leaders To Assess Peace Efforts.
lead_paragraph: AFRICA ANGOLA: AMNESTY FOR REBELS With a cease-fire set to be signed this week, Parliament unanimously approved a law granting amnesty to rebel fighters from the National Union for Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita. The moves toward peace, after a civil war that dates to the 1970's and that has devastated the country, come less than six weeks after Unita's leader, Jonas Savimbi, was killed in an ambush by government troops.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: President Speaks Out On Rape
snippet: South African Pres Thabo Mbeki uses New Year's address to call for end to silence and indifference about rape, particularly attacks on children; his photo (S)
lead_paragraph: In his New Year's address, President Thabo Mbeki urged people to end the silence and indifference that have helped to allow rape, particularly of children, to plague the country. Mr. Mbeki praised the country's progress in many areas but said more had to be done on crime. A number of child rapes over the last couple of months have focused attention on what Mr. Mbeki called ''a matter on which both government and the people have to act together.'' Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: All of Africa’s a Stage
snippet: How a young man from Fargo wound up doing Shakespeare in Cape Town.
lead_paragraph: The coming-of-age of this particular young man from Fargo, N.D., couldn’t have been that funny at the time: hitchhiking through countries at war (with one another and themselves), being mugged for his glasses, sleeping in the rough, doing time in jail, being ditched by an adored hooker, falling ill — actually paranoid — from an excessive affection for dope. But with the benefit of hindsight and an exquisite sense of the absurd, Thomas Goltz has turned his memories of a post-drama-school tour of Africa in the late 1970s into an insanely entertaining travel book.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Winnie Mandela Pleads Not Guilty
snippet: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who headed African National Congress Women's League, pleads not guilty to defrauding South African bank of about $100,000; denies signing letters accompany loan applications for 60 people who falsely claimed to be league...
lead_paragraph: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela has pleaded not guilty to defrauding a local bank of about $100,000. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, who headed the African National Congress Women's League, is accused of signing letters accompanying loan applications for 60 people who falsely claimed to be employees of the league. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, the ex-wife of former President Nelson Mandela, denied that she had signed the letters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ashanti Endorses Bid
snippet: Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana recommends that shareholders accept improved takeover bid from AngloGold that values company at about $1.4 billion; AngloGold is battling smaller competitor RandGold for Ghana mine; RandGold all-stock bid is worth about...
lead_paragraph: Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana recommended late Tuesday that shareholders accept an improved takeover bid from AngloGold that values the company at about $1.4 billion. AngloGold, the world's second- largest gold producer, is battling a smaller competitor, RandGold, for the Ghana mine. The RandGold all-stock bid is worth about $1.5 billion. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Winnie Mandela Pleads Not Guilty
snippet: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who headed African National Congress Women's League, pleads not guilty to defrauding South African bank of about $100,000; denies signing letters accompany loan applications for 60 people who falsely claimed to be league...
lead_paragraph: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela has pleaded not guilty to defrauding a local bank of about $100,000. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, who headed the African National Congress Women's League, is accused of signing letters accompanying loan applications for 60 people who falsely claimed to be employees of the league. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, the ex-wife of former President Nelson Mandela, denied that she had signed the letters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Africa: Coffee Growers Form Group
snippet: Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, Rwanda and Ethiopia form group called Eastern African Fine Coffee Association to market their product to American and European consumers; Kenya, one of oldest coffee producers, represents only 2 percent of world m...
lead_paragraph: Six coffee-growing countries in East Africa have formed a private organization to market their product to American and European consumers. The group, called the Eastern African Fine Coffee Association, is made up of Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, Rwanda and Ethiopia. Based in Kampala, Uganda, the association will seek to increase the sale of coffee from the region. Kenya is one of the oldest coffee producers yet it represents only 2 percent of the world market. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: LIBERIA: 3 Aid Workers Missing; SOMALIA: Warning On Peace Talks; SOUTH AFRICA: I Was Duped, Winnie Mandela Says;.
lead_paragraph: LIBERIA: 3 AID WORKERS MISSING A Norwegian aid worker and two Liberian colleagues are still missing a week after their burned-out vehicle was found near the border with Ivory Coast, Norway's ambassador in the region, Egel Andhoy, said. Kare Lund, Emmanuel Sharpolu and Musa Kita, who all worked for the Adventist Relief and Development Agency, were last in radio contact on Feb. 27.    (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Airline Selects Airbus
snippet: Airbus Industrie wins order for 41 planes from South African Airways, defeating Boeing Co, which once supplied most of carrier's fleet (S)
lead_paragraph: Airbus won an order for 41 planes worth as much as $3.5 billion from South African Airways, defeating the Boeing Company, which once supplied most of the carrier's fleet. The airline chose Airbus because its planes are cheaper to fly and better suited to African airports, Andre Viljoen, the chief executive, said. South African Airways will purchase six A340-600 and six A340-300 Enhanced long-haul jetliners, plus 11 A319 and 15 A320 narrowbodies.

title: An African Literary Festival for the Age of Coronavirus
snippet: Book events worldwide are on hold, but Afrolit Sans Frontieres uses social media to host frank discussions around writing, creativity, sex and violence.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — For the novelist Maaza Mengiste, the coronavirus lockdowns and stay-at-home measures that have taken hold around the world have brought back the sense of exile she felt when she and her family fled Ethiopia in the 1970s.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Government Opposes Stoning Sentence; SOUTH AFRICA: Trouble For Winnie Mandela;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: GOVERNMENT OPPOSES STONING SENTENCE The government is "totally opposed" to an Islamic court's ruling that a single mother be stoned to death for having sex outside marriage and will aid the woman's appeal, Justice Minister Kanu Agabi said. On Monday, an Islamic court in the northern town of Funtua rejected Ms. Lawal's appeal against the stoning sentence. Nigeria is deeply divided about the application of Islamic law, which has been adopted by a dozen states in the mainly Muslim north. (AP)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Adoptions By Gay Couples Approved
snippet: South Africa's highest court rules gay and lesbian couples can adopt children; upholds lower court ruling striking down two laws that barred such adoptions (S)
lead_paragraph: The country's highest court ruled that gay and lesbian couples can adopt children. The ruling by the Constitutional Court affirmed a lower court ruling striking down provisions of two laws that barred such adoptions. The high court said that a child could receive proper care and support from a same-sex couple and that in prohibiting such adoptions the laws failed to consider adequately the interests of the child. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: Accord Signed;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: ACCORD SIGNED The government signed a peace agreement with rebel groups in a bid to end a four-and-a-half-year civil war. The agreements, signed in Sun City, South Africa, will see President Joseph Kabila remain as head of state during a transition of two years, extendable to three, leading to the first democratic elections since those on independence from Belgium in 1960. He will share power with four vice presidents; one from each of the two main rebel movements, one from the government and one from the opposition.    (AP)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Thinning Out Prisons; IVORY COAST: Rebels To Rejoin Government;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: THINNING OUT PRISONS President Mwai Kibaki freed 11,546 prisoners to ease crowding in prisons notorious among Kenyans as centers of malnutrition and disease. Kenya's 97 prisons hold tens of thousands of inmates, and the government blames a slow and corrupt judiciary for overcrowding. Most of those freed were petty or first-time offenders with a record of good conduct, a government statement said. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SUDAN: Goverment Agrees To Resume Talks; CONGO: Peacekeepers Fire At Protesters;.
lead_paragraph: SUDAN: GOVERMENT AGREES TO RESUME TALKS The government has agreed to return to peace negotiations a month after calling a halt to them because of military victories by rebels in the south. Sudanese officials said they had recaptured the southern town of Torit from the Sudan People's Liberation Army, which said that the government had lost a series of important battles. Despite the continued fighting, analysts consider the talks a breakthrough in ending one of Africa's most intractable conflicts. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Protean South African Blend
snippet: Eric Asimov comments on wines of South Africa; map (S)
lead_paragraph: THE wines of South Africa have largely been ignored in the American market. Burdened by the fading stigma of apartheid, and without the romantic imagery of, say, French and Italian wines, South Africa has had difficulty gaining traction here.

title: Returning to Africa With Logos and Experience
snippet: Basketball Without Borders brought 15 teenage basketball players from seven African countries to Texas for three-week program designed to develop talent overseas and provide young athletes with enriching educational experiences in US; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The three teenagers left Emmanuel Negedu's house in darkness, boarded a bus, then slept for much of the 12-hour trip to Lagos, Nigeria's biggest city, their eyes closed to what awaited them.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Police Officers Plead Guilty
lead_paragraph: Four police officers pleaded guilty to unleashing police dogs on three illegal immigrants from Mozambique in an attack that shocked the country when a videotape of the 1998 incident was broadcast on television last year. The officers have said they were training their dogs. Two other officers have denied the accusations and will go to trial. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZAMBIA: Rains Destroy Homes And Crops; LIBERIA: Rebels Close In On Capital;.
lead_paragraph: ZAMBIA: RAINS DESTROY HOMES AND CROPS More than 10,000 people are homeless as flooding swept away homes, roads and maize crops in the hunger-stricken Gwembe district south of the capital, Lusaka, officials said. Prolonged heavy rains have also damaged electricity and telephone poles, and many roads have become impassable. Zambia was already facing huge food shortages affecting more than a quarter of the population of almost 10 million.    (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Genital Cutting May Halt U.S. Deal; ANGOLA: Calling On Food Donors; SOUTH AFRICA: Government Criticizes Strike;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: GENITAL CUTTING MAY HALT U.S. DEAL Somali Bantu families who rushed to put young women through ritual genital cutting before being resettled to the United States are likely to be excluded from the program, an American official said. About 12,000 Somali Bantu exiled in Kenya had been given priority for resettlement. But genital cutting, sometimes called female circumcision, is illegal in the United States, so many families hurried the procedure before leaving. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Terror Warning; CONGO: 2 U.N. Observers Abducted;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: TERROR WARNING The American Embassy in Nairobi closed its doors amid heightened concerns of a terrorist attack against United States interests in Kenya. American officials have warned of such an attack for weeks and American diplomats have been offered voluntary evacuation from the country. But the situation grew more tense after a new warning of a possible attack issued by the Defense Intelligence Agency in Washington. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: An African Statesman
lead_paragraph: So far, Senegal is unique in Africa for making a peaceful transfer of power after its first President, Leopold Senghor, retired. Now the new President, Abdou Diouf, seeks to extend the record by legitimizing all political parties and expunging all past convictions on political or press control grounds.

title: Into Africa
snippet: mil's brief seizure of ballot boxes revd (S)
lead_paragraph: The President of Zambia had a warning for the West last week: “The risk or full‐scale, worldwide war is too grave to be‐ignored.” At the time, Kenneth D. Kaunda, visiting in Washington, was talking specifically about Rhodesia (where dozens of blacks were killed when Government troops, supposedly seeking guerrillas, invaded a rural meeting) and South Africa.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: RWANDA: Genocide Suspect ; CENTRAL AFRICA: Peace Accord; ZIMBABWE: 6 Farmers To Be Charged;.
lead_paragraph: RWANDA: GENOCIDE SUSPECT A senior Rwandan military commander was transferred to the international criminal tribunal in Tanzania after his arrest in Angola. The suspect, Augustin Bizimungu, led the Rwandan Army in 1994, when Hutu extremists killed an estimated 800,000 Tutsis and Hutu moderates. He faces 10 counts of genocide and crimes against humanity including rape and extermination.    (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: BURUNDI: Cease-Fire Is Signed; IVORY COAST: Foreigners Leave Town;.
lead_paragraph: BURUNDI: CEASE-FIRE IS SIGNED Burundi's government and one of two main rebel forces signed a cease-fire to try to end a civil war that has claimed 300,000 lives since 1993. President Pierre Buyoya and Pierre Nkurunzizasat, leader of the rebel Forces for the Defense of Democracy, signed the accord at an African summit meeting in Tanzania. The other rebel force, the National Liberation Front, was not invited to the meeting because it had refused to meet with Mr. Buyoya for earlier talks. The war has pitted rebels from the ethnic Hutu majority against the Tutsi-led army.    (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: Charges For Interlopers; MADAGASCAR: Storm Toll At 154;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: CHARGES FOR INTERLOPERS Sixty-four suspected mercenaries suspected of being hired to overthrow the government of Equatorial Guinea will face charges under Zimbabwe's aviation, firearms and immigration laws, Attorney General Bharat Patel said. The three-man flight crew will also be charged. The men, arrested Sunday when their plane stopped in Harare, are expected to appear in court today or Saturday.   (AP)

title: AIDS in South Africa
snippet: Editorial says fighting AIDS epidemic in South Africa is not helped when Pres Thabo Mbeki voices doubts about whether HIV causes AIDS, since this discourages the use of condoms; also notes that government failed to spend millions of dollars of las...
lead_paragraph: South Africa, the host of the world AIDS conference this week, has 4.2 million people who are infected with the AIDS virus, more than any other nation. It also has the world's fastest-growing epidemic, with infection rates that rose from 13 percent to 20 percent in the last two years. While AIDS is tragic everywhere, it is particularly so in South Africa, a nation with a wealthier and more effective government and health care system than other sub-Saharan African countries.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Curfew After Unrest; NIGERIA: Death Toll Rises In Blast;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: CURFEW AFTER UNREST A dawn-to-dusk curfew was imposed in the southern oil city of Warri after a third night of ethnic violence that brought the number of deaths to more than 20, including members of the security forces. Youths went on the rampage overnight in Warri, in the oil-rich Niger Delta, killing police officers and setting dozens of homes and offices ablaze, witnesses said. The latest violence has pitted ethnic Urhobos against Itsekiris in a long-standing dispute over the location of government offices and amenities.

title: Africa's AIDS War
snippet: News analysis of AIDS epidemic in Africa; says now that world's biggest pharmaceutical companies have been forced into painful negotiations over patient rights and price of medicines, question suddenly is no longer whether Africans will get life-s...
lead_paragraph: This week, the unthinkable happened in Africa: the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies were forced into a painful negotiation over patent rights and the price of AIDS medicines. Suddenly, the question is no longer whether Africans will get life-saving drug cocktails, but how.

title: The South African Queen
snippet: Neil Gordon reviews book The Madonna of Excelsior by Zakes Mda; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: THE MADONNA

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Embassy Reopens; UGANDA: Abducted Girls Released;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: EMBASSY REOPENS The American Embassy in Nairobi reopened after closing for several days in response to fears of a terrorist attack. The embassy, which replaced one destroyed by Al Qaeda bombers in 1998, is designed to withstand attack. Kenyan soldiers stood guard as diplomats returned to work. Meanwhile, the presidents of Kenya and Tanzania criticized the American and British governments for issuing warnings against travel to east Africa, likening the advisories to economic sanctions.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: American Reporter Goes On Trial; MOZAMBIQUE: Presidential Candidate Chosen;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: AMERICAN REPORTER GOES ON TRIAL On the opening day of his trial, an American reporter who is the first journalist to be tried under the country's new press law pleaded not guilty to publishing false information. Andrew Meldrum, the Zimbabwe correspondent for The Guardian, reported that an opposition sympathizer had been beheaded by supporters of President Robert Mugabe.
