The story, first reported in a local newspaper and then picked up by a number of news organizations, turned out to be false and was retracted by the paper, The Daily News. A reporter for The Daily News is to go on trial later this month in connection with the report. Mr. Meldrum maintains that he did not intend to publish false information and that the police were unable confirm or deny the account of the woman's death.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SOMALIA: U.N. Worker Kidnapped; SUDAN: Egyptian Leader Warns Against Split;.
lead_paragraph: SOMALIA: U.N. WORKER KIDNAPPED A United Nations staff member was abducted this week in Mogadishu in the fourth such incident in the capital this year. Five armed men kidnapped Mohammed Farah Omar of the Food and Agriculture Organization outside his home on Tuesday morning, relatives said. The three previous victims, seized by members of the militia groups that rule much of Somalia, were all released.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Miner's Profit Falls
snippet: Anglo American reports net income fell fifty percent in 2002, to $1.56 billion, from $3.09 billion in 2001 (S)
lead_paragraph: The world's biggest precious-metals company, Anglo American, said net income fell 50 percent last year, to $1.56 billion, or $1.10 a share, from $3.09 billion, or $2.07 a share, a year earlier. Earnings before one-time items and goodwill costs rose to $1.76 billion from $1.68 billion. Profit was helped by a 25 percent jump in gold prices last year, the biggest rise since 1980, and a 16 percent increase in sales at De Beers, in which Anglo owns a 45 percent stake. Profit at Anglo American Platinum fell 28 percent, hurt by the stronger rand.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Former Foes Discuss Alliance
snippet: Leaders of governing African National Congress and New National Party, which created apartheid, meet to discuss forming alliance; New National Party pulls out of Democratic Alliance, nation's leading white opposition party, after its leaders clash...
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the governing African National Congress and the New National Party, which created apartheid, met to discuss forming an alliance. The New National Party pulled out of the Democratic Alliance, the nation's leading white opposition party, after its leaders clashed. Dozens of New National Party members oppose the proposed partnership with the African National Congress but congress officials said they were willing to consider it.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Former Foes Discuss Alliance
snippet: Leaders of governing African National Congress and New National Party, which created apartheid, meet to discuss forming alliance; New National Party pulls out of Democratic Alliance, nation's leading white opposition party, after its leaders clash...
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the governing African National Congress and the New National Party, which created apartheid, met to discuss forming an alliance. The New National Party pulled out of the Democratic Alliance, the nation's leading white opposition party, after its leaders clashed. Dozens of New National Party members oppose the proposed partnership with the African National Congress but congress officials said they were willing to consider it.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SUDAN: Plane Bombs Chad Side Of Border; UGANDA: War Crimes Inquiry;.
lead_paragraph: SUDAN: PLANE BOMBS CHAD SIDE OF BORDER In a battle against rebel insurgency in the western Darfur area, a Sudanese plane bombed a border town in neighboring Chad, killing 2 civilians and 15 others, a United Nations official said. The official said it was the first time since war broke out a year ago between the Sudanese government and guerillas in Darfur that Chadian territory had been bombed. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Little Research Is Done in Africa by or for Nurses
snippet: While most health care in Africa is delivered by nurses rather than doctors, little medical research is done to benefit them, according to a study.
lead_paragraph: While most health care in Africa is delivered by nurses rather than doctors, little medical research is done by nurses or for them, and too much is determined by donors’ priorities rather than by the challenges that African nurses actually are facing, according to a new study.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: MOROCCO: Separatists To Release Prisoners; ZAMBIA: President Dodges Impeachment;.
lead_paragraph: MOROCCO: SEPARATISTS TO RELEASE PRISONERS The Polisario Front, a guerrilla group that has been fighting a 30-year war for independence of the contested territory of Western Sahara, said it would release 243 Moroccan prisoners at the "renewed urging of the Spanish president, José María Aznar, as a humanitarian gesture," the Spanish news agency EFE reported. The move follows a call by the United Nations Security Council last month for a referendum on the future of Western Sahara, a former Spanish colony. Almost 1,000 Moroccan soldiers and officers are still being held by the Polisario, human rights groups estimate. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Searching for a Promised Land in South Africa
snippet: “A Man of Good Hope,” a new musical drama opening in London from the South African Isango Ensemble, tells the story of a Somalian migrant.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — “They steal our jobs. They steal our women. They sell drugs.” The conversation about migrants could have been taking place on any street corner in London, a post-”Brexit” conversation in a climate increasingly hostile to anyone perceived as an outsider.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: UGANDA: Rebels Declare Cease-Fire; NIGERIA: 64 Die In Ethnic Clashes;.
lead_paragraph: UGANDA: REBELS DECLARE CEASE-FIRE The Lord's Resistance Army, a rebel group that has long terrorized northern Uganda, told a group of religious leaders that it had declared a cease-fire. The government immediately said such a move, if carried out, could lead to face-to-face talks on permanently ending the fighting.    Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: South African Lawyers
lead_paragraph: While Georgetown undergraduates continue to demonstrate against the university's investment in companies with interests in South Africa, the Georgetown University Law Center has established a program to help black lawyers from South Africa win the right to practice before that country's Supreme Court.

title: In Africa : A damaging warning
snippet: The war on terrorism looks very different from abroad. Like most Americans, I too have been horrified by terrorist attacks in various parts of the world. But recently, the war hit closer to home..My wife Sara and I are scheduled to take 20 student...
lead_paragraph: The war on terrorism looks very different from abroad. Like most Americans, I too have been horrified by terrorist attacks in various parts of the world. But recently, the war hit closer to home.

title: Conflict in Africa's horn
lead_paragraph: The war that killed 70,000 people between 1998 and 2000 has stopped, but the conflict between Ethiopia and Eritrea has not ended. The UN Security Council would encourage resumption of fighting if it reduced the 3,000-man peacekeeping force on the border.

title: The Wars in North Africa
snippet: Russell F Weigley reviews following books: Alamein by Jon Latimer; and An Army at Dawn: The War in North Africa, 1942-1943: Volume I of the Liberation Trilogy by Rick Atkinson (M)
lead_paragraph: ALAMEIN

title: Don’t Let Ebola Dehumanize Africa
snippet: Fear-mongering about the disease is threatening to reverse decades of progress for the continent's image.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, I posted a note on Facebook about my scheduled concert next week at Carnegie Hall honoring the late South African singer Miriam Makeba, who was known widely as Mama Africa. I was saddened to see the following comments appear: “Instead of mama africa it should be mama ebola” and “I wonder if she is bringing aby Ebloa [sic] with her?”

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: Getting Tougher With Whites; CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Deal With Libya;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: GETTING TOUGHER WITH WHITES The government plans to stiffen the penalties faced by white farmers who defy eviction orders. Farmers currently face a fine of about $385 if they ignore government orders to leave their farms; under the proposed plan, which requires Parliament's approval, the farmers would face fines of about $1,925. Officials say bigger fines are necessary to persuade white farmers to hand over their properties to blacks in compliance with the land-redistribution program. A tiny white minority owns more than half the fertile land.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Presidential Race Begins; ANGOLA: A Call To Lift Penalties ;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA BURIES ITS DEAD Trucks ferried bodies from hospitals in Nigeria's northern city of Kaduna for mass burials as calm returned after sectarian riots over the Miss World beauty pageant that killed at least 215 people. Shops, banks and schools reopened in the city. Warning shots rang out in Kaduna overnight as troops enforced a curfew. The violence began over a newspaper article that dismissed criticisms of the beauty pageant in terms that Muslims considered insulting.    Reuters

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: Two Views Of Anti-Mugabe Strike; SUDAN: Agreement With Rebels On Civilians;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: TWO VIEWS OF ANTI-MUGABE STRIKE Businesses across the country were crippled by a strike against President Robert Mugabe, opposition leaders reported, while a police spokesman called the strike "a total failure." Leaders of the Movement for Democratic Change said nearly 200 opposition supporters had been arrested, many pulled from food lines or arrested in their homes. Party officials said the walkout had been called to protest repression against opposition supporters by Mr. Mugabe, whose re-election last year was marred by widespread charges of fraud, and an economic crisis that has put nearly half of Zimbabwe's 11 million people at risk of starvation. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: South African Riots Over ‘Xenophobia’ Prompt Backlash Across Africa
snippet: After rioters in Johannesburg targeted immigrants from other African countries, South Africa has been hit with boycotts and cancellations of soccer games and concerts.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Pop stars have announced a boycott. Air Tanzania has suspended flights to Johannesburg. Madagascar and Zambia are refusing to send their soccer teams. Nigeria has recalled its ambassador and pulled out of a major economic forum.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Officers Sentenced In Dog Attack
snippet: Four police officers who used their police dogs to attack three illegal immigrants from Mozambique are sentenced to prison terms ranging from four to five years, South Africa; officers were videotaped by colleague and tape was broadcast on televis...
lead_paragraph: Four police officers who used their police dogs to attack three illegal immigrants from Mozambique were sentenced to prison terms ranging from four to five years. The officers were videotaped by a colleague as they were encouraging their dogs to bite the immigrants. The tape touched off an outcry when it was broadcast on state television last year. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: Boat Massacres Reported; MOROCCO: Writer Spurns Prize Over Illiteracy;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: BOAT MASSACRES REPORTED United Nations officials said they were investigating reports that up to 100 people might have been killed when armed fighters attacked several passenger boats in Congo's lawless northeast last week. United Nations peacekeepers could not confirm the death toll, which was reported by survivors in Mokambo, 62 miles northeast of the town of Bunia. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Hearings Start On Soccer Deaths
snippet: South African commission of inquiry opens public hearings into stampede at soccer match in Johannesburg three months ago that killed 43 fans (S)
lead_paragraph: Three months after a stampede killed 43 fans at a soccer match in Johannesburg, a commission of inquiry opened public hearings and was told by the general manager of the stadium where the calamity unfolded that extra measures had been taken to accommodate the large crowd expected for the match. The victims of the worst accident in the country's sports history died as thousands of fans tried to make their way into the already crowded stadium for the start of one of the season's biggest games. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: Tornado'S Toll Lowered; CONGO: Uganda Sets Withdrawal Date;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: TORNADO'S TOLL LOWERED A tornado that swept through a remote town in western Congo earlier this month killed 17 people, not the 164 initially feared. A delegation of experts discovered that many residents of Yumbi, in the northwest of Bandundu Province, had been rescued from under the debris of their homes and others who had been declared dead had merely fled into the surrounding jungle. Despite the lower death toll, the impact of the storm on Feb. 2 remained devastating. At least 4,000 people were injured and at least 1,700 people lost their homes, officials said.    Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: Africa NIGERIA: Obasanjo To Seek Second Term ; NIGERIA: Death Penalty Sought ; LIBERIA: Independent Newspaper Closed ; Aid For 31 African Countries.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: OBASANJO TO SEEK SECOND TERM President Olusegun Obasanjo said he would seek a second term and run in next year's election. Mr. Obasanjo, who was also the country's military ruler in the late 1970's, won the presidency in 1999 with strong backing from fellow retired generals.

title: OUT OF AFRICA
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is astonishing to read an article entitled ''Kenya Seen Through Writers' Eyes'' (Travel, Jan. 12) that does not mention a single indigenous Kenyan writer. Among the leading Kenyan writers are Ngugi wa Thiong'o, Grace Ogot and Meja Mwangi.

title: No Cup, No Joy in South Africa
snippet: South African fans are stunned by nation's failure to be chosen to host soccer's 2006 World Cup; vote dashes hopes of crisis-ridden continent desperate for something to cheer about; South Africa had gone to great lengths to press bid; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: South Africa is nothing if not soccer-mad, so the past few weeks have been crazed as the country collectively counted down the seconds to today's vote on who will host the World Cup in 2006.

title: ON DOLE AND SOUTH AFRICA
lead_paragraph: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, had no more than made his campaign for the Presidency more or less official Tuesday than TransAfrica, the Washington-based black American lobby for Africa and the Caribbean, singled him out as a ''friend of apartheid.''

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: Ministers Arrested; NIGERIA: Anticorruption Law Tightened;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: MINISTERS ARRESTED The authorities arrested about 20 ministers who carried wooden crosses as they marched to police headquarters in the capital, Harare, to protest laws restricting freedom of assembly. Under the laws, approved by Parliament last year, citizens must get permission from the police before holding public meetings. The ministers said intelligence officers recently harassed a congregation that was listening to testimony from victims of political violence.    Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: TUNISIA: Trial For Attack Suspect'S Uncle; MALAWI: President Will Need New Job; NIGERIA: Crime-Fighting Aid From U.S.;.
lead_paragraph: TUNISIA: TRIAL FOR ATTACK SUSPECT'S UNCLE The uncle of a Tunisian suspected of bombing a famous synagogue in April, killing 21 people, will go on trial next week, Reuters reported, quoting court officials and lawyers. Belgacem Nouar, an uncle of Nizar Nouar, is accused of concealing information and helping his nephew plan the suicide attack. The younger Mr. Nouar, who exploded a gasoline truck just outside the El Ghriba synagogue, was immolated; Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: RWANDA: TribunalS Defense Lawyers Strike; CONGO: Armed U.N. Convoy Off To Aid Villages;.
lead_paragraph: RWANDA: TRIBUNAL'S DEFENSE LAWYERS STRIKE Lawyers defending suspects facing charges in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda began a three-day strike. The lawyers said they backed a list of defendant demands, including rights to bail, to subpoena defense witnesses, and to know the identity of prosecution witnesses sometimes protected by the international court, based in Tanzania. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: European Warning; UGANDA: No More Mr. Nice Guy; SWAZILAND: New Constitution On Hold;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: EUROPEAN WARNING The European Union will withhold $469 million in aid promised for Ivory Coast's rebuilding until combatants in the civil war comply with a stalled peace accord, the European Commission president, Romano Prodi, said. He insisted that the accord signed in January had to be fully implemented before the money would be distributed. "The money is on the table," Mr. Prodi said. "We're waiting for the country to make progress. We have no sticks, only carrots." (AP)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: 63 Die Of Hunger In Country'S Second City;.
lead_paragraph: SRI LANKA: HEAVY COMBAT BETWEEN REBEL FACTIONS Heavy fighting erupted Friday between the main Tamil Tiger rebel group and a breakaway faction, the country's first major violence since a 2002 cease-fire halted its civil war, the guerrillas and military said. A spokesman for the breakaway faction said fighters from the main group had invaded its territory by crossing the Verugal River. The Sri Lankan army has a large presence near the river, raising fears that it could be drawn into any conflict.    (AP)

title: American Held Hostage in Africa Is Freed
snippet: Jeffery Woodke, an aid worker abducted in Niger by militants, was released after more than six years in captivity. A second hostage was also released: Olivier Dubois, a French journalist who disappeared in April 2021.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American aid worker abducted by militants more than six years ago in West Africa has been freed, his wife and U.S. officials said on Monday, but the circumstances of his release were not immediately clear.

title: Africa’s Tennis Talent, Though Obscure, Is Burgeoning
snippet: The continent has skilled players, but a lack of resources and opportunities, including access to top competition, keeps them from breaking through.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, I was a Peace Corps volunteer living in a village of mud huts on the dry Sahel landscape of northern Ivory Coast. The nearest market town, Ferkessédougou, was 20 miles away, and every Thursday morning I would mount my Trek 820 and pedal out past the last huts, announcing in limited Senufo-Palaka my intention to ride to Ferké and return by sundown.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: Police Break Up Siege Of French; RWANDA: 18 Sentenced In Killing Frenzy;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: POLICE BREAK UP SIEGE OF FRENCH Riot police officers dispersed protesters outside a French base in Abidjan who had demonstrated through the night to urge the soldiers to leave the country. The protests followed clashes over the weekend between Ivoirian soldiers and French forces policing a cease-fire line through the center of the country. The French Foreign Ministry said a pullout was "out of the question." French troops were sent to Ivory Coast in November 2002, two months after a rebellion boiled over into civil war, to police a cease-fire. (Agence France-Presse)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Miner's Earnings Fall
snippet: Anglo American's first-half net earnings are down 7 percent, to $884 million, because of decline in diamond sales and metals prices (S)
lead_paragraph: Anglo American, the giant mining company, announced that net earnings for the first half, before exceptional items, were down 7 percent, to $884 million, from $951 million during the period a year earlier. The company said a steep decline in diamond sales and a fall in base and ferrous metal prices had eaten into the company's earnings. With the prices of platinum and palladium plunging in recent weeks and little prospect of a big bump in diamond sales, the second half of the year does not appear likely to deliver better news. Anglo American holds a 45 percent stake in De Beers, the world's biggest diamond miner. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: AIDS Drugs in Africa
snippet: Free medicine offers the poor a chance to live.
lead_paragraph: Free medicine offers the poor a chance to live.

title: Looking Into the Decline in African-American Players
snippet: African-Americans make up about 8.5 percent of major league rosters, down from 19 percent in 1986. Are youth travel leagues and college scholarships contributing factors?
lead_paragraph: Every player in the major leagues will wear No. 42 on Monday as baseball pays its annual tribute to Jackie Robinson, who integrated the game in 1947 and whose life story will play out in movie theaters nationwide this weekend. Yet few of the players wearing Robinson’s number will be African-American, a trend that has grown increasingly troubling to major league officials.

title: African Islamists Free French Captives
snippet: A French family held hostage for two months by Islamist militants in West Africa has been released, French and Cameroonian officials announced on Friday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French family held hostage for two months by Islamist militants in West Africa has been released, French and Cameroonian officials announced on Friday.

title: Fighting AIDS in Africa
snippet: Editorial says announcement by Indian drug company Cipla that it would sell AIDS therapy for $600 a year or less to African countries is step toward commuting death sentences now hanging over 25 million Africans infected with HIV; says Bush admini...
lead_paragraph: The recent announcement by the Indian drug company Cipla that it would sell AIDS therapy for $600 a year or less to African countries is a step toward commuting the death sentences now hanging over the 25 million Africans infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. A year and a half ago, few people even dreamed that the citizens of poor nations would be able to get the antiretroviral drugs that have turned AIDS into a manageable disease in rich countries. Now, each week brings new developments on fighting AIDS in poor nations, and a stronger international consensus that poor countries can provide treatment to those infected and improve their prevention campaigns to slow the spread of the virus. None of this will be possible, however, without leadership from the Bush administration, which must take a more aggressive role in combatting AIDS abroad than its predecessor.

title: For Sale: African Art, In Abundance
snippet: Antiques column on late Hubert Goldet's collection of African tribal art, to be auctioned in Paris; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ''You have to know how to get rid of ideas that turn out to be wrong,'' said Hubert Goldet (1945-2000), a Parisian who collected contemporary paintings as a young man, then switched to African tribal art for the rest of his life.

title: The AIDS Epidemic in Africa
snippet: Editorial on United Nations prediction that about half of all 15-year-olds in AIDS-plagued African countries will eventually die of AIDS says domestic commitment and international support are critical to saving Africa's next generation
lead_paragraph: The United Nations' prediction this week that about half of all 15-year-olds in AIDS-plagued African countries will eventually die of AIDS is the latest measure of the devastating impact of the epidemic on the African continent. It is difficult to imagine what kind of future may be in store for countries if half of their adult populations will have died of the disease within coming decades.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: RWANDA: Europeans Cite Flaws In Election; IVORY COAST: Suspects Said To Admit Plot;.
lead_paragraph: RWANDA: EUROPEANS CITE FLAWS IN ELECTION European Union observers said Rwanda's presidential election did not entirely meet "free and fair standards" but was an important step toward democracy. The incumbent president, Paul Kagame, won 95 percent of the vote in the first presidential election since 1994. The observers noted voter intimidation and stuffed ballot boxes. "The optimum conditions for a free and fair election were probably not met, but this presidential election is a promise for the opening of a new democratic era for Rwanda," the head of the observer mission, Colette Flesch, said. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: Newspaper'S Equipment Seized; NIGERIA: Taylor Warned On Liberia;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: NEWSPAPER'S EQUIPMENT SEIZED The police seized computers and other equipment from the offices of the country's biggest and only independent daily newspaper, The Daily News, a lawyer for the paper said. The paper, with a circulation of 100,000, was shut down by armed police officers on Friday because it had failed to register with a state commission. The paper is fiercely critical of President Robert G. Mugabe. "They are simply using brute force," Gugulethu Moyo, the lawyer for the paper, said in a telephone interview. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Stoning Sentence Stands; ZAMBIA: Food Aid Agreement;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: STONING SENTENCE STANDS The government of Katsina state, the home of Amina Lawal, who was convicted by an Islamic court of having sex outside wedlock, will not intervene to overturn her sentence of death by stoning, a spokesman said. The fate of Ms. Lawal, 30, now rests solely with her legal appeals, as the federal government has also refused to gainsay the court. The decision is a blow for rights campaigners and organizers of the Miss World contest, who had hoped the issue might be settled early in order to head off protests from beauty contestants in Lagos, where the event is to take place in November. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: MOROCCO: Frenchman Convicted Of Insurrection; ZIMBABWE: Banned Paper Allowed To Reopen;.
lead_paragraph: MOROCCO: FRENCHMAN CONVICTED OF INSURRECTION A Frenchman was convicted and sentenced to life in prison on charges of trying to organize an uprising. The man, Pierre Robert, 31, a convert to Islam, made a final plea of innocence and asked King Mohamed VI to intervene. Mr. Robert and 33 others on trial with him were arrested after suicide bombings in Casablanca on May 16 killed 45 people, including 12 bombers. His case was not directly related to the bombings. Instead, prosecutors said he led a network of Islamic militants in northern Morocco plotting to foment an uprising.    (AP)

title: Action on AIDS in Africa
snippet: Editorial lauds Clinton Administration for using its monthlong leadership of Security Council to put African AIDS crisis at top of world's security agenda
lead_paragraph: Imagine 40 million hungry and destitute orphans in sub-Saharan Africa by the year 2010 -- roaming the streets without schooling or work, prime candidates for the criminal gangs, marauding militias and child armies that have slaughtered and mutilated tens of thousands of civilians in countries like Sierra Leone and Liberia in the last decade.

title: South Africa’s World Cup Illusions
snippet: Hosting the World Cup failed to deliver the promised boost to our economy.
lead_paragraph: It’s the soccer off-season in South Africa these days. Cape Town’s huge Green Point Stadium — purpose-built for the 2010 FIFA World Cup — sits dormant, an imposing but vacant sentry blotting the sweeping ocean views once enjoyed by the area’s wealthy residents. The $600 million, 55,000-seat behemoth was, for the past three seasons, home turf for Ajax Cape Town, the city’s only representative in South Africa’s premier soccer league.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: New Government To Tackle Prisons; CAMEROON: Urine Drinkers Are Warned;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: NEW GOVERNMENT TO TACKLE PRISONS The new government is vowing to overhaul the country's notoriously overcrowded and violent prison system. "The government is committed to reforming the prisons because people there are not treated like human beings," Home Affairs Minister Moody Awori told Agence France-Presse. Inmates have complained of widespread torture, illness and mistreatment in the prisons, which squeeze 50,000 people into cells designed for 15,000.

title: Melania Trump: Out of Africa, Still in Costume
snippet: During her first solo trip abroad, the first lady said people should focus on what she does, not what she wears. But she still seems dedicated to dressing a part.
lead_paragraph: In the end the most viral moment of Melania Trump’s five-day, four-country solo trip, which came to a close Sunday when she stepped off the plane at Joint Base Andrews, had to do with clothes, as it so often does.

title: African Food, Comfortable Informality
snippet: Stephanie Lyness reviews Caffe Adulis in New Haven, Conn; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: CAFFÉ ADULIS is an Eritrean restaurant in downtown New Haven on the edge of the Yale campus. The restaurant is a loftlike modern space with clean white walls broken by areas of exposed brick and some bright contemporary art.

title: First African to Play in the Major Leagues Is a ‘Pinnacle’ for Baseball
snippet: Gift Ngoepe of the Pittsburgh Pirates has become the first African major league player. His path, meandering and sometimes painful, has never been conventional.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Every promotion to the major leagues is a triumph. The rookie has ascended to the top of his profession, realized his dream, validated his toil and sacrifice. He deserves the support that awaits him.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: LIBERIA: Rebel Leader Sought; BURUNDI: Presidential Transition;.
lead_paragraph: LIBERIA: REBEL LEADER SOUGHT Wanted for a campaign of rapes and mutilations in Sierra Leone and accused in the assassination of Felix Doh, a top rebel commander in western Ivory Coast, the warlord Sam Bockarie has found shelter in Liberia, the chief investigator for a special United Nations court said. Mr. Bockarie has been in hiding since his March 10 indictment by the Sierra Leone-based court for crimes against humanity. The investigator, Al White, called on the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, to turn him in or risk prosecution for harboring a war criminal. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: An African Success Story
snippet: Editorial lauds Ghana as welcome African example of legitimate democracy and successful economic reform; praises peaceful transfer of power from civilian government that grew out of military regime to opposition, which won recent election (S)
lead_paragraph: In its first two decades of independence, the West African nation of Ghana was an archetypal political disaster, brought low by successive coups and dictatorships, corruption and near total economic collapse. Today, Ghana is a welcome African example of legitimate democracy and successful economic reform. In an unusually peaceful transfer of power, a civilian government that grew out of a military regime has accepted an election defeat and surrendered power to the opposition.

title: Drugs for AIDS in Africa
snippet: Editorial urges Clinton Administration to stop pressuring South Africa to change law that would allow it to make cheap versions of still-patented drugs for AIDS or to import them at less than manufacturers want to charge; says while protecting int...
lead_paragraph: The average African nation spends less than $10 per person each year on health care. The mix of drugs, including the new protease inhibitors, necessary to turn AIDS from a death sentence into a chronic disease costs at least $12,000 per person each year. That disparity virtually guarantees that most of the 22 million Africans infected with the AIDS virus will not get the best available treatment. Few will even be able to afford less expensive life-prolonging drugs such as AZT or ddI or -- far cheaper and just as crucial -- medicines to fight the infections that accompany AIDS.

title: Report Optimistic on Africa Economies
snippet: A new report by McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, presents Africa as a continent of growing national economies and opportunities for foreign investment.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Africa is often depicted as a place of war, disease and poverty, with a begging bowl extended to the world. But a new report paints a much more optimistic portrait of a continent with growing national economies and an expanding consumer class that offers foreign investors the highest rates of return in the developing world.

title: African Photos
lead_paragraph: ''New World Africans: 19th-Century Images of Blacks in South Africa and the Caribbean,'' an exhibition of 19th century photographs, will be on view through Sept. 7 at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black play includes photographs of people at work as well as studio portraits; among the photographers in the show are the noted Brazilian artist Marc Ferrez. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: Thousands Flee New Fighting; IVORY COAST: French Foreign Minister To Visit;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: THOUSANDS FLEE NEW FIGHTING Tens of thousands of people have been displaced as fighting has flared in the northeast Ituri region despite a truce signed there this week by three rebel groups. Displaced civilians have taken refuge in camps set up by local churches or have been taken in by local residents. Aid organizations were distributing food and medical supplies to the refugees.    (Agence France-Presse)

title: South Africa Is Outraged by a Shortcut to a Wedding
snippet: The use of a military air base to transport civilian guests to the wedding of a wealthy family has set off anger.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — It was to be an affair to remember. The bride was a daughter of a powerful and politically connected immigrant family. Her parents booked all 338 rooms in one of South Africa’s most lavish resorts, complete with exclusive access to its artificial beach. Kathakali dancers with painted faces and turbaned Rajasthani musicians from the family’s native country, India, performed for the guests. A pontoon carried the happy couple across an imitation Roman bath to greet their guests.

title: War in the Horn of Africa
snippet: Washington should use its influence to push for a swift cessation of hostilities, lest the conflict pull in neighboring countries and explode over the entire region.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to wink at Ethiopia’s stunningly successful offensive in Somalia. It pushed back a hateful Islamic militia that was defying the United Nations, threatening to impose religious tyranny and, according to Washington, harboring international terrorists. The Bush administration quickly succumbed to temptation, lauding Ethiopia’s attacks as a legitimate response to “aggression.”

title: Europe, Asia, Africa
snippet: <em style=
lead_paragraph: EUROPE

title: A Diverse Africa at the Smithsonian
snippet: Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History opens new permanent exhibition on Africa; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: One exhibit shows step by step how Nakunte Diarra, an artisan from Mali, uses mud and other organic ingredients to dye cloth. Another, a detailed floor plan, visually condenses the sprawling Makola market in the Ghanaian city of Accra into a two-dimensional rendition of its teeming activity. And a life-size television monitor shows two Somalis, who now live here in Washington, sharing memories of growing up in migrant herding communities.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: UGANDA: Soldiers Executed; CONGO REPUBLIC: Ebola Toll Reaches 88; KENYA: Central Banker Resigns;.
lead_paragraph: UGANDA: SOLDIERS ARE EXECUTED Three Ugandan soldiers have been executed after their court-martial convictions on murder charges, the army said. A spokesman, Maj. Shaban Bantariza, said the executions were held at the scenes of the crimes so that victims' families could witness the sentences being carried out. Richard Wigiri, Kambacho Ssenyonjo and Alfred Okech, all privates, were executed by firing squads on Monday, a government official said. The last public executions of soldiers took place a year ago when two soldiers found guilty of murdering an Irish priest and two other people were shot by firing squad.   (Agence France-Presse)

title: Jihadists Deepen Collaboration in North Africa
snippet: The active coordination is turning one of the most inhospitable territories on earth into a complex security challenge for African and global forces.
lead_paragraph: SAHARA DESERT, Niger — A group of light armored vehicles skated over the moonscape of the Sahara, part of one of the largest detachments the French military has deployed here since colonial times. Its mission is growing ever more urgent: to cut smuggling routes used by jihadists who have turned this inhospitable terrain into a sprawling security challenge for African and international forces alike.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Dismay Over Loss Of Territory;.
lead_paragraph: YUGOSLAVIA: CONVICTIONS IN KOSOVO KILLINGS A Serbian military court jailed two Yugoslav Army officers and two former soldiers for three to seven years for the murders of two Kosovo Albanian civilians in April 1999. The war crimes trial was the second to be heard in Yugoslavia, a federation of Serbia and Montenegro, since NATO's bombing campaign ended Serbia's repression of the majority Albanian population in Kosovo in the summer of 1999. A third case, against two former Serbian policemen charged with killing 19 Albanian civilians in March 1999, opened this week.

title: A Smart African Itinerary
snippet: Editorial says Pres Clinton's trip to Nigeria will demonstrate US support of Pres Olusegun Obasanjo's efforts for democratic reform, but Washington will have to vigilantly monitor performance of Nigerian troops who are being trained as peacekeeper...
lead_paragraph: President Clinton has devoted unusual energy to strengthening ties between Africa and the United States. But some of Mr. Clinton's past efforts have led him to embrace leaders who were neither democrats nor statesmen. The journey he embarks on today is more promising.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ALGERIA: Chirac To Make State Visit; MOZAMBIQUE: Convictions In Reporter'S Killing;.
lead_paragraph: ALGERIA: CHIRAC TO MAKE STATE VISIT President Jacques Chirac of France will make a state visit to Algeria from March 2 to 4 as part of French efforts to improve relations. On Feb. 5, the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, will visit Paris. It will be Mr. Chirac's second visit to Algeria — but his first official state visit — and the fourth by a French president since Algeria obtained its independence from France in 1962. Relations between France and Algeria have been difficult and complicated since Algeria won its independence after a bitter eight-year war that caused the death of hundreds of thousands and the expulsion of large numbers of French settlers. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: LIBERIA: Leader Agrees To Truce; ZIMBABWE: President'S Rival Still In Jail;.
lead_paragraph: LIBERIA: LEADER AGREES TO TRUCE With rebels bearing down on the capital, President Charles Taylor told international mediators that he was ready to resume negotiations. The insurgents said they too were willing to stop fighting, but only if government forces stopped attacking them. "I think it is a good sign that both sides are pulling back, halting hostilities so that negotiations for a comprehensive peace agreement can be reached," Ghana's foreign minister, Nana Akuffo Addo, said after a meeting with Mr. Taylor. "For the sake of the people of this country, these hostilities must stop." (AP)

title: IN THE HEART OF AFRICA
lead_paragraph: THE ROAD TO Nsukka in eastern Nigeria is rutted and crumpled, the aging asphalt torn like a ragged strip of tar paper.

title: The Challenge for South Africa
snippet: Editorial contends that most important task facing Thabo Mbeki, who will become president following African National Congress's apparent election victory, is to improve life for millions of poor blacks living in South Africa's slums
lead_paragraph: The slums in South Africa are as bleak as any in the world -- miles of single-room hovels, each holding a huge family or two, with no electricity or water and only a bucket for waste. Apartheid forced millions of blacks into these slums, and many have not been able to leave. The most important task facing Thabo Mbeki, who will become president following the African National Congress's apparent election victory yesterday, is to improve life for these poor.

title: Images out of Africa
snippet: Marion Lesage is packing for New York: pale muslin to veil loins, skinny brown legs and bared feet, and a brilliant sunset orange and brown head wrap.. In these frozen January temperatures? She must be mad. But Lesage is not organizing her persona...
lead_paragraph: Marion Lesage is packing for New York: pale muslin to veil loins, skinny brown legs and bared feet, and a brilliant sunset orange and brown head wrap.

title: The World Bank’s Diminishing Role in Africa
snippet: Ideally, the World Bank should work toward the goal of putting itself out of a job in Africa.
lead_paragraph: Two recent African events illustrate how much the landscape for development finance has changed — and what role the World Bank will play in the future.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: U.N. Troops To Expand Patrol; ETHIOPIA: High Risk Of Malaria; SOMALIA: 2 Arrested In Killing Of Aid Worker;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: U.N. TROOPS TO EXPAND PATROL Peacekeepers will begin to deploy next week deeper into Ituri Province, in the northeast, to try to stop further ethnic bloodshed, said William Swing, head of the United Nations mission. At least 65 people, including 40 children, were shot and hacked to death on Monday in Katshelli, 38 miles from Bunia, the province's main town, where peacekeepers have already deployed. Fighting between militias for control of the mineral-rich region has killed more than 50,000 people since 1999.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: SUDAN: New Bid For Peace; KENYA: Aides Fired For Opposing President;.
lead_paragraph: SUDAN: NEW BID FOR PEACE Rebels and government officials met in Kenya for the start of talks widely viewed as the best chance yet of ending a 19-year war that has killed two million people. The negotiations, scheduled to last around five weeks, follow a round of talks in July that raised hopes for a comprehensive cease-fire. The rebels want southern Sudan, which is mainly animist with a small percentage of Christians and Muslims, to have more autonomy from the mainly Muslim north and want exemption from Islamic law, which has been applied countrywide. The government agreed to those demands last month, signing a framework deal that will allow southerners to opt for secession after a six-year period of administrative autonomy. (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Diamond Sales Down
snippet: De Beers reports its sales of rough diamonds fell to $2.62 billion in first half of year, down 26 percent from record high last year because of falling United States demand; says full-year sales will be $4.8 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: De Beers said its sales of rough diamonds in the first half of the year slumped to $2.62 billion, down 26 percent from a record high last year because of falling demand in the United States, the world's biggest market for the cut and polished stones used in jewelry. The sales report was the first since De Beers went private last month in a $19 billion takeover led by the Oppenheimer family and the miner Anglo American. Each owns 45 percent of De Beers. De Beers said full-year sales would be $4.8 billion. De Beers sells about 65 percent of the world's rough diamonds and produces some 45 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: On Africa's Caravan Trail
lead_paragraph: In a corner of Niger that was once a vast sea, dozens of families mine salt, and are the inheritors of a caravan trade that brought life to the Sahara for centuries. Page A12.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: BURUNDI: Thousands Flee Fighting; RWANDA: Ex-Governor Denies Genocide Charge;.
lead_paragraph: BURUNDI: THOUSANDS FLEE FIGHTING Fighting between the army and ethnic Hutu rebels has prompted as many as 10,000 people to flee their homes 25 miles northwest of Bujumbura, the capital, officials said. The fighting has worsened since peace talks broke off this month. Dating to 1993, war between the Tutsi-led army and Hutu rebels has killed about 300,000 people. The army and the rebel group called Forces for Defense of Democracy accused each other of being the aggressor in the fighting.    Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: South Africa Project
lead_paragraph: After the first of the year, J. Douglas Holladay, who is now with the White House office of public liaison, will become the director of the State Department's working group on Southern Africa. Mr. Holladay will hold the rank of ambassador and will be working in the United States with members of Congress, corporations and higher education and religious groups; in Europe especially with the British and West Germans, South Africa's biggest trading partners; and in South Africa itself.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: Unity As Death Toll Mounts; SOMALIA: Italian Honored For Refugee Work;.
lead_paragraph: IVORY COAST: UNITY AS DEATH TOLL MOUNTS The country's new unity government held its first cabinet meeting with newly sworn-in rebel ministers, even as the rebels accused the government of new attacks in the western region. The new government includes members of the governing party, the political opposition and rebels. The coalition is part of French-brokered January peace accords aimed at ending six months of civil war in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa-producing nation. "We are going to live together and build peace," a government spokesman said. But a rebel spokesman said government-sponsored helicopter attacks had killed 28 people in the last 10 days and injured almost 100 others, many of them civilians. France, which has 3,000 troops monitoring the cease-fire, confirmed the attacks. (AP)

title: Scaled-Back but Determined Protests in Kenya Call for President to Resign
snippet: The demonstrations were held despite his withdrawal of the tax bill that sparked days of protests. Some activists, fearing more bloodshed, warned people not to march to the president’s official residence.
lead_paragraph: Protesters returned to the streets of Kenya on Thursday, some of them demanding the resignation of President William Ruto, despite his announcement a day earlier that he was abandoning a tax bill that drew large-scale demonstrations in which nearly two dozen people were killed.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: 2 More Journalists On Trial; ZAMBIA: Chiluba Offered A Deal;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: 2 MORE JOURNALISTS ON TRIAL Two Zimbabwean journalists, who went on trial on charges of publishing falsehoods in breach of tough new media legislation, called for sections the law to be declared unconstitutional. Geoff Nyarota, editor of The Daily News, the country's sole independent daily, and a reporter, Lloyd Mudiwa, face charges of publishing falsehoods and abusing journalistic privileges. The case follows that of the journalist Andrew Meldrum, who was acquitted last week and is fighting an expulsion order. Since the law took effect on March 15, 12 journalists have been arrested — some of them more than once.

title: War in the Horn of Africa
snippet: Editorial says Bush administration was too quick to praise Ethiopia's attack on Islamic militia in Somalia; says this pre-emptive attack by Somalia's longstanding enemy could pull in neighboring countries and explode over entire region; says Unite...
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to wink at Ethiopia's stunningly successful offensive in Somalia. It pushed back a hateful Islamic militia that was defying the United Nations, threatening to impose religious tyranny and, according to Washington, harboring international terrorists. The Bush administration quickly succumbed to temptation, lauding Ethiopia's attacks as a legitimate response to "aggression."

title: Church Helps Fill a Void in Africa
snippet: With 16 percent of the world’s Catholics now living in Africa, the church’s future, many say, lies in the continent.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The young woman slept soundly on the cool marble floor before the altar, a break from the chaos at home. In the courtyard, neighborhood teenagers filled giant jerrycans with purified water from a stone fountain. In an aisle, a rail-thin young woman from a nearby slum said she had not eaten since yesterday but was expecting sustenance here.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: ZIMBABWE: More White Farmers Arrested; ZAMBIA: Ex-President In Limbo;.
lead_paragraph: ZIMBABWE: MORE WHITE FARMERS ARRESTED The police are continuing to arrest white farmers who have defied a new government law that requires many of the country's 3,500 white farmers to turn over their property to the state. Since last week, when the police began enforcing the 10-day-old law, 193 farmers have been arrested, the chief police spokesman said. More than 100 have appeared in court, a spokesman for the Commercial Farmers Union said. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Africa's Plague, and Everyone's
snippet: Nadine Gordimer Op-Ed article on scourge of AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa, which accounts for 69 percent of world's infected; drawing
lead_paragraph: Sixty-nine percent of the world's victims of H.I.V. and AIDS are in sub-Saharan Africa. This figure is not easy to take in. AIDS seems to have come upon everyone while we were looking the other way: it happened to some sex or color other than our own; it was endemic to some other country.

title: South Africa Unions’ Strike Suspended
snippet: South Africa’s trade unions suspended a three-week-old strike by hundreds of thousands of government workers.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa  South Africa’s trade unions Monday suspended an almost  three-week-old strike by hundreds of thousands of government workers that had closed schools and hamstrung ambitious new efforts to expand urgently needed medical services in the region’s richest but most inequitable economy.

title: At Least 750,000 on Brink of Starvation and Death in Sudan, Experts Warn
snippet: A devastating civil war is pushing the country toward a full-blown famine, according to the international body that measures hunger.
lead_paragraph: At least 750,000 people are on the brink of starvation and death in Sudan, where a devastating civil war has left over half the country’s 48 million people in a situation of chronic hunger, the global authority on famine said on Thursday.

title: Celebrating African Traditions
snippet: Bess Liebenson reviews African sculpture exhibit at Bruce Museum, Greenwich, Conn; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IN ''Three African Traditions: The Art of the Dogon, Fang and Songye,'' an exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through April 18, the aura created by figurative sculptures and masks is eclipsed by a compulsion to ferret out differences and commonalities.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: Africa SOMALIA: Kidnapping Prompts U.N. Shutdown ; NIGERIA: 100 Lashes For Premarital Sex A 19-.
lead_paragraph: SOMALIA: KIDNAPPING PROMPTS U.N. SHUTDOWN The United Nations said it was suspending all activities in Mogadishu to protest the April 28 abduction of one of its Somali workers, the 14th such incident since 1995. Maxwell Gaylard, the United Nations' aid coordinator for Somalia, said a polio vaccination campaign scheduled for next week and other programs had been called off until Mohamed All Abokor is released. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: South Africa: Showpiece Mall for Soweto
snippet: A 700,000-square-foot shopping mall housing 200 stores and billed as the largest in southern Africa opened in Soweto.
lead_paragraph: A 700,000-square-foot shopping mall housing 200 stores and billed as the largest in southern Africa opened in Soweto, South Africa’s most famous township, adding to evidence that the onetime all-black slum is emerging as a major residential and business center in its own right.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: Death Sentences In Slaying Of President; NIGERIA: A Leg For A Leg;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: DEATH SENTENCES IN SLAYING OF PRESIDENT A military court sentenced 26 people to death for their involvement in the assassination of President Laurent Kabila two years ago. Mr. Kabila was shot and killed by a bodyguard in the presidential palace in January 2001 and replaced soon afterward by his son Joseph. The bodyguard was shot dead at the scene of the killing. Among those sentenced to death was Col. Eddy Kapend, Laurent Kabila's closest aide, who was found guilty of having organized what prosecutors said was a failed coup plot. The 26 were among 135 people who have been on trial since March. Some 40 other defendants were acquitted and about 50 were given sentences ranging from three years to life.    (Reuters)

title: South Africa: Officials Fired for Graft
snippet: The African National Congress party said Thursday that it had fired the mayor and other officials in the Lekwa municipality in Mpumalanga Province.
lead_paragraph: The African National Congress party said Thursday that it had fired the mayor and other officials in the Lekwa municipality in Mpumalanga Province to show “zero tolerance” for mismanagement and corruption. Sakhile Township there has been racked by protests against what residents see as crooked, incompetent local leaders.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Beauty Business Returns; BURUNDI: 150 Drown As Boat Capsizes; ZIMBABWE: Government Retaliation;.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: BEAUTY BUSINESS RETURNS Four months after violence wrecked their country's elaborate plan to stage the Miss World contest, 500 guests at a Lagos hotel whooped and whistled at 24 contestants in the Most Beautiful Girl in Nigeria pageant. The winner on Sunday was 19-year-old Celia Bissong Ohumoto. She will represent Nigeria in the Miss World content in Panama City in June. Last year, Islamic anger over the staging of Miss World during Ramadan here, where about half the population is Muslim, fueled a religious riot in the northern city of Kaduna that left at least 220 people dead. (Agence France-Presse)

title: South Africa to Fight Parole for Killer of Anti-Apartheid Activist
snippet: The government said it would appeal the release of Janusz Walus, who had been serving a life sentence for the murder of Chris Hani in 1993.
lead_paragraph: The South African government will appeal a judge’s decision to grant parole to the killer of Chris Hani, a leading anti-apartheid activist who was assassinated in 1993, a spokesman for Justice Minister Michael Masutha announced on Wednesday.

title: South Africa: Trial Delay for Zuma
snippet: The corruption trial of Jacob G. Zuma, the presumptive next president of South Africa, has been delayed yet again.
lead_paragraph: The corruption trial of Jacob G. Zuma, the presumptive next president of South Africa, has been delayed yet again. The trial had been scheduled to start Aug. 4, but no new date was set. It is now likely that Mr. Zuma, president of the governing African National Congress, will become president next April with the charges still unresolved.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: Africa NIGERIA: Court Sides With Government On Oil; SUDAN: Cease-fire Monitors.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA: COURT SIDES WITH GOVERNMENT ON OIL The Supreme Court ruled that offshore resources, including potential crude oil and gas deposits, are under the control of the federal government, not state authorities. Six southern states, which produce almost all of Nigeria's oil, had tried to exert control over the ocean off the Niger Delta, where most untapped oil deposits are believed to lie. The federal government has long claimed all the revenues from the crude oil in the region, which received little in return. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: NIGERIA: Arrests And Evidence In Deadly Blast; LIBERIA: Army Said To Push Back Rebels;.
lead_paragraph: LAOS: 10 SHOT TO DEATH ON BUS At least 10 people, including 3 foreigners, were killed yesterday when gunmen attacked a bus in Laos, officials said. A group of about 20 men sprayed the bus with automatic weapons fire on the road to Vangviang, about 75 miles north of the capital, Vientiane, an official in Vangviang said. A senior government official said seven Laotians on the bus were killed, along with a Chinese person and two foreign cyclists, one male and one female.   (Reuters)

title: LINKAGE IN AFRICA
lead_paragraph: What hints there have been of the Reagan Administration's likely outlook toward black Africa suggest, not surprisingly, an emphasis on stability. America will keep supporting Robert Mugabe's effort to hold Zimbabwe on course. It will try to prevent economic collapse in Zaire. It will work to maintain improved relations with Nigeria, the economic giant of the region, with its new civilian government.

title: Grand Jury Declines to Indict Principal Accused of Endangering a Student
snippet: In a case that roiled a racially diverse town in New Jersey for months, a high school principal is one step closer to getting his job back.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury in New Jersey dismissed charges on Wednesday against the high school principal who had been accused of endangering a student, in a racially charged case that roiled the liberal, diverse towns of South Orange and Maplewood.

title: South Africa's Curse
snippet: Op-Ed article by author Sindiwe Magona examines hatred of whites among South African blacks; says even though hatred may not have achieved institutionalized status among blacks as apartheid was among whites, it is abundant in black folklore; urges...
lead_paragraph: The murder of Amy Biehl, an American student, in Guguletu, South Africa, nearly five years ago highlighted a seldom-mentioned legacy of apartheid: the deep-seated racial hatred that many South African blacks hold for whites. The granting of amnesty last week to the four young men convicted in the killing gives us a chance to take stock and ask whether harboring such hate does us any good.

title: Peace in the Horn of Africa
lead_paragraph: After a two-year conflict involving World War II-style trench warfare, Eritrea and Ethiopia finally decided to opt for peace. The war, which ate the budgets of two very poor countries prone to drought, has left many displaced people and destroyed towns. The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, who visited and declared the war over, said it was time to ''begin the urgent task of reconstruction.'' Barbara Crossette

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: MALI: Tourists' Kidnappers Demand Ransom; RWANDA: 105 Convicted In Ethnic Killings; KENYA: Bomb Suspect Kills Policeman; SUDAN: Political Detainees Released;.
lead_paragraph: MALI: TOURISTS' KIDNAPPERS DEMAND RANSOM Officials in Mali have received a videotape of 14 European tourists abducted in the Sahara in which they appear to be in good health and refer to a ransom demand. The officials did not mention a figure, but N-TV television in Germany reported that an Islamic group was demanding $5.2 million for each hostage. The 14 tourists — 9 Germans, 4 Swiss and a Dutchman — are believed to have been kidnapped by the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, a radical Islamic group. They were reported missing in February and March while traveling without local guides in Algeria. One hostage has died; the other 14 are now apparently being held across the border from Kidal, Mali. (Agence France-Presse)

title: African-American History Concerts
lead_paragraph: FOR African-American History Month, which starts Tuesday, the Downtown Music Series at Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains and the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers have planned multiple observations.

title: Ebola Gets Worse in West Africa
snippet: Nations afflicted by the epidemic, as well as their neighbors, will need to redouble efforts to contain the virus.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization warned last Wednesday that the epidemic caused by the deadly Ebola virus in West Africa, which had seemed to be waning, has recently taken a turn for the worse. The afflicted nations and their neighbors will need to redouble their efforts to contain a virus for which there is neither a cure nor a vaccine.

title: Central African Republic: Hunger Threatens Population, U.N. Warns
snippet: Nearly half the people in the country are now facing hunger, the main food aid agency of the United Nations said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 2.5 million people in the Central African Republic — half the population — are now facing hunger, double the figure from a year ago, the main food aid agency of the United Nations said Wednesday. The agency, the World Food Program, attributed the increase to years of conflict and insecurity that have kept people from tending their fields and livestock, exacerbated by a poor harvest. “This is not the run-of-the-mill emergency,” Guy Adoua, the agency’s deputy director for the country, said in a statement. “People are left with nothing.” The agency called for an emergency cash infusion of $41 million from donor countries to deal with the crisis.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: CONGO: A Power-Sharing Government; ZIMBABWE: Churches Regret Inaction; UGANDA: Children Drowned, Army Says; MOROCCO: Hundreds Of Suspects On Trial;.
lead_paragraph: CONGO: A POWER-SHARING GOVERNMENT Congo's main rebel leaders were sworn in as vice presidents in a new power-sharing government, intended to end the country's civil war. The new government, led by President Joseph Kabila, left, brings together the rebels, Mr. Kabila's supporters and the unarmed opposition in an effort to reunite the country. The new government has until Aug. 4 to draft a plan for elections within about a year. The two rebel leaders — Jean-Pierre Bemba and Azarias Ruberwa — were sworn in with Abdoulaye Yerodia Nbombasi, who is allied to Mr. Kabila, and Arthur Z'Ahidi Ngoma, a member of the unarmed political opposition. Rival tribal militias continued to clash in northeastern Congo; more than 80 people have been killed in fighting this week. (AP)

title: What to Know About Chemical Hair Relaxers and Health
snippet: A growing body of evidence shows a link between these products and a number of health disorders in Black women.
lead_paragraph: Straightened hair has long been the dominant societal standard of beauty for Black women, from the working class to those in government and corporate America to celebrities and even someone in the White House. Michelle Obama said in 2022 that she felt she had to straighten her hair while serving as first lady rather than wear a natural style. “Nope,” she said. “They’re not ready for it.” Hair can be straightened with heat, but a vast majority of Black women — an estimated 89 percent — have used chemical relaxers, which are easier and more affordable, at some point in their lives, often beginning in childhood.

title: South African Students Clash With Police in Cape Town Over Tuition
snippet: Hundreds of students protesting a planned 6 percent tuition increase tried to force their way into the Parliament building during a speech by the finance minister.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Riot police officers and students protesting against tuition increases clashed on Wednesday outside the Parliament building in Cape Town, the latest in a series of student demonstrations that have gripped South Africa this year.

title: South Africa: Elections Scheduled for April
snippet: South Africa’s president, Kgalema Motlanthe, announced that national elections would take place on April 22.
lead_paragraph: President Kgalema Motlanthe announced Tuesday that national elections would take place on April 22. While the African National Congress, the party of both Nelson Mandela and Mr. Motlanthe, remains a heavy favorite, this time it faces a challenge from a splinter group, the Congress of the People.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: KENYA: Opposition Chooses Candidate; ZIMBABWE: Cracking Down On White Farmers; NIGERIA: A Higher Christian-Muslim Toll;.
lead_paragraph: KENYA: OPPOSITION CHOOSES CANDIDATE The National Alliance Party named Mwai Kibaki, leader of the opposition in Parliament, as its presidential candidate to challenge the governing party's 39-year hold on power. President Daniel arap Moi is expected to set a date for the election by the end of this year. Mr. Moi, 78, has been president for 24 years. His term under the current constitution ends in January and he is supporting Uhuru Kenyatta, son of Kenya's first president, Jomo Kenyatta, as the governing party's candidate. (AP)

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: IVORY COAST: Peace Plan Signed; SUDAN: Talks Resume;.
lead_paragraph: JAPAN: CULT SURVEILLANCE EXTENDED A public security commission extended by three years its close surveillance of Aum Shinrikyo, the cult responsible for a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway in 1995, citing the risk that it may try to commit further massacres. The decision will allow security officials and the police to inspect cult sites and force it to report the names, addresses and other information of its followers every three months. "It is determined that there is danger of the organization committing indiscriminate mass murder," said a secretary for the Public Security Examination Commission. The gas attack killed 12 people and sickened thousands.    Howard W. French (NYT)

title: In South Africa, a Push for Industrial Growth
snippet: South Africa is providing companies with financial help as it tries to take advantage of an opportunity to create jobs and advance economically in the African market.
lead_paragraph: To many outsiders, South Africa has long been an unstable business environment with an economy overly dependent on natural resources.

title: The Business of War in Africa
snippet: Editorial calls for halt to flow of arms to Africa, where it fuels deadly conflicts; says pressure must be put on Ukraine, Bulgaria and other former Soviet bloc countries to crack down on arms sales to continent; says action must also be taken aga...
lead_paragraph: In many African nations, the natural resources that should be used to feed and educate people are instead being used to destroy them. The Government and guerrillas in Angola, for example, are selling the country's oil and diamonds to buy weapons and pay soldiers in a 30-year civil war that has made the nation perhaps the most miserable in the world. In Congo and Sierra Leone as well, natural wealth is fueling catastrophic conflict. But no warring party can make an arms deal alone. Outside nations and companies are also profiting. They should be helping instead to limit the ability of African warlords to sell a country's patrimony and to block the flow of weapons to Africa's conflicts.

title: A Realist Among Fans of South Africa
snippet: The World Cup has excited South Africa soccer fans but it is plain to the pragmatist that the country’s level of play is lacking.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra, South Africa

title: A Realist Among Fans of South Africa
snippet: The World Cup has excited South Africa soccer fans but it is plain to the pragmatist that the country’s level of play is lacking.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra, South Africa

title: South Africa I
lead_paragraph: President Reagan's imposition of limited sanctions on South Africa involved more complications than a reversal of White House policy toward that country. His decision to ban the importation of the gold Krugerrand coins required a new interpretation of international trade regulations that has produced serious legal questions for the State and Commerce Departments and raised, although perhaps remotely, the possibility of economic retaliation by South Africa.

title: South Africa: New Post for Annan
snippet: Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, said he would serve as chairman of the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa, a $150 million undertaking financed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation....
lead_paragraph: Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, said he would serve as chairman of the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa, a $150 million undertaking financed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation. Mr. Annan made the announcement while speaking at the World Economic Forum in Cape Town. The alliance’s aim is to increase the productivity of millions of small scale farmers in Africa, where per capita food production lags behind population growth and a third of the population suffers from chronic hunger.

title: Correction: AIDS in Africa
snippet: Corrected maps depicting spread of AIDS in Africa

title: How African Immigrants Have Revived a Remote Corner of Quebec
snippet: Hundreds of newcomers from Africa have filled a shortage of workers in Rouyn-Noranda, creating a new community in a remote mining town.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the handful of African immigrants in Rouyn-Noranda, a remote city in northern Quebec, all knew one another.

title: A South African Diamond
snippet: Howard Goldberg reviews 1997 South African Blue White chenin blanc produced by Irina von Holdt; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: If the bad news is that South African producers, in lock step with overseas counterparts, are rushing headlong into chardonnay, a white that mostly runs the gamut of A to B, the good news is that chenin blanc has sprung up as the country's most promising white.

title: African Art World Nestled in Tenafly
snippet: The African Art Museum of the SMA Fathers is a place of visual magic and the real African deal.
lead_paragraph: TENAFLY, N.J.  You can count the number of American public museums devoted entirely to African art on a few fingers.

title: Virus Ravages Cassava Plants in Africa
snippet: Cassava, eaten by 800 million people in Africa, South America and Asia, is threatened by a blight.
lead_paragraph: MUKONO, Uganda  Lynet Nalugo dug a cassava tuber out of her field and sliced it open.

title: African Unity Faces a Test in Ivory Coast
snippet: Ivory Coast has become a test case of whether the global community can impose its will on leaders who refuse to recognize elections they lose.
lead_paragraph: On a continent where coups and stolen elections are far from uncommon, one thing makes the standoff over Ivory Coast exceptional: all the major powers in Africa and overseas agree that Laurent Gbagbo, the strongman leader, must go.

title: South Africans Seek Meaning in a Shooting
snippet: Reeva Steenkamp, who was shot by the sprinter Oscar Pistorius, had big plans for her newfound fame, including speaking about violence against women in South Africa, friends and family said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The day before Reeva Steenkamp died, she was getting ready to give a speech on a subject that she had known first hand and that is endemic in South Africa: violence against women.

title: World Briefing: Africa
snippet: BURUNDI: Officers Arrested After Massacre;.
lead_paragraph: UKRAINE: PANEL TO STUDY REFORMS President Leonid D. Kuchma has formed a commission of local and federal officials, members of Parliament and scholars to study constitutional reforms and electoral law amendments that would increase the powers of Parliament. Mr. Kuchma's decree, signed Thursday, said the goal is a "European model" of participatory democracy. His government has been accused of corruption, of human rights violations and, most recently, of selling weapons to Iraq, and is under attack by opposition politicians.

title: South Africa's Role
snippet: News analysis of South Africa's unsuccessful efforts to mediate peaceful resolution of conflict in Congo; finds minimal results of efforts by Pres Nelson Mandela shows South Africa is still struggling to find its footing among neighboring nations,...
lead_paragraph: While South Africa tried this weekend to find a peaceful resolution to the conflict in Congo, its minimal results so far were in some ways predictable.

title: South Africa Sentences 11 Africans as Terrorists
snippet: 11 Africans, including a woman, get 10- to 20-yr jail terms for terrorism and attempt to overthrow Govt by violent revolution, Sup Ct, Pietermaritzburg

title: BIRDIE AFRICA
lead_paragraph: AFTER the bomb had been dropped on the roof and as the fire roared out of control in West Philadelphia, the badly burned boy escaped from the building at 6221 Osage Avenue, used as headquarters by the Move group. Because the boy was so small and malnourished, the police gave his age as 9; in fact, he was 13. He was admitted to Children's Hospital with burns covering his arms and legs.

title: Stumbling in the Race to Feed Africa’s Millions
snippet: While much of the world enjoys plentiful harvests, malnutrition remains epidemic in sub-Saharan Africa.
lead_paragraph: During the 20th century, country after country adopted methods of industrial agriculture — use of fertilizers, pesticides, irrigation and high-productivity grain hybrids — that caused yields of corn, wheat, rice and other staples to soar. This “green revolution,” as it became known, brought food self-sufficiency to nations like China and India, laying the groundwork for their emergence as economic powerhouses.

title: To Africa, Through Its Food
snippet: Comment on new book by Jessica B Harris, The Africa Cookbook: Tastes of a Continent; recipe (M)
lead_paragraph: JESSICA B. HARRIS'S first trip to Africa, when she was 24, was a ''going home,'' to the West Africa of her roots. It was her introduction to a continent of vast geographic and ethnic diversity, which she has revisited many times since that first trip in 1972. Those trips, and the foods she sampled in her travels, are recounted in her new book, ''The Africa Cookbook: Tastes of a Continent'' (Simon & Schuster, $25).

title: Trump Prosecutor in Georgia Rebukes Critics in Speech to Black Church Group
snippet: “I’ve lived the experience of a Black woman who is attacked and over-sexualized,” the prosecutor, Fani Willis, told leaders of the African Methodist Episcopal Church on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: With her prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump bottled up in a state appeals court fight, the Georgia district attorney who brought the case pushed back at her conservative critics on Thursday, appearing to single out recent remarks made about her by Mr. Trump’s co-defendant Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: A Trilobite Pompeii Preserves Exquisite Fossils in Volcanic Ash
snippet: A fossil bed in the High Atlas Mountains of Morocco is allowing new insights into the anatomies of arthropods that lived a half-billion years ago.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of millions of years ago, trilobites could be found all over the Earth. Cloaked in tough exoskeletons, the animals left behind countless fossils to be studied by paleontologists today. Despite all those preserved shells, scientists have been unable to understand certain aspects of trilobite anatomy after centuries of study, especially the soft internal structures of the ancient arthropods.

title: Nominee Named for African Affairs Post
snippet: President Obama said he was nominating Johnnie Carson, one of the government’s most senior Africa hands and career Foreign Service officers, to succeed Jendayi Frazer as assistant secretary of state for African affairs. Mr. Carson had stints in tw...
lead_paragraph: President Obama said he was nominating Johnnie Carson, one of the government’s most senior Africa hands and career Foreign Service officers, to succeed Jendayi Frazer as assistant secretary of state for African affairs. Mr. Carson had stints in two nations that have endured the greatest political turmoil over the past two years, serving as ambassador to Kenya from 1999 to 2003 and Zimbabwe from 1995 to 1997. He was also ambassador to Uganda from 1991 to 1994. Most recently, Mr. Carson was the national intelligence officer for Africa on the National Intelligence Council. Before he joined the council, he spent 37 years in the Foreign Service, with posts in Botswana, Mozambique and Nigeria, among others.

title: South Africans to Visit
lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is bringing 11

title: Blame to Share in Africa
snippet: Harvard Law School Prof Makau Mutua Op-Ed article contends that recent massacre of eight Western tourists in Uganda was horrible event, but response of Ugandan and Rwandan Governments has been just as chilling; criticizes Ugandan Pres Yoweri Musev...
lead_paragraph: The recent massacre of eight Western tourists in Uganda was a horrible event, but the response of the Ugandan and Rwandan Governments has been just as chilling. Uganda's President, Yoweri Museveni, who came to power in a coup in 1986, vowed to kill the suspects on sight, even before their guilt was established.

title: A Taste of France via South Africa
snippet: Outside the Loire, world-class chenin blanc is virtually nonexistent except for South Africa. “A lot of producers are playing it as their top-end card,” said Kevin Arnold, managing partner and senior winemaker at Waterford Estate in Stellenbosch, ...
lead_paragraph: Outside the Loire, world-class chenin blanc is virtually nonexistent except for South Africa. “A lot of producers are playing it as their top-end card,” said Kevin Arnold, managing partner and senior winemaker at Waterford Estate in Stellenbosch, near South Africa’s southern tip.
