snippet: Howard W French reviews book Into the House of the Ancestors: Inside the New Africa by Karl Maier (L)
lead_paragraph: INTO THE HOUSE OF THE ANCESTORS

title: American Culture (and Goods) Thrive in South Africa
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant, sipping Coca-Cola and listening to a Whitney Houston tape, Gift Neku does not seem like a man starved for Americana.

title: Unproductive Agriculture Is Holding Africa Back
snippet: Farm output has grown, but at a high cost — and that’s a problem for the region.
lead_paragraph: Africa south of the Sahara is producing more than six times as much food as it did in 1961. That’s a much bigger increase than that of the world as a whole, which has merely quadrupled agricultural output, as this chart shows. From this data alone, sub-Saharan Africa seems to be an agricultural success story.

title: AFRICAN COLLECTIONS IN BERGEN
lead_paragraph: TWO Bergen County establishments about a mile from each other are becoming active centers of African art.

title: South Africa: Police Chief to Be Charged
snippet: Prosecutors said they would charge Jackie Selebi, the national police commissioner and president of Interpol who has been accused of having links to organized crime syndicates, with corruption. A date for the court hearing has yet to be determined...
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors said they would charge Jackie Selebi, the national police commissioner and president of Interpol who has been accused of having links to organized crime syndicates, with corruption. A date for the court hearing has yet to be determined, they said.

title: South Africa: Telkom in Talks for Sale
snippet: Telkom South Africa may sell the rest of a mobile-phone venture, the nation’s biggest, to Vodafone Group and dispose of its fixed-line unit to the MTN Group. Telkom South Africa said in a statement that it was in talks with Vodafone and MTN over “...
lead_paragraph: Telkom South Africa may sell the rest of a mobile-phone venture, the nation’s biggest, to Vodafone Group and dispose of its fixed-line unit to the MTN Group. Telkom South Africa said in a statement that it was in talks with Vodafone and MTN over “mobile strategy.” Telkom, which has a market value of about 103.4 billion rand ($14.4 billion), declined to give details. MTN and Vodafone confirmed the discussions in separate statements. The sales would effectively dismantle what was until last year a monopoly over fixed-line phone services in South Africa. They also would give the government an exit from its investment in Telkom. South Africa owns about 38 percent of the company.

title: Africans Before Americans
snippet: Prof K Anthony Appiah reviews book Exchanging Our Country Marks: The Transformation of African Identities in the Colonial and Antebellum South by Prof Michael A Gomez (M)
lead_paragraph: EXCHANGING OUR COUNTRY MARKS The Transformation of African Identities in the Colonial and Antebellum South. By Michael A. Gomez. 370 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $18.95.

title: Radebe, South Africa's Unofficial Ambassador
snippet: Lucas Radebe, a former star defender for Leeds United and South Africa, was in the United States last week to promote the World Cup in his home country.
lead_paragraph: It was eight years ago that Lucas Radebe, soccer player, came face to face with the idol of every South African -- Nelson Mandela -- in, of all places, Leeds, a city in the north of England.

title: Radebe, South Africa's Unofficial Ambassador
snippet: Lucas Radebe, a former star defender for Leeds United and South Africa, was in the United States last week to promote the World Cup in his home country.
lead_paragraph: It was eight years ago that Lucas Radebe, soccer player, came face to face with the idol of every South African -- Nelson Mandela -- in, of all places, Leeds, a city in the north of England.

title: South Africa: Inquiry Into Report on Minister
snippet: Prosecutors confirmed that they were investigating a newspaper editor in connection with the paper’s disclosure of medical records of the government’s health minister.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors confirmed that they were investigating the editor of The Sunday Times of Johannesburg in connection with the newspaper’s disclosure of medical records of the government’s health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, which detailed her alcohol consumption. But the prosecutors declined to confirm reports in the paper that they intended to arrest the editor and a staff member for violating a law that bars access to health records without a patient’s permission.

title: An African Kaleidoscope of Cultures
snippet: The novelty is stunning, the pageantry dizzying. Turning over the pages of "African Ceremonies" is like stepping into a magic garden through a door nobody knew and embarking on a journey into our forgotten past, when man roamed desert immensiti
lead_paragraph: The novelty is stunning, the pageantry dizzying. Turning over the pages of "African Ceremonies" is like stepping into a magic garden through a door nobody knew and embarking on a journey into our forgotten past, when man roamed desert immensities and wound his way through primeval forests.

title: African Currency Funds
snippet: J P Morgan & Co and Standard New York, subsidiary of Standard Bank Investment Corp of South Africa, may introduce funds dedicated to investing in African currencies and sovereign debt (S)
lead_paragraph: J.P. Morgan & Company and Standard New York, a subsidiary of the Standard Bank Investment Corporation of South Africa, may introduce funds dedicated to investing in African currencies and sovereign debt, the newsletter Emerging Markets Week reported yesterday. The funds, which would be aimed at Botswana, Ghana, Kenya and Zimbabwe, would be the first to focus on African currencies and fixed-income securities, the newsletter said. It quoted Carsten Hils, head of foreign exchange and money markets at Standard, as saying that investors have shown interest and confidence in Africa.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Bees Kill Man As Rite Fails
snippet: African honeybees stung a 73-year-old man to death after a traditional ceremony to remove their hive from a home in Eastern Cape Province went awry. The man, Victor Nyembezi, was among 100 residents of Mgomanzi who were trying to get the bees to l...
lead_paragraph: African honeybees stung a 73-year-old man to death after a traditional ceremony to remove their hive from a home in Eastern Cape Province went awry. The man, Victor Nyembezi, was among 100 residents of Mgomanzi who were trying to get the bees to leave the homestead, in part by serving home-brewed beer in an effort to enlist ancestral spirits in their campaign. When the bees attacked instead, Mr. Nyembezi was too slow to escape and was killed by the swarm. A bee expert, Prof. Randall Hepburn of Rhodes University, told the South African Press Association that the instructions for traditional bee-removal ceremonies were simple: "Don't do it," he said. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: A Stormy Test for Democracy in South Africa
snippet: Some say the bare-knuckled succession struggle for the presidency could foretell how robust South Africa’s young democracy is.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 22 — South Africa’s first democratic president was a foregone conclusion. Its second was anointed with odometer-like predictability. Now for something completely different: a bare-knuckled succession struggle, replete with mudslinging, grandstanding, ideological splits and all the other earmarks of a robust democracy.

title: Scandal Touches African Athletes
snippet: Far-reaching Olympic corruption scandal could threaten long-term participation of athletes from deveoping nations, particularly from Africa, which already struggle to support sport while contending with more urgent problems of poverty, disease and...
lead_paragraph: In the West African nation of Senegal, there is one all-weather running track, one indoor basketball court and one Olympic-sized pool, filled with seawater and located not at a training center, but at a hotel.

title: Africa's Futile War
snippet: Editorial urges Ethiopia and Eritrea to settle territorial dispute since cost of their stubbornness could be one of deadliest international wars Africa has ever seen (M)
lead_paragraph: Few nations can less afford to go to war than Ethiopia and Eritrea, yet many of the 200,000 troops facing each other on their common border were battling yesterday. The immediate cause is a dispute over ownership of a 250-square-mile triangle of rocky land of consequence to neither nation. The real problem is that leaders of both countries feel compelled by honor to stand their ground. The cost of their stubbornness could be one of the deadliest international wars Africa has ever seen.

title: Letter: On Africa
snippet:
Foreign Aid Strings That Could Bind 


 To the Editor:

The principal argument of your March 11 editorial ''The Broken Plows of Africa'' is unobjectionable - namely, that one of the main causes of Africa's food shortage is that many African govern...
lead_paragraph: Foreign Aid Strings That Could Bind

title: Jaded See South Africa As 'Flavor of the Month'
snippet: South African reaction to Pres Clinton's visit has been subdued; variety of reasons have been offered, with some analysts saying Clnton himself may be partly to blame for tepid reception; note how disappointed Parliament was that Clinton failed to...
lead_paragraph: It could be argued that Michael Jackson got a more enthusiastic reception when he arrived in South Africa.

title: African Music
lead_paragraph: A program of African and African- American music will be performed Sunday at 2 P.M. in the Studio Museum in Harlem by the Women of Calabash, a trio led by Madeleine Nelson that uses calabash instruments, such as gourds and shekeres, as well as the voice.

title: South Africa: Suspect in Historian’s Killing
snippet: A day after South Africans buried the renowned historian David Rattray, the leading expert on the 19th-century Anglo-Zulu war and a close friend of Prince Charles, a 23-year-old man pleaded guilty to killing him at his KwaZulu-Natal lodge, and a s...
lead_paragraph: A day after South Africans buried the renowned historian David Rattray, the leading expert on the 19th-century Anglo-Zulu war and a close friend of Prince Charles, a 23-year-old man pleaded guilty to killing him at his KwaZulu-Natal lodge, and a second man was arrested in connection with the crime. Mr. Rattray was killed in an apparent botched robbery at his property on Jan. 26, the latest in a string of killings that has riveted South Africans’ attention on security issues.

title: Omens for South Africa
lead_paragraph: Final touches have been put on the new constitution. South-west Africa will become independent Namibia on March 21, the first day of spring, completing the formal decolonization of Africa.

title: On the Scene: Comic Con Africa
snippet: A Times reporter went to Comic Con Africa, which showcased African superheroes and their creators.
lead_paragraph: A Times reporter went to Comic Con Africa, which showcased African superheroes and their creators.

title: AFRICAN APOCALYPSE
South African Drama
lead_paragraph: The photographer caught Winnie Mandela as she left the court after her conviction for kidnapping. She was smiling exuberantly, as if she had just won a great victory. Behind her was Nelson Mandela, eyes downcast, looking stricken and exhausted.

title: South African Farewell
lead_paragraph: With his largely white-supported National Party in disarray and dropping in popularity, former South African President F. W. de Klerk decided last week that the time had come for him to retire from politics and write his memoirs.

title: Detention Is Urged for African TB Cases
snippet: Doctors recommended forcibly detaining people in South Africa who refuse treatment for a drug-resistant form of tuberculosis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP)  A team of doctors has recommended forcibly detaining people in South Africa who refuse treatment for a drug-resistant form of tuberculosis, an extreme measure meant to keep the infected away from others to curb the spread of the disease, according to a paper published Monday in an international medical journal.

title: Peace in the Horn of Africa
snippet: Editorial lauds American-brokered peace agreement to end fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea as profoundly positive development that should bring formal end to conflict that has claimed lives of between 75,000 and 100,000 conscripts and on which...
lead_paragraph: A disputed border, nationalistic fervor, reckless personal honor and diplomatic miscalculation have all contributed to the fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea, and have produced one of the world's bloodiest conventional wars in recent years. Horrific trench combat reminiscent of World War I has claimed the lives of between 75,000 and 100,000 conscripts. The two countries, among the poorest on earth, have squandered more than $1 billion on arms, enriching profiteers from Russia and Bulgaria to China and North Korea while impoverishing their own people.

title: Africa Museum Director
snippet: National Museum of African Art in Washington names Roslyn Adele Walter to be its new director; she succeeds Sylvia H Williams, who died last year (S)
lead_paragraph: The National Museum of African Art in Washington has named Roslyn Adele Walker to be its new director. Ms. Walker, who was the museum's senior curator, succeeds Sylvia H. Williams, who died last year. Patricia L. Fiske, who has served as the museum's acting director, will resume her job as assistant director.

title: Out of Africa Comes Diversity
snippet: Benjamin Genocchio reviews exhibit of contemporary African art at Newark Museum; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Newark - Many of us probably think we know African art when we see it: It's those fierce masks, totemic figures and bright textiles, right? In fact, it is much more diverse than that, as an exhibition of new acquisitions of contemporary African art at the Newark Museum seeks to show.

title: Glimpsing Africa Anew in Its Art
snippet: Everything is in a spotlight in this show of 30 sculptures, which rethinks and reshapes the old one-tribe-one-style concept.
lead_paragraph: PURCHASE, N.Y. — To fit African art into Western art history, we had to contain it, tame it. One way was by sorting the art into so-called tribal styles, in much the way we split up the continent into countries. Sure, the divisions were fake, but they gave us a feeling of control.

title: West Africa Trembles With Nigeria
snippet: Howard W French article on sudden death of Nigeria's iron-fisted Pres Gen Sani Abacha and naming of Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar to succeed him; contends that any political transition in African continent's most populous, most complicated and arguably ...
lead_paragraph: THERE was something more than faintly American about the first speech of Nigeria's new military head of state, following the sudden death on Monday of the country's iron-fisted President, Gen. Sani Abacha.

title: Betrayal and Suspense in Remote West Africa
snippet: A French thriller, set in a remote corner of Africa, concerns the death of a worker and its cover-up.
lead_paragraph: Everyone in “Battle of Black and Dogs” is nervous. Anxious. High-strung. Hanging onto sanity or civility by the thinnest of threads.

title: Finding Her Groove in Africa and a Violin
snippet: The jazz violinist Regina Carter plumbed the sounds of African folk at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Regina Carter bookended her first set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night with duologue, plucking or bowing her violin alongside the Malian kora player Yacouba Sissoko. The graceful symmetry of their exchanges came with a transparent subtext. Ms. Carter had landed at the club with a new agenda: to put a personal spin on African folk music, as she does throughout her forthcoming album, “Reverse Thread” (E1), due on May 18. Presenting Mr. Sissoko as a partner was a way to signal her intentions.

title: Uganda Could Be Model For 'New' Africa's Goals
snippet: Uganda has achieved most stunning transformation of six countries Pres Clinton is visiting during his African trip; Uganda's economy is fastest growing in Africa; security has been re-established in most of country after years of lawlessness; fram...
lead_paragraph: Winston Churchill called this lush, landlocked country ''the pearl of Africa.'' Idi Amin turned it into a charnel house. Now it is a display window for an African renaissance.

title: An African Peace Force
snippet: Editorial contends that Clinton Administration is giving belated but useful attention to one of Africa's most acute problems--terrible human suffering caused by civil conflicts, like current fighting between Tutsi and Hutu in Zaire; notes that Adm...
lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration is giving belated but useful attention to one of Africa's most acute problems -- the terrible human suffering caused by civil conflicts, like the current fighting between Tutsi and Hutu in eastern Zaire. The Administration has proposed creation of an African Crisis Response Force, whose troops would come from African armies and much of the financing and training from the West. The idea marks a welcome departure from the recent international neglect of Africa's problems and could save thousands of lives.

title: African at the Savoy
lead_paragraph: Tabu Ley Rochereau, one of Africa's most popular performers, will return tomorrow night at 8:30 to the Savoy (398-0662), 141 West 44th Street. He will be accompanied by the musicians and dancers of Orchestre Afrisa International, featuring the singer M'Bilia Bel. Tickets are $15.

title: In Africa, wary thanks for Hu - Africa & Middle East - International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — China's ascendance into the ranks of global powers is often depicted as a juggernaut of sorts, an untroubled and unfettered rise that lesser countries can only watch with awe and trepidation.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ex-No. 2 Accused In Rape Trial
snippet: The rape trial of Jacob G. Zuma, left, the nation's former vice president, took a threatening turn as protesters burned photographs of his accuser outside the Johannesburg courthouse. Officials of the African National Congress, of which Mr. Zuma r...
lead_paragraph: The rape trial of Jacob G. Zuma, left, the nation's former vice president, took a threatening turn as protesters burned photographs of his accuser outside the Johannesburg courthouse. Officials of the African National Congress, of which Mr. Zuma remains deputy president, and his legal defense fund distanced themselves from the protest. In court, Mr. Zuma's lawyers, who won court permission to examine the 31-year-old accuser's sexual history, questioned her statement that she had believed that she and Mr. Zuma, 63, who has admitted consensual sex with her, had had a father-daughter relationship before the alleged attack. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: Germany: Report on Africa Aid Disputed
snippet: The Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development disagreed with the contention of Bono and his antipoverty advocacy group, DATA, that Germany has gone off track in meeting its promise to double aid to Africa by 2010. The ministry said the gro...
lead_paragraph: The Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development disagreed with the contention of Bono and his antipoverty advocacy group, DATA, that Germany has gone off track in meeting its promise to double aid to Africa by 2010. The ministry said the group’s decision to exclude debt relief as a form of aid was “factually unjustified.” It said the debt relief it provided had helped African governments put more children in school and improve health. France, too, has disputed the organization’s exclusion of debt relief.

title: Black Africa And Israel
South Africa Is Divided on Gesture by Educator
snippet: A pardon of four white students who were expelled for a racist video has incited outrage across South Africa.
lead_paragraph: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa  For a speech about reconciliation it could hardly have been more divisive. Jonathan D. Jansen, the new head of the University of the Free State, spoke of the “place of infamy” just 100 yards behind him, the residence hall where four white students last year made a racist video that incited outrage across the country.

title: ON SOUTHERN AFRICA
lead_paragraph: The English say that treacle traps flies more easily than a swatter. The Administration's treacly foreign policy for Southern Africa - called ''constructive engagement'' - is designed first to encourage South Africa to yield control of Namibia and second to persuade South Africa to help the West insure the region's security. In fact, the policy has brought no answer to the Namibian question and has unintentionally allowed South Africa to intensify security measures at home.

title: Mutiny in Central Africa
lead_paragraph: Soldiers took control of the center of this capital city today and surrounded the presidential palace in the second mutiny in the Central African Republic in as many months.

title: The Lawmakers’ Letter on South Africa
snippet: The letter is the first concrete effort at retaliation by members of the U.S. government over the growing view that South Africa’s ties with Russia is moving in a direction that threatens America’s national interests.
lead_paragraph: The letter is the first concrete effort at retaliation by members of the U.S. government over the growing view that South Africa’s ties with Russia is moving in a direction that threatens America’s national interests.

title: Ford Foundation to Announce Africa Initiative
snippet: Ford Foundation to announce new philanthropic venture led by Africans and based in Senegal, which aims to strengthen nonprofit groups across continent that seek to hold governments accountable; commits $30 million; Trust Africa director Akwasi Aid...
lead_paragraph: The Ford Foundation will announce today the creation of a new philanthropic venture, led by Africans and based in Dakar, Senegal. The project, Trust Africa, aims to strengthen an expanding network of nonprofit groups across the continent that seek to hold governments accountable, whether elected or dictatorships.

title: Audra McDonald Is Returning to Broadway! There’s Just One Catch.
snippet: Colorblind casting is wonderful. Don’t use it to sanitize our racist past.
lead_paragraph: The recent announcement that Audra McDonald will be starring as Mama Rose in “Gypsy” has thrilled Broadway fans. I’m as delighted as anyone and eager to catch the show when it opens in December. McDonald is the queen of American musical theater, and “Gypsy” is often considered the best musical ever (and if there were no “Follies,” it would be).

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: America's Cup Crew Hits Whale
snippet: Shosholoza, South Africa's yacht entered in 2007 America's Cup race, hits Southern right whale near Cape Town; skipper and navigator are injured when keel hits whale; condition of whale is unknown (S)
lead_paragraph: The yacht being used to train crew members for South Africa's entry in the 2007 America's Cup competition struck a Southern right whale off Cape Town, injuring the skipper and the navigator. The racing yacht, Shosholoza, was traveling at 10 knots when its keel, which extends some 13 feet below the surface, collided with the whale and brought the boat to a dead stop. The skipper, Geoff Meek, and the navigator, Marc Lagesse, were at the port and starboard steering wheels, both of which were snapped off when they were thrown into them. A third crewman, Charles Nankin, was thrown overboard but was picked up by an accompanying crew boat. A team spokeswoman said the keel was damaged; injuries to the whale, which surfaced nearby after the impact, remain unknown. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Youthful African Envoys of Continuing Traditions
snippet: The 21 young performers in the lively “Spirit of Uganda,” a music and dance revue that opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, are from a country where, according to the program, 2.4 million children have lost their parents to AIDS, civil wa...
lead_paragraph: The 21 young performers in the lively “Spirit of Uganda,” a music and dance revue that opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, are from a country where, according to the program, 2.4 million children have lost their parents to AIDS, civil war and poverty. Now on a national tour that ends May 1, these Ugandans are performing to raise money for Empower African Children, a Dallas organization that is producing the tour and handled events by the revue’s predecessor, the Children of Uganda.

title: Africans in U.N. Press South Africa Curbs
snippet: Western nations seek African backing for new proposal; 49-member African group is demanding sweeping embargo (M)
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28—Western countries sought African backing today for their new proposal for a six‐month mandatory embargo on arms sales to South Africa.

title: A Theft From South Africa’s President. A Silence From South Africa.
snippet: Namibian investigators tracing money transfers by men suspected of stealing wads of cash from President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa say their cross-border calls for help went unanswered.
lead_paragraph: WINDHOEK, Namibia — Namibian investigators were hot on the trail of the suspected burglars. After receiving a tip about a sensational heist — the theft of cash from a farm belonging to President Cyril Ramaphosa of neighboring South Africa — they had traced large money transfers that the suspects made from South African to Namibian bank accounts.

title: Out of Africa, a Collection and a Dedication to Giving Back
snippet: Mercedes Vilardell fell in love with the art when she visited Malick Sidibé’s studio. Now she travels to Africa several times a year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As a philanthropist and as a collector, Mercedes Vilardell has distinguished herself by her focus. In the former arena, there is a consistent mission; in the latter, a tight aesthetic.

title: Deadly Rains and Floods Sweep Cities Across East Africa
snippet: Downpours have killed at least 200 people and submerged homes and farms in Tanzania, Kenya and Burundi.
lead_paragraph: At least 200 people were killed and dozens more were injured across East Africa in recent days, officials and aid groups said, as torrential rains, floods and landslides pummeled towns and cities in a region already grappling with the devastating effects of the climate change crisis and dilapidated infrastructure in poor areas.

title: A Beginning For South Africa
lead_paragraph: MANDELA AND DE KLERK traces the career of Nelson Mandela (played by Sidney Poitier, above) from his imprisonment in 1964 for organizing the African National Congress through his election to the presidency of South Africa three decades later. The film details the inside political maneuvering between Mr. Mandela, F. W. de Klerk (Michael Caine) and the hard-liner Prime Minister P. W. Botha (portrayed with verisimilitude by Gerry Maritz).For their part in ending apartheid, Mr. Mandela and Mr. de Klerk shared the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Israel Deports African Migrants
snippet: The deportation of a group of 50 migrants, said to include Sudanese refugees from war-torn Darfur, was condemned by Israeli human rights advocates.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 — Israel sent approximately 50 African migrants, said to include Sudanese refugees from war-torn Darfur, back across the border to Egypt late Saturday night, a move that was condemned by Israeli human rights advocates when it became known today.

title: Bagging Bargains in Cape Town, South Africa
snippet: With stunning landscapes, inventive chefs, great beaches and a currency that has lost nearly a third of its value, this city is now an affordable luxury.
lead_paragraph: The inhabited world seems to peter out at Noordhoek Beach, a five-mile strip of white sand bordered by verdant cliffs, on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula 15 miles southwest of Cape Town. At 4 o’clock in the afternoon, with a pale sun shining weakly through an overcast sky, a friend and I followed a trail on horseback through dunes and wetlands leading to the coast. A long-billed Hadeda ibis and a pair of Egyptian geese waded in a freshwater stream swollen with recent rains.

title: Country of the Week: South Africa
snippet: Can you find South Africa on a map? Did you know South Africa has 11 official languages? Test your knowledge with our new quiz.
lead_paragraph: Can you find South Africa on a map? Did you know South Africa has 11 official languages? Test your knowledge with our new quiz.

title: Obama Addresses African Union
snippet: President Obama on Tuesday called on leaders in Africa to support democracy and create jobs for the young to help forestall instability and disorder.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Tuesday called on leaders in Africa to support democracy and create jobs for the young to help forestall instability and disorder.

title: Anger at South Africa’s Leader
snippet: Jacob Zuma and the African National Congress need to look at how entrenched rule and corruption have damaged the country.
lead_paragraph: This month, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa did the sort of thing that has become common in his administration: He abruptly fired a respected finance minister who had tried to put the brakes on irresponsible government spending and put in an obscure political hack. To Mr. Zuma’s surprise, South Africans erupted in anger this time, compelling the president to yank his new appointee in favor of a trusted former finance minister, Pravin Gordhan. But that failed to calm the waters, and it should not. Mr. Zuma has done far too much damage to his country to be let off the hook.

title: How an Artist Became the Queen of Baltimore
snippet: Joyce J. Scott’s 50-year retrospective at the Baltimore Museum of Art draws inspiration, beauty and humor from her hometown and its people.
lead_paragraph: Joyce J. Scott is not an easy woman to interview. It’s not that she is reticent. It’s just hard to get a word in edgewise because practically every person we passed during our day together in Baltimore stopped to talk to her, shouting out “The Queen!” or “Mama Joyce!” whenever we entered one of her local haunts.

title: A Tentative Move Toward South African Reform
snippet: Cyril Ramaphosa’s election as leader of the African National Congress rebuked the corrupt President Jacob Zuma, but he, too, has been an insider.
lead_paragraph: Cyril Ramaphosa, once Nelson Mandela’s choice to be his heir, was elected on Monday as leader of South Africa’s African National Congress, the country’s dominant party, and thus almost certainly will become the next president. He was distinctly the better of the two available choices, but whether he can live up to the hopes of his late mentor is a far different question.

title: Helping Africa to reach for the moon
snippet: An African-led space exploration initiative launches a crowdfunding mission to reach the continent's final frontier - the moon. As Grace Pascoe reports, it's about winning the hearts of young Africans too.
lead_paragraph: An African-led space exploration initiative launches a crowdfunding mission to reach the continent's final frontier - the moon. As Grace Pascoe reports, it's about winning the hearts of young Africans too.

title: Photographing Africa’s Fashion Elite
snippet: The Swedish photographer Per-Anders Pettersson has spent the last five years documenting the vibrant fashion scene across sub-Saharan African.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish photographer Per-Anders Pettersson has spent the last five years documenting the vibrant fashion scene across sub-Saharan African.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Hunt For Boy Swept Away In Sewer
snippet: Rescuers continue search for three-year-old boy, who fell into open sewer on Soweto township (Johannesburg, South Africa) construction site; allegations that boy was pushed by playmates noted (S)
lead_paragraph: Rescuers searched frantically but without success for a 3-year-old boy who fell into an open sewer construction site in Johannesburg's Soweto township and was swept away in a rapid tide of storm water. The disappearance and later charges that playmates had accidentally pushed the toddler into a hole left uncovered by construction workers, has dominated South African headlines. Officials said there was no hope that the boy would be found alive. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: From Southern Africa to American Tracks
snippet: Gabriel Mvumvure of Louisiana State and Ngonidzashe Makusha of Florida State, from an unlikely home for sprinters, have run to the forefront of college track and field.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia

title: A Promise of a Cleaner South Africa
snippet: With the departure of a compromised top prosecutor, the country’s new president can now take on endemic corruption in government and the ruling African National Congress.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of South Africa’s chief prosecutor by the country’s highest court on Monday demonstrates both the hurdles and the promise of the battle against deeply ingrained corruption, which he pledged after the resignation under duress of the perfidious Jacob Zuma as president six months ago.

title: Embassy Terror in Africa
snippet: Editorial says embassy bombings in Africa are unwelcome reminder that world's most powerful country is world's number one target for terrorists; says US embassies everywhere need to be provided with highest possible standards of physical security ...
lead_paragraph: The deadly terrorism that struck United States embassies in Africa yesterday stunned Americans. It came as an unwelcome reminder that, in a terrorist's eyes, the world's most powerful country remains the world's number one target. American embassies everywhere will need to be provided with the highest possible standards of physical security.

title: Europe and Migration From Africa
snippet: With tens of thousands arriving from Africa, the E.U. needs to have a coherent plan to deal humanely with refugees.
lead_paragraph: A controversial deal signed between the European Union and Turkey in March has reduced the flow of refugees and migrants to Greece from Turkey. Now, the European Union is turning its attention to migrants from Africa heading across the Mediterranean to Italy.

title: Straight Talk in Africa
lead_paragraph: Olusegun Obasanjo, former President and still a powerful personality of Nigeria, says it straight out. ''The bold fact is that Africa is a continent in dereliction and decay. We are moving backward as the rest of the world is forging ahead.''

title: Collector Fights for African Art
snippet: Sindika Dokolo aims to force the West to return art he contends was looted from Africa during the colonial era.
lead_paragraph: PORTO, Portugal — Sindika Dokolo, a Congolese businessman and art collector, is on a crusade to force Western museums, art dealers and auction houses to return Africa’s art, particularly works that might have been removed illegally during the colonial era.

title: Healing South Africa
lead_paragraph: South Africa's apartheid regime has been dismantled, but not its legacy of suffering, particularly among survivors of the violent crimes committed in its name. Paying the debt of accountability and reparations owed to these South Africans is essential to building a peaceful nonracial democracy.

title: A Basket Maker Keeping Alive, and Reinventing, an Ancestral Craft
snippet: Mary Jackson, who is featured in museums like the Smithsonian, works in the fiber-arts tradition of the Gullah Geechee of coastal South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jackson was 4 when she learned how to weave. Sitting at her mother’s knee in the late 1940s, she tied her first knots with nimble little fingers, binding coils of sea grasses. In the Gullah Geechee communities of coastal South Carolina, where basket making is a centuries-old tradition, young children often start the weave for their elders. Jackson grew up surrounded by expert needlewomen who elevated this style of weaving from a strictly domestic craft to culturally profound artistry.

title: NYT: Africa: Land of Hope
snippet: There are signs of a turnaround in Africa, and plenty of reason for optimism.
lead_paragraph: There are signs of a turnaround in Africa, and plenty of reason for optimism.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: De Beers To Cut Supplier
snippet: European Commission orders De Beers to stop buying rough diamonds from Alrosa of Russia as of 2009 in order to open market to more competition; De Beers accounts for 70 percent of all rough diamonds in world, while Alrosa accounts for 20 percent; ...
lead_paragraph: The European Commission has ordered De Beers, the world's biggest diamond company, to stop buying rough diamonds from Alrosa of Russia as of 2009 in order to open the market to more competition. De Beers accounts for 70 percent of all rough diamonds in the world, while Alrosa accounts for 20 percent. De Beers agreed to cooperate, and will phase out purchases from Alrosa over the next three years, the commission said in a statement yesterday. "For the first time in the history of the diamond market, there is an opportunity for genuine competition," Europe's competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, said. PAUL MELLER (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Minister Who Balked On AIDS Is Reappointed
snippet: South African President Thabo Mbeki reappoints Health Minister Manto Tshabalala-Msimang despite concerns of critics who say she mishandled AIDS crisis by suggesting HIV can be treated with garlic and beet root (S)
lead_paragraph: President Thabo Mbeki reappointed his health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, over the protests of many who say she has badly mishandled the nation's staggering AIDS crisis. She once suggested that H.I.V. infections can be treated with garlic and beet root. An estimated 600 South Africans die of the disease each day. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: Born Free in South Africa
snippet: The future of South African politics may depend on the generation born after Mandela.
lead_paragraph: The future of South African politics may depend on the generation born after Mandela.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 'Sister Beating' Remark Draws Fire
snippet: South African Pres Thabo Mbeki draws bitter criticism from opposition politicians for saying he would beat his sister if she fell in love with Christian Democratic leader; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: President Thabo Mbeki drew bitter criticism from opposition politicians after he said at a campaign rally that he would beat his sister should she fall in love with the leader of the rival African Christian Democratic Party. Aides said the remark, at a rally for the ruling African National Congress, was made in a lighthearted vein. But the No. 2 party, the Democratic Alliance, said Mr. Mbeki's statement, on the nation's Human Rights Day, was a low point in his tenure. A spokesman for the Christian Democrats said the remark was evidence that Mr. Mbeki was becoming desperate in advance of elections next month. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: South African Signals
lead_paragraph: A few hours after F. W. de Klerk became its Acting President, South Africa substantially eased a problem threatening the transition of neighboring Namibia to independence. Its officials recalled to base 1,200 policemen, former members of a brutal paramilitary unit, who were accused of harassing civilians.

title: Catalyzing Africa’s Climate Potential
snippet: A high-profile summit tries to kick-start the transition to clean energy.
lead_paragraph: Hopes were running high in Nairobi, Kenya, this week as African leaders gathered for an inaugural climate summit designed to urgently kick-start the continent’s transition to clean energy.

title: African Languages Grow as a Wikipedia Presence
snippet: Swahili version of free online encyclopedia Wikipedia has only 1,025 entries, compared to English language version's 1,377,015 and counting; Wikipedias in less common languages face basic questions like how to create online encyclopedia when few n...
lead_paragraph: At the second annual Wikimania conference, held this year at Harvard Law School, there was what might be considered a quintessential Wikipedian moment: as Martin Benjamin, a researcher at Yale University, gave a talk about the Swahili dictionary he is creating online, Ndesanjo Macha was simultaneously sitting in the audience using a Wi-Fi connection and laptop to put the finishing touches on his Wikipedia entry, "Martin Benjamin," in Swahili.

title: On Tour, Pompeo Courts Africa, to Counter China
snippet: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, on his first visit to sub-Saharan Africa, promotes partnerships with American companies, but finds China’s presence pervasive.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo landed in Ethiopia as part of his first foray into sub-Saharan Africa, he arrived in a city shaped by the same adversary that he had come to preach against: China.

title: Jackson as African-American
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is here, telling leaders at the conference of the African-American Institute what they want to hear from the U.S.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 2 Guilty Of Feeding Victim To Lions
snippet: A judge handed down murder convictions for a farm owner and an employee who were accused of beating a rural laborer and then throwing him to 20 rare white lions. The farmer, Mark Scott-Crossley, left, and his employee, Simon Mathebula, were said t...
lead_paragraph: A judge handed down murder convictions for a farm owner and an employee who were accused of beating a rural laborer and then throwing him to 20 rare white lions. The farmer, Mark Scott-Crossley, left, and his employee, Simon Mathebula, were said to have attacked Nelson Chisale with knives in January 2004, after Mr. Chisale, who had been fired, came to collect his belongings. Mr. Chisale was tied to a tree and beaten, then driven to the lion enclosure and thrown over its fence. Only part of a skull, a few bones and shredded clothes remained when the police searched the pen. Testimony never established whether Mr. Chisale was alive when he was tossed to the lions. The spectacular case was held up as an example of continuing racism in rural South Africa. Mr. Scott-Crossley is white, his employee and Mr. Chisale black. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Drawing on the Optimism in African Gumboot Dance
snippet: The St. Lawrence String Quartet gave the premiere of David Bruce’s lively “Gumboots” for clarinet and string quartet on Thursday at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: Classical composers have incorporated numerous traditions into their music, including Czech folk tunes, jazz, blues and tango. David Bruce goes further afield with a work inspired by South African gumboot dancing, a form that originated during apartheid.

title: African and Invisible: The Other New York Migrant Crisis
snippet: Like many who have crossed the border from Latin America, they arrived in New York after a desperate journey. But these men have few options in the city, often relying on one man in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t know from the outside of Imam Omar Niass’s house, but the tidy brick building on a residential block in the Bronx is filled to capacity. Every night, nearly 70 men, newly arrived African migrants, sleep squashed together on the floor in an airless basement, a tangle of arms and feet and fitful dreams.

title: African Deal For Nielsen
lead_paragraph: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's A. C. Nielsen unit will return to South Africa after a seven-year hiatus by buying a stake in the locally based Integrated Business Information Services.

title: Russian Mercenaries Are Destabilizing Africa
snippet: Wagner’s reach extends far beyond the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: One of the groups that have risen to international prominence (or infamy) with the invasion of Ukraine is Wagner, a Kremlin-backed mercenary outfit that regularly employs former criminals. In Ukraine, they often fight when conventional Russian Army troops flee the battlefield, and they are noted for their brutality.

title: South Africa's Loss
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bloom, perhaps the most outspoken foe of apartheid in the South African business community, is moving to England. Mr. Bloom, the 49-year-old chairman of a food processing conglomerate, says he is leaving for ''business, personal and family'' reasons. But it's no secret that the man who accused his Government of ''thuggery and authoritarianism'' in the last election has been deeply depressed by the drift of white South Africans to the right.

title: South Africa Is Falling Apart
snippet: The deep rot of the country’s social and political order is now on full display.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In the past few weeks, South Africa was gripped by the biggest explosion of unrest in decades. Shopping malls and warehouses were looted, supply trucks attacked and businesses destroyed. At least 337 people died.

title: A Nibble of Caledonia in Africa
snippet: Travel article describes trout fishing in mountains of eastern Zimbabwe; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: I AM nominally Scottish.

title: Tales Out of Africa
lead_paragraph: ZENZELE A Letter for My Daughter. By J. Nozipo Maraire. 194 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $20.

title: African Languages Grow as a Wikipedia Presence
snippet: How do you create an online encyclopedia when few native speakers have access to the Internet?
lead_paragraph: At the second annual Wikimania conference, held this year at Harvard Law School, there was what might be considered a quintessential Wikipedian moment: as Martin Benjamin, a researcher at Yale University, gave a talk about the Swahili dictionary he is creating online, Ndesanjo Macha was simultaneously sitting in the audience using a Wi-Fi connection and laptop to put the finishing touches on his Wikipedia entry, “Martin Benjamin,” in Swahili.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Minister Defends Garlic Aids Diet
snippet: South African Health Minister Manto Tshabalala-Msimang repeats her advice for boosting immune system, which she believes will keep HIV positive individuals from developing AIDS; suggested diet of garlic, olive oil and lemon juice was denounced by ...
lead_paragraph: The minister of health, Manto Tshabalala-Msimangagain, insisted that a diet of garlic, olive oil and lemon juice helps fend off the effects of AIDS, repeating a message denounced last year by a leading national medical journal as ''ill-considered advice'' not backed up by scientific data. Ms. Tshabalala-Msimang scolded reporters at a parliamentary briefing for their earlier ridicule of her prescription, saying that the three ingredients are ''absolutely critical'' to boosting the immune system and that as little as a monthly teaspoon of olive oil would reap benefits. Like President Thabo Mbeki, she has cast doubt on what most scientists call an irrefutable link between the HIV virus and AIDS. Estimates vary, but at least one in 10 South Africans is H.I.V.-positive. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: International African American Museum Delays Opening
snippet: One month before its debut, the long-awaited Charleston center acknowledged problems with humidity and temperature controls. It will open later in 2023.
lead_paragraph: The International African American Museum in Charleston, S.C., has building issues that will delay the eagerly awaited center’s opening until later in 2023, museum leaders said.

title: A Getaway At the Tip of Africa
snippet: Joseph Berger article on the travel attractions of False Bay, a quiet South African fishing village; listing of accomodations and highlights; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: AMONG the latest visitors to discover the pleasures of False Bay, at the tip of Africa, are jackass penguins, which soar out of the Indian Ocean water and, with a Charlie Chaplin tramp walk, scurry up Boulders Beach to nest in the thick, sloping brush behind the ivory sand.

title: Africa's forgotten AIDS cases - Africa & Middle East - International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: YAOUNDÉ, Cameroon — Five-year-old Anastasia Enongo lies curled like a fetus in the top bunk of the hospital here, coughing weakly, intravenous medicine dripping into her arm. Born to a mother who died of AIDS, the girl has always been sick, relatives said with an air of annoyance, her life a parade of doctors' visits for fevers, coughs, diarrhea.

title: A New Destination for African Art
snippet: “Luminós/C/ity.Ordinary Joy” inaugurates the new Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African and African American Art at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A few weeks before the revamped Harvard Art Museums reopened here, a new university-affiliated art space, the Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African & African American Art, made its debut in modest quarters, two former storefront offices off Harvard Square, filling a slot that other local institutions left all but empty. The raw spaces were unpromising, to say the least, but the architect David Adjaye has done miracles in linking them and carving out eight nichelike galleries for the first show, "Luminós/C/ity.Ordinary Joy: From the Pigozzi Contemporary African Art Collection,” for which he also served as curator along with Mariane Ibrahim-Lenhardt.

title: A Warning for the A.N.C. in South Africa
snippet: The narrow margin of victory for the governing party showed that voters are sick of stagnation and corruption.
lead_paragraph: Cyril Ramaphosa, who retained South Africa's presidency in national elections last week, faces a serious quandary. His party, the African National Congress — the party of Nelson Mandela, which has governed the country since the end of apartheid — has become profoundly corrupt, as any party would after 25 years of unchallenged power. Yet because of that same corruption, voters denied Mr. Ramaphosa the strong mandate he may need to cleanse the party and put South Africa back on track.

title: Watching and Waiting in South Africa
snippet: The Times’s Marcus Mabry reports from Johannesburg, where South Africans are closely watching Nelson Mandela’s condition.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Marcus Mabry reports from Johannesburg, where South Africans are closely watching Nelson Mandela’s condition.

title: South Africa’s Odious Monument to Cecil John Rhodes
snippet: University of Cape Town students are right to demand the removal of a statue honoring colonialism’s great exemplar.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — For two decades, many South Africans assumed that our university campuses had become politically apathetic. But this may be the year that South Africa’s students wake up from a deep sleep, refreshed and determined to demand transformation of their educational institutions.

title: Africa Needs Science, Not Aid
snippet: Education — and science and technology in particular — must be at the forefront of the debate about African development.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When John F. Kennedy came to the University of Michigan to campaign for president in the fall of 1960, Africa was plagued with trade and governance challenges far more daunting than those it faces today. The young senator recognized that African nations — like other countries emerging from colonialism — were preoccupied with developing basic literacy and manpower. And so he urged students to go abroad and help them. The spirited response resulted in one of America’s greatest gifts to the world: the Peace Corps.

title: Conflict Spreads in Central Africa
snippet: Could religious extremism and terrorism spread through the region?

title: Wanted: An Airline For All of Africa
snippet: Most airlines in Africa, except South African Airways, provide spotty, unreliable service around continent; 1999 pan-African agreement to deregulate airlines and allow more competition is not adhered to; South African Airways attempts multiple cro...
lead_paragraph: FLYING around this continent of dilapidated airports on dysfunctional airlines can take much time and patience. Andrew Mthembu, a South African mobile-telephone executive, has little of either.

title: South African To Join MetroStars
snippet: MetroStars invite South African midfielder Dillon Sheppard to train with team (S)
lead_paragraph: The MetroStars leave on Tuesday for two weeks of training at the IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla., and will be met by a promising young South African player who could stick with the club.

title: House Hunting in ... South Africa
snippet: After several years of slow, consistent growth, most sectors of the housing market in South Africa saw a noticeable hike in home prices in 2014 linked to housing shortages, particularly in metropolitan markets.
lead_paragraph: A CAPE DUTCH-STYLE HOME WITH A POOL IN A SUBURB OF DURBAN

title: 1915: Germans Capitulate in Africa
snippet: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany fails in South-West Africa in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An official telegram received from Pretoria to-day [July 9] announces that General Botha has accepted the capitulation of the whole of the German forces in German South-West Africa. This triumphal end of General Botha’s masterly campaign against the German forces had been expected for some days, owing to the rapid progress of General Botha’s troops in Damaraland. A despatch received from Cape Town yesterday stated that the capture of 750 Germans and their guns represented only the first results of General Botha’s masterly enveloping movement, which is paralyzing the Germans and has entirely frustrated any attempt at scattered guerrilla warfare. The end is believed to be near. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1915

title: Eagles Take to South African Agriculture
snippet: A community of Verreaux’s eagles is faring better in a landscape of farms than a similar group in a more remote region.
lead_paragraph: An eagle population in South Africa is thriving despite its situation in an agricultural landscape, according to a new paper in The Condor: Ornithological Applications. The birds are Verreaux’s eagles, predators in decline in southern Africa. Surprisingly, a community in the heavily farmed Sandveld region is healthier than one in the nearby, less developed Cederberg Mountains. The researchers speculate that the agricultural terrain may be easier for eagles to navigate and that their prey may be more diverse. The researchers said that potential threats, like the development of wind turbines, should be monitored.

title: Music Is Over for the Brazil of Africa
snippet: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column discusses Ghana's 3-0 loss to Brazil in second round of World Cup; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: DORTMUND, Germany - IT is hard to carry the flag for an entire continent, even in something as trivial as soccer.

title: African Struggle
lead_paragraph: CRY FREEDOM Starring Denzel Washington, Kevin Kline (in photo), Penelope Wilton, Kate Hardie, Josette Simon, John Thaw, Zakes Mokae, Sophie Mgcina. Directed by Sir Richard Attenborough. 1987. MCA Home Video. 156 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG. Some violent episodes.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: Brewer's Profit Is Up
snippet: SAB Miller says revenue and earnings for five months ended Aug 31 were up from year-earlier period; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The South African company that bought the Miller Brewing Company, SABMiller, as it is now called, said revenue and earnings for the five months ended Aug. 31 were higher than during the period a year ago. The growth was buoyed by strong sales in Central and Eastern Europe as well as in Africa. Sales of the Miller Brewing Company's own lager in the United States were below that of year-ago levels, but in line with the company's expectations, Graham Mackay, the chief executive, said in a statement. The amount of beer sold in Poland and the Czech Republic increased compared with last year, as did volumes in most major African markets, except for South Africa. Growth in Russia was smaller than SABMiller had anticipated. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Paradigm Shift for Aid to Africa
snippet: Politics and growing economies are driving parallel changes in priorities for aid, posing a continuing challenge to donors as they try to channel funds and advice to where it will do the most good.
lead_paragraph: The junta that took control of Mali in March holds court at a barracks at Kati, a town northeast of the country’s capital, Bamako. Heavily armed men lounge under trees drinking tea; a machine gun nest sits next to a soccer field.

title: Chaos in South Africa's parliament
snippet: Members of South Africa's Economic Freedom Fighters party clash with security officials, after they were ordered out of the chamber during President Jacob Zuma's annual address. Yiming Woo reports.
lead_paragraph: Members of South Africa's Economic Freedom Fighters party clash with security officials, after they were ordered out of the chamber during President Jacob Zuma's annual address. Yiming Woo reports.

title: Africa econs stronger in 2015?
snippet: Despite boosting investment and finding new and unique sources of revenue, African economies showed their vulnerability in 2014. Will they be more resilient this year? Joel Flynn reports.
lead_paragraph: Despite boosting investment and finding new and unique sources of revenue, African economies showed their vulnerability in 2014. Will they be more resilient this year? Joel Flynn reports.

title: Germany Grapples With Its African Genocide
snippet: Tens of thousands of Namibians were killed in what historians call the 20th century’s first genocide, and Germany is finally close to recognizing it as such.
lead_paragraph: WATERBERG, Namibia — In this faraway corner of southern Africa, scores of German soldiers lie in a military cemetery, their names, dates and details engraved on separate polished tombstones.

title: Art and the African-American Experience
snippet: Here is a sampling of Long Island events — including exhibitions, lectures, musical performances and films — that commemorate the black experience this month.
lead_paragraph: Those planning to attend the Feb. 8 concert at Hofstra University commemorating Black History Month, be prepared: There will be a vocal “call and response” moment during the otherwise instrumental performance of Imani Winds.

title: African Diasporas, Playing With the Past
snippet: A Senegalese has recreated portraits made centuries ago of Africans who lived in Europe and were commemorated in now-forgotten Western art.
lead_paragraph: Omar Victor Diop, a Senegalese photographer, was feeling out of place during an artist residency in Málaga, Spain, when he discovered the seminal series “The Image of the Black in Western Art.” In it, he found centuries-old Western paintings from the Menil Collection in Houston that depicted people of African descent from the Renaissance to the emergence of the slave trade. As an African who was educated in Paris, he was aware of the long history of marginalizing the African diaspora in European museums. Understandably, he was captivated by what he saw.

title: Behind the Comparison of Zuma’s South Africa and Mugabe’s Zimbabwe
snippet: Cracks are showing in the post-apartheid compromise that cannot be explained away by personality politics.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — “Heh, you people, you used to laugh at us. Look at you now. You can’t even buy a bottle of Coke!”

title: A Festival of Ideas and Photos in Africa
snippet: The Lagos Photo Festival strives to foster encounters among photographers inspired by Africa and to nurture local artists.
lead_paragraph: Azu Nwagbogu, the founder of the Lagos Photo Festival, is guided by a simple credo: He wants to exhibit everybody. Yes, that’s a big goal. But it’s an even bigger continent with a breathtaking range of people, stories and photographers who have been inspired by it.

title: President Obama’s Africa Push
snippet: A landmark summit meeting was a splashy event that advertised the continent’s economic potential. But major follow-through is necessary to achieve results.
lead_paragraph: One major purpose of President Obama’s landmark White House summit meeting on Africa last week was to advertise this often underrated continent’s economic potential and ensure it a brighter future. But determined follow-through will be required if the aspirations of the president and more than 40 African heads of state who were his guests are to be realized and Africa is to satisfy its promise as the world’s last big economic frontier.

title: Looking Past Africa's Turmoil
snippet: The perception of Africa as a collection of dystopian states and regions persists, but there are signs of a subtle shift.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Question: How does the West see Africa? Answer: Through a prism, darkly.

title: Gold threatens Africa's cocoa
snippet: West Africa's cocoa future is under threat as farmers turn to gold. As Sonia Legg reports lucrative gold prices are largely to blame.
lead_paragraph: West Africa's cocoa future is under threat as farmers turn to gold. As Sonia Legg reports lucrative gold prices are largely to blame.

title: Africa, Out in the Cold
lead_paragraph: In a burst of compassion and amid loud applause, the United States a year ago rushed to the rescue of the sick and starving in Somalia. But for Africans, this holiday season is even bleaker, and not just for Somalis. When the humanitarian mission in Somalia went sour, most of Africa below the Sahara also seemed to drop from sight. Every bit of bad news -- civil wars, military coups, drought and disease -- has sadly reinforced a mood of fatalism or still worse, callous unconcern.

title: Citibank in South Africa
lead_paragraph: Citibank said yesterday that it had received clearance from the Reserve Bank of South Africa to open its first office there. Initially, Citibank intends to open a representative office providing advisory services to corporate clients. Such a branch is typically a "prelude to a full branch office," a spokesman said. When a full branch does open, it will provide service to commercial clients rather than individuals, he said. He declined to give a timetable or site for the opening or to say how many people would work in the office.

title: A Touchy South Africa Takes Pains Not to Kowtow
snippet: Pres Clinton is spending 11 days in Africa, but he is really making two different trips: one to Africa and one to South Africa; South Africa is of Africa, but different too; its economy dwarfs that of any other African countries; some 300 American...
lead_paragraph: President Clinton is spending 11 days on this continent, but he is really making two different trips: one to Africa and one to South Africa.

title: Curator Puts Contemporary African Art on the Map
snippet: Over the last two decades, Koyo Kouoh has become one of Africa’s pre-eminent curators and art managers
lead_paragraph: LUND, SWEDEN — Watching Koyo Kouoh make a last quality check on an exhibition she has curated is a lesson in focus, attention to detail and zen.

title: African Billionaire Looks Ahead
snippet: CNBC interview at Davos with Aliko Dangote, the Nigerian-born billionaire who controls an enormous commodities empire on the continent, on investing in Africa.
lead_paragraph: CNBC interview at Davos with Aliko Dangote, the Nigerian-born billionaire who controls an enormous commodities empire on the continent, on investing in Africa.

title: Curator Puts Contemporary African Art on the Map
snippet: Over the last two decades, Koyo Kouoh has become one of Africa’s pre-eminent curators and art managers
lead_paragraph: LUND, SWEDEN — Watching Koyo Kouoh make a last quality check on an exhibition she has curated is a lesson in focus, attention to detail and zen.

title: Who Is Telling Africa’s Stories?
snippet: Easier access to digital equipment has led to a surge of local photographers, but not to more opportunities for aspiring photojournalists.
lead_paragraph: Easier access to digital equipment has led to a surge of local photographers, but not to more opportunities for aspiring photojournalists.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mining Company's Profit Rises
snippet: World Business Briefing: South Africa: Mining Company's Profit
lead_paragraph: The mining company Anglo American announced first-half profits of $767 million, saying cost-cutting had helped the company through a slump in commodities markets. Profits were up slightly from the period last year, when, after discounting one-time gains, the company earned $765 million. Anglo said its base metals division, which includes copper and zinc, had shown substantial improvement, offsetting poor performances by its coal and platinum units. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Africa: The new BRIC in investing
snippet: The U.S. is late with more than $17 billion in new investments in the fast-growing African economy, but companies are eager to get a piece of the action as growth in Brazil, Russia, India, and China (BRIC countries) slow.  Conway G. Gittens report...
lead_paragraph: The U.S. is late with more than $17 billion in new investments in the fast-growing African economy, but companies are eager to get a piece of the action as growth in Brazil, Russia, India, and China (BRIC countries) slow.  Conway G. Gittens reports.

title: A Gentle Welcome to West Africa, at Teranga in East Harlem
snippet: You can build your own meal at this restaurant in the Africa Center, but it’s best to follow the chef Pierre Thiam’s lead.
lead_paragraph: A drape of waxy leaves, a drip of vines: You have arrived at another latitude. Palms lean protectively, ready to offer shade, but none is needed here indoors at Teranga in East Harlem, one of the city’s loveliest spaces in which to graze, lounge and resist the levies of life.

title: Out of Africa, Part II
snippet: A farming village too parched to sustain crops is also losing its men, who leave in search of work to support their families.
lead_paragraph: Ndiamaguene, SENEGAL — I am visiting Ndiamaguene village in the far northwest of Senegal. If I were giving you directions I’d tell you that it’s the last stop after the last stop — it’s the village after the highway ends, after the paved road ends, after the gravel road ends and after the desert track ends. Turn left at the last baobab tree.

title: No Ibrahim Prize for African Leadership This Year
snippet: For the third time in four years, the Ibrahim Foundation found no former African head of state worthy of its good-governance award.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — For the third time in four years, a multimillion-dollar good-governance prize for African leaders has failed to find a winner, testimony to the continuing difficulties bedeviling democracy and human rights on the continent.

title: A Link That Divides in South Africa
snippet: Millions of blacks still live in townships far from centers of commerce and employment, forced to endure commutes that devour their time and meager incomes.
lead_paragraph: Millions of blacks still live in townships far from centers of commerce and employment, forced to endure commutes that devour their time and meager incomes.

title: African Diasporas, Playing With the Past
snippet: A Senegalese has recreated portraits made centuries ago of Africans who lived in Europe and were commemorated in now-forgotten Western art.
lead_paragraph: A Senegalese has recreated portraits made centuries ago of Africans who lived in Europe and were commemorated in now-forgotten Western art.

title: A Comeback for African National Parks
snippet: As wildlife authorities on the continent work with nonprofit organizations to secure ecologically valuable landscapes, populations of large mammals have grown.
lead_paragraph: The earth’s sixth mass extinction, scientists warn, is now well underway.

title: Born Free in South Africa
snippet: A young South African photographer born after apartheid explores his country, from black and white to rich and poor.
lead_paragraph: With bold confidence, Sipho Mpongo, born in 1993, a year before apartheid ended, declares himself part of “the new age of South Africa.” His parents, like many of their generation, fought for freedom. And though he came of age in a nation claiming to be democratic, he knows better than anyone that moving past decades of state-sanctioned segregation takes time.

title: For Africa, a Pivotal Plane Crash
snippet: Students of modern Africa exploring the dramas of the postcolonial era might start their quest for pointers in the period surrounding the death of Dag Hammarskjold.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a tragedy that resonated far from its time and its place.

title: Photographer’s Lens: Obama in Africa
snippet: The Times’s Doug Mills examines a few key moments that occurred while following President Obama on his seven-day tour of Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Doug Mills examines a few key moments that occurred while following President Obama on his seven-day tour of Africa.

title: South Africa's War on Women
snippet: Unlike India, our society has not reckoned with an epidemic of misogynistic violence
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — Two years ago, when Jyoti Pandey, a 23-year-old Indian physiotherapy intern, was gang-raped and fatally beaten by six men on a bus in New Delhi, there was a moment of soul searching among South Africans.

title: Philadelphia Offers a Full-Fledged Summer of African Art
snippet: “Creative Africa,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and “Nari Ward: Sun Splashed,” at the Barnes Foundation, bring us into a present that pushes toward the future.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — People talk about Africa as if it were a unitary thing, one culture, one mind, which it’s not. That’s my only problem with “Creative Africa,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and my complaint stops with the title. The project itself, a set of five small, tight, concurrent exhibitions of African material, is richly textured, and in one case sensational.

title: From Peru's African Heritage
snippet: Article on Afro-Peruvian music and dance tradition preserved by Peru Negro, group performing at University of California at Los Angeles; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: THINK of Peruvian music and dance and you probably imagine Andean folk groups, blowing their pan pipes in Times Square or plazas throughout Europe. Yet there's another side to Peruvian culture, the African side. And for more than 30 years, the most respected caretaker of this Afro-Peruvian tradition has been the music and dance ensemble Peru Negro. On Saturday at Town Hall, the company will make its New York debut.

title: A Circle of Celebration, Forged in Africa
snippet: Angélique Kidjo’s Carnegie Hall concert commemorating Miriam Makeba on Wednesday night was respectful, yet far from solemn.
lead_paragraph: One strong African woman honored another at Angélique Kidjo’s tribute concert for Miriam Makeba on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, where she was joined by Vusi Mahlasela from South Africa, Laura Mvulu from England and Ezra Koenig from the African-influenced New York City band Vampire Weekend. Whoopi Goldberg started the concert with praise for both Makeba, who died in 2008, and Ms. Kidjo.

title: Real African China Patterns
lead_paragraph: UNLIKE the generic ethnicity and exoticism that have marked many home-furnishing designs targeted to a mass market, the Africa Collection from Essex Enviro-Safe Fine China has clear, authentic references. Two china patterns are based on 19th-century textiles from the Yorubas of Nigeria.

title: Fashion Companies Embrace Africa
snippet: Suzy Menkes speaks with Ali Hewson, her husband Bono and Renzo Rosso about the trio’s new clothing line that sources materials from Africa.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes speaks with Ali Hewson, her husband Bono and Renzo Rosso about the trio’s new clothing line that sources materials from Africa.

title: For Lincoln Center’s West Side, A New Story
snippet: The formidable arts institution has hired a design team to reconsider its relationship with its neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The formidable arts institution has hired a design team to reconsider its relationship with its neighborhood.

title: A Microcosm of the New South Africa
snippet: The South African township of Soweto — famed for its resistance to apartheid — captured the imagination of Per-Anders Pettersson when he covered South Africa’s first democratic elections in 1994. Nearly twenty years later, its bustle still appeals...
lead_paragraph: Few place names are as burdened with history as Soweto. Nelson Mandela once called it home. The infamous center of resistance to apartheid — South Africa’s entrenched system of white supremacy — the township was a symbol of poverty and oppression on the one hand and heroism and sacrifice on the other. Fittingly, it gave its name to a 1976 uprising of young activists that forever changed the country’s political landscape.

title: Righting Wrongs and Generating Attention for Art of the African Diaspora
snippet: Pamela J. Joyner is on a mission to bring more attention to artists who have been overlooked and to help develop the careers of others.
lead_paragraph: Sheena Wagstaff, chairwoman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s modern and contemporary art department, was relatively new on the job in 2013 when Pamela J. Joyner, a prolific art collector and supporter of artists of African descent, invited her on a trip to Washington to visit the studio of the Color Field painter Sam Gilliam. They looked at Mr. Gilliam’s in-progress pieces, a series of striking works with a thin stream of paint poured on board.

title: Sick in America, Aching for Africa
snippet: Africa’s no-frills attitude toward health care is more effective than America’s no-expenses-spared approach in treating diseases like malaria.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — I came down with my first African disease in America. It happened after I traveled to Nigeria last April to witness my country elect a new government. I landed with notebooks and questions, but not antimalarial medication. I had been more prudent on dozens of prior stays, but, I thought, no matter: I had already been running around the continent for months with no mishaps. After three rounds of free and fair voting, I returned to my apartment in Nairobi, buoyant about democracy in Africa.

title: South Africa's Wreckers
lead_paragraph: Two groups have formed an unscrupulous alliance to disrupt the first elections in South Africa in which all races will have a vote. A glance at opinion polls shows why die-hard white separatists have joined with the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party to boycott the April election. Their own political strength is anemic. The boycotters together get less than 10 percent, and Inkatha trails badly even in its Natal Province stronghold. Unable to rule, the Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi and his white fellow wreckers now threaten to ruin anyone else's chance to govern.

title: Real Estate in South Africa
snippet: The market in the affluent beachfront suburbs of Cape Town, like Camps Bay and nearby Clifton, has improved over the last year.
lead_paragraph: The market in the affluent beachfront suburbs of Cape Town, like Camps Bay and nearby Clifton, has improved over the last year.

title: South Africa Wins Medals
lead_paragraph: South Africa took its first medals in these Olympics today when the doubles team of Wayne Ferreira and Piet Norval won a silver medal in tennis and a distance runner, Elana Meyer, took a silver medal in the women's 10,000-meter run.

title: Yellow Fever Epidemic in Africa Shows Gaps in Vaccine Pipeline
snippet: The outbreak was stopped by a huge vaccination campaign that stretched supplies by diluting doses.
lead_paragraph: The yellow fever outbreak in Africa this year came closer to being a disaster than is widely recognized, public health experts recently disclosed. The epidemic also revealed glaring weaknesses in the emergency vaccine supply pipeline.

title: End of Apartheid in South Africa? Not in Economic Terms
snippet: Political liberation has yet to translate into material gains for blacks. As one woman said, “I’ve gone from a shack to a shack.”
lead_paragraph: CROSSROADS, South Africa — The end of apartheid was supposed to be a beginning.

title: A New Age for African Artists
snippet: With the expectations of democracy and liberated by the Internet, the Kenyan artist collective Just a Band has found an international audience for its mix of entertainment and political content.
lead_paragraph: With the expectations of democracy and liberated by the Internet, the Kenyan artist collective Just a Band has found an international audience for its mix of entertainment and political content.

title: African Oils, Exotic and in Demand
snippet: Moving away from chemical formulas, many companies are adding naturals oil and extracts from Africa.
lead_paragraph: Working with a chemist and a French perfumer, Magatte Wade sought to incorporate ingredients traditionally used by healers from her native Senegal into Tiossan, a line of fragrance and bath products.

title: Finding the Beauty in African Sales
snippet: Local cosmetics companies are growing but they still struggle with expansion and the continent's sprawling informal trade system.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Suzie Wokabi had sticker shock when she returned to her native Kenya in 2007 and saw that the high-end cosmetics she had used as a MAC makeup artist in the United States were in short supply — and three times as expensive.

title: Zimbabwe and the Causes of African Poverty
snippet: My take is that colonialism isn’t as big a factor in Africa’s poverty as many believe. But bad governance has been a central problem. Your take?
lead_paragraph: In my Sunday column, I cite Zimbabwe as evidence that Africa’s basic problem has been bad governance. So here’s your chance to weigh in on the larger question of why Africa has been left behind.

title: South Africa: President Announces New Spending on Jobs
snippet: President Jacob Zuma made tackling staggering unemployment the government’s top priority on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Jacob Zuma made tackling staggering unemployment the government’s top priority on Thursday. He announced $2.7 billion in tax breaks to encourage investment in manufacturing, and an additional $1.25 billion for job-creation undertakings, without offering specifics. The unemployment rate fell to 24 percent from 25.3 percent in the final quarter of 2010. When those who have given up looking for work are included, more than a third of the potential work force is jobless.

title: The Technology Our West Africa Bureau Chief Relies On
snippet: Dionne Searcey says that even with sometimes spotty internet connectivity, West Africans have embraced smartphones and apps like WhatsApp and Skype.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Dionne Searcey, The Times’s West Africa bureau chief based in Dakar, Senegal, discussed the tech she’s using.

title: Coping With an African Emergency
