snippet: Bodhana Sivanandan, a fourth-grader, has become one of England’s best players just a few years after discovering chess during pandemic lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Since learning chess during a pandemic lockdown, Bodhana Sivanandan has won a European title in the game, qualified for this year’s prestigious Chess Olympiad tournament, and established herself as one of England’s best players.

title: F-16 Fighter Jet, Recently Supplied to Ukraine, Crashes
snippet: A Western official said the advanced fighter crashed while defending against a Russian aerial assault. It was not clear how it was destroyed, but the loss is a blow to Ukraine, given the planes’ prominence.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian F-16, recently supplied by NATO countries, was destroyed this week while defending against a sweeping Russian aerial assault and the pilot was killed, Ukraine’s military said on Thursday.

title: E.C.B. Leaves Rates Unchanged but Keeps Door Open for September
snippet: The central bank left its key deposit rate at 3.75 percent as inflation in the eurozone is expected to fluctuate throughout the rest of the year.
lead_paragraph: European Central Bank policymakers held interest rates steady on Thursday, as they reiterated their cautious approach to cutting rates as inflation bumps around above the bank’s target.

title: Investigation Into Yacht That Sank Off Sicily Broadens
snippet: Prosecutors are looking into the actions of two other crew members in connection with the sinking of the luxury yacht Bayesian, which caused the deaths of seven people.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Sicily have broadened their investigation into the sinking of the luxury yacht, the Bayesian, and are now looking into the actions of two more crew members, their lawyer said Thursday.

title: Telegram Founder’s Indictment Thrusts Encryption Into the Spotlight
snippet: The criminal charges against Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, raised concerns in Silicon Valley about encryption and the app’s approach to privacy and security.
lead_paragraph: When French prosecutors charged Pavel Durov, the chief executive of the messaging app Telegram, with a litany of criminal offenses on Wednesday, one accusation stood out to Silicon Valley companies.

title: U.K. Failed in Handling of Covid Pandemic, Inquiry Finds
snippet: The British authorities prepared for the wrong pandemic, with an outdated plan overly focused on influenza, an official investigation reported.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s government “failed” the country’s citizens in its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, a damning report from an official public inquiry said on Thursday, partly because officials had prepared for “the wrong pandemic.”

title: Von der Leyen Secures Second E.U. Term, but It’s a New World Out There
snippet: The German conservative, a steadfast U.S. ally, gained European Parliament approval to lead the European Commission for another five years. She’ll face tumult at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: After a pandemic, a cost-of-living crisis and a major war in Europe, not many feel nostalgia for the past five years. Ursula von der Leyen soon might.

title: This Biopic Could Be Angelina Jolie’s Oscar Comeback
snippet: “Maria,” about the opera diva Maria Callas, plays to the star’s strengths. Its Venice Film Festival debut was timed so the actress could avoid Brad Pitt.
lead_paragraph: She’s one of the most famous actresses to have ever lived, but how formidable is Angelina Jolie’s filmography?

title: In Europe, Tactical Voting Was a Big Winner. In the U.S. It Is Harder.
snippet: In France and England, parties worked to limit voters’ choices to avoid splitting votes.
lead_paragraph: France and Britain held elections last week, and the big winner turned out to be … tactical voting. In both countries, the election results showed the effectiveness of political parties coordinating to limit the choices that voters face — and of voters using that information to vote tactically against a party they oppose, even if that means not voting for their true first choice.

title: Ukraine Says It Struck at 2 Oil Depots Inside Russia
snippet: Kyiv is pressing its drone campaign while lobbying allies for permission to use weapons supplied by NATO countries for strikes deep inside Russia.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the Russia-Ukraine war.

title: The Woman Shaking Up German Politics From the East
snippet: Sahra Wagenknecht, a former Communist, has founded her own party to respond to German grievances about migrants, crime and the dangers of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Sahra Wagenknecht, who has never met a political party she could tolerate, has founded her own, and she is shaking up German politics with a combination of right-wing nationalism and left-wing socialism, articulated with seriousness and fluency.

title: Inquiry Into ‘Killer Nurse’ Won’t Weigh Key Question: Is She Innocent?
snippet: More than 20 experts have called on the U.K. government to delay a public inquiry into the case of Lucy Letby, who was convicted of murdering babies, because of growing concerns about the evidence.
lead_paragraph: A public inquiry into the case of Lucy Letby, a British neonatal nurse convicted of killing seven babies, has come under fire from scientific and medical experts who have called for it to be delayed or broadened to consider whether the deaths could have been caused by other factors.

title: Thursday Briefing
snippet: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Durov, the Russian-born entrepreneur who founded the online communications tool Telegram, was charged yesterday in France with a wide range of crimes and barred from leaving the country. The Paris prosecutor said that Durov was released from custody, but had been ordered to pay bail of five million euros, or about $5.5 million.

title: Algerian Man Charged Over Synagogue Arson Attack in France
snippet: The man expressed deep hatred of Jews and said he had acted to “support the Palestinian cause,” according to French antiterrorism prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A 33-year-old Algerian man was charged on Wednesday with attempted murder and other crimes after an arson attack on a synagogue in southern France last week, prosecutors said.

title: C.I.A. Warning Helped Thwart ISIS Attack at Taylor Swift Concert in Vienna
snippet: The agency provided information about several suspects that led to arrests, the deputy director said.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. provided intelligence to Austrian authorities that allowed them to disrupt a plot that could have killed thousands of people at a Taylor Swift concert in Vienna this month, the agency’s deputy director said on Wednesday.

title: Jenna Ortega Has Fans Lining Up at the Venice Film Festival
snippet: After the actors’ strike muted the 2023 edition, this year’s event is being powered by stars like the “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” actress and her castmates.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, several hours before Tim Burton’s “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” opened the Venice Film Festival, dozens of young people were already camped out by the Palazzo del Cinema in the hopes of seeing one of the film’s stars.

title: Italians Fight for the Right to Feast on the Beach
snippet: For those who feel priced out of expensive, privatized seaside clubs in Italy, elaborate lunch spreads feel like the last bastion of good spirits.
lead_paragraph: At 1 p.m. at the San Girolamo beach in Italy’s southern city of Bari, as the sun reached its summit and temperatures came close to 100 degrees, the smell of fried green peppers made its way through a thick maze of umbrellas and folding chairs.

title: Shelling Kills 6 in Ukraine as Russia Pushes Ahead in East
snippet: The rest of the country, though, was largely spared from another consecutive night of large-scale Russian bombardment.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the Russia-Ukraine war.

title: E.U. Court Rebukes Bloc’s Executive Arm Over Covid Vaccine Contract Secrecy
snippet: The court ruled that the European Commission wrongly withheld information, casting a shadow on its leader, Ursula von der Leyen, before a crucial vote on her future.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s second-highest court delivered an unusual reprimand to the European Commission on Wednesday, ruling that it did not give the public sufficient information about its agreements to purchase Covid-19 vaccines during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The East Rises in Germany, and So Does Political Extremism
snippet: Closely watched elections in the former East Germany are likely to reveal a still-divided country and yield a worrying challenge to Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Anna Wenske, 69, worked for decades at the national theater of East Germany, where she was born and still lives. “After the reunification, everything went kaput,” she said. She lost her job and her savings; it took her years of part-time work to reach a kind of equilibrium.

title: Promise of a Changed U.K. Comes Wrapped in Royal Tradition
snippet: From plans to tackle climate change to ending the role of hereditary legislators, the ceremonial King’s Speech showcased the progressive priorities of Britain’s Labour government.
lead_paragraph: At last, a “King’s Speech” that the king himself might have written, at least in its bridge-building, planet-saving passages.

title: Venice Film Festival 2024: What to Watch For
snippet: “Joker: Folie à Deux,” with Joaquin Phoenix, and Pedro Almodóvar’s first English-language feature are on tap. Here are the questions we hope to answer.
lead_paragraph: The 81st edition of the Venice Film Festival kicks off Wednesday with the premiere of Tim Burton’s sequel “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice,” and starry fare will follow, like the sexually provocative Nicole Kidman film “Babygirl” and the George Clooney-Brad Pitt team-up “Wolfs.”

title: Meghan Markle Is a ‘Dolphin,’ Not a Shark
snippet: At least when it comes to investing. The latest addition to her portfolio: the handbag brand Cesta Collective.
lead_paragraph: Many things have changed since Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, moved from London to California.

title: Want a Rich, Rustic Taste of Spain? Head for the Hills of La Rioja.
snippet: A drive through rolling vineyards will take you to 5 family-run restaurants where you’ll find flavorful, affordable dishes you can linger over for hours.
lead_paragraph: Hear the word “Rioja” and the first thing that comes to mind is wine — high-quality, fruit-forward red wine.

title: Can Tech Executives Be Held Responsible for What Happens on Their Platforms?
snippet: The indictment of Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, as part of an investigation into illicit activities on the messaging app set off worries about the personal liability of tech executives.
lead_paragraph: This month, X closed its Brazil operations after one of its executives was threatened with arrest for not taking down certain content. Last year, Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, pleaded guilty to federal money-laundering violations that took place on his cryptocurrency platform. In 2021, Twitter executives in India faced arrest over posts that the government wanted removed from the site.

title: Why Hasn’t Russia Kicked Out Ukrainian Invaders? Its Own Invaders Are Busy.
snippet: Despite its overwhelming firepower, Russia has been unable for weeks to push Ukrainian troops back across the border, with the failure as much the result of priorities as a lack of personnel.
lead_paragraph: The barrage of airstrikes that Russia launched against Ukraine over the past two days, with hundreds of drones and missiles, provided punishing evidence of Moscow’s enduring military might.

title: Wednesday Briefing
snippet: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 70 days away. This is what we’re watching.

title: Trekking Across Switzerland, Guided by Locals’ Hand-Drawn Maps
snippet: Nostalgic for a time before ubiquitous connectivity, a writer ditched his phone and relied instead on serendipity — and maps made by people he met along the way.
lead_paragraph: Nostalgic for a time before ubiquitous connectivity, a writer ditched his phone and relied instead on serendipity — and maps made by people he met along the way.

title: Russia Bombards Ukrainian Cities for a Second Day
snippet: An early morning barrage hit several locations across Ukraine, including a hotel in Kryvyi Rih where at least four people were killed and several others wounded, Ukrainian officials said.
lead_paragraph: An early morning barrage hit several locations across Ukraine, including a hotel in Kryvyi Rih where at least four people were killed and several others wounded, Ukrainian officials said.

title: Scientists Have a New Theory About Why Orcas Are Attacking Boats
snippet: A pod of orcas damaged a boat and left its two-person crew stranded. It was the latest in a string of attacks that research suggests could be used for hunting practice.
lead_paragraph: The orcas have struck again — this time ramming a sailboat off Spain’s northwest coast, rescue workers said on Tuesday.

title: ‘Sinners’ and ‘Russian Talibans’: A Holy War Roils a Once Placid Village
snippet: A battle has erupted in Moldova over its links to the Russian Orthodox Church, seen by many as a tool of Moscow’s influence abroad.
lead_paragraph: The village was a placid place until the local priest, disoriented by the war in Ukraine, succumbed to Satan, according to the retired teacher in northern Moldova. Before that, people got on well and attended Sunday services at the same Russian Orthodox Church.

title: To Revitalize Britain’s Economy, a Plan for a Stronger Government Role
snippet: The Labour Party’s economic agenda, like many other programs around the world, puts political leaders more firmly in charge of industrial policy.
lead_paragraph: The last time a freshly minted Labour government unabashedly campaigned on an ambitious national industrial policy to revive the British economy was 50 years ago, and the results were generally viewed as disastrous.

title: Is This Concert the Gold Standard for a Green Gig?
snippet: Coldplay and Billie Eilish have tried to drive down carbon emissions while touring, but the British band Massive Attack has tried to take the efforts even further.
lead_paragraph: When the British band Massive Attack was halfway through a West Coast tour in 2019, flying from show to show, the rapper and singer Robert Del Naja had a moment of crisis. Given all the carbon emitted by moving the band and its equipment around, he recalled wondering: Can I justify this anymore?

title: Russia Launches Deadly New Wave of Missiles and Drones at Ukraine
snippet: The bombardment that began on Monday could have additional significance, coming three weeks after the Ukrainian military’s incursion into Russia’s Kursk region.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a fresh wave of pre-dawn missile and drone attacks on Kyiv and several other large Ukrainian cities on Tuesday, the second day of a deadly, far-reaching bombing campaign that comes as Moscow fights to fend off a Ukrainian offensive on Russian soil.

title: To Stay Relevant, a Spanish Energy Giant Turns to Waste
snippet: Repsol figures that there is still life in vehicle fuels as long as they can be portrayed as low carbon.
lead_paragraph: In a narrow valley with steep sides near the ancient city of Cartagena, Spain, a team of 150 engineers has just finished building a plant that could be a game changer for Repsol, the Spanish energy company, and a bellwether for the transportation industry.

title: Europe Rejoins Space Race but New Rocket’s Flight Ends in Anomaly
snippet: Ariane 6 reached orbit on Tuesday. But a problem made the European Space Agency rocket deviate from its flight plan late in the mission.
lead_paragraph: At long last, Europe’s eagerly awaited rocket headed to space.

title: Prosecutor Turned Politician: Could Britain’s Leader Show Harris a Path to Power?
snippet: Like Kamala Harris, Prime Minister Keir Starmer was a prosecutor before embracing politics. The two share a few other traits.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris said last week in Chicago, “you can always trust me to put country above party,” it struck a familiar note in Britain, where the new prime minister, Keir Starmer, used much the same phrase throughout the Labour Party’s relentless march to power earlier this summer.

title: In Eastern Ukraine, Terrifying Bombardment and Near Total Destruction
snippet: Powerful guided “glide bombs” have helped Russia raze entire towns with ever greater speed. “When you drive into a ruined town, it’s like hopelessness,” one soldier said.
lead_paragraph: In the darkness of the cellar in the eastern Ukrainian town of Toretsk, the soldiers did not know how close the Russian glide bombs were landing. But the sudden change in air pressure that accompanied bone-rattling booms testified to the bombs’ destructive force as they tore into nearby buildings.

title: Tuesday Briefing
snippet: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine yesterday, in what Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, described as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war. Officials said four people had been killed and more than 30 others had been injured.

title: Pushing Quick End to Ukraine War, Orban Plays Trump’s Messenger to E.U.
snippet: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary has been on a self-appointed diplomatic mission that aligns with Donald J. Trump’s preferences in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
lead_paragraph: After meeting with Donald J. Trump at his Mar-a-Lago home on Thursday, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary wrote to a top E.U. official to say that Mr. Trump had told him he was planning a swift push for a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine.

title: Uber Fined $324 Million by Dutch Watchdog Over Driver Data Protection
snippet: The authorities in the Netherlands said the ride-hailing company had violated European data protection laws when it sent sensitive information to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Uber faces a fine of 290 million euros, or more than $324 million, over a violation of European Union rules that protect data privacy, a Dutch agency said Monday.

title: Russia Strikes Ukrainian Cities With Missiles and Drones
snippet: Cities across Ukraine were hit in a widespread attack that also targeted energy infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.
lead_paragraph: Cities across Ukraine were hit in a widespread attack that also targeted energy infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.

title: Telegram Turmoil Threatens Dominant Chronicle of the War in Ukraine
snippet: The detention of Telegram’s founder has highlighted the messaging app’s outsize status in Europe’s deadliest war since World War II.
lead_paragraph: The detention of Pavel Durov, the founder of the Telegram messaging app, in Paris on Saturday has raised questions about the future of a platform that has come to define the public perception of Russia’s war in Ukraine.

title: Wales’s First Minister Steps Down After Rising Pressure From Colleagues
snippet: Vaughan Gething became the first minister of Wales in March. But a growing controversy over campaign financing precipitated his decision to resign.
lead_paragraph: Vaughan Gething, the first minister of Wales, announced his resignation on Tuesday after less than four months, amid a controversy over campaign donations that prompted a vote of no confidence in his leadership.

title: Captain of Sunken Yacht Under Investigation in Deaths on Ship
snippet: The investigation does not necessarily imply that formal charges will follow against the captain, James Cutfield.
lead_paragraph: Italian authorities have opened a formal investigation into the actions of James Cutfield, the captain of the superyacht that sank last Monday off the coast of Sicily, killing seven of the 22 people on board, including British tech billionaire Mike Lynch.

title: Gareth Southgate’s England Tenure Ends With a Jump, Not a Push
snippet: Southgate’s eight years in charge made him the most successful England manager in decades. In stepping down two days after losing the Euro 2024 final, he got the last word.
lead_paragraph: Outside Gareth Southgate’s office at St. George’s Park, the remote training facility that serves as the home of English soccer, a series of portraits had been mounted on the wall. They depicted the 14 men who had preceded him in what was once described as the second-most important job in the country: manager of the England men’s soccer team.

title: How Telegram’s Founder Went From Russia’s Mark Zuckerberg to Wanted Man
snippet: Pavel Durov’s anti-establishment streak helped him create one of the world’s biggest online platforms, which emphasizes free speech. It also put a target on his back.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, when Russia pushed Pavel Durov to shut down the pages of opposition politicians on a Facebook-like site he had created, the tech entrepreneur responded online by posting a cheeky picture of a hoodie-wearing dog with its tongue out.

title: A Fire in East London Recalls Deadly Grenfell Cladding Scandal
snippet: More than 80 people were evacuated in the early hours of Monday from a building that had used similar insulation.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 people had to be evacuated after a major fire broke out in east London early Monday, fire officials said. The blaze brought back painful memories of the Grenfell Tower fire that killed 72 people in the city in 2017.

title: Russia Pounds Ukraine With ‘One of the Largest Strikes’ of the War
snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
lead_paragraph: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine on Monday, damaging energy facilities and sending residents of Kyiv into basements and subways to seek shelter. President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the assault as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war.

title: Fox Hunters in the U.K. Want Protected Status Under Discrimination Law
snippet: A lobbying group is preparing a bid to define hunting with animals as a protected belief. Many experts have questions.
lead_paragraph: English fox hunters have tried, for years, to push back against a nearly 20-year-old ban on their beloved sport.

title: The Warrior Queen Who Carried a Head in a Bag, and Other Omissions
snippet: In her corrective “The Missing Thread,” the classical historian Daisy Dunn paints a fuller picture of the ancient world.
lead_paragraph: Feminist retellings of classical myth and history are having a moment. This is partly a publishing-industry trend, but also the result of a real thirst for stories about women in the ancient world, women whose lives have long been ignored or were never recorded in the first place.

title: 1 Tourist Is Dead and 1 Injured After Ice Canyon Collapses in Iceland
snippet: Rescuers on Monday called off a search for what they initially believed were two other trapped tourists after it became clear that all the visitors were accounted for.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers in Iceland on Monday called off the search of a deadly ice canyon collapse after they determined that, contrary to initial reports, there were no other tourists trapped beneath the debris, the police said.

title: Monday Briefing
snippet: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: After Israel’s military and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah fired back and forth over the weekend in one of the largest cross-border barrages since the war in Gaza began, both sides quickly claimed victories of sorts. By yesterday morning, the two sides were employing the language of containment.

title: French Authorities Arrest Suspect in Synagogue Attack
snippet: Antiterrorism prosecutors said officers had taken a man into custody in connection with a blast outside a synagogue in the southern French resort of La Grande Motte.
lead_paragraph: A suspect who has an arrest record for minor crimes but was not on the radar of French or foreign antiterrorism authorities has been detained in connection with Saturday morning’s attack on a synagogue in southern France, which is being investigated as a terrorist act, the French authorities said on Sunday.

title: German Prosecutor Says Islamic State Terrorist Link Is Suspected in Festival Stabbings
snippet: The police say they have arrested a man they believe killed three people and wounded eight others at a festival in the town of Solingen, in western Germany.
lead_paragraph: An attack by a man armed with a knife that left three dead at a local festival in a western German city is being treated as terrorism, with possible links to the Islamic State, German prosecutors said on Sunday

title: Forces on Both Left and Right Battle for Europe’s Political Soul
snippet: A coarsening of public discourse and contempt for mainstream parties have politicians on both sides denouncing what they say are extreme positions by their opponents, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Primed to celebrate victory but left explaining why his party finished third, the leader of France’s hard-right National Rally blamed Sunday’s surprise election result on the “caricature” of his party as extremist. That “disinformation,” he said, handed victory to “formations of the extreme left.”

title: Telegram Becomes Free Speech Flashpoint After Founder’s Arrest
snippet: Pavel Durov, the founder of the app, which has more than 900 million users, was taken into custody by the French authorities.
lead_paragraph: Telegram, founded in 2013 by the Russian entrepreneur Pavel Durov, has grown into one of the world’s largest online communication tools and is central to everyday life in countries like Russia, Ukraine and India for messaging, getting independent news and exchanging views.

title: Reuters Safety Adviser Killed and 2 Journalists Injured in Strike on Ukraine Hotel
snippet: Reuters said that a safety adviser working with the journalists was killed, and that two other members of its team were wounded after a hotel in eastern Ukraine was hit in a strike on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A safety adviser working with a team of journalists for the Reuters news agency was killed on Sunday and two journalists were wounded after a missile hit the hotel in which they were staying in eastern Ukraine, Reuters said in a statement.

title: Battle-Hardened Poets Fuel a Literary Revival in Ukraine
snippet: With verses that capture the raw emotions of the war and resonate deeply with the population, Ukrainian poets have emerged as some of the country’s most influential voices.
lead_paragraph: For several days in March 2022, the battalion of Yaryna Chornohuz, a Ukrainian poet and combat medic, faced fierce attacks from a column of Russian tanks in southeastern Ukraine. Outgunned, the soldiers repelled the first two assaults, but suffered many casualties.

title: Questions for Investigators Trying to Unravel Mystery of Luxury Yacht’s Sinking
snippet: The investigators searching for answers about the shipwreck, leaving seven dead, face questions about extreme weather and possible human error or problems with the yacht itself.
lead_paragraph: More than 180 feet long, with a mast towering about 240 feet and a keel that could be lowered for greater stability, the Bayesian luxury yacht did not, in the eyes of its maker, have the vulnerabilities of a ship that would easily sink.

title: The Young Frenchman Striving to Give Voice to a Troubled Area
snippet: As a teenager, Amine Kessaci confronted Emmanuel Macron, founded an environmental group and lost a brother to drug violence. At 20, he almost won a National Assembly seat.
lead_paragraph: At 17, Amine Kessaci found himself seated close to the president of France, Emmanuel Macron, who had come to Marseille to kick off his second presidential campaign in 2021.

title: Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Italy Yacht Disaster
snippet: An Italian prosecutor in charge of the case said it was just the “initial phases” of the inquiry into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht where seven were killed.
lead_paragraph: An Italian prosecutor in charge of the case said it was just the “initial phases” of the inquiry into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht where seven were killed.

title: Explosions Outside a France Synagogue Were a Terrorist Attack, Prosecutors Say
snippet: Politicians quickly condemned the attack, at a time when antisemitic incidents have been on the rise in France. A suspect has been arrested in the case.
lead_paragraph: Two vehicles parked outside a synagogue exploded in a French town on Saturday in what prosecutors called an act of terrorism.

title: New Arrest Made in Knife Attack That Left 3 Dead in Germany
snippet: The authorities announced the end of a manhunt, nearly a day after the attack, which happened Friday night at a festival in the city of Solingen.
lead_paragraph: The German police late Saturday made a third arrest in the fatal knife attack that took place Friday at a street festival in the western city of Solingen. An official said they had ended the search for a suspect in the stabbing episode, which killed three and injured several more, some of them seriously.

title: Italian Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Yacht Disaster
snippet: A prosecutor involved in the inquiry into the sinking said it was “plausible” that crimes were committed during the accident.
lead_paragraph: Italian authorities said on Saturday that they had opened a manslaughter investigation into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht, but that they had not yet zeroed in on any potential suspects.

title: On Ukraine’s Independence Day, Zelensky Celebrates Push Into Russia
snippet: Although the cross-border offensive carries risks, it also paid dividends on Saturday with the first prisoner swap with Russia in several months.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky, always adept at messaging, used his latest Independence Day speech on Saturday to drive home the idea that Ukraine is taking the fight to Russia, even as his troops struggle along the front line in the east.

title: Not Only for Killing: Drones Are Now Detecting Land Mines in Ukraine
snippet: Ukraine is a beta test for embedding artificial intelligence and other new technologies in drones and robots to find deadly land mines, saving lives and allowing military forces to advance more quickly.
lead_paragraph: With a stiff gait, a drone dog stomped up and down a makeshift minefield at a U.S. Army testing center in Virginia, shuddering when it neared a plate-size puck meant to simulate an anti-tank explosive. On its back was a stack of cameras, GPS devices, radios and thermal imaging technology that military developers hope will help it detect mines at close range, sparing humans from that dangerous task.

title: A French Museum Has Global Needs (but It Can’t Have New Jersey)
snippet: The Pompidou Center is creating international outposts to help fund a renovation of its Paris home. What happens now that Jersey City has pulled out?
lead_paragraph: The century-old Pathside Building in downtown Jersey City was originally a transportation hub for streetcar lines, but it took on a new role three years ago: It became the chosen destination for an outpost of the Pompidou Center, the Paris arts complex.

title: Isabelle Huppert Believes Festivals Are Crucial to Cinema’s Future
snippet: The veteran French actress of stage and screen is the jury president of this year’s Venice Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Actors often have more than one project on the boil. The French actress Isabelle Huppert takes multitasking to the next level.

title: Marina Cicogna’s Glamorous, Cinematic Legacy
snippet: Cicogna, who died in November, was the face of the Venice Film Festival for decades and a pioneer for women in the Italian film industry. She also knew how to throw a party.
lead_paragraph: She threw at least one party that would have made Bacchus envious, photographed Greta Garbo and Marilyn Monroe (both friends), co-produced the Oscar-winning “Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion” and distributed films by the directors Luchino Visconti, Luis Buñuel and Pier Paolo Pasolini, among others. If a person can personify a global film festival, Marina Cicogna was for decades the face of the Venice Film Festival.

title: How to Survive (and Maybe Conquer) the Edinburgh Fringe Festival
snippet: It’s a prime opportunity for performers looking to make a splash. Nadia Quinn, a comic actress and singer from New York, decided to give it a shot.
lead_paragraph: Nadia Quinn had been warned about bringing her show of wacky comic songs to the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh. Facebook groups, Reddit posts and friends suggested that taking on the 77-year-old festival as an unestablished performer was too daunting.

title: Police Investigate Deadly Knife Attack in Western Germany
snippet: The attack took place in a central square in Solingen, Germany, during a festival celebrating the town’s 650th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The attack took place in a central square in Solingen, Germany, during a festival celebrating the town’s 650th anniversary.

title: Manhunt in Western Germany After Knife Attack Kills at Least 3
snippet: The attack took place in Solingen during a celebration of the 650th anniversary of the city’s founding. Eight people were wounded.
lead_paragraph: The police in Germany were conducting a large-scale manhunt on Saturday after a person armed with a knife killed at least three people at a festival in the western city of Solingen on Friday night. The attacker, who escaped, also wounded eight others, five of them severely.

title: Iceland Volcano Erupts for Sixth Time in Less Than a Year
snippet: A volcano in Iceland near the town of Grindavik erupted on Thursday. Experts say the zone may continue to generate eruptions for years, potentially leading to the endangerment of nearby populated areas.
lead_paragraph: A volcano in Iceland near the town of Grindavik erupted on Thursday. Experts say the zone may continue to generate eruptions for years, potentially leading to the endangerment of nearby populated areas.

title: U.S. Tightens Technology Controls to Target Russian War Machine
snippet: The Biden administration announced new penalties on shell companies and suppliers that were feeding Russia’s war against Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Friday that it would add more than 100 companies and organizations in Russia, China and several other countries to a restricted trade list and take other measures, as it widens its net to try to capture more advanced technology that is flowing to the Russian military.

title: Peace Talks at Swiss Resort Beckoned. Sudan’s Divided Generals Wouldn’t Go.
snippet: American-led mediators secured famine relief for needy areas. But with Sudan’s military failing to attend, a cease-fire was far out of reach.
lead_paragraph: American-led talks to halt Sudan’s war, convened at an exclusive Swiss ski resort, ended after 10 days on Friday with agreements to deliver food and medicine to millions of starving Sudanese in the country’s most famine-stricken areas.

title: France’s Political Truce for the Olympics Is Over. Now What?
snippet: Lucie Castets, a relatively obscure bureaucrat, is the left’s choice to be prime minister. Just one person stands in her way: the president.
lead_paragraph: The first thing Lucie Castets intends to do as France’s next prime minister is to peel back the age of retirement to 62. Then, she will pour more money into the creaking health care and education systems. To pay for at least some of that, she will introduce a tax on the country’s ultrarich.

title: Are Soccer’s Showcase Games the Riskiest Gig in Music?
snippet: Performing before a major match like the Euro 2024 final offers priceless visibility, and the nonzero chance that you’ll be booed.
lead_paragraph: Even to some of the most glittering names in music, the pitch is compelling.

title: As Ukraine Pushes Into Russia, Its Next Steps Are Unclear
snippet: American officials are not convinced that Ukraine intends to hold its position in Russia long term.
lead_paragraph: More than two weeks into Ukraine’s incursion into western Russia, Ukrainian politicians have begun talking about establishing a buffer zone there. But how much farther Ukraine might try to advance into Russia, and how long it plans to stay, is unclear, U.S. officials said.

title: In England, a Changed Nation Hopes for a Change in Soccer Fortunes
snippet: After installing a Labour government for the first time in 14 years, the country is looking to a historical precedent as a presage to a long-awaited sporting success.
lead_paragraph: Whether “football’s coming home” is as unpredictable as ever. But in England, watching this weekend as its men’s national soccer team comes within touching distance of glory, the dreaming and dreading seem less anguished this time around.

title: Russia Quashes Deadly Prison Mutiny by Islamist Inmates
snippet: The revolt is the latest in a series of terrorist attacks in Russia claimed by Islamic militants.
lead_paragraph: Russian commandos quashed a mutiny at a southern Russian prison on Friday, killing the attackers and freeing their hostages, according to the local governor.

title: Ukraine Steps Up Strikes Into Russia as Moscow Pushes Ahead in the East
snippet: Ukraine struck a port across from Crimea and damaged a cargo ferry. But Kyiv’s forces continued to struggle in eastern areas under a relentless Russian assault.
lead_paragraph: As Ukrainian forces fight to isolate a large group of Russian soldiers caught between a river in Russia’s Kursk Province and the Ukrainian border, Kyiv has launched a series of strikes at airfields, ports and oil depots in other regions of Russia aimed at degrading the Kremlin’s war effort.

title: Final Body Is Recovered From Yacht That Sank Off Sicily
snippet: Hannah Lynch, the 18-year-old daughter of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, was on board a yacht that was hit by a storm and went down in the early hours on Monday.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a week after a violent storm sent a luxury yacht to the bottom of the sea off the coast of Sicily, Italian scuba divers plunged deep underwater, moving through ropes and fallen objects inside the yacht in a desperate search for the six people missing.

title: Indian Leader Visits Kyiv as Ukraine Pushes Diplomacy
snippet: Ukrainian officials were portraying the visit by Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India as a welcome show of support for their country during the war with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited Kyiv on Friday, furthering a diplomatic effort by Ukraine to engage non-Western nations in potential settlement talks with Russia, even as Ukraine’s military pressed ahead with an offensive into Russian territory.

title: Mapping Ukraine’s Surprise Invasion of Russia
snippet: Ukraine has captured dozens of Russian settlements, adding a new twist to a war that had largely settled into grueling fighting in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has captured dozens of Russian settlements, adding a new twist to a war that had largely settled into grueling fighting in eastern Ukraine.

title: Friday Briefing
snippet: The final night of the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.

title: Volcano Erupts Near Fishing Town in Iceland
snippet: The latest eruption, the sixth since December, is part of increased volcanic activity that began in 2021.
lead_paragraph: A volcano in southwestern Iceland erupted on Thursday, spewing ashes and lava, the sixth such eruption since December, according to the Icelandic Meteorological Office.

title: What I’m reading: A ‘Book of the Century’ I’d Somehow Missed
snippet: “The Last Samurai,” which has nothing to do with the Tom Cruise movie of the same name, is as good as everyone says.
lead_paragraph: Until a few weeks ago, when The New York Times's list of the best books of this century reminded me of the oversight, I had never read “The Last Samurai,” by Helen DeWitt.

title: Russia Opens New Cases Against Journalists Who Covered Ukrainian Incursion
snippet: Moscow said it was investigating three more reporters, including a CNN correspondent, who crossed into Russian territory to cover the fighting.
lead_paragraph: Russia on Thursday announced that it had opened a criminal case against a CNN correspondent and two Ukrainian reporters on charges of entering the country illegally while reporting on an incursion into the Kursk region by Ukraine’s armed forces.

title: A Times Russia Reporter Reflects on Evan Gershkovich’s Release
snippet: Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, was freed on Thursday after 16 months in a Russian prison. Anton Troianovski, The Times’s Moscow bureau chief, shared how he covered the moment.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, multiple planes touched down in Ankara, Turkey, releasing 24 people in a seven-nation prisoner exchange that finally resolved a human drama and diplomatic standoff.

title: Ukraine Cites Modi Visit as the Fruit of an Emerging Diplomatic Push
snippet: Officials say efforts to engage neutral nations like India along with the military incursion into Russia will strengthen Ukraine’s hand in any peace talks.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials are claiming that their military incursion into Russia this month coincides with a flurry of diplomatic overtures that could strengthen Kyiv’s push for wider international backing for its negotiating position in any potential peace talks.

title: A TikTok Cucumber Craze Has Iceland in a Pickle
snippet: Icelandic cooks, eager to try the latest social media trend, are amused and a little surprised by their empty produce aisles.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes,” the TikTok star known as “Cucumber Guy” intones at the start of his videos, “you need to eat an entire cucumber.”

title: Russian Attitudes About Putin Might Be Shifting
snippet: Negative remarks on social media have increased since Ukrainian troops launched an incursion, according to a firm that tracks Russian attitudes.
lead_paragraph: Negative feelings about President Vladimir V. Putin have appeared to increase across Russia since Ukrainian troops pushed into Russian territory two weeks ago, according to a firm that tracks attitudes in the country by analyzing social media and other internet postings.

title: Mike Lynch, Tech Mogul Acquitted of Fraud, Dies at 59
snippet: The British entrepreneur was found not guilty of fraud charges in the sale of his company to Hewlett-Packard. He was celebrating his acquittal when his yacht sank off the coast of Sicily.
lead_paragraph: Mike Lynch, a British software mogul who was once celebrated as a top technology leader — only to spend more than a decade defending himself against accusations that he orchestrated one of the biggest frauds in Silicon Valley history — died on Monday after his yacht sank off the coast of Sicily. He was 59.

title: Russia Pushes Forward in Ukraine’s East as Kursk Offensive Slows
snippet: The Ukrainians must defend a critical front in their country’s east, including the city of Pokrovsk, while trying to press forward in western Russia.
lead_paragraph: More than two weeks into its surprise offensive in western Russia, Ukraine’s advance has slowed, with its troops making only marginal gains around territory they already control.

title: Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Leader, Surprises Europe Again With Visit to China
snippet: Mr. Orban said his meeting with President Xi Jinping was part of a “peace mission” for Ukraine. But both leaders want to offset Western power.
lead_paragraph: Just three days after a visit to Moscow that infuriated his European allies, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary sprung another surprise on Monday by turning up in Beijing for previously unannounced talks with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, that featured promises to strengthen their countries’ robust relationship.

title: Mike Lynch’s Body Is Found After Sicily Yacht Sinking, Official Says
snippet: The authorities have recovered the bodies of all but one of the six people missing after disaster struck a yacht carrying the British software tycoon.
lead_paragraph: The body of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch was among those recovered by Italian divers, an official in the Sicilian capital, Palermo, said on Thursday, confirming that he was killed when a violent storm struck his yacht this week.

title: A Film Festival Founded in a War Zone, Still Going Strong
snippet: The Sarajevo Film Festival, now 30 years old, grew out of underground screenings during the siege of the city. Those roots still define the event’s character.
lead_paragraph: From 1992 to 1996, Serbian forces laid siege to the city of Sarajevo, relentlessly bombarding it and cutting off electricity, heat, running water and regular food supplies. Because of snipers perched on hillsides and constant shelling, going outside was a life-threatening act.

title: Lynch Yacht Sinking Off Sicily Proves as Baffling as It Is Tragic
snippet: As bodies were recovered, the authorities and experts wondered how a $40 million, stable and secure vessel could have sunk so quickly.
lead_paragraph: Two months after being cleared in a bruising legal battle over fraud charges, the British tech mogul Mike Lynch celebrated his freedom with a cruise. He invited his family, friends and part of his legal team on board his luxury sailing yacht, a majestic 180-foot vessel named Bayesian after the mathematical theorem around which he had built his empire.

title: A Combat Medic’s Quest to Change Tributes to Fallen Soldiers
snippet: Iryna Tsybukh, who was killed on the front line in Ukraine, wanted to humanize the way Kyiv commemorated the war dead. She also left notes for her own funeral.
lead_paragraph: Her funeral would be “awesome,” the young Ukrainian combat medic said, if it went as she had planned.

title: Thursday Briefing
snippet: Hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military and Hezbollah traded cross-border strikes yesterday, leaving at least one person dead deep inside eastern Lebanon, as months of diplomatic efforts have failed to ease tensions in the region.

title: Ex-U.S. Airman Charged With Child Pornography Appears in Russian Propaganda Video
snippet: “I don’t consider myself a traitor,” said Wilmer Puello-Mota, who has enlisted in the Russian military.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Air Force airman who absconded to Russia after being hit with child pornography charges appears to be featured in a Russian propaganda video in which he defends his decision to enlist in the military there.

title: The U.K. Riots Were Fomented Online. Will Social Media Companies Act?
snippet: Prime Minister Keir Starmer called out social media groups for the misinformation on their platforms that sparked violent clashes this week. But holding them accountable is tough.
lead_paragraph: Standing in front of a lectern on Thursday, his voice at times taut with anger, Britain’s prime minister announced a crackdown on what he called the “gangs of thugs” who instigated violent unrest in several towns this week.

title: Andy Kim, Who Cleaned the Capitol After Jan. 6, Debuts on a Bigger Stage
snippet: The likely next senator from New Jersey spoke at the Democratic National Convention with a message about the importance of service and participation to safeguard democracy.
lead_paragraph: The first time most Americans were introduced to Representative Andy Kim was in the wee hours of Jan. 7, 2021, when a photographer captured a single image of the bespectacled congressman kneeling alone in the Capitol Rotunda, picking up trash left behind by rioters who had stormed the building just hours earlier.

title: Divers Find 4 Bodies From Yacht That Sank Off Sicily
snippet: The discoveries came after the vessel went down this week in what some witnesses described as a waterspout, or a small tornado, during a violent downpour. No names were immediately released.
lead_paragraph: After three days of searching the hull of a sailing yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily, divers on Wednesday recovered the bodies of four passengers who were believed to have been trapped inside their cabins when the vessel went down, officials in Sicily said.

title: Russia Said It Repelled a Large Ukrainian Drone Attack on Moscow
snippet: The attack came as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive into western Russia that has rattled the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: Russia said on Wednesday that Moscow had come under a sizable drone attack overnight, as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive far from the capital that has rattled the Kremlin.

title: A Bleak View of Soccer’s Future Misses the Full Picture
snippet: Uruguay Coach Marcelo Bielsa lamented that the sport was surrendering its appeal in service to its business. He’s right. And also wrong.
lead_paragraph: Barely lifting his eyes from the floor, Marcelo Bielsa started out with an elegy for what had been lost and ended with a lament for all that is to come. Lesser managers than Bielsa, Uruguay’s philosopher-coach, might have been preoccupied by the looming material reality of a Copa América quarterfinal with Brazil. Bielsa has always been more concerned by the ethereal.

title: Finland Passes Law to Turn Away Asylum Seekers at Border
snippet: The country last year closed all land crossings with Russia, accusing Moscow of trying to weaponize migration. Russian authorities have called the accusations “unsubstantiated.”
lead_paragraph: Finland on Friday passed a temporary bill that would allow border agents to turn away asylum seekers at its borders, an escalation in its ongoing dispute with Russia that experts and human rights groups warn will violate international law.

title: I Kept Failing to Learn French. This Is What Finally Worked.
snippet: Doing exercises in a book was très terrible. A friend suggested something more radical.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene I love in the movie “Husbands,” when John Cassavetes, performing in his own film, is attempting to smooth-talk a beautiful blonde in a London casino. “What languages do you speak?” he asks her. None, she answers. “I’m going to give you a little bit of French,” he says, before launching, with seductive gravitas, into a language that sounds like French. But the words are nonsense. It’s fake French. “You like Italian?” he asks, and then he does his fake version. The woman laughs and says, “It’s not real.” “It’s real to me,” he replies.

title: Cycling the Western Balkans: A Wild, Yet Welcoming, Mountain Tour
snippet: High temperatures and higher mountains were no match for our author and her companion as they biked the Trans Dinarica, a new cycling route that winds through eight countries in the remote Dinaric Alps.
lead_paragraph: “Hey mate!” a cyclist called to us in an Australian accent as he pedaled by on the rocky dirt road that serves as the main street of the village of Theth deep in Albania’s Dinaric Alps. Along with my friend and travel companion, Dave, I had not seen another bikepacker in four days.

title: They Spouted Hate Online. Then They Were Arrested.
snippet: As hundreds of people appear in court for their role in recent anti-immigrant riots in Britain, several are accused of fueling disorder through online posts, raising questions about the limits of free speech.
lead_paragraph: A 53-year-old woman from northwest England was jailed for 15 months after posting on Facebook that a mosque should be blown up “with the adults inside.” A 45-year-old man was sentenced to 20 months for goading his online followers to torch a hotel that houses refugees. A 55-year-old woman was questioned by the police for a viral post that wrongly identified the suspect in a deadly knife attack at a children’s dance class.

title: Russia Seeks to Turn Humbling Incursion Into Military Gains
snippet: Two weeks after Ukraine launched its surprise attack, Russian forces have recovered from the initial shock and are trying to use the expanding war to their battlefield advantage.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after Ukraine’s surprise incursion into Russia, the Kremlin’s forces have slowed the advance, with the hardening front line in the Kursk region of Russia setting up the next phase of a battle with great political stakes for both sides.

title: Wednesday Briefing
snippet: The second night of the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.

title: Wanted: A Miracle Worker on Migration
snippet: Britain’s new center-left government is moving quickly to tackle a challenge that bedeviled its predecessors: how to prevent migrants crossing the Channel and break up trafficking gangs.
lead_paragraph: Wanted: an “exceptional leader” with experience in policing, intelligence or the military, who is ready to tackle one of the thorniest issues in British politics.

title: ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Is Not the Far Right’s Playground
snippet: MAGA misunderstands the fellowship of the ring.
lead_paragraph: You can’t say you weren’t warned. Right there in the middle of my Times bio, it says, “If there were a Nerd Olympics, I might take the gold medal.” It means I’m ready to bend your ear over “Star Wars.” We can talk for hours about “Dune.” But if you really want to get me wound up, say something about J.R.R. Tolkien and “The Lord of the Rings.”

title: A Waterspout Was Seen When a Luxury Yacht Sank. What Is It?
snippet: Witnesses reported seeing the tornado-like phenomenon hit the Bayesian, a sailing yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily on Monday.
lead_paragraph: What caused the sinking on Monday of a sailing yacht carrying the British billionaire Mike Lynch and 21 other people off the coast of Sicily is still unknown. But some attention has focused on observations by witnesses, who described seeing a small tornado-like column known as a waterspout forming over the water during an abrupt and violent storm as the vessel sank.

title: Rocket Test on Remote Scottish Island Ends in Flames
snippet: As European countries push to develop more independent space capabilities, a test at one new site produced an explosion.
lead_paragraph: The test was spectacular, but not in the way those involved had hoped.

title: Ukrainian Lawmakers Pass Bill Aiming to Ban Russian-Aligned Church
snippet: The measure, which awaits President Volodymyr Zelensky’s signature, would further a long, post-Soviet split between two of the world’s largest Orthodox communities.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday creating a legal path to ban a Russian-aligned branch of the Orthodox church, furthering a long, post-Soviet split between two of the world’s largest Orthodox communities.

title: Greenpeace Tries a Novel Tactic in Lawsuit Over Dakota Access Pipeline
snippet: The environmental group, which is being sued by the pipeline company in North Dakota, threatened to use new European rules to try to limit potential damages.
lead_paragraph: Greenpeace recently unveiled a new strategy for fighting a costly lawsuit by an energy company that the group contends is designed to silence critics of the oil industry.

title: Maria Branyas Morera, World’s Oldest Person, Dies at 117
snippet: Born before the emergence of the telephone, she came to embrace the digital revolution and cultivated a following on social media as “Super Catalan Grandma.”
lead_paragraph: Maria Branyas Morera, an American-born Spanish woman believed to be the oldest person in the world, died on Monday in Olot, Spain. She was 117.

title: Risking His Own Extinction to Rescue the Rarest of Flowers
snippet: Carlos Magdalena, whose botanical adventures have shades of Indiana Jones, was a driving force in saving the world’s smallest water lily and finding the largest one. He has been called the “plant messiah.”
lead_paragraph: In Australia, he went plant hunting by helicopter and waded in crocodile-infested waters to watch a water lily bloom. In Mauritius, he grabbed a plant specimen off the ledge of a cliff. Last month, while looking for lilies in a Colombian tributary of the piranha-packed Orinoco River, he jumped from plank to plank in the pitch dark at 4 a.m. to get to a floating pontoon.

title: Who Was on the Sunken Yacht? Tech Mogul Mike Lynch, His Family and Friends.
snippet: Mr. Lynch, the former chief executive of the software firm Autonomy, who was acquitted on fraud charges in June, was with friends and family when the yacht went down in a severe storm.
lead_paragraph: A cruise on the Mediterranean Sea aboard a superyacht was supposed to be a celebratory event for the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, who was acquitted in June of fraud charges tied to the sale of his company, Autonomy, to the tech giant Hewlett-Packard.

title: Election Setbacks Leave France’s Far Right at a Crossroads
snippet: The National Rally’s campaign was marred by controversies that undercut its effort to convince voters that it was ready for power. Now, leaders are asking where the party goes from here.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Bardella, the president of the far-right National Rally, greeted his party’s 125 newly elected lawmakers on Wednesday morning with a few congratulations — and a lot of warnings.

title: Zelensky Says Push Into Russia Shows the West’s Red Lines Are ‘Naïve’
snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine seized on the incursion’s success to press allies to lift a longtime restriction: the use of Western-supplied long-range weapons against Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that Ukraine’s surprise offensive into western Russia, which entered its third week on Tuesday, shows the West that its fears about the ramifications of attacks on Russian territory are unfounded and should be abandoned.

title: A Swiss Dilemma: How to Get Old Bombs Out of Deep Lakes?
snippet: Switzerland is offering $58,000 in prize money for ideas to remove munitions from the depths, in case they start polluting. The catch: The cure can’t be worse than the problem.
lead_paragraph: Switzerland’s lakes reflect its craggy mountains and lap against its cities. Their blue surfaces are peaceful. And the waters are, seemingly, pristine.

title: 5 Breakouts From Classical Music’s Most Prestigious Festival
snippet: The Salzburg Festival is synonymous with excellence and fame. But it’s also a place where artists on the cusp of stardom can shine.
lead_paragraph: The Salzburg Festival has, since its founding more than 100 years ago, been known as a gathering place for the world’s finest musicians.

title: War Is Draining Ukraine’s Male-Dominated Work Force. Enter the Women.
snippet: More and more women are replacing men mobilized in the army. But there are not enough of them to make up for the labor shortage affecting the economy.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning in eastern Ukraine, Karina Yatsina, a mine worker, was busy operating a conveyor belt in a dim, 1,200-foot-deep tunnel. Lights flickered at the end of the shaft, illuminating miners carving out the coal seams.

title: Search Resumes for British Mogul and 5 Others After Yacht Sinks Off Sicily
snippet: The body of the vessel’s cook was recovered while divers searched the hull of the Bayesian for passengers, including the tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Deep-sea divers with Italy’s firefighter corps resumed their search on Tuesday for six missing passengers — including a British software mogul and his daughter — of a yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily the previous day.

title: ‘The Demand Is Unstoppable’: Can Barcelona Survive Mass Tourism?
snippet: This summer, thousands of local protesters in the Spanish city denounced overtourism. With more crowds expected for the America’s Cup, we visited the areas where tensions are highest.
lead_paragraph: On a steamy August evening, a stream of young people bearing boxes of pizza and bottles of cheap cava began the uphill slog to Carmel Bunkers in Barcelona. Set on a hill overlooking the Catalan capital, the concrete structures once housed antiaircraft weapons that protected the city during Spain’s civil war in the 1930s. Later the site became a destination for residents on evening strolls and a hangout for local youths.

title: Apple Settles E.U. Case by Opening Its Payment Service to Rivals
snippet: Customers in Europe may see an influx of new apps and services for making tap-and-go purchases.
lead_paragraph: Apple will for the first time allow banks, payment services and other app developers to use the underlying technology behind Apple Pay to make rival tap-and-go payment services, settling a long-running European Union antitrust investigation, regulators said on Thursday.

title: Tuesday Briefing
snippet: The U.S. push for a cease-fire in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said yesterday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had accepted a “bridging proposal” aimed at closing the gap between Israel and Hamas on a cease-fire deal for Gaza. Hamas officials did not immediately comment, but they have called the proposal slanted toward Israel.

title: 36 Hours in Izmir, Turkey
snippet: Thousands of years of culture and history converge in this vibrant, coastal city known as the “Pearl of the Aegean.”
lead_paragraph: Thousands of years of culture and history converge in this vibrant, coastal city known as the “Pearl of the Aegean.”

title: At the Ruhrtriennale, Searching for the Sublime Among the Ruins
snippet: In the abandoned industrial sites that serve as the festival’s venues, our critic witnessed beauty struggling to be born: fitfully, clumsily and sometimes stunningly.
lead_paragraph: “I Want Absolute Beauty,” the title of the opening production for this year’s Ruhrtriennale, sounds like a mission statement of sorts.

title: NATO on the Edge: Biden Praises and Trump Denigrates a 75-Year Alliance
snippet: As leaders gathered in Washington to mark the anniversary of the organization, they heard starkly different messages from two American presidents on NATO’s future.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest Biden news and election polls.

title: Alain Delon, Godfather of the Belted Trench
snippet: As a titan of French cinema, he dressed the part, even when playing a killer.
lead_paragraph: Alain Delon, the French film star who died on Sunday at 88, was not big on smiling.

title: Michel Guérard, Who Lowered the Calories in Haute Cuisine, Dies at 91
snippet: Appalled by the food options available to those seeking to lose weight, he developed a form of nouvelle cuisine for dieters at a spa in southwestern France.
lead_paragraph: Michel Guérard, a driving force behind the 1960s culinary movement known as nouvelle cuisine and the creator of the enormously influential “slimming cuisine” at his 19th-century spa in Eugénie-les-Bains, France, died at his home there. He was 91.

title: Trying to Recover the British Museum’s Gems, and Its Reputation
snippet: The police haven’t charged anybody over the missing artifacts, but the museum is running its own investigations to get the items back.
lead_paragraph: A year has passed since the British Museum said it had fired a curator for stealing from its supposedly lock-tight storerooms and selling the artifacts online. Ever since, the museum has struggled to deal with the fallout from the scandal, which has battered its reputation as a protector of world treasures.

title: Ukraine Strikes Bridges in Russia, Aiming to Entrap Troops
snippet: The attacks aim to destroy or damage crossings over a river in the Kursk region that are Russian forces’ only routes for resupply or retreat, military analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops defending a pocket of territory wedged between a river and the border with Ukraine were at risk of becoming encircled, military analysts said Monday, after Ukraine bombed bridges that are the only routes for resupply or retreat.

title: At Least 1 Dead and 6 Missing After Yacht Sinks Off Sicily
snippet: Fifteen other people were rescued. Expert divers were called in to carry out search operations in the deep water. Among the missing was a British software mogul, Mike Lynch.
lead_paragraph: At least one person was killed and six others, including a British software mogul, were missing on Monday after a sailing yacht carrying 22 people sank during a violent storm off the coast of Sicily, Italian officials said.

title: Ukraine Says Its Incursion Will Bring Peace. Putin’s Plans May Differ.
snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky wants to hold Russian territory as leverage in future talks. In Moscow, many doubt the strategy.
lead_paragraph: In July, as he secretly readied an invasion of Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sent a very different signal in public: He wanted talks to end the war.

title: Monday Briefing
snippet: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.

title: Sparing the Horse, Brussels Warms Up to the Electric Carriage
snippet: The city’s last horse-drawn carriage operator says business is good since making the switch, placing the Belgian capital in the vanguard of a global change.
lead_paragraph: It started a number of years ago with angry remarks from tourists every now and again. But in recent years, the comments flew all of the time, with people shouting, “Shame!” at Thibault Danthine, a horse-drawn carriage operator in Brussels, as they walked by.

title: U.S. and Allies Aim to Forge Commitments to Ukraine That Will Endure
snippet: The specter of a second Donald J. Trump presidency injects new urgency into the NATO summit this week. President Biden and other leaders agree Ukraine should have an “irreversible” path to membership.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its NATO allies have agreed that Ukraine should have an “irreversible” path to membership in the alliance, enshrining the phrase in a document that was released on Wednesday during the alliance’s summit in Washington.

title: Premier League Preview: Here We Go Again
snippet: The European soccer season is back. Here are the top story lines to watch this season.
lead_paragraph: You will, in all likelihood, have heard the sentence already. You will certainly hear it on Friday, at least once, and then over and over again on Saturday and Sunday, delivered by every pearly toothed host and every red-faced pundit and every eager-voiced commentator. The Premier League, they will say, is back.

title: Europe Tells China’s Carmakers: Get Ready to Pay Tariffs
snippet: The European Union took the next step toward collecting heavy tariffs on electric vehicles, ahead of a final decision in October.
lead_paragraph: The European Union took the next step on Thursday toward collecting new tariffs on Chinese electric cars, telling automakers to obtain guarantees from banks that they would be able to pay the taxes set to be made final in October.

title: Alert Level Raised at U.S. Bases in Europe Over Russian Threats
snippet: Officials said there was no specific intelligence about possible Russian attacks on American bases, but Moscow has made vague threats over Ukraine’s use of long-range weapons on its territory.
lead_paragraph: American defense officials raised the security alert level at military bases in Europe over the weekend in response to vague threats from the Kremlin over Ukraine’s use of long-range weapons on Russian territory, according to U.S. and Western officials.

title: Has Power Moderated Italy’s Leader? Not to Same-Sex Parents.
snippet: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has mostly shown a pragmatic streak abroad. But at home, her government is plunging many gay families into panic.
lead_paragraph: While their curly-haired rescue dog napped on the floor, an Italian couple logged on to a late-night video call with their American surrogate, sunbathing in her garden in Oregon. The fathers-to-be cooed as she told them she was playing fairy tales close to her belly that they had recorded for their future daughter. “And she is kicking!” she said.

title: A City of Blaring Sirens Fills With Russians Who Fled Ukraine’s Advance
snippet: In the regional capital, those who left their homes as Ukrainian forces tore into western Russia are uncertain whether they can ever return to their old lives.
lead_paragraph: In the Russian city of Kursk, several dozen miles from the heart of the fighting, Ukraine’s surprise thrust into Russia is not visible even as smoke on the horizon. But the scars of its impact are impossible to miss.

title: You Are Cordially Invited to Euro 2024’s Best Party. Please Wear Orange.
snippet: With thousands of voices and a few well-choreographed dance moves, Dutch fans have transformed match days into pulsing, joyous celebrations. Their next one is Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: It started with an old double-decker bus.

title: With Macron and Biden Vulnerable, So Is Europe
snippet: The U.S. presidential debate and Sunday’s snap election in France have emboldened nationalist forces that could challenge NATO and undo the defense of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: This month, President Biden, flanked by President Emmanuel Macron of France, stood on the Normandy bluffs to commemorate the young men who clambered ashore 80 years ago into a hail of Nazi gunfire because “they knew beyond any doubt there are things worth fighting and dying for.”

title: During Ukraine’s Incursion, Russian Conscripts Recount Surrendering in Droves
snippet: More than 300 have been processed in a prison in Ukraine, providing the country with a much-needed “exchange fund” for future swaps of prisoners of war.
lead_paragraph: They were lanky and fresh-faced, and the battle they lost had been their first.

title: Ukraine Destroys Key Russian Bridge as It Presses On With Offensive
snippet: The bridge’s destruction is a setback for Russian supply lines as Ukraine seeks to consolidate its territorial gains in the Kursk region of western Russia.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has destroyed a critical bridge and appears to have targeted at least one more in Russia’s western Kursk region as it tries to sever Russian supply lines and consolidate its territorial gains, a dozen days into its startling cross-border offensive.

title: A Political Fight Won, France’s Stars Turn Back to a Soccer One
snippet: Some of the country’s top players had urged voters to reject the far right in a pivotal election. With that battle over, a date with Spain in Euro 2024 offers a more familiar challenge.
lead_paragraph: For once, Didier Deschamps could reflect on a news conference that passed by almost without incident. Given the timing, that had seemed unlikely. On Sunday, French voters had issued a stinging rebuke to their country’s resurgent far right in a seismic legislative election. On Tuesday, the country’s increasingly activist soccer team will face Spain in a European Championship semifinal.

title: U.S. Officials Say Russia Is Unlikely to Take Much More Ukrainian Territory
snippet: Russian forces continue to inflict pain, but NATO leaders gathering in Washington can say that their efforts to strengthen Ukraine are working.
lead_paragraph: Russia is unlikely to make significant territorial gains in Ukraine in the coming months as its poorly trained forces struggle to break through Ukrainian defenses that are now reinforced with Western munitions, U.S. officials say.

title: NATO’s New Boss: Affable, Pragmatic and Ready for Trump, if Required
snippet: When he takes over as secretary general in October, Mark Rutte will face strains over Russia, Ukraine and the potential return of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Mark Rutte rode off into the sunset on his bicycle last week, making a carefully choreographed exit from Dutch politics, which he has dominated as prime minister for nearly 14 years. His next job will be even more challenging: He will be the new head of a NATO that is facing threats ranging from Russian aggression to the rise of right-wing nationalism across Europe.

title: New Zealand Diplomat Is Victim of Armed Robbery, Paris Authorities Say
snippet: The Paris prosecutor’s office said that the diplomat had been struck in the face with the butt of a pistol. The robbery took place in Paris’s affluent 7th arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: A diplomat from New Zealand’s Embassy in France was the victim of an armed robbery in Paris on Thursday, the city’s prosecutor’s office said the following day.

title: Biden Looks to Move Past His Troubles, Opening NATO Summit With Warning to Putin
snippet: A summit meant to convey confidence in the newly expanded alliance opened with a dazzling celebration and no mention of President Biden’s political peril.
lead_paragraph: President Biden opened NATO’s 75th anniversary summit on Tuesday seeking to bolster confidence in both the alliance and his own political standing with a forceful speech warning of the threat posed by Russia and other authoritarian states as the world plunges into a new era of superpower conflict.

title: What I’m Reading: Why Democracy Erodes From the Top
snippet: Three book recommendations from sunny London.
lead_paragraph: Greetings from London’s long, hot* summer, where I am keeping cool through the traditional method of my people: staying inside and reading books.

title: France Learns a New Word: Ungovernable
snippet: Far from producing a “clarification,” President Emmanuel Macron’s snap election has yielded a muddle that could take months to sort out.
lead_paragraph: Instead of waking up on Monday to a country dominated by the far right, France awoke to becoming Italy, a country where only painstaking parliamentary negotiation may eventually yield a viable coalition government.

title: Russia Closes In on Key Eastern Ukrainian City Despite Kursk Incursion
snippet: A Russian advance toward Pokrovsk casts doubts on Ukraine’s hopes that its cross-border offensive will prompt Moscow to scale back attacks elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops are closing in on the strategic eastern Ukrainian town of Pokrovsk, according to open-source battlefield maps, casting doubts on Ukraine’s hopes that its new offensive into western Russia will prompt Moscow to scale back its attacks elsewhere on the battlefield.

title: Ukraine’s Push Into Russia Met Early Success. Where Does It Go From Here?
snippet: Ukraine’s forces could try advancing farther on Russian soil, or return to the front line, where Moscow is making gains. There are arguments for various options.
lead_paragraph: The success of Ukraine’s secret incursion into Russia is clear. Ukrainian forces pushed past two lines of Russian defenses in the southwestern region of Kursk and moved through Russian highways and villages with little resistance. Since the operation began 11 days ago, they have gone beyond Kursk to the neighboring region of Belgorod, putting other communities on edge and rattling Moscow.

title: A Rescue Dog Went Blind. Now She’s Helping Other Pups Avoid Her Fate.
snippet: Shola, who assisted with search-and-rescue operations in the U.K., has moved to her second act: saving other English Shepherds from blindness.
lead_paragraph: All dogs, it must be said, are born great. Most achieve greatness in their own waggy ways. But some — like Shola, a 9-year-old English Shepherd — have greatness thrust upon them.

title: Navalny’s Widow Disputes Russian Report on Her Husband’s Death
snippet: The Russian authorities said Aleksei A. Navalny had died of a grab bag of diseases, including heart arrhythmia triggered by hypertension.
lead_paragraph: The Russian authorities have attributed the death six months ago of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s main opposition leader, to a grab bag of diseases aggravated by heart arrhythmia, a conclusion described as preposterous by his widow on Thursday.

title: Amid Heightened Security, Taylor Swift Returns to the Stage in London
snippet: Fans at Wembley Stadium said they trusted British security officials to keep them safe and cheered loudly when the pop star came onstage.
lead_paragraph: When Taylor Swift canceled three concerts in Vienna last week after officials there foiled a terrorist plot, Swifties soon expressed fears about the pop star’s next shows, in London.

title: Macron Honors African Soldiers Who Helped Liberate France in World War II
snippet: Two months after D-Day, an Allied force dominated by soldiers conscripted from French colonies swept into southern France. It’s a chapter of its history that France has long obscured.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron came to the south of France on Thursday to honor a second landing, the less white and more forgotten one, in which over 350,000 Allied troops stormed ashore in Provence and went on to liberate towns including Marseille and Toulon, before moving northward.

title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia Reveals a Dramatic Shift
snippet: The offensive was developed in secret, devised to divert Russian troops away from the front lines in Ukraine and seize territory to use as a bargaining chip.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s incursion into a sliver of Russia is likely to make it harder for Moscow to mount a major renewed offensive in Ukraine’s east and is the kind of surprise operation that could eventually impose real costs on the Kremlin, according to U.S. officials.

title: Whimsical Parade of Banksy Animals Sends Fans on a Giddy Hunt
snippet: Each day for nine straight days, a new Banksy artwork appeared somewhere in London. For some, it became a citywide treasure hunt.
lead_paragraph: The first Banksy piece to show up was a mountain goat, spotted by passers-by on a wall near the River Thames. The second work, a pair of elephants, appeared overnight on a house in southwest London. Then came some playful monkeys, a howling wolf, two hungry pelicans and a cat.

title: For Stonehenge’s Altar Stone, an Improbably Long Ancient Journey
snippet: A six-ton megalith at the heart of the archaeological site traveled more than 450 miles to get there, a new study concludes.
lead_paragraph: Near the center of the roughly 5,000-year-old circular monument known as Stonehenge is a six-ton, rectangular chunk of red sandstone. In Arthurian legend, the so-called Altar Stone was part of the ring of giant rocks that the wizard Merlin magically transported from Mount Killaurus, in Ireland, to Salisbury Plain, a chalk plateau in southern England — a journey chronicled around 1136 by a Welsh cleric, Geoffrey of Monmouth, in his “Historia Regum Britanniae.”

title: What People Wear in One of the Happiest Places on Earth
snippet: At Copenhagen Fashion Week, outfits on and off the runway had a lively spirit that reflected the event’s location in a country known for its quality of life.
lead_paragraph: Not every fashion week can be characterized as friendly, approachable and relaxed. But those are three ways to describe Copenhagen Fashion Week, a twice-a-year event in the capital city of Denmark, a country that has often been ranked among the happiest in the world.

title: Ukraine’s Surprise Attack Forces Russia to Divert Forces in Response
snippet: Russia has begun moving some troops from Ukraine to deal with a Ukrainian incursion, the U.S. and Ukraine say. But Moscow appears reluctant to withdraw units from hot spots in eastern Ukraine.
