lead_paragraph: Fast Facts: There wereeight strikes last year in Switzerland, tying a record set in1979…The number of students leaving Ireland, with itscrowded campuses, to attenduniversity in Britain andNorthern Ireland is up bymore than 50 percent fromlast year.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Good manners are not a thing of the past in Germany, according to a recent survey. Ninety-two percent of 1,000 Germans polled for the Hamburg newspaper Die Woche rate politeness as "important" or "very important." . Most tradit
lead_paragraph: Good manners are not a thing of the past in Germany, according to a recent survey. Ninety-two percent of 1,000 Germans polled for the Hamburg newspaper Die Woche rate politeness as "important" or "very important."

title: A Dead Russian Satellite Broke Into More Than 100 Pieces in Space
snippet: The cause of the incident, which added to a growing amount of dangerous space junk in low Earth orbit, remains unknown.
lead_paragraph: A decommissioned Russian satellite fractured in space on Wednesday, creating a cloud of debris in low Earth orbit that prompted astronauts aboard the International Space Station to take protective measures.

title: Spain, Norway and Ireland Recognize Palestinian State, Further Isolating Israel
snippet: The moves, while largely symbolic, were welcomed by Palestinians and denounced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who called them “a prize for terrorism.”
lead_paragraph: Spain, Norway and Ireland said on Wednesday that they would recognize an independent Palestinian state, delivering a diplomatic blow to Israel that showed the country’s growing isolation on the world stage more than seven months into its devastating military offensive in the Gaza Strip.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: In the past, some elderly French people left their fortunes to be administered by the village or city government, which each year would confer an award on a local person or couple of unusual merit. The quaint-sounding practice endures, but it has ...
lead_paragraph: In the past, some elderly French people left their fortunes to be administered by the village or city government, which each year would confer an award on a local person or couple of unusual merit. The quaint-sounding practice endures, but it has required some updating. In 1892, one Victorine Gilbert left her fortune to provide annual awards to "the person who, at greatest risk to life and limb, has managed to stop a runaway horse in Paris." The City of Paris has combined and modernized such prizes, now recognizing,for example, a person "displaying great courage." Years ago, a certain Mademoiselle Garbillier left her own fortune to award "virginly maidens of the seventh arrondissement." Now there is an award for a "deserving young wife."

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: A British record producer,Falcon Nemon Stuart, wants torealize a dream his father proposed in 1960 and build a hugebust of Winston Churchill onthe south bank of the Thames inLondon.The great statesman'sdescendants have likened theplanne
lead_paragraph: A British record producer,Falcon Nemon Stuart, wants torealize a dream his father proposed in 1960 and build a hugebust of Winston Churchill onthe south bank of the Thames inLondon.The great statesman'sdescendants have likened theplanned 40-foot (12-meter)bronze likeness to "a Stalinisticmonument" and vowed toblock it.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: While many retirees are living better than ever, the picture grows darker for those over 80, a French government study shows. More than 30 percent of France's octogenarians are confined to their homes, the study found, and 11 percent have no conta...
lead_paragraph: While many retirees are living better than ever, the picture grows darker for those over 80, a French government study shows. More than 30 percent of France's octogenarians are confined to their homes, the study found, and 11 percent have no contact with friends or relatives.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS: Around Europe
snippet: Two Norwegians, LisbethAmundsen, 32, an ad writer,and her twin sister, Bente, anart director — both active opponents of French nucleartesting in the Pacific — havehad remarkable success withan unappetizing ad campaignthey rece
lead_paragraph: Two Norwegians, LisbethAmundsen, 32, an ad writer,and her twin sister, Bente, anart director — both active opponents of French nucleartesting in the Pacific — havehad remarkable success withan unappetizing ad campaignthey recently mounted. A 20- second televised spot shows achic young woman sippingfrom a glass of red wine. Sheclears her throat and spits intothe glass, then swirls itaround. "This is what theFrench are doing to our environment," a voice says. Salesof French wine have reportedly plunged since the ads beganappearing.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Drivers with an ear to a mobile phone make 10 times as many "corrective steering movements" as other drivers, most often while dialing, a German federal study has concluded. Insurance companies in Germany refuse to cover drivers who have accide
lead_paragraph: Drivers with an ear to a mobile phone make 10 times as many "corrective steering movements" as other drivers, most often while dialing, a German federal study has concluded. Insurance companies in Germany refuse to cover drivers who have accidents while on the phone. The Transportation Ministry has decided against an outright ban, while noting that devices restricting a driver's "sight or hearing" are illegal.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: The police, summoned to remove an object thought to be a bomb from the underside of a car in the Dutch city of Enschede,found that the object had been placed there by fellow officers. It was a tracking device to follow the movements of a suspected...
lead_paragraph: The police, summoned to remove an object thought to be a bomb from the underside of a car in the Dutch city of Enschede,found that the object had been placed there by fellow officers. It was a tracking device to follow the movements of a suspected drug trafficker. The bomb squad pretended to disarm the device.The police later arrested the owner of the vehicle.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: After five years of decline, the suicide rate in France rose in 1992 and 1993, the most recent years for which statistics are available. About 2 percent of all deaths in the country are now self-inflicted. Although reporting standards vary for cul...
lead_paragraph: After five years of decline, the suicide rate in France rose in 1992 and 1993, the most recent years for which statistics are available. About 2 percent of all deaths in the country are now self-inflicted. Although reporting standards vary for cultural reasons, France appears to have a higher rate than most European countries, with more than twice as many suicides per capita as in Britain, Spain or Italy.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: In a setback to the British Labor Party, aLeeds court has ruled that even "positive discrimination" is illegal. A Labor Party congress in 1993 decided that half of all seats coming open should be occupied by women. Two men, whose candidacie
lead_paragraph: In a setback to the British Labor Party, aLeeds court has ruled that even "positive discrimination" is illegal. A Labor Party congress in 1993 decided that half of all seats coming open should be occupied by women. Two men, whose candidacies in a regional party organization were rejected in favor of women, filed suit, and a three-judge labor court ruled that even if the point of such policies might be praiseworthy, theyviolated the 1975 Sex Discrimination Act. There are now 60 women in Parliament, occupying less than one-tenth the 651 seats.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The British Army's last 20 horses retired from active duty this week. Their last real service in combat came during World War I, when mounted cavalry were sent against entrenched gunners, with suicidal result. Since then, army horses have been rel...
lead_paragraph: The British Army's last 20 horses retired from active duty this week. Their last real service in combat came during World War I, when mounted cavalry were sent against entrenched gunners, with suicidal result. Since then, army horses have been relegated largely to patrol and to ceremonial duty. They will be replaced by all-terrain motorcycles, said the army, at a savings of £500,000 ($775,000).

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Fast Facts: Nordics have more cellular phones than any other Europeans. The Swedes lead, with 159 per 1,000 residents, followed by Norwegians (137), Finns (128) and Danes (99). ... Italians drink more mineral water than other Europeans: 124 liters...
lead_paragraph: Fast Facts: Nordics have more cellular phones than any other Europeans. The Swedes lead, with 159 per 1,000 residents, followed by Norwegians (137), Finns (128) and Danes (99). ... Italians drink more mineral water than other Europeans: 124 liters each a year. Next are Belgians (105), Germans (103), French (83) and Swiss (81). ... Young French are not only less likely to get married than before, they are also less likely to live together out of wedlock. Thirteen percent of those over 25 now live the single life.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
lead_paragraph: British husbands are three times less likely to commit suicide than their single counterparts, says a new report.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: European Union farm ministers were unable to agree this week on stricter rules on the transportation of animals. Germany, the current EU president, had proposed an eight-hour limit for journeys within national borders followed by a two- hour perio...
lead_paragraph: European Union farm ministers were unable to agree this week on stricter rules on the transportation of animals. Germany, the current EU president, had proposed an eight-hour limit for journeys within national borders followed by a two- hour period for feeding and watering. For cross-border trips, it suggested a 15-hour or a 22-hour limit, followed by a six-hour rest.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Half of all Spanish girls aged 15 to 19 who become pregnant get abortions, according to a recent study. Researchers for the Youth Institute in Madrid found a general rejection in this age group of anything that makes the sex act seem less natural....
lead_paragraph: Half of all Spanish girls aged 15 to 19 who become pregnant get abortions, according to a recent study. Researchers for the Youth Institute in Madrid found a general rejection in this age group of anything that makes the sex act seem less natural. Reactions to the pill is negative; most girls who use it do so withouta prescription or medical control. There is also considerable hesitation in approaching doctors for guidance. Most girls surveyed said they enteredsexual relationships with feelings of guilt.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: The strength of family bonds is tied to youths' drinking patterns, according to a survey of 6,000 11-to 16-year-olds in Britain, France and Spain. The closer and more structured the family and the better the lines of communication, researchers fou...
lead_paragraph: The strength of family bonds is tied to youths' drinking patterns, according to a survey of 6,000 11-to 16-year-olds in Britain, France and Spain. The closer and more structured the family and the better the lines of communication, researchers found, the less likely were young people to drink. Spanish parents were three times more likely to forbid their children to drink than were the British — the French fell right in the middle — and drinking patterns closely reflected this.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
lead_paragraph: The Swiss are Western Europe's biggest train travelers. They log a yearly average of 1,854 kilometers (1,150 miles) per person by rail. Next are the French (1,145 kilometers) and the Austrians (1,130).

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: A 60-year-old promise has finally been kept: Survivors of the International Brigades who fought in the Spanish Civil War on the Republican side are to be granted Spanish citizenship. They had come from every continent, some 40,000 in all, to rally...
lead_paragraph: A 60-year-old promise has finally been kept: Survivors of the International Brigades who fought in the Spanish Civil War on the Republican side are to be granted Spanish citizenship. They had come from every continent, some 40,000 in all, to rally around the battle cry of "No pasaran" against the forces of Franco. Now, says Ana Pérez, president of the Association of Friends of the International Brigades, perhaps300 of them survive. About half of the volunteers died in the Civil War, many others in World War II.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The police helmet worn by British bobbies since Victorian times is to disappear, the Sunday Times reports, replaced gradually by peaked caps. Police in Manchester are switching this month; otherforces are expected to follow. A nationwide survey fo...
lead_paragraph: The police helmet worn by British bobbies since Victorian times is to disappear, the Sunday Times reports, replaced gradually by peaked caps. Police in Manchester are switching this month; otherforces are expected to follow. A nationwide survey found that officershad little good to say about the old helmets, which were based on a Prussian army design: They are hot and uncomfortable; hooligans take pleasure inknocking them off; they are too big to wear in a patrol car; they fall off during foot chases. And, one officer said, the bad guys can "see them coming from half a mile away."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: There is plenty of room for argument, but these are the 10 best films of all times according to readers surveyed by The Sunday Times of London: 1) "Casablanca" (director, Michael Curtiz), 2) "Gone With the Wind" (Victor Fleming), 3) &
lead_paragraph: There is plenty of room for argument, but these are the 10 best films of all times according to readers surveyed by The Sunday Times of London: 1) "Casablanca" (director, Michael Curtiz), 2) "Gone With the Wind" (Victor Fleming), 3) "Citizen Kane" (Orson Welles), 4) "Some Like It Hot" (Billy Wilder), 5) "The Godfather" (Francis Ford Coppola), 6) "Star Wars" (George Lucas), 7) "Pulp Fiction" (Quentin Tarantino), 8) "Brief Encounter" (David Lean), 9) "Schindler's List" (Steven Spielberg), 10) "The Third Man" (Carol Reed). Have a list of your own favorites? Send it in.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Who are the true English? The Independent of London has offered a cheeky questionnaire to help people determine, at least, what they're not. Thus, if you prefer a good Chivas to lukewarm beer, if you dream of making love in a hotel suite where Mar...
lead_paragraph: Who are the true English? The Independent of London has offered a cheeky questionnaire to help people determine, at least, what they're not. Thus, if you prefer a good Chivas to lukewarm beer, if you dream of making love in a hotel suite where Mary Stuart once slept and if you prefer a Rover even if its pieces were made abroad, then you are a foreigner pretending to be English. If, on the other hand, you think of hooligans when you see the Union Jack, if you say ciao instead of goodbye and if you think Manchester United's French star Eric Cantona is Britain's greatest soccer player, then you're a hopeless European.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Two men who danced together at a Belfast social club have been banned for life. When the pair took to an empty dance floor, with the band playing "Baggy Trousers," a bouncer asked them to sit. Club rules allow women to dance together, he explain
lead_paragraph: Two men who danced together at a Belfast social club have been banned for life. When the pair took to an empty dance floor, with the band playing "Baggy Trousers," a bouncer asked them to sit. Club rules allow women to dance together, he explained, but not men. The men have accused the club of discrimination.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Robberies have become a serious problem on some overnight trains in Germany. Some of the thieves, using a technique seen elsewhere, spray a soporific gas into sleeper compartments, then help themselves to money, passports and other valuables. The ...
lead_paragraph: Robberies have become a serious problem on some overnight trains in Germany. Some of the thieves, using a technique seen elsewhere, spray a soporific gas into sleeper compartments, then help themselves to money, passports and other valuables. The hardest-hit lines have been Warsaw-Frankfurt, Hamburg-Basel and Munich-Hamburg, and 48 special guards now work those lines nightly to improve security.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Hostility toward Continental Europe is far stronger among the old than among the young in Britain. Only one-fifth of those aged 15 to 24 considered Europe to be a threat rather than an opportunity, while among those aged 55 to 64, 48 percent saw i...
lead_paragraph: Hostility toward Continental Europe is far stronger among the old than among the young in Britain. Only one-fifth of those aged 15 to 24 considered Europe to be a threat rather than an opportunity, while among those aged 55 to 64, 48 percent saw it as a threat. In all, 44 percent of the 1,921 people interviewed last month by the NOP polling organization viewed the European Union as more of an opportunity than a threat, while 35 percent saw it more as a threat.

title: Europe
snippet: EUROPE.
lead_paragraph: EUROPE

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: An odd problem has faced Europe's largest solar-energy plant outside Toledo, Spain, since it opened early this summer: too much sun. Temperatures in the barren plains of central Spain, where the sun shines 3,000 hours a year, have reached 50 degre...
lead_paragraph: An odd problem has faced Europe's largest solar-energy plant outside Toledo, Spain, since it opened early this summer: too much sun. Temperatures in the barren plains of central Spain, where the sun shines 3,000 hours a year, have reached 50 degrees (122 Fahrenheit) in recent weeks, damaging some of the sensitive solar panels.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Adultery will no longer be a crime in Austria, if legislation proposed by the government is adopted by Parliament. The nation's two dominant political parties support the change, as part of a comprehensive legal reform package set to take effect n...
lead_paragraph: Adultery will no longer be a crime in Austria, if legislation proposed by the government is adopted by Parliament. The nation's two dominant political parties support the change, as part of a comprehensive legal reform package set to take effect next year. But Roman Catholic bishops stoutly oppose it. "We're afraid," Bishop Klaus Küng of Vorarlberg told the daily Suddeutsche Zeitung, "that the awareness of what adultery is will fade away." At present, extramarital wandering is punishable by up to six months in prison, though the sanction has rarely been applied in recent years. But Austrians see themselves lagging in this domain: Among members of the Council of Europe, only Austria and Turkey still apply any penalties for adultery.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Ecologically sound logging,Sweden is finding, also can beeconomically smart. Swedishloggers, long practitioners of arazed-earth approach, haveshifted their emphasis, pressedby environmentalists, new lawand a recessionary economy.Surpr
lead_paragraph: Ecologically sound logging,Sweden is finding, also can beeconomically smart. Swedishloggers, long practitioners of arazed-earth approach, haveshifted their emphasis, pressedby environmentalists, new lawand a recessionary economy.Surprisingly,profits are risingby as much as $1,000 per hectare, reports the German weeklyFocus. Where once loggerswould leave up to 300 hectarescompletely denuded, their "ecological cuts" now measure only3 to 30 hectares. Trees growfaster on these small patches,reducing the need for expensivereforestation.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: A gang of four or five masked men intercepted a truck from Hungary as it was arriving at Rungis, Paris's wholesale food market, Sunday night. The men locked the drivers in a walk-in cooler, then drove off with their booty - 13 tons of goose liver ...
lead_paragraph: A gang of four or five masked men intercepted a truck from Hungary as it was arriving at Rungis, Paris's wholesale food market, Sunday night. The men locked the drivers in a walk-in cooler, then drove off with their booty - 13 tons of goose liver paté, worth about 700,000 francs ($130,000). So far there are no suspects. But authorities may want to keep an eye open for anyone making extraordinarily large purchases of Sauternes.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The Swedish newspaper Metro, barely three months old, already has the second- largest circulation in the country, just behind Dagens Nyheter but ahead of other established dailies. Its secret: Metro is free..Distributed each morning in the Stockho...
lead_paragraph: The Swedish newspaper Metro, barely three months old, already has the second- largest circulation in the country, just behind Dagens Nyheter but ahead of other established dailies. Its secret: Metro is free.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Yes, even Parisians get tired of it, and residents of a quiet Right Bank street are now doing something about it. On the Rue Legouve and the Passage des Marais, locals recently traced thick chalk circles around dog excrement on their sidewalks - s...
lead_paragraph: Yes, even Parisians get tired of it, and residents of a quiet Right Bank street are now doing something about it. On the Rue Legouve and the Passage des Marais, locals recently traced thick chalk circles around dog excrement on their sidewalks - some 200 circles in all - or, in a bit of provocative street art, encircled canine leavings with strands of spaghetti, quartered tomatoes and lettuce leaves. In case City Hall didn't get wind of the happening, a letter was mailed to the mayor asking for "subsidies for the purchase of boots so that we might walk in the street." Paris now spends about 42 million francs a year on the bright green motorcycles used to vacuum up 3.5 tons of excrement each day. But that is only 14 percent of the total. One cautious walker has suggested that the offending pet owners be required to attend obedience courses.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Sign of (the tension of) the times: In France each year, about 800 persons legally change their names. Some are shedding old French names that have subjected them to ridicule, like Cochon, or Pig, or Cocu, meaning the Cuckolded. But two-thirds of ...
lead_paragraph: Sign of (the tension of) the times: In France each year, about 800 persons legally change their names. Some are shedding old French names that have subjected them to ridicule, like Cochon, or Pig, or Cocu, meaning the Cuckolded. But two-thirds of the changes, according to a study reported by the daily Libération, are to more French- sounding names. About one- fifth of this group is people with Jewish-sounding names, and one-fourth of people with North African-sounding names. This last group is expected to grow. The desire to Frenchify one's name, a government spokesman said, "is never as great as in a period of crisis. Each era has its scapegoats."

title: European Parliament : People power for Europe
snippet: The negotiations on a new European Union constitutional treaty are drawing to a close. European governments are busy fighting for more voting power, vetoes and a place for God. Now the politicians need to take a step back and focus on the issue th...
lead_paragraph: The negotiations on a new European Union constitutional treaty are drawing to a close. European governments are busy fighting for more voting power, vetoes and a place for God. Now the politicians need to take a step back and focus on the issue that their citizens care about: injecting more democracy and transparency into Europe's decision making.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The thatched-roof cottage has long been a symbol of a simple but rewarding country life, summoning images of friends and family around a cozy fireplace on a cold winter night. But while the thatched roof is still popular in the Belgian, English an...
lead_paragraph: The thatched-roof cottage has long been a symbol of a simple but rewarding country life, summoning images of friends and family around a cozy fireplace on a cold winter night. But while the thatched roof is still popular in the Belgian, English and Dutch countrysides, it has lost popularity in France - ironically, Europe's biggest supplier of thatching.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Germaninventors deserve protection as an endangered species. At least that's the contention of Joachim Bader, president of the German Inventors Association. He says his fellow creators have a bad rap as wild-eyed madmen with little sense of the pr...
lead_paragraph: Germaninventors deserve protection as an endangered species. At least that's the contention of Joachim Bader, president of the German Inventors Association. He says his fellow creators have a bad rap as wild-eyed madmen with little sense of the practical. But to Mr. Bader, they are "a driving force in the evolution of our society."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: A gang of four or five masked men intercepted a truck from Hungary as it was arriving at Rungis, Paris's wholesale food market, Sunday night. The men locked the drivers in a walk-in cooler, then drove off with their booty - 13 tons of goose liver ...
lead_paragraph: A gang of four or five masked men intercepted a truck from Hungary as it was arriving at Rungis, Paris's wholesale food market, Sunday night. The men locked the drivers in a walk-in cooler, then drove off with their booty - 13 tons of goose liver paté, worth about 700,000 francs ($130,000). So far there are no suspects. But authorities may want to keep an eye open for anyone making extraordinarily large purchases of Sauternes.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The number of deaths in Italy has exceeded the number of births for the first time since 1914. Figures for 1993 show that the fertility rate has dropped to only 1.21 children per woman. That is the lowest in Europe, which has an average of 1.55. T...
lead_paragraph: The number of deaths in Italy has exceeded the number of births for the first time since 1914. Figures for 1993 show that the fertility rate has dropped to only 1.21 children per woman. That is the lowest in Europe, which has an average of 1.55. The trend, particularly marked in northern and central Italy, reflects the aging of the population and a desire to limit family size, says the National Statistical Institute. But the Vatican newspaper, l'Osservatore Romano, blames "selfishness" and "a sense of self-satisfaction" among Italians who regard divorce and abortion as "something natural."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: About 4,500 Irish country pub owners marched on Parliament on Tuesday to protest new laws they say are ruining their lives..The laws, which brought Ireland into line with European Union regulations, lowered the legal alcohol blood level for driver...
lead_paragraph: About 4,500 Irish country pub owners marched on Parliament on Tuesday to protest new laws they say are ruining their lives.

title: A Holocaust Survivor Gets a Vogue Cover
snippet: Anna Wintour called Vogue Germany’s latest cover star, 102-year-old Margot Friedländer, a “meaningful” subject.
lead_paragraph: Margot Friedländer, a 102-year-old Holocaust survivor whose family was murdered at Auschwitz, would seem an unlikely — even radical — choice to front a fashion glossy that customarily features comely models and celebrities. But a weathered and white-haired Ms. Friedländer is the latest cover star of Vogue Germany, a distinction she seems to wear as lightly as the tailored coat she models on the magazine’s July/August issue.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Prostitution could be outlawed in Sweden, that pioneer of sexual freedom, if recommendations of a Health Ministry commission are adopted. The panel, citing the danger of AIDS, the links between prostitution and crime, and the potential for the exp...
lead_paragraph: Prostitution could be outlawed in Sweden, that pioneer of sexual freedom, if recommendations of a Health Ministry commission are adopted. The panel, citing the danger of AIDS, the links between prostitution and crime, and the potential for the exploitation of foreigners and young people in the sex trade, has called for fines or prison sentences of up to six months for prostitutes and their clients. "There are two trends in Europe," said the commission secretary, Lii Orlov-Lempert. "The first says it's a human right to be a prostitute, the second says it's a human right not to be abused."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Young people in Spain are having sexual relations less than any other age group but those over 65, according to a Madrid sociological research institute. One in three of those aged 18 to 24 reported not having had relations in the previous five ye...
lead_paragraph: Young people in Spain are having sexual relations less than any other age group but those over 65, according to a Madrid sociological research institute. One in three of those aged 18 to 24 reported not having had relations in the previous five years; four in 10 of those in the older group said the same.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: Lively competition — make that fierce competition — will hit French funeral homesJan. 1, when a law deregulating the death business takes effect.Key players have wasted no time. In July, SCI, a big American company with branches in Canada
lead_paragraph: Lively competition — make that fierce competition — will hit French funeral homesJan. 1, when a law deregulating the death business takes effect.Key players have wasted no time. In July, SCI, a big American company with branches in Canada and Britain, bought out the funeral subsidiary of Lyonnaise des Eaux, which had been losing market share. The Pompes Funebres Européennes and its allied Roc'Eclerc have built a 5 percent share of this 5 billion franc market, which includes coffins, hearses and rental of casket bearers. But deregulation is expected to profit the many small providers.The fight will be over a shrinking pie — people are living longer in France, home of Jeanne Calment, the world's oldest living person. And it will be at least five years before the graying of the Baby Boom allows business to pick up again.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: More than 100 people lost money to a clever high-tech scam in Paris. The crooks affixed a bogus slot to the outside of automatic bank-teller machines, and placed a fake keyboard above the real one. When users inserted their cards and punched in th...
lead_paragraph: More than 100 people lost money to a clever high-tech scam in Paris. The crooks affixed a bogus slot to the outside of automatic bank-teller machines, and placed a fake keyboard above the real one. When users inserted their cards and punched in their codes, the machine kept the cards, while the keyboard, disguising a pocket calculator, memorized the numbers.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: A major row has developed in Poland over the screening of a British film about a homosexual priest. The movie, "The Priest," has won awards at the Edinburgh and Berlin film festivals. But Roman Catholic groups call it "pornographic" a
lead_paragraph: A major row has developed in Poland over the screening of a British film about a homosexual priest. The movie, "The Priest," has won awards at the Edinburgh and Berlin film festivals. But Roman Catholic groups call it "pornographic" and say it mocks the church. The episcopate has joined with the Solidarity trade movement to demand that copies of the film be seized. But many young people say they want to judge the film for themselves. Until a public prosecutor renders his verdict, the film is banned to those under 18.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: A Dutch court dropped a murder charge this week against a doctor accused of killing a severely deformed newborn. The ruling by the Amsterdam Court of Appeal further erodesthe country's strict limitations on euthanasia. Government guidelines demand...
lead_paragraph: A Dutch court dropped a murder charge this week against a doctor accused of killing a severely deformed newborn. The ruling by the Amsterdam Court of Appeal further erodesthe country's strict limitations on euthanasia. Government guidelines demand that patients repeatedly and lucidly ask for death. Tuesday's decision — in the case of a 3-day-old suffering in excruciating pain from severe brain, spinal and leg deformities — was seen as opening the door to so-called mercy killings of those unable to ask for death.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Lottery winners in Germany are increasingly unlikely to mention their winnings to their spouses, according to officials of WestLotto in Münster. Sometimes lottery staff must meet the winners in a car or on a park bench to keep spouses in the dark....
lead_paragraph: Lottery winners in Germany are increasingly unlikely to mention their winnings to their spouses, according to officials of WestLotto in Münster. Sometimes lottery staff must meet the winners in a car or on a park bench to keep spouses in the dark. Legally, the clients' desire for secrecy poses no problem: A winning ticket is considered a contract strictly between its possessor and the lottery company.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Residents of a Barcelona neighborhood, disturbed by the presence of a bookstore specializing in materials from the political far right, want to make a statement. They're circulating a petition to rename the street after Anne Frank, the Jewish girl...
lead_paragraph: Residents of a Barcelona neighborhood, disturbed by the presence of a bookstore specializing in materials from the political far right, want to make a statement. They're circulating a petition to rename the street after Anne Frank, the Jewish girl who died in a German concentration camp in World War II.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
lead_paragraph: The number of German tourists visiting Croatia is expected to rise this year to 461,000 from last year's 355,000, still far below the pre-Yugoslav war year of 1990, when it was nearly 1.5 million.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: In Strasbourg, people will have a chance to test a new electric scooter for a nominal 200 francs ($40) per month. Peugeot will provide 24-hour service for the two- wheelers and asks only that users keep a log of any problems. Top speed of the scoo...
lead_paragraph: In Strasbourg, people will have a chance to test a new electric scooter for a nominal 200 francs ($40) per month. Peugeot will provide 24-hour service for the two- wheelers and asks only that users keep a log of any problems. Top speed of the scooter is 45 kilometers per hour (28 miles per hour). It has a range of 45 kilometers.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Portuguese voters who like a service-oriented approach to government might want to consider a dark-horse candidate for the presidency. Carlos Ferreira says his 24 years of waiting tables at one of Lisbon's finer eateries, the restaurant at the Tiv...
lead_paragraph: Portuguese voters who like a service-oriented approach to government might want to consider a dark-horse candidate for the presidency. Carlos Ferreira says his 24 years of waiting tables at one of Lisbon's finer eateries, the restaurant at the Tivoli Hotel, have shown him he has what it takes. "I've studied Lech Walesa, Felipe González, Mário Soares and many others" over their meals, he told The Sunday Times of London. "I don't see why I shouldn't be able to do the job as well as them." Or better than President Soares, whom he hopes to succeed. He thinks his rough and humble upbringing on Lisbon's streets helped give him the strength of character and simple honesty the Portuguese want.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: It has become increasingly common for people in London — well, at least in the journalistic and publishing worlds — to take their dogs with them to the office, Chrissy Iley writes in The Sunday Times. At John Brown Publishing in west London, f
lead_paragraph: It has become increasingly common for people in London — well, at least in the journalistic and publishing worlds — to take their dogs with them to the office, Chrissy Iley writes in The Sunday Times. At John Brown Publishing in west London, five of 45 employees bring their dogs along. And at Country Life magazine, there are said to be nearly as many dog baskets as desks.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Plans for a big airport serving the Berlin area - the most ambitious transportation project in German history - have brought together an unlikely alliance in opposition..The conservative Christian Democrats of Berlin say the 15 billion Deutsche ma...
lead_paragraph: Plans for a big airport serving the Berlin area - the most ambitious transportation project in German history - have brought together an unlikely alliance in opposition.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: François Mitterrand and his wife, Danielle, say they plan to be buried on a hillside plot in France's Morvan regional park. The site overlooks the former president's political home base and the school where his wife's father once taught. Burial ou...
lead_paragraph: François Mitterrand and his wife, Danielle, say they plan to be buried on a hillside plot in France's Morvan regional park. The site overlooks the former president's political home base and the school where his wife's father once taught. Burial outside of cemeteries is not a simple matter in France. Normally, the plot has to have been in the family for years, and be approved by a hydrologist. A more certain way to spend eternity in one's favorite haunt is cremation, the choice of 10 percent of the French. There are limits on that. Ashes may be dropped from a bridge or spread in a forest but not deposited on public roads or sidewalks. So no one needs worry about treading on someone's Oncle Louis.

title: Russia Sends Waves of Troops to the Front in a Brutal Style of Fighting
snippet: More than 1,000 Russian soldiers in Ukraine were killed or wounded on average each day in May, according to NATO and Western military officials.
lead_paragraph: May was a particularly deadly month for the Russian army in Ukraine, with an average of more than 1,000 of its soldiers injured or killed each day, according to U.S., British and other Western intelligence agencies.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Neither snow nor rain nor heat - but possibly high water - will stay Jutta Pudenz from the leisurely completion of her appointed rounds. Poling along the canal system in the Spreewald mountains southeast of Berlin, she is Germany's last mail carri...
lead_paragraph: Neither snow nor rain nor heat - but possibly high water - will stay Jutta Pudenz from the leisurely completion of her appointed rounds. Poling along the canal system in the Spreewald mountains southeast of Berlin, she is Germany's last mail carrier to use a flat-bottomed boat. Mrs. Pudenz, 42, delivers 1,300 letters to 78 homes along the waterway each week.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: With its very clunkiness part of its charm, the old East German-produced Trabant automobile has forged a fiercely loyal following in the reunited Germany. Trabant lovers have formed some 60 clubs around the country to share their enthusiasm for th...
lead_paragraph: With its very clunkiness part of its charm, the old East German-produced Trabant automobile has forged a fiercely loyal following in the reunited Germany. Trabant lovers have formed some 60 clubs around the country to share their enthusiasm for these cars - loud, smelly and slow though they may be. A summer Trabi festival drew 28,000 fans. A few years ago, some Trabis were abandoned on roadsides in Eastern Europe in the first big wave of departures after the fall of the Iron Curtain. Now they sell for up to 4,000 Deutsche marks (about $2,800) apiece. So great is demand that the longtime automaker, now privatized, has decided to offer a "Last Edition" Trabi, reports the weekly Der Spiegel. Production ended in April 1991, but 444 of the cars were found moldering in a Turkish port, abandoned by a bankrupt importer. Brought back to Germany, they have been repainted, fitted with four- cylinder motors instead of the standard two-, and equipped with imitation leather seats. The breathtaking price tag for these, the "absolute last" Trabis: 19,444 DM.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Four Swedish bookstores have announced a "regret week" policy that will allow clients to return books they have read but disliked. The shops want people to take a chance on books, hopefully to be pleasantly surprised, the daily Nya Tidning in U
lead_paragraph: Four Swedish bookstores have announced a "regret week" policy that will allow clients to return books they have read but disliked. The shops want people to take a chance on books, hopefully to be pleasantly surprised, the daily Nya Tidning in Uppsala reported. The returned books, which are resold at a reduced price, must be brought back within one week and in good condition.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: The severely overweight have a lower life expectancy, so a British insurance company is planning to offer a new policy that will pay them higher annuities. The policy will be similar to one offered heavy smokers. To qualify, people will probably h...
lead_paragraph: The severely overweight have a lower life expectancy, so a British insurance company is planning to offer a new policy that will pay them higher annuities. The policy will be similar to one offered heavy smokers. To qualify, people will probably have to be 20 percent to 25 percent above the average weight expected for their height, The Sunday Times reports. But at 65, they would receive at least £1,000 ($1,500) more each year than their leaner counterparts. Some critics say the policy could encourage obesity in a country where half of adults already are overweight. But a spokesman for one group, Diet Breakers, disagreed, saying, "This is one of the few instances which rewards being large in our thin-obsessed society."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: About 4,500 Irish country pub owners marched on Parliament on Tuesday to protest new laws they say are ruining their lives..The laws, which brought Ireland into line with European Union regulations, lowered the legal alcohol blood level for driver...
lead_paragraph: About 4,500 Irish country pub owners marched on Parliament on Tuesday to protest new laws they say are ruining their lives.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: While other parts of Europe were joining together, part of Belgium was coming apart. The bilingual province of Brabant, a last vestige of a unitary Belgium, officially broke up Monday into a Flemish Brabant, to the north, and a French-speaking Bra...
lead_paragraph: While other parts of Europe were joining together, part of Belgium was coming apart. The bilingual province of Brabant, a last vestige of a unitary Belgium, officially broke up Monday into a Flemish Brabant, to the north, and a French-speaking Brabant, to the south.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Smudge, a tortoise-shell cat, survived six weeks stuck in a drainpipe, eating nothing but insects and drinking drops of condensation, his owner said Wednesday. The pet, long since given up for dead, was skeletal when it was found by a garage owner...
lead_paragraph: Smudge, a tortoise-shell cat, survived six weeks stuck in a drainpipe, eating nothing but insects and drinking drops of condensation, his owner said Wednesday. The pet, long since given up for dead, was skeletal when it was found by a garage owner at Gillingham in the southeastern English county of Kent. "Smudge was weak and could hardly stand," said his owner, Beryl Banks. "The vet gave her liquids and medication and we were all amazed when she pulled through." Eight left.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The European Commission is not - repeat not - planning to go into the pizza business. But the message doesn't seem to be getting through. Reports circulating in Italy that Brussels officials were planning to decree standards for pizza thickness an...
lead_paragraph: The European Commission is not - repeat not - planning to go into the pizza business. But the message doesn't seem to be getting through. Reports circulating in Italy that Brussels officials were planning to decree standards for pizza thickness and diameter led to angry protests; the Real Pizza association in Naples denounced the alleged new rules as "pure nonsense." But then maybe the rumormongers can be excused - if the Eurocrats can set standards for banana length (as they have), why not, say, pizza crusts?

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: A new Czech nationality law has come under fire from human-rights advocates, who say it is intended to chase Gypsies, most of them born in Slovakia, out of the country..The new law requires proof of two years of established residence and five year...
lead_paragraph: A new Czech nationality law has come under fire from human-rights advocates, who say it is intended to chase Gypsies, most of them born in Slovakia, out of the country.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: A program in interpreting sign language has been added to the syllabus of the School of Translation and Interpretation at the University of Geneva..The program, a first in Switzerland, will prepare students to interpret in a variety of circumstanc...
lead_paragraph: A program in interpreting sign language has been added to the syllabus of the School of Translation and Interpretation at the University of Geneva.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Talk about fast work... According to the Paris daily Libération, a work crew on the Rue de Provence was seen on a recent morning painting stripes to indicate that the street had become a metered parking zone. Trucks were employed to hoist cars up ...
lead_paragraph: Talk about fast work... According to the Paris daily Libération, a work crew on the Rue de Provence was seen on a recent morning painting stripes to indicate that the street had become a metered parking zone. Trucks were employed to hoist cars up while painters applied stripes beneath them. So far nothing new. But locals were astounded when, with the paint still wet, an "army" of light-blue-garbed meter readers swarmed in to ticket the cars, now illegally parked.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: A small town in northern Sweden has deformed the Arctic Circle to attract tourists, according to the daily Dagens Nyheter. Travelers passing through Niskanpaeae receive certificates to mark their Arctic Circle crossing. In fact, the circle lies 4 ...
lead_paragraph: A small town in northern Sweden has deformed the Arctic Circle to attract tourists, according to the daily Dagens Nyheter. Travelers passing through Niskanpaeae receive certificates to mark their Arctic Circle crossing. In fact, the circle lies 4 kilometers (2.5 miles) farther north. Harry Grape, the town's new centrist mayor, blames this creative bit of gerrymandering on his predecessors, the Social Democrats, who originated the practice.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The Green Party of Britain, at its recent conference in Weston-super-Mare, staged an hourlong workshop in how to hug a woman without being insensitive..A sumo-wrestler embrace involving full chest and pelvic contact is "totally inappropriate,"
lead_paragraph: The Green Party of Britain, at its recent conference in Weston-super-Mare, staged an hourlong workshop in how to hug a woman without being insensitive.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Since reunification, the number of women in Eastern Germany who have had themselves sterilized has soared. The number of sterilizations in Brandenburg state alone shot up to 6,224 in 1993, from 827 in 1991, according to a report by a Berlin sociol...
lead_paragraph: Since reunification, the number of women in Eastern Germany who have had themselves sterilized has soared. The number of sterilizations in Brandenburg state alone shot up to 6,224 in 1993, from 827 in 1991, according to a report by a Berlin sociologist, Daphne Hornig. Many of the women involved, she found, were acting in response to "high pressure to show flexibility" regarding work or to fears that they would be unable to care for children. The birthrate in Brandenburg has meanwhile fallen by two-thirds.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: An 85-year-old Bavarian man called the police on a recent night after his wife, also 85, locked herself in their bedroom with her young lover, the police said. .The man asked the police to expel his wife's friend because he was too frail to do it ...
lead_paragraph: An 85-year-old Bavarian man called the police on a recent night after his wife, also 85, locked herself in their bedroom with her young lover, the police said.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Abortion remains controversial in France 20 years after its legalization. Groups calling themselves "God's commandos" still protest outside some clinics or burst in to exhort staff members to stop their "bloody madness." Generally the
lead_paragraph: Abortion remains controversial in France 20 years after its legalization. Groups calling themselves "God's commandos" still protest outside some clinics or burst in to exhort staff members to stop their "bloody madness." Generally their members receive light sentences - suspended jail terms and fines of 5,000 francs ($945) in one recent case.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The naming of children has been seen as a challenge to British wits over the years, judging by recent letters to The Times. One writer mentions such authenticated names as Morning Dew, Winter Frost, Holly Bush and Hay Stack Brown. The prize, howev...
lead_paragraph: The naming of children has been seen as a challenge to British wits over the years, judging by recent letters to The Times. One writer mentions such authenticated names as Morning Dew, Winter Frost, Holly Bush and Hay Stack Brown. The prize, however, may have to go to a Mr. and Mrs. Shaw, who named their daughter Bythesee (pronounced "by the sea.")

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: As people live longer, the number of four-generation families in France is growing fast, reports the daily Libération. In a reversal of conventional wisdom, links between generations have become stronger..The numbers of healthy young grandparents
lead_paragraph: As people live longer, the number of four-generation families in France is growing fast, reports the daily Libération. In a reversal of conventional wisdom, links between generations have become stronger.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The newest soccer commentator for the Italian television channel Rai Tre has the fervor and devotion of many a sports fan, but with a difference: She is a Franciscan nun. A Rai sports reporter had discovered Sister Paola in the stands of a Lazio R...
lead_paragraph: The newest soccer commentator for the Italian television channel Rai Tre has the fervor and devotion of many a sports fan, but with a difference: She is a Franciscan nun. A Rai sports reporter had discovered Sister Paola in the stands of a Lazio Rome soccer match; she is a season-ticket holder. Their meeting, reports Die Welt, evolved into an invitation to do commentary, with results like these: "People, you just wouldn't believe how much I prayed to Our Mother Mary over this match ... " or "Ah, it is halftime now. I must withdraw for a spiritual pause." But the sister's perspective on the game is not universally appreciated: she seems to see the Lazio team as a force for good and its opponents as vectors of evil. Fans of another team, AS Rome, have petitioned Rai to have Sister Paola confine her commentary to less worldly topics.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
lead_paragraph: Overheard at the starting line of the Paris Marathon on Sunday:

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The lack of manners among Germans today causes Gisela Tautz-Wiessner, longtime etiquette adviser to the Berlin government, to wince discreetly. She blames what she sees as a lack of tolerance, consideration and general humanity on the '60s generat...
lead_paragraph: The lack of manners among Germans today causes Gisela Tautz-Wiessner, longtime etiquette adviser to the Berlin government, to wince discreetly. She blames what she sees as a lack of tolerance, consideration and general humanity on the '60s generation, which tossed out old codes of behavior without putting anything in their place.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Businessmen hit by a one-boy crime wave in a British town have appealed to the government to give the courts the power to detain the 14-year-old responsible. The boy, who cannot be named under British law, has been convicted 138 times for vandalis...
lead_paragraph: Businessmen hit by a one-boy crime wave in a British town have appealed to the government to give the courts the power to detain the 14-year-old responsible. The boy, who cannot be named under British law, has been convicted 138 times for vandalism and theft in the northern English town of Elland. He has been blamed for driving businesses out, sending insurance premiums soaring and doubling the town's crime rate. But existing law prevents children under 15 from being detained within the penal system, The Times reports. A criminal justice act passed this year provides for training centers for persistent juvenile offenders, but they have yet to be opened.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Filip Andronik, a 13-year- old Sarajevo schoolboy, started a rather unusual collection in 1992, when war broke out: He has kept every empty box, tin can, tube or bottle - every bit of packing material - in which humanitarian aid has come for his f...
lead_paragraph: Filip Andronik, a 13-year- old Sarajevo schoolboy, started a rather unusual collection in 1992, when war broke out: He has kept every empty box, tin can, tube or bottle - every bit of packing material - in which humanitarian aid has come for his family, which includes his mother and brother. The count to date: 51 tin cans and 484 other containers. It hasn't been easy: Every used item has to be washed, and water is obtained in Sarajevo at some risk. Filip hopes to find a place in the Guinness Book of Records, but only when the war is over. "I want to show people how much we got," he said, "and what we had to live on."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: The numbers of Genevans seeking psychiatric help is up sharply. From 50,000 psychiatric visits recorded in 1983, the number soared in 10 years to 180,000. Over the same period, the number of practitioners more than doubled, from 73 to 188, accordi...
lead_paragraph: The numbers of Genevans seeking psychiatric help is up sharply. From 50,000 psychiatric visits recorded in 1983, the number soared in 10 years to 180,000. Over the same period, the number of practitioners more than doubled, from 73 to 188, according to the Journal de Genève. Has life in Geneva become so much harder? Are people quicker to seek help?

title: European Topics : Around Europe
lead_paragraph: Authorities have decided to set aside 70 mixed cells in the new wing of Arajuez prison, in Spain, for husbands and wives who are both serving jail terms. Space will also be provided for their young children.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Lars Windhorst is a wunderkind if ever there was one. Two years ago, aged 16, he founded an electronic components company, with help from his elders. Since then, his Windhorst Group has expanded to include 13 firms, with turnover in its first year...
lead_paragraph: Lars Windhorst is a wunderkind if ever there was one. Two years ago, aged 16, he founded an electronic components company, with help from his elders. Since then, his Windhorst Group has expanded to include 13 firms, with turnover in its first year of 80 million Deutsche marks. But the whole time, his father had to sign his checks, and his mother drove him to work each day. All young Lars wanted was a Mercedes sports car. On Tuesday, his 18th birthday, he got his wish.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Around Europe
snippet: The Italian government has proposed raising the maximum age at which people may adopt children from 40 to 50. "Society has changed," says the minister of social affairs, Antonio Guidi. "People live longer, marry later and have children lat
lead_paragraph: The Italian government has proposed raising the maximum age at which people may adopt children from 40 to 50. "Society has changed," says the minister of social affairs, Antonio Guidi. "People live longer, marry later and have children later." Child advocacy groups have protested that the draft law is "less concerned with children's interests than with those of adults." Parliament will decide next month.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Some things don't translate. Among the scores of American situation comedies imported to Germany over the years, only a few - notably "The Cosby Show" and "Roseanne" - have been big hits. "One criterion for success is careful syn
lead_paragraph: Some things don't translate. Among the scores of American situation comedies imported to Germany over the years, only a few - notably "The Cosby Show" and "Roseanne" - have been big hits. "One criterion for success is careful synchronization," says Hartmut Neugebauer of Munich, who writes the German dialogue for "Roseanne." "In English the gags are shorter. You have to be more creative."

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: A sad record was set last week in Germany: 17 people killed themselves by jumping in front of trains. With two such attempts every day on German railroads, engineers have had to live with the grim knowledge that at least once in their careers, the...
lead_paragraph: A sad record was set last week in Germany: 17 people killed themselves by jumping in front of trains. With two such attempts every day on German railroads, engineers have had to live with the grim knowledge that at least once in their careers, they are likely to be involved in such a death, the daily Süddeutsche Zeitung reports.

title: Around Europe : European Topics
snippet: Disgusted with the corruption of Italian democracy, the village of Seborga, near the French border, has declared its independence - and made a flower grower, Giorgio Carbone, its king. As one of his first official acts, "King Giorgio" nailed th
lead_paragraph: Disgusted with the corruption of Italian democracy, the village of Seborga, near the French border, has declared its independence - and made a flower grower, Giorgio Carbone, its king. As one of his first official acts, "King Giorgio" nailed the town's white and blue flag to the church tower, and declared that Seborga would pursue a peaceful foreign policy. But he also said it would stop paying taxes to the "rotten" Italian state. SeborHL gians await Rome's response.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: It is a most unusual monument: Stretching through Paris from north to south, it has 135 separate parts, and yet you might easily overlook it. Implanted in city streets and courtyards, 135 bronze circles, each bearing only the word Arago and an "N&...
lead_paragraph: It is a most unusual monument: Stretching through Paris from north to south, it has 135 separate parts, and yet you might easily overlook it. Implanted in city streets and courtyards, 135 bronze circles, each bearing only the word Arago and an "N" and "S" for the compass points, honor François Arago, the 19th century scientist and politician. They follow the imaginary line between the Earth's poles, known as the meridian of Paris, which Mr. Arago had helped trace out even before his election to the French Academy of Sciences at the age of 23. (The line through Greenwich, England, later replaced it as the standard reference.)

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Britain's House of Lords has approved the introduction of a new offense of male rape, carrying a maximum penalty of life imprisonment - the same as for the rape of a woman..The amendment follows a controversial decision by Parliament earlier this ...
lead_paragraph: Britain's House of Lords has approved the introduction of a new offense of male rape, carrying a maximum penalty of life imprisonment - the same as for the rape of a woman.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Stress is on the rise in Britain, and doctors are called on increasingly to counsel their patients, according to a new study. Four of five generalists surveyed say the number of patients seeking help for stress-related problems had risen significa...
lead_paragraph: Stress is on the rise in Britain, and doctors are called on increasingly to counsel their patients, according to a new study. Four of five generalists surveyed say the number of patients seeking help for stress-related problems had risen significantly in the past 15 years, according to the British Medical Association News Review. Fifty-eight percent said their patients were drinking more (the figure rose to 70 percent in Wales and southwest England) and 60 percent said they were seeing more patients with drug problems. Unemployment was the chief cause cited for growing stress, followed by frustrations at work.

title: European Topics : Around Europe
snippet: Most of Amsterdam's 18th-century bridges are in bad shape. About 120 of the 170 bridges need repairs, said Klaas Pascha, a civil engineer..The hump-backed bridges were designed so canal boats could pass under them. .A city spokesman said that 19 b...
lead_paragraph: Most of Amsterdam's 18th-century bridges are in bad shape. About 120 of the 170 bridges need repairs, said Klaas Pascha, a civil engineer.

title: Wednesday Briefing
snippet: Anti-tax protests tore through Kenya’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Kenya’s president, William Ruto, deployed the military yesterday to crack down on what he called “treasonous” protesters after thousands of demonstrators, furious over the passage of tax increases, flooded the streets of the capital, Nairobi, stormed the Parliament building and set fire to the entrance.

title: EUROPEAN PRODUCER PRICES
snippet: Eurostat says industrial producer prices in 12-nation euro zone rose 0.2 percent in February from previous month (S)
lead_paragraph: Industrial producer prices in the 12-nation euro zone rose 0.2 percent in February from the previous month, Eurostat, the European Union's statistical office, said. The rise was in line with analysts' expectations. Prices of nondurable consumer goods had the largest monthly rise at 0.5 percent, durable goods prices rose 0.3 percent, and capital goods increased 0.2 percent. But the prices of intermediate goods remained flat at January's level. Paul Meller

title: CONFIDENCE SLIPS IN EUROPE
snippet: Confidence among executives and consumers in euro region falls to lowest level in 15 months in January (S)
lead_paragraph: Confidence among executives and consumers in the euro region fell to the lowest level in 15 months in January amid concern an economic slowdown in the United States will spill across the Atlantic. A European Commission index, based on a survey of 25,000 consumers and 50,000 companies, fell to 103, the lowest since October 1999, from 103.3 in December. Manufacturers' orders weakened, and their outlook for future production worsened.

title: World Briefing | Europe: New European Commissioners
snippet: European Union Parliament approves new executive branch to be led by incoming commissioner Jose Manuel Durao Barroso of Portugal (S)
lead_paragraph: The Parliament of the European Union approved a new lineup for the European Commission, ending a three-week stalemate. The decision in Strasbourg means the union will have a new executive branch in place by Monday. José Manuel Durão Barroso of Portugal, the incoming commission president, vowed to push economic reform during his five-year term. He put forward the new team after Italy was forced to replace its candidate for the justice and home affairs portfolio because of his conservative views on homosexuality and women. Graham Bowley (NYT)

title: New Europe’s Boomtown
snippet: Philippe Benoit du Rey is not one of those gloomy Frenchmen who frets about the threat to Gallic civilization from McDonald's and Microsoft. He thinks international competition is good for his countrymen. He's confident France will flourish in a g...
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, ESTONIA - Philippe Benoit du Rey is not one of those gloomy Frenchmen who frets about the threat to Gallic civilization from McDonald's and Microsoft. He thinks international competition is good for his countrymen. He's confident France will flourish in a global economy -- eventually.

title: EUROPEANS DELIBERATE ON DEALS
snippet: European antitrust regulators meet in Brussels to decide whether concessions submitted by Time Warner and its proposed partners, America Online and the EMI Music Group, are sufficient to allay European concerns that planned deals will choke compet...
lead_paragraph: European antitrust regulators met in Brussels yesterday to decide whether concessions submitted by Time Warner and its proposed partners, America Online and the EMI Music Group, were sufficient to allay European concerns that the planned deals would choke competition in the Internet distribution of music. The regulators, from the national antitrust agencies of the 15 European Union member states, were expected to issue a recommendation whether to accept or reject the concessions, or possibly to seek further clarification from the companies. John Tagliabue

title: Russia Opens Secret Trial of U.S. Reporter Accused of Espionage
snippet: Evan Gershkovich of The Wall Street Journal has endured 15 months in prison by reading letters and Russian classics, while the authorities have not publicly offered any evidence that he was a spy.
lead_paragraph: In his nearly 15 months in Moscow’s infamous Lefortovo prison, Evan Gershkovich has plowed through Russian literary classics like “War and Peace,” and played slow-moving chess by mail with his father in the United States. He tries to keep himself in shape during the hourlong exercise period he is permitted each day.

title: EUROPE'S INFLATION RISES
snippet: February consumer prices in 12 countries using euro rises at annual rate of 2.6 percent, lessening likelihood of European Central Bank cutting interest rates soon (S)
lead_paragraph: Consumer prices in the 12 countries using the euro rose at an annual rate of 2.6 percent in February, a bit faster than the 2.4 percent in January, the European Commission announced yesterday. Given the European Central Bank's inflation target of 2 percent or less for the year, the new data made an interest rate cut unlikely for several months despite signs of a global economic slowdown, analysts said. The bank left rates unchanged at its most recent policy meeting on Thursday. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: RATES STEADY IN EUROPE
snippet: European Central Bank's council decides to keep interest rates unchanged, leaving key minimum bid rate at 4.75 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank's council decided to keep interest rates unchanged yesterday, leaving the key minimum bid rate at 4.75 percent. In contrast to the United States Federal Reserve's fears about American growth, the council has remained confident about the euro zone. But a rate cut is expected within the next several months. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: EUROPEAN PHONE DEAL
snippet: NetCom, Sweden's second-largest phone company, agrees to buy 82 percent it does not already own of Societe Europeenne de Communication in stock swap that values company, unprofitable phone operation, at 31.3 billion kronor ($3.5 billion) (S)
lead_paragraph: Sweden's second-largest phone company, NetCom, agreed to buy the 82 percent it did not already own of Societe Europeenne de Communication in a stock swap valuing S.E.C., an unprofitable phone operation, at 31.3 billion kronor ($3.5 billion). NetCom offered one Class B share for every 11.5 shares of S.E.C. The Swedish media executive Jan Stenbeck controls both companies.

title: To the Top of Europe
