title: Australia’s Addiction to Coal
snippet: The country’s politicians say they want to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions while planning to build new coal mines.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — A world determined to limit climate change needs fewer coal mines. Burning coal is the largest single source of greenhouse-gas emissions, and the particles from its combustion are a major cause of air pollution, causing hundreds of thousands of deaths each year.

title: For Australians, a Blow to the Ego
snippet: The Aussies may still see a resounding victory or two. But in the medal count, there would appear to be no saving the essential: bragging rights over Great Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It may still get better for Australia, sunburned land where Olympic champions used to grow on eucalyptus trees.

title: Australia’s Leftward Turn
snippet: Economic growth has unleashed two trends that tilt an electorate to the left: booming cities and mass migration.
lead_paragraph: Melbourne, Australia — The political fault lines are familiar to any democracy. At election time, the people divide according to location. Those living in coastal cities tend to vote center-left; those in the hinterland are likely to vote conservative. The pattern repeats by age, education and ethnicity. The university graduate and the migrant lean center-left; the retiree and the local-born lean conservative.

title: The End of the Australian Dream?
snippet: When you have a nation full of people trying to get to the top, eventually most of the population is forced to run just to keep up.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Let me tell you a fairy tale called Australia. Despite what you may have heard about snakes and spiders and sharks, the remarkable thing about Australia is not its danger but its safety. At its best, this is a peaceful nation, with health care and education for almost everyone, that has enjoyed over the past two decades the longest period of economic expansion of any developed country in modern history. Our cities are regularly judged to be among the most livable in the world.

title: Australia’s Guantánamo Problem
snippet: Dozens of people are being held without trial in violation of international law.
lead_paragraph: On a remote, sunny island, some 52 people have been detained for up to nearly five years without trial on secret evidence, with no prospect of release. A series of suicide attempts since 2012 speaks to their profound suffering. One man attempted to hang himself with a bedsheet. Another tried to electrocute himself. Another drank bleach. Another cut himself and used his blood to leave a message on a wall. All remain in detention; the government dismisses them as attention-seekers.

title: A Test of Australian Identity
snippet: It doesn’t matter how exclusively Australian you say you are, chances are you’ve come from somewhere else not very long ago.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible for a constitutional crisis to be funny? I give you Australia.

title: Australia’s Offshore Cruelty
snippet: Scrap a policy that condemns refugees to a desperate and hopeless limbo.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian treatment of refugees trying to reach this vast, thinly populated country by boat follows textbook rules for the administering of cruelty. It begins with the anodyne name for the procedures — “offshore processing” — as if these desperate human beings were just an accumulation of data.

title: Living With Racism in Australia
snippet: You can try to keep a low profile, but you can never choose invisibility. When the bigots decide to see you, they will see you.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — My father survived the killing fields of Cambodia, where he was threatened with having his tongue cut out with a sickle for speaking his native language, Teochew Chinese. When he and my pregnant mother arrived in Australia in 1980 and discovered that their new country encouraged them to maintain their language and culture, they were incredulous. My father named me Alice because he believed I was delivered into a Wonderland, a place that allowed for the full expression of human personality and potential.

title: Touring Is a Tonic for Australians
snippet: The Australian Ballet, which last brought its full company to New York in 1999, will perform programs at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: IT’S not every season the Lincoln Center studios ring with “G’day!” But that’s about to change, at least for a week, when the Australian Ballet visits New York for the first time since 1999.

title: ‘Dead Poets Society’ Has Some Distinctly Australian Relevance
snippet: Brought to life by the Australian director Peter Weir, the movie’s conflict reflects a collective cultural trait his fellow citizens can relate to.
lead_paragraph: With my 13-year-old daughter home for a break from her one-year adventure at a boarding school in the Australian bush, we put on an old movie the other night that she had asked to see: “Dead Poets Society.”

title: Australia and Oman Tie
snippet: Tim Cahill scored in injury time as Australia rescued a 1-1 draw against Oman in its opening Asia Cup match in Bangkok. Cahill, a midfielder who plays for Everton of the English Premier League, volleyed into the net from close range for Australia....
lead_paragraph: Tim Cahill scored in injury time as Australia rescued a 1-1 draw against Oman in its opening Asia Cup match in Bangkok. Cahill, a midfielder who plays for Everton of the English Premier League, volleyed into the net from close range for Australia. Oman took the lead in the 32nd minute on a strike from Badar Mubarak.

title: Broadway Cowboy of Australia
snippet: David Campbell, the Australian pop singer, is back in New York in a show at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency celebrating his recent CD, “On Broadway.”
lead_paragraph: It seems like only a year or two ago that David Campbell, the shape-shifting Australian pop singer, was hailed as the next big thing when he became the youngest performer ever to open at the Rainbow and Stars cabaret, now defunct, in Rockefeller Center. But the year was actually 1997, and Mr. Campbell was a 24-year-old eager beaver of seemingly boundless confidence and ambition. Although American stardom eluded him, he went on to establish himself as a top-of-the-line musical theater performer in his homeland while continuing to pay visits to the United States.

title: Photographer Cleared in Australia
snippet: The Australian police have dropped their investigation into the work of Bill Henson, whose photographs of naked children caused controversy after the authorities shut down an exhibition in Sydney last month, Bloomberg News reported. The New South ...
lead_paragraph: The Australian police have dropped their investigation into the work of Bill Henson, whose photographs of naked children caused controversy after the authorities shut down an exhibition in Sydney last month, Bloomberg News reported. The New South Wales state police said in a statement on Friday that “there is no reasonable prospect for a successful conviction.” Mr. Henson’s images captured headlines after officers shut down the exhibition, saying they had received complaints. Australia’s prime minister, Kevin Rudd, called the photos “absolutely revolting,” while more than 40 prominent people in the arts, including the actress Cate Blanchett, signed an open letter in support of Mr. Henson. The artist said in a statement that it had been “profoundly humbling to witness the depth of support” for his work in the last few weeks. “It is reassuring to see existing laws, having been rigorously tested, still provide a framework in which debate and expression of ideas can occur,” he added.

title: AUSTRALIA: ENGINEERING MERGER
lead_paragraph: The British engineering company GKN P.L.C. confirmed it had agreed to combine its industrial services division with Brambles Industries, an Australian transport and logistics company. The new entity will have a market value of £6.9 billion ($9.9 billion), based on the closing share price of Brambles on April 18, the day before the deal was announced, the companies said. Brambles shareholders will own 57 percent, with GKN shareholders holding the balance. Don Argus, Brambles' chairman, will become the chairman of the new group. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: SLOW AUSTRALIAN GROWTH
snippet: Australia's economy grew at its slowest rate in three years in second quarter; gross domestic product rose two-tenths of 1 percent from previous quarter (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's economy grew at its slowest rate in three years in the second quarter, as miners and other companies exposed to Asia's slump invested less and consumer spending slowed. Gross domestic product rose two-tenths of 1 percent from the previous quarter, the Bureau of Statistics said. Economists had expected a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent. Compared with a year earlier, the economy grew 4.1 percent in the second quarter.

title: AUSTRALIAN MINE DEAL
snippet: Shares of Nippon Telephone & Telegraph rise 6.5 percent following announcement that it will lower fees it charges other carriers to use its local networks (S)
lead_paragraph: The British mining company Billiton P.L.C. agreed to acquire CSR Ltd.'s stake in the Gove alumina refinery and bauxite mine in Australia's Northern Territory for $275 million. CSR, an Australian building materials and sugar company, holds its interest in the refinery and mine joint venture through Gove Aluminium Ltd. CSR owns 70 percent of Gove Aluminium. The Billiton offer values the project at $393 million.

title: AUSTRALIA RATE CUT
snippet: Australian central bank reduces overnight cash rate to 5.75 percent from 6.25 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: The Australian central bank reduced a key rate, cutting the overnight cash rate to 5.75 percent from 6.25 percent. The bank cited slower world growth and restrained inflation. Analysts here foresaw a further easing of Australian monetary policy in coming months. In a statement announcing the rate reduction, the bank said domestic business confidence had slipped and the labor market had softened. Rory Robertson, interest rate strategist at Macquarie Equities, called the move ''a pre-emptive strike against weaker growth down the track.'' Becky Gaylord

title: AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL
snippet: Cable and Wireless Optus, Australia's number 2 telecommunications carrier, will sell its 10.6 percent stake in AAPT Ltd to Telecom Corp of New Zealand, giving company foothold in nation's telecommunications market, valued at $16 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's No. 2 telecommunications carrier, Cable and Wireless Optus, said it would sell its 10.6 percent stake in AAPT Ltd. to the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand, giving that company a foothold in the nation's telecommunications market, valued at 25 billion Australian dollars, or $16 billion. Optus, which is based in Sydney, said it would accept Telecom's offer of 5.10 Australian dollars a share after its own bid for AAPT was blocked by Australia's antitrust regulator earlier this year. The sale increases Telecom's stake in AAPT to about 43 percent.

title: A Bit of Australia in Every Watch
snippet: At Bausele, timepieces contain beach sand, red dirt from the outback, tile from the Sydney Opera House and more.
lead_paragraph: Australia has some of the world’s most celebrated attractions, from Bondi Beach to the Great Barrier Reef.

title: Indigenous Australians Plan to Go Bigger on Australia Day
snippet: “Invasion Day is the reason why we’re all here today, but we must go beyond that,” one activist said.
lead_paragraph: Parades, Union Jack themed barbecues, angry protests, and reflective vigils — it’s 2024, and Jan. 26 in Australia remains a day that inspires many different reactions across the nation.

title: AUSTRALIAN TAKEOVER BLOCKED
snippet: Shares in AAPT Ltd fall almost 11 percent after hostile takeover bid by Cable and Wireless Optus Ltd is blocked by Australia's antitrust regulator; withdrawal of Optus opens way for Telecom Corp of New Zealand, which holds 9.9 percent of AAPT, to ...
lead_paragraph: Shares in AAPT Ltd. fell almost 11 percent after a hostile takeover bid by Cable and Wireless Optus Ltd. was blocked by Australia's antitrust regulator. The withdrawal of Optus opens the way for the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand, which holds 9.9 percent of AAPT, to increase its stake in that company to nearly 20 percent. Optus owns 10.6 percent of AAPT, which is based in Sydney. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission refused to approve the bid for AAPT because it said the removal of one of the country's three providers of national telecommunications networks would substantially lessen competition.

title: Australia Is Burning
snippet: Hazard reduction is more complex than some would have you believe.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — Every state in Australia has been touched by fire since the season started in September. The fires have burned over 12 million acres, an area larger than Maryland. Four hundred and eighty million animals are estimated to be killed or badly injured. Thousands of people have been evacuated. At least 24 have died.

title: Mourning in Australia
snippet: Australians wake up to the news that a 16-hour siege inside a Sydney cafe ended overnight with three people dead, including the attacker. Deborah Lutterbeck reports.
lead_paragraph: Australians wake up to the news that a 16-hour siege inside a Sydney cafe ended overnight with three people dead, including the attacker. Deborah Lutterbeck reports.

title: Australian PM Abbott: Indonesia's execution of Australians "cruel"
snippet: Australia recalls its ambassador to Indonesia following the execution of two convicted Australian drug smugglers by firing squad and Prime Minister Tony Abbott says the Australia-Indonesia relationship "has suffered as a result of what's been done...
lead_paragraph: Australia recalls its ambassador to Indonesia following the execution of two convicted Australian drug smugglers by firing squad and Prime Minister Tony Abbott says the Australia-Indonesia relationship "has suffered as a result of what's been done." Rough Cut (no reporter narration).

title: Australia or Anywhere
snippet: A world is taking form that wants you never to be lost, never displaced.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — I boarded a flight at Kennedy Airport in New York. There were HSBC ads in the jet bridge. I flew for 24 hours to the bottom of the world. There were HSBC ads in the jet bridge.

title: The Look of ‘Australia’
snippet: Images of Catherine Martin’s costume design for the movie “Australia.”
lead_paragraph: Images of Catherine Martin’s costume design for the movie “Australia.”

title: Hobart, Australia
snippet: Mayor Anna Reynolds talks about reducing climate vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Anna Reynolds talks about reducing climate vulnerability.

title: Coming to Australia
snippet: Catering to an immigration-sensitive electorate, the Australian government is making it harder for Afghan refugees to make a new home on a land they’ve risked death to reach.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE — A takeaway kebab shop in a leafy Australian suburb seems a far cry from the troubles of Afghanistan. But even here the anguish of war and centuries-old prejudices bite.

title: Australia in Sonoma
snippet: Linda Dodwell, an intrepid motorcyclist, adventurer and artist, built a compound in California that was inspired by her solo ride across the Australian outback.
lead_paragraph: SONOMA, Calif.
