lead_paragraph: A SEVEN-BEDROOM, THREE-AND-A-HALF-BATH MANSION WITH HARBOR VIEWS IN NEWCASTLE, NEW SOUTH WALES

title: Wildfires in Australia
snippet: A series of wildfires that tore across the southern state of Victoria over the weekend killed at least 128 people, the state police said.
lead_paragraph: A series of wildfires that tore across the southern state of Victoria over the weekend killed at least 128 people, the state police said.

title: VINTAGE AUSTRALIA
lead_paragraph: Once, a list of the great red wines of the world would have begun and ended in France; five or six Bordeaux, a couple of Burgundies, maybe one from the Rhone Valley. No longer. Great red wines are made all over the place these days: Italy, Spain, California, Chile, Australia. In fact, one of the best of them all comes from Australia. It's called Grange Hermitage, it's made by Penfolds in South Australia and it's one of the most sought-after of all wines, red or white.

title: Flavors of Australia
snippet: The winemaker Russell Hearn left his native Australia in 1985, but his new label, T’jara, shows he hasn’t really left the country behind.
lead_paragraph: The winemaker Russell Hearn left his native Australia in 1985, but he hasn’t left Australia behind.

title: House Hunting in ... Australia
snippet: Perth used to be one of the lowest-priced cities in Australia but over the past decade housing prices boomed.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM TWO-BATH 1937 HOUSE IN SUBURBAN PERTH

title: Australian Encounters
snippet: In this historical novel, a British marine is inspired and troubled by clashes of culture and justice.
lead_paragraph: The Australian history that Kate Grenville learned as a schoolgirl in the 1960s was that of the explorers — “the Aboriginal people were mostly an adjunct,” she has written; “between the lines was the message that they had more or less disappeared.”

title: Australian Labyrinth
snippet: This New Zealander’s exploration of Australia, stretching from the 1600s to the present, is part history, part memoir, part fable.
lead_paragraph: The porousness of generic borders isn’t exactly news, and anyone who’s read W. G. Sebald has a vivid sense of just how much can be accomplished in that hazy ground between memoir, history and speculation. Martin Edmond sallies into that same ground with “Luca Antara” — part memoir, part fiction and part quasi-­scholarly inquiry into the history of the earliest discoverers of Australia. The author of two books of poetry and several works of nonfiction, Edmond is a New Zealander who sees Australia as both familiar and exotic. In an opening author’s note, he reminds us of Mark Twain’s remark in “Following the Equator” that Australia’s history is “so curious and strange” that it reads like “the most beautiful lies.”

title: Western Australia
snippet: Remote Western Australia is home to white sand beaches, vineyards yielding renowned wine and the endless outback.
lead_paragraph: Remote Western Australia is home to white sand beaches, vineyards yielding renowned wine and the endless outback.

title: ONE FOR AUSTRALIA
lead_paragraph: Pat Cash, in upsetting Ivan Lendl on Sunday, became the first Australian to win the Wimbledon men's singles championship since John Newcombe took his third title in 1971. Cash, the 11th men's champion from Australia, ran his country's total of men's singles titles to 20. A total of 14 Englishmen have won 34 All-England titles, while 19 men from the United States have won the crown 25 times. Among other non-English winners, four men from France won seven times, Bjorn Borg of Sweden captured five titles, Anthony Wilding of New Zealand took four and Boris Becker of West Germany won two. The Australian winners in men's singles:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bank Acquired
snippet: australia: bank acq
lead_paragraph: Britain's fourth-largest bank, HBOS, said it would buy the 43 percent of the Bank of Western Australia that it did not already own for 1.05 billion Australian dollars ($664 million) to ''maximize the value of its investment'' in the bank. HBOS purchased a stake in BankWest, which has 24.43 billion Australian dollars in assets, in 1995. Last year BankWest's profits fell 7 percent, to 212.6 million Australian dollars, because of a rise in bad business loans. HBOS said it would finance the deal with existing capital. BankWest is based in Perth. Its shares rose 19 percent on the news while shares in HBOS were flat. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: The Fiery New World of Australian Barbecue
snippet: Two Sydney restaurants, and one in Singapore, are using flames and Australian ingredients in ways that feel exciting and new.
lead_paragraph: “Is that part of the counter supposed to be on fire?” I asked the bartender, and pointed at the open kitchen of Firedoor, in Sydney, Australia. There is so much open flame on display at this restaurant, it was a little hard to tell if the small, bright flicker on one of the stainless steel counters was intentional or not.

title: Australian pique
An Australian at the Helm
snippet: IF you like Australians' openness, odds are you will enjoy Pellegrini wines.     Russell Hearn, the winemaker, is Australian, and his extroverted reds especially seem to reflect his origins. You get the impression he wishes they were all shirazes ...
lead_paragraph: IF you like Australians' openness, odds are you will enjoy Pellegrini wines.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Venture
snippet: Patrick Corp, Australia's leading port cargo handler, agrees to buy half of Richard Branson's discount carrier Virgin Blue for at least 260 million Australian dollars ($136 million); Virgin's chief executive Brett Godfrey says Virgin Blue plans to...
lead_paragraph: The Patrick Corporation, Australia's No. 1 port cargo handler, agreed to buy half of Richard Branson's discount carrier Virgin Blue for at least 260 million Australian dollars ($136 million), stepping up rivalry in the aviation market. Virgin Blue, which took 18 months to gain 15 percent of local air traffic, plans to use Patrick's partnership to help its initial share sale, planned for as early as the final quarter of 2002, said Brett Godfrey, Virgin's chief executive. Virgin Blue may bid for assets of the failed Australian carrier Ansett Holdings Ltd., he said. Virgin Blue now offers the only competition at home for Qantas Airways Ltd. after the demise last week of Ansett, the country's former No. 2 carrier.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Phone Layoffs
snippet: Australia's Cable and Wireless Optus will eliminate 560 jobs, bringing to 10 percent share of its work force laid off since Singapore Telecommunications took control of it; Vodafone Australia will lay off unspecified number of workers as it tries ...
lead_paragraph: The second- and third-largest telecommunications companies in Australia both announced layoffs and cost-cutting measures yesterday to stem losses. Cable and Wireless Optus will eliminate 560 jobs, bringing to 10 percent the share of its work force laid off since Singapore Telecommunications took control of it two months ago. Vodafone Australia said it would lay off an unspecified number of workers as it tries to cut operating costs up to 50 percent. Competition and slack demand in the industry forced several smaller companies out of business this year, including One.Tel, which was backed by the News Corporation. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Powering Australia’s Economic Surge
snippet: While other wealthy nations struggle to define their purpose, Australia has unlocked the secret to its next wave of prosperity: immigration.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — If you were designing a nation from scratch, it would look something like Australia. A Eurasian people, boring politicians, and an economy that virtually runs itself.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Growth Accelerates
snippet: Australia's economy grows at annual pace of 3.7 percent in third quarter, down from 3.8 percent in second quarter but higher than 3.4 percent that was expected by economists (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's economy grew at an annual pace of 3.7 percent in the third quarter, down from 3.8 percent in the second quarter but higher than the 3.4 percent that was expected by economists. The data confirmed Australia's place as one of the fastest-growing economies among the industrialized nations. Australia's treasurer, Peter Costello, said, however, that growth would probably slow in the fourth quarter, reflecting the effects of a prolonged drought.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Rates Lowered
snippet: Reserve Bank of Australia cuts overnight cash rate to 4.5 percent, down from 4.75 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: The Reserve Bank of Australia cut a crucial lending rate, the fifth time this year the central bank reduced interest rates. The overnight cash rate target now stands at 4.5 percent, down from 4.75 percent. Ian Macfarlane, the governor of the Reserve Bank, said global economic conditions had continued to soften in recent months. He added that the terrorist attacks in the United States would aggravate the downturn not only in Australia, but also internationally. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bid For Miner
snippet: Stock price of Australia's WMC, world's third-largest nickel producer, rises more than 3 percent on reports Alcoa might bid $5 billion for company (S)
lead_paragraph: The stock price of WMC, the world's third-largest nickel producer, rose more than 3 percent after media reports said Alcoa might bid $5 billion for the company. Alcoa already owns 60 percent of a joint venture with WMC called Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals. WMC, which is based in Melbourne and would not comment on the speculation, has embarked on an aggressive cost-cutting program and improved production at its mines.

title: A Chinese Threat to Australian Openness
snippet: Visiting students are importing a pro-Beijing approach to the university classroom that is stifling free debate.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australians are increasingly concerned about China’s growing influence in the country. Chinese money is being funneled to politicians. Beijing-run media outlets buy ads in Australian newspapers to promote the Communist Party view on local and regional issues. Chinese companies are buying Australian farms and natural resources.

title: Australia’s China Challenge
snippet: With Beijing pushing as far as it can wherever it can in the era of President Xi Jinping, Australia has become a global case study in Chinese government influence.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In a gold-curtained meeting room in Sydney, the Chinese consul general appealed to a closed-door gathering of about 100 people, all of them Australian residents and citizens of Chinese ancestry.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Directors Penalized
snippet: Three senior figures at HIH, insurer that collapsed last year amid accounting irregularities, are punished by Sydney court in civil prosecution over efforts to manipulate HIH's stock using company money; director Rodney Adler is fined $450,000 for...
lead_paragraph: Three senior figures at HIH, the insurer that collapsed last year amid accounting irregularities, were punished by a Sydney court yesterday in a civil prosecution over efforts to manipulate HIH's stock using company money. Rodney Adler, a director of HIH and prominent entrepreneur, drew the harshest penalty, fines totaling $450,000 for himself and his family's company and a 20-year ban from corporate directorships. HIH's chief executive, Ray Williams, was fined $125,000 and banned for 10 years. Dominic Fodera, financial director of HIH and a former partner at Arthur Andersen, HIH's auditor, was fined $2,500. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Australia: Stimulus Program Begins
snippet: Australia is beginning a spending program of 17 billion Australian dollars ($11.8 billion) to stimulate the economy amid the global financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Australia is beginning a spending program of 17 billion Australian dollars ($11.8 billion) to stimulate the economy amid the global financial crisis, the nation’s treasurer, Wayne Swan, left, said. The previously announced money will go to pensioners, families and first-time home buyers in addition to education, health and transport projects. The program comes after Australia’s economy expanded at its weakest rate in eight years in the third quarter.

title: 36 Hours in Melbourne, Australia
snippet: Home to street art, buzzing cafes and a cool bar scene, Australia’s second city is charged with creative energy.
lead_paragraph: The fact that Melbourne, the capital of the Australian state of Victoria, regularly appears near the top of lists ranking the world’s most livable cities says a lot about its efficiency, cleanliness and safety. What that recognition doesn’t immediately reveal is how Melbourne is now arguably the most exciting city for food Down Under — something the annual Melbourne Food and Wine Festival (melbournefoodandwine.com.au), running March 1 to 17 this year, should help highlight. But even more noteworthy is the city’s distinctive creative energy, manifested everywhere, from flourishing street art and a cool bar scene to homegrown boutiques and buzzing back-street cafes. When even cosmopolitan Sydney talks of “Melbournising,” it’s clear that something special is happening in Oz’s second city.

title: When Australia Soared on Film
snippet: The Last New Wave, the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s survey of Australian film in the 1970s, opens on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Last New Wave, the title of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s retrospective of the late-1970s resurgence of the Australian movie industry, might not sit well with everyone. What about Romania, you might ask, or Iran or South Korea?

title: Australian Merger
lead_paragraph: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group announced it would merge with National Mutual Life Association, making it the biggest financial institution in Australia. A.N.Z. said it would pay $2.5 billion for a 51 percent stake in National Mutual. The merger, scheduled for Oct. 1, must be approved by regulators and National Mutual policyholders. The merger will give the group assets of $98 billion, compared with $89 billion held by Westpac Bank, currently Australia's largest bank.

title: Ford in Australia
lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company of Australia, the country's biggest car maker and a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company of the United States, said it planned to spend $1.2 billion (Australian), or $916 million in United States currency, in the next five years to improve its products and factories. The announcement came as the company said earnings had slid to $124.1 million (Australian) in 1989 from $126 million in 1988, despite a 16 percent increase in new car sales.

title: Liquidation In Australia
lead_paragraph: The company that operates Australia's cash-short Ten television network was ordered into liquidation today.

title: Toyota Australia
lead_paragraph: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it would begin building a $355 million car plant here early next year to insure its long-term survival in Australia. The first cars are expected to be produced in 1994, said Robert Johnston, the president of Toyota Australia. The plant, to be built in Altona, a western suburb of Melbourne, will include a body shop, assembly line and high-technology paint shop. Its annual capacity is projected at 100,000 cars. Toyota, the big Japanese car maker, has been making autos in Australia for 30 years.

title: The Human Toll of Nuclear Testing
snippet: The U.S. bombings that ended World War II didn’t mark the close of atomic warfare. They were just the beginning.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. bombings that ended World War II didn’t mark the close of atomic warfare. They were just the beginning.

title: Australian Honeymoon
snippet: A seven-night honeymoon starts at $3,899 a person from Newmans Vacations.
lead_paragraph: Aseven-night honeymoon starts at $3,899 a person from Newmans Vacations. Besides air fares from the West Coast, it includes a three-night stay at Silky Oaks, a spa chalet in the Queensland rain forest, that includes a massage, daily breakfast, one dinner and a trip to the Great Barrier Reef or wilderness tour. That's followed by three nights in a private villa on Bedarra Island, off northern Queensland, and then one night at the Sydney Regent Hotel with a harborview room. Information: (888) 592-6224 or on the Web at www.newmansvacations.com .

title: Landscapes of Australia and America
snippet: William Zimmer reviews exhibit of 19th-century landscapes by American and Australian artists at Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, Conn; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ''A FASCINATING mix of the similar and dissimilar'' is how an Australian critic sums up ''New Worlds From Old,'' an exhibition of 19th-century landscape paintings that was shown first in Australia and is now at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. Indeed, the dynamic of the show is in comparisons of the development of landscape painting in Australia and America.

title: Surgeon Held for Deaths in Australia
snippet: An American surgeon was in a Portland jail on Thursday awaiting extradition proceedings over charges that he caused the deaths of three patients in Australia.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  An American surgeon was in a Portland jail on Thursday awaiting extradition proceedings over charges that he caused the deaths of three patients in Australia.

title: Australia’s Dust Bowl
snippet: An arid continent has suffered cycles of drought and dust storms for centuries. What is different now?
lead_paragraph: How do scientists know when nature's disasters are caused by global warming -- a fire, a flood and, in Australia last week, dust storms?

title: Australia: Acquisition for Gas Company
snippet: Queensland Gas, one of the companies proposing a liquefied natural gas project in northeast Australia, has agreed to buy Sunshine Gas Ltd. for at least 837 million Australian dollars ($730 million).
lead_paragraph: Queensland Gas, one of the companies proposing a liquefied natural gas project in northeast Australia, has agreed to buy Sunshine Gas Ltd. for at least 837 million Australian dollars ($730 million), increasing its reserves by almost a quarter. The offer values the company, which extracts gas from coal seam reserves, at 2.70 or 2.88 Australian dollars a share, depending on whether shareholders accept all stock or a mix of cash and stock, Queensland Gas said. That is at least 23 percent higher than Tuesday’s closing share price for Sunshine Gas, based in Brisbane. Queensland Gas, also based in Brisbane, said it would use Sunshine’s reserves primarily to meet rising local demand, as well as to bolster its liquefied natural gas project, to be built in Gladstone, on the Queensland coast. That export facility will have estimated cost of 8 billion Australian dollars.

title: Australians to Investigate Qantas Safety
snippet: Australia’s Civil Aviation Safety Authority said Sunday that it would investigate safety standards at Qantas Airways after recent episodes involving the carrier’s fleet.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia’s Civil Aviation Safety Authority said Sunday that it would investigate safety standards at Qantas Airways after recent episodes involving the carrier’s fleet.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Iraq Suspends Purchase Of Australian Wheat
snippet: Iraq has suspended the purchase of wheat from the Australian wheat export company AWB pending an Australian royal commission investigation into allegations that AWB paid more than $200 million in kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government from 1999 ...
lead_paragraph: Iraq has suspended the purchase of wheat from the Australian wheat export company AWB pending an Australian royal commission investigation into allegations that AWB paid more than $200 million in kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government from 1999 through 2003, in violation of United Nations sanctions. Iraq's move is certain to please American wheat farmers. U.S. Wheat Associates, a trade association representing American wheat growers, had urged the American-led Coalition Provisional Authority in Iraq to take similar action after Mr. Hussein was toppled in 2003, and has led an effort to have AWB investigated. The Australian trade minister, Mark Vaile, called Iraq's action "regrettable given that Australia has been a reliable supplier of high quality wheat to Iraq for many years." RAYMOND BONNER (NYT)

title: Australia: Economic Expansion Slows
snippet: Australia’s economic expansion slowed to the weakest rate in more than three years as consumers reduced spending, stoking speculation the central bank would cut interest rates again.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s economic expansion slowed to the weakest rate in more than three years as consumers reduced spending, stoking speculation the central bank would cut interest rates again. Gross domestic product rose 0.3 percent from the first quarter, when it increased a revised 0.7 percent, the Bureau of Statistics said. The economy grew 2.7 percent from a year earlier. Australia’s dollar fell to its lowest level in a year, and stocks slid. The report supported comments by Glenn Stevens, the central bank governor, who said that he had more scope to cut rates as consumer spending, business confidence and stock-market values slump. The bank reduced the overnight cash rate target on Tuesday by a quarter percentage point to 7 percent, from a 12-year high of 6.75 percent.

title: Grieving And Tired, Australian Plays On
snippet: Jason Day, who lost eight relatives when a typhoon hit the Philippines, received comforting words from fans at the World Challenge.
lead_paragraph: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — After signing for a four-over-par 76 at Sherwood Country Club on Thursday, Jason Day plunged into a funereal assembly that warmed his heart.

title: Australia: Bid for Chemical Maker
snippet: The China National Chemical Corporation, backed by the Blackstone Group, agreed to pay 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) in cash for Nufarm of Australia to form the world’s largest supplier of generic farm chemicals. The offer by China N...
lead_paragraph: The China National Chemical Corporation, backed by the Blackstone Group, agreed to pay 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) in cash for Nufarm of Australia to form the world’s largest supplier of generic farm chemicals. The offer by China National values Nufarm at 17.55 Australian dollars a share, 27 percent higher than its closing price on Oct. 30, Nufarm said. The price includes the payment of a 30-cents-a-share dividend by Nufarm, it said. Buying Nufarm gives China National entry to the $36 billion global market for herbicides and pesticides as a worldwide agricultural boom spurs acquisitions.

title: Second Cyberattack on Australian Festival
snippet: Chinese hackers were believed to have infiltrated the Melbourne International Film Festival’s Web site for the second time in a week, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Chinese hackers were believed to have infiltrated the Melbourne International Film Festival’s Web site for the second time in a week, Reuters reported, shutting down online ticket sales on Saturday apparently in protest of the planned appearance of Rebiya Kadeer, the exiled leader of the ethnic Uighur minority in China. A spokeswoman for that Australian festival told Reuters that fake online accounts had been created to reserve large numbers of tickets and foster the impression that films were sold out. On July 25 hackers posted a Chinese flag on the site and demanded an apology from festival organizers. Chinese filmmakers have also withdrawn five films from the event. Festival organizers said they were tightening security for Ms. Kadeer’s appearance on Saturday, when “The Ten Conditions of Love,” a documentary about her activism and her family, is to be screened. Ms. Kadeer is a former businesswoman whom the Chinese government has blamed for inciting violence between Muslim Uighurs and Han Chinese. She lives in exile in the United States and has denied any involvement.

title: A Guide to Australia’s Election
snippet: Election Day has arrived. Here’s what to watch.
lead_paragraph: Australians go to the polls on Saturday to choose a new government. Will Prime Minister Scott Morrison and his conservative coalition be given another three years, or will Anthony Albanese, the opposition Labor Party leader, seize a victory?

title: An Australian Entry in the Smartphone Wars
snippet: The Agora Android phone, from the Australian tech company Kogan, comes with a 2.5-inch touch screen, qwerty keyboard, 3G, GPS, a two-megapixel camera and Wi-Fi.
lead_paragraph: The number of iPhone owners is growing by the minute, and T-Mobile’s G1, well, it won’t score you any pretty points. If you really want a phone no one has seen yet, it may be time to look Down Under.

title: 100 Pilot Whales Are Rescued After Mass Stranding in Australia
snippet: Of the 160 whales stranded near the town of Dunsborough on Thursday morning, more than 100 were returned to the ocean. Twenty-nine others, however, died on the beach.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 long-finned pilot whales stranded along the shores of Western Australia on Thursday have returned to the ocean, while 29 died on the beach, wildlife officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Trade Gap Widens
snippet: Australia reports its Nov trade deficit grew to 1.14 billion Australian dollars ($656 million) from revised 957 million dollar gap in Oct (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's trade deficit grew in November to its widest in more than two years, as imports of consumer goods rose and a drought reduced the earnings from wheat, cotton and meat exports. The shortfall widened to 1.14 billion Australian dollars ($656 million) from a revised 957 million Australian dollars in October, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said. The trade gap was the widest since August 2000, when it reached 1.15 billion Australian dollars.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bank Profit Falls
snippet: Commonwealth Bank of Australia says first-half profit fell 48 percent; net income fell to 622 million Australian dollars ($368 million) in six months through Dec 31, from 1.2 billion Australian dollars year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the nation's second-largest lender, said its first-half profit fell 48 percent after cutting the value of fund management and life insurance units because of slumping stock markets. Net income fell to 622 million Australian dollars ($368 million), or 48.2 cents a share, in the six months through Dec. 31, from 1.2 billion Australian dollars, or 95 cents, a year earlier.

title: Love/Loathe Australia
snippet: Our Australia Letter readers shared what they love and loathe about their country. Ilya Milstein, an Italian-Australian artist who grew up in Melbourne, created a cityscape with some of their thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Our Australia Letter readers shared what they love and loathe about their country. Ilya Milstein, an Italian-Australian artist who grew up in Melbourne, created a cityscape with some of their thoughts.

title: AUSTRALIAN PLOY
lead_paragraph: Attending the Spring Nationals in Honolulu earlier this month meant a long journey for nearly all the participants, but that did not prove a deterrent. More than 4,000 players took part, and 47 states were represented, making the tournament the third-biggest in a series that began in 1958.

title: Shots Fired at Airport in Australia’s Capital
snippet: There were no reports of injuries, but the episode was nonetheless shocking in a country where mass and random shootings are extremely rare.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A lone gunman fired several gunshots inside Canberra Airport Sunday, prompting a rapid evacuation and grounding flights in Australia’s capital, according to witnesses and the police.

title: Reporting on Indigenous Australia
snippet: The more difficult the access to a story, the more often it is worth doing.
lead_paragraph: When I first heard about Australia’s “bush courts,” I knew they were something I wanted to report on. Makeshift courtrooms, fly-in legal services, and Australians processed through that system who neither understood English nor how the courts worked. The details shocked me.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Profit Falls At Winemaker
snippet: Southcorp, Australia's largest wine producer and exporter, reports decline of 97 percent in after-tax profit for half-year; says sales increased 2 percent, to 728 million Australian dollars ($440 million), while net profits dropped to 5.7 million ...
lead_paragraph: The country's largest wine producer and exporter, Southcorp, reported a decline of 97 percent in after-tax profit for the half-year. Sales increased 2 percent, to 728 million Australian dollars ($440 million) in the period, but costs, divestments, currency hedging, discounting and lower margins cut net profits to 5.7 million Australian dollars ($3.5 million) from 210 million Australian dollars. Southcorp shares fell 16 percent. The British beverage group Allied Domecq and the Australian brewer Fosters have been named in media and market reports as possible bidders for Southcorp, whose big brands are Penfolds, Rosemount and Lindemans. But the executive chairman, Brian Finn, said the company had not received or requested any offers. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Qantas Cuts Outlook
snippet: Australian airline Qantas cuts its profit outlook for second time in six weeks as result of impact of severe acute respiratory syndrome on travel; chief executive Geoff Dixon comments; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The Australian airline Qantas cut its profit outlook for the second time in six weeks as a result of the impact of severe acute respiratory syndrome on travel. The airline did not provide a specific figure, but it said that SARS had affected all areas of the airline. ''The outbreak of SARS, which was entirely unexpected, has compounded the difficulties facing our industry, particularly in this region,'' Geoff Dixon, the chief executive, said in a statement. As a result, the airline said it would make further staff reductions and defer delivery of new aircraft.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Gasoline Price Investigation
snippet: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission raids offices of Caltex Australia, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Exxon Mobil Corp to search for evidence of price collusion at gasoline stations across Australia; motorists' organizations complained abo...
lead_paragraph: Australia's antitrust regulator raided offices of Caltex Australia, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Mobil Corporation to search for evidence of price collusion at gasoline stations. About 90 officers raided 11 sites in Melbourne, Sydney and Newcastle on Tuesday, ''looking for documents and computer hard drives,'' said Lin Enright, a spokeswoman for the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Motorists' organizations had complained about gasoline price increases around Easter. Allan Fels, at left, the commission's chairman, said the oil companies might face fines of as much as 10 million Australian dollars, ($5.4 million) per violation.

title: Australia: Metal Recyclers to Merge
snippet: Sims Group agreed to buy Metal Management for about $1.49 billion in stock to create the world’s largest publicly traded scrap-metal recycler. Metal Management investors will get 2.05 American depositary receipts for each share, the companies said...
lead_paragraph: Sims Group agreed to buy Metal Management for about $1.49 billion in stock to create the world’s largest publicly traded scrap-metal recycler. Metal Management investors will get 2.05 American depositary receipts for each share, the companies said. Sims, based in Sydney, is paying about $57.75 a share, 18 percent more than Metal Management’s closing price on Friday. The combined company will have sales of about $6.8 billion a year, with more than 200 locations on four continents and the ability to process more than 15 million tons of metal. Sims shareholders will own about 70 percent of the new company, to be called Sims Metal Management.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Corporate Regulator Named
snippet: Graeme Samuel is named Australia's chief corporate regulator, succeeding Allan Fels; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Graeme Samuel, a former merchant banker, was named Australia's chief corporate regulator and consumer watchdog. He was confirmed for a five-year term as chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, an independent federal agency. Mr. Samuel succeeds Allan Fels, an economics professor who will return to teaching after 12 years in the position. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Australia’s Amazon Book Battle
snippet: The online retailer is moving in. Booksellers are nervous. But disrupting Australians’ reading habits might not be so easy to do.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Borders opened in 2002 across the street from Readings, Melbourne’s best-known independent bookseller, retail experts predicted catastrophe for the musty old shop competing with the shiny new chain store.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Retailer's Profit Rises
snippet: Australia's Woolworths says first-half profit rose 18 percent, to 350 million Australian dollars ($211 million), as sales rose 11 percent, to 14.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.5 billion) (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's largest retailer, Woolworths, said its first-half profit rose 18 percent, to 350 million Australian dollars ($211 million), as its sales rose 11 percent, to 14.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.5 billion). The result topped analysts' estimates, and Woolworths said it planned to buy back as much as 6 percent of its outstanding shares. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Air Alliance Rejected
snippet: World Business Briefing: Australia:
lead_paragraph: Regulators in Australia and New Zealand rejected a proposed alliance of Qantas and Air New Zealand, involving the acquisiton by Qantas of a 22 percent stake in the New Zealand airline for $300 million. The regulators said the terms of the bid would reduce flights and increase fares between the nations. Industry sources expect the airlines to make a new offer including assurances that competition on routes between Australia and New Zealand will not be reduced. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Trump Pushes Australia Toward China
snippet: This is how America’s long era of leadership in Asia comes to an end.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — The United States-Australia alliance faces a crucial test over how to deal with a powerful and increasingly assertive China. Under President Trump, it is already failing.

title: Dagginess as an Australian Asset
snippet: Two restaurants, two countries, one major difference.

title: Australia’s New Queen
snippet: Sam Kerr is the face of the World Cup. She has the weight of a nation on her shoulders. She does not seem to have noticed.
lead_paragraph: Sam Kerr’s tone barely shifted. She had not, she said, had time to think about it yet. She had put it to the back of her mind. She had other things on which to focus her attention.

title: Dagginess as an Australian Asset
snippet: Two restaurants, two countries, one major difference.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telstra Chairman Resigns
snippet: Robert C Mansfield resigns as chairman of Australia's Telstra Corp; deputy chairman John Ralph will fill in while new chairman is sought; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Robert C. Mansfield, left, has quit as chairman of the Telstra Corporation, Australia's biggest phone company, saying the ''bond of trust'' he needed to work with the board had been broken. His resignation comes two months after a magazine, The Bulletin, said the board had rejected a plan backed by Mr. Mansfield and the chief executive, Zygmunt E. Switkowski, to make a bid of 3.5 billion Australian dollars ($2.6 billion) for John Fairfax Holdings, the country's second-biggest newspaper publisher. ''It has become evident to me recently that the bond of trust necessary for the board to operate effectively has been ruptured,'' Mr. Mansfield said. The deputy chairman, John Ralph, will fill in while a new chairman is sought, Telstra said.

title: Australia’s New Queen
snippet: Sam Kerr is the face of the World Cup. She has the weight of a nation on her shoulders. She does not seem to have noticed.
lead_paragraph: Sam Kerr’s tone barely shifted. She had not, she said, had time to think about it yet. She had put it to the back of her mind. She had other things on which to focus her attention.

title: Why Australia Is Burning
snippet: As firefighters battle flames across the country, Australia’s prime minister is fighting to keep climate change out of the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Real Estate Acquisition
snippet: World Business B
lead_paragraph: Australia's largest property company, Westfield Trust, paid 247 million Australian dollars ($145.9 million) for 16.9 percent of AMP Shopping Center Trust, a move that appeared to block a hostile takeover bid of 1.32 billion Australian dollars by a rival, Centro Properties Group, for the unit, a subsidiary of the troubled financial services company, AMP. Centro made its bid last week, when it bought 19.9 percent of AMP Shopping Center, triggering a mandatory takeover offer. But Westfield Trust, a unit of the shopping center developer, Westfield Holdings, paid at least 10 percent more than Centro is offering. Centro said it would not raise its bid. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Giving Thanks in Australia
snippet: It’s an odd affair outside America, but maybe the holiday will inspire more of us to pause and appreciate the gifts we’ve been given.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving in Australia has always been an odd affair for my partly-American family. The springtime weather is all wrong for a huge harvest-season feast. Cranberries of any kind are hard to source. Curious Australian friends want to understand the story behind the holiday, when many — including my family — have taken the good from the day and rejected the origin story, which is mostly fiction.

title: Saying Goodbye to Australia
snippet: With an upcoming departure from Sydney, one Australian reporter reflects on the experience of home and the country’s culture of simple pleasures.
lead_paragraph: It was the slow pace that struck me most when I returned to my hometown, Sydney, three years ago from Washington, D.C.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecom Write-Down
snippet: Australian telephone company Telstra and Hong Kong carrier PCCW write down value of their Reach undersea cable venture by $1.55 billion because drop in prices has cut revenue; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: The Australian telephone company Telstra and the Hong Kong carrier PCCW wrote down the value of their Reach undersea cable venture by $1.55 billion because a drop in prices cut revenue. Telstra will take a $546 million charge against first-half earnings to cut the value of its Reach stake to zero. PCCW will take a charge of 8.26 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1 billion) in its 2002 earnings to reduce the value of its holding.

title: Australia, France 3 Victorious; Australia Wins Easily
World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Amcor Buys Bottler
snippet: Amcor will buy bottling assets of Schmalbach-Lubeca, owned by German insurance giant Allianz for 2.88 billion Australian dollars or $1.55 billion; purchase will make it world's largest producer of plastic soft drink bottles (S)
lead_paragraph: Amcor announced yesterday that it would buy the bottling assets of Schmalbach-Lubeca, now owned by the German insurance giant, Allianz, for 2.88 billion Australian dollars or $1.55 billion. Amcor said the purchase would make it the world's largest producer of plastic soft drink bottles. It said it would issue equity and debt to finance the deal and would exercise its option to sell its 45 percent stake in Kimberly-Clark Australia back to its American parent for $379 million. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Interest Rate Unchanged
snippet: Australia's Reserve Bank leaves its benchmark interest rate at 4.75 percent for 11th straight month; growth rate of 3 percent is strongest among developed countries and currency is at three-year high against US dollar (S)
lead_paragraph: The Reserve Bank left its benchmark interest rate at 4.75 percent for an 11th straight month. Economists had expected the action at the bank's monthly meeting because the domestic economy is strong but the global economy is unsteady. The country's growth rate of 3 percent is the strongest among developed countries and its currency is at a three-year high against the United States dollar. John Shaw (NYT)

title: South Sudanese in Australia
snippet: When an influx of South Sudanese refugees were resettled in a small Sydney suburb, Conor Ashleigh began to document how his new neighbors adjusted to life in Australia.
lead_paragraph: Conor Ashleigh grew up in Newcastle, Australia, just north of Sydney, which he described as a typical Australian suburb: not very diverse. But in 2004, the first of many South Sudanese families seeking refuge from a 22-year civil war and a floundering independence movement moved into his neighborhood.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Insurance Executive Resigns
snippet: Paul Batchelor resigns as chief executive of AMP Ltd after bailout of its British unit, Pearl, and regulatory inquiry send its shares falling 15 percent in three days; chief operating officer Andrew Mohl is named acting chief executive (S)
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of AMP Ltd., Paul Batchelor, resigned after a bailout of its British unit, Pearl, and a regulatory inquiry sent its shares falling 15 percent in three days. AMP is Australia's largest life insurer. Mr. Batchelor joined two other executives in leaving the company. The chief financial officer, Marc de Cure, resigned earlier this month and the chairman, Stan Wallis, will leave in six months. Andrew Mohl, the chief operating officer, was named acting chief executive.

title: Australia’s Gulag Archipelago
snippet: The conditions of refugee detention centers on remote islands are a national disgrace. But can shame force reform?
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In Dante’s view, the unfortunate souls who dwell in purgatory may suffer excruciating pain, but the promise of their final destination is clear: paradise. Those who languish on the remote, tiny islands — Manus and Nauru — that host Australia’s offshore immigration detention centers are not so lucky.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Australia: Normandy Still Favors Newmont
snippet: Normandy Mining continues to favor takeover bid from Newmont Mining over competing bid from AngloGold (S)
lead_paragraph: Pursued by two suitors, Normandy Mining continued to back the takeover bid it received from Newmont Mining, which trumped a bid from AngloGold. A report by Grant Samuel & Associates determined that the bid by AngloGold, which values Normandy at 1.46 Australian dollars a share (76 cents), ''is neither fair nor reasonable,'' Normandy told the Australian Stock Exchange. But Bobby Godsell, AngloGold's chief executive, is asserting that since last week, when Newmont offered 1.70 Australian dollars a share, a drop in its stock price has lowered the value of its offer. The difference between the bids now is marginal, Mr. Godsell said, adding that Normandy's response ''is potentially misleading'' for its shareholders.'' Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Australia vs. Canada
snippet: This week’s newsletter features a contest, with international bragging rights as the prize.
lead_paragraph: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

title: Australia’s New Creative Commune
snippet: Three storefronts in Sydney, all in a former canning factory, have set out to celebrate the best of the country’s agriculture, craftsmanship and furniture design.
lead_paragraph: A factory space on Sydney’s fringe has become a surprising center for forward-thinking local artisans.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Miner Rejects Bid
snippet: AurionGold Ltd rejects $1.1 billion takeover offer from Placer Dome Inc; weighs rival bids (S)
lead_paragraph: AurionGold Ltd. rejected a $1.1 billion takeover offer from Placer Dome Inc. of Canada and said it was considering rival bids. AurionGold, which opened its books to rival suitors last month, said it could not give information about the probability of another bid. Placer's offer of 17.5 shares for every 100 AurionGold shares is worth about 3.86 Australian dollars ($3.78) a share, based on the closing price Tuesday of Placer's Canadian stock. If Placer's bid succeeds, AurionGold shareholders will receive lower dividends and also be exposed to higher risk through Placer operations in South Africa, AurionGold said. Placer, which is based in Toronto, responded to the rejection by saying that it felt its offer was fair. Auriongold, based in Sydney, is the biggest gold miner in Australia.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Shuts Down
snippet: Ansett Australia, only national competitor to Qantas, says it will immediately suspend all flights; airline, subsidiary of Air New Zealand, has filed for equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)
lead_paragraph: Ansett Australia, the only national competitor to Qantas, said early on Friday that it would immediately suspend all flights. The airline, a subsidiary of Air New Zealand, filed for the equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection earlier this week and is being run by administrators from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who said the daily losses were so high and the finances so weak that Ansett had no choice but to stop flying. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Insurance Units Sold
snippet: AMP Ltd sells its Australian general insurance division to Suncorp-Metway Ltd; sells its British general insurance business to Church Insurance, unit of Credit Suisse First Boston (S)
lead_paragraph: AMP Ltd. sold its insurance units in Australia and Britain as it turned its focus to fund management. Suncorp-Metway Ltd., Queensland's biggest car and home insurer, will buy AMP's Australian general insurance unit for 1.24 billion Australian dollars ($650 million) to expand into the nation's most populous state. AMP will also sell its British general insurance business for 211 million Australian dollars to Churchill Insurance, a unit of Credit Suisse First Boston, after taking out 87 million Australian dollars in capital.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bid For Hardware Retailer
snippet: Wesfarmers Ltd, Australian conglomerate that owns Bunnings hardware and home center chain, offers $1.14 billion in cash and stock for Howard Smith Ltd, owner of rival BBC Hardware chain (S)
lead_paragraph: Wesfarmers Ltd., the Australian conglomerate that owns the Bunnings hardware and home center chain, offered $1.14 billion in cash and stock for Howard Smith Ltd., owner of the rival BBC Hardware chain. The two retail units have 13 percent of the Australian market; their parents also have distribution and industrial products units that would fit together well, analysts said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Energy Acquisition Considered
snippet: Australia's Woodside Petroleum wants to buy oil and gas exploration and production assets of Germany's Veba Oil and Gas; details undisclosed, but media reports in Australia suggest assets could be worth $2 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: Woodside Petroleum of Australia wants to buy the oil and gas exploration and production assets of the German energy company Veba Oil and Gas, the company told the Australian Stock Exchange. Woodside would not disclose details, but media reports in Australia suggest the assets could be worth $2 billion. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecom Profit Surges
snippet: Australia's Cable and Wireless Optus posts stronger-than-expected profit of 423.8 million Australian dollars ($220.3 million) for fiscal year ended March 31, rise of 60 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's second-largest wireless telecommunications company, Cable and Wireless Optus, posted a stronger-than-expected profit of 423.8 million Australian dollars ($220.3 million) for the fiscal year ended March 31, a rise of 60 percent. The sale of wireless transmission towers bolstered earnings by 88 million Australian dollars ($45.8 million).

title: Riding Perseverance to Finals in Australia
snippet: Serena Williams reaching a Grand Slam final, and winning in convincing fashion, without being in peak condition is a testimony to her dominance.
lead_paragraph: For Asha Price, watching from afar as her youngest sister made a remarkable run at the Australian Open has been a nerve-racking, eye-opening experience.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Railroad Assets Sold
snippet: Joint $477 million bid by Australia's Lang Corp and Toll Holdings is chosen by Australian government for package of railroad assets it is privatizing; included in sale are National Rail and FreightCorp (S)
lead_paragraph: A joint $477 million bid by two Australian transportation companies, the Lang Corporation and Toll Holdings, was chosen by the Australian government for a package of railroad assets it is privatizing. Included in the sale are the country's two largest freight carriers, National Rail, mainly an industrial freight hauler, and FreightCorp, which mainly hauls commodities like grain and ore. Two American companies, RailAmerica of Boca Raton, Fla., and Genesee & Wyoming of Greenwich, Conn., were unsuccessful bidders; each already has rail interests in Australia. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Jets Fly Again
snippet: Regulators say Ansett Australia can resume flying all but two of its 767 jets, which were grounded in April because of safety problems and lax maintenance; other two 767's were already scheduled for overhauls (S)
lead_paragraph: Regulators said Ansett Australia could resume flying all but two of its 767 jets, which were grounded last month because of safety problems and lax maintenance. The other two 767's had already been scheduled for overhauls, a spokesman said. Ansett is owned by Air New Zealand and its rival, Qantas. Those airlines have both warned of falling profits because of high fuel costs, currency weakness and slowing demand. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Shares Fall
snippet: Analysts reduce earnings forecasts for Australia's Qantas Airways, causing 11 percent decline in its share price in two days' trading; airline announced 15 percent profit drop recently and said that earnings may not revive in 2001 (S)
lead_paragraph: Qantas Airways shares posted their biggest two-day decline in nearly five months, falling 11 percent, after analysts reduced their earnings forecasts following a 15 percent drop in second-half profit. Qantas's shares fell 15 cents, or 5 percent, to 2.87 Australian dollars, the lowest close since April 30 and extending yesterday's 6.5 percent drop. Qantas, based in Sydney, said Thursday that net income in the six months ended June 30 fell to 153 million Australian dollars ($81 million) from the year-earlier 180 million Australian dollars. Qantas said earnings might not revive this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Banking Profits Rise
snippet: Profits at Westpac Banking Corp, Australia, for six months ended March 31, 2001, rise 13 percent, to $480 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Profit at the Westpac Banking Corporation for the six months ended March 31 rose 13 percent to 924 million Australian dollars ($480 million) on increased volume of mortgage, credit card and business lending. Expenses were flat, but bad debt nearly tripled to 176 million Australian dollars ($91.4 million) from the period last year, a sign that economic sluggishness in the second half will probably retard growth, the bank said, echoing a warning from a major rival, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, earlier this week. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Takeover Cleared
snippet: Australian antitrust regulators approve Qantas Airways' takeover of bankrupt Impulse Airlines; Air New Zealand may challenge deal (S)
lead_paragraph: Antitrust regulators, who have rejected previous airline mergers, gave Qantas Airways, the country's largest airline, permission to take over the operations of a bankrupt discount competitor, Impulse Airlines, on condition that Qantas ease its rivals' access to takeoff and landing slots during peak hours in Sydney. Air New Zealand, owner of Qantas's largest competitor, Ansett Australia, may challenge the deal anyway, its chief executive, Gary Toomey, said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Surfer, Environmentalist, Novelist. Australia’s Living Legend.
snippet: In “The Shepherd’s Hut,” Tim Winton finds poetry and beauty in the country’s interior saltlands and in a young teenager hardened by life.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In the remote Western Australian fishing town he calls home, Tim Winton, one of this country’s most talented writers, says many residents for years assumed he was selling weed.

title: World Business Briefing  Australia: Australia: Lamb Trade Dispute
snippet: World Trade Organization rebuffs appeal by US to earlier ruling voiding its restrictions against imports of Australian and New Zealand lamb (S)
lead_paragraph: The World Trade Organization rebuffed an appeal by the United States to an earlier ruling voiding its restrictions against imports of Australian and New Zealand lamb. A trade organization dispute panel found in December that tariffs imposed by the United States on lamb imports in 1999 violated free trade regulations. The Clinton administration had taken the action after the International Trade Commission found that the imports could harm American producers. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Billiton's Profit Down
snippet: BHP Billiton reports 33 percent decline in net earnings for third fiscal quarter ended March 31; profit fell to $406 million from $604 million; revenue slipped 8 percent, to $4.3 billion; chief executive Paul M Anderson comments (S)
lead_paragraph: BHP Billiton, the international mining, energy and steel group, reported a 33 percent decline in net earnings for its third fiscal quarter, and cautioned that it still sees little evidence of stronger demand for many of its products. Citing cutbacks in base metal production, lower petroleum prices and difficult conditions in steel markets, the group, which is based in Melbourne, Australia, said that profit attributable to common shareholders fell to $406 million from $604 million a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended March 31, slipped 8 percent, to $4.3 billion. Paul M. Anderson, the chief executive, said that high inventory levels, slack demand and lackluster commodity prices, would continue to hurt the company's earnings. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Steel Strike Ends
snippet: BHP Billiton Ltd says 24-hour strike at its Western Port factory in Australia ends, allowing its steel unit to resume supplies to customers including automakers Toyota, Ford Motor and Mitsubishi; strike threatened to stop production at Australia's...
lead_paragraph: BHP Billiton Ltd. said a 24-day strike at its Western Port factory ended, allowing its steel unit to resume supplies to customers including the automakers, Toyota, Ford Motor and Mitsubishi. The strike had curbed steel output at the BHP Steel plant and threatened to stop production at Australia's four biggest automakers. BHP Steel said it and the three unions involved reached a labor agreement without providing further details. BHP employs 1,380 people at its Western Port plant.

title: Review: Momofuku Seiobo in Sydney, Australia
snippet: Paul Carmichael, the chef, delivers a profoundly pleasurable experience at the Sydney location of David Chang‘s restaurant group.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — As a teenager in St. James Parish, Barbados, Paul Carmichael spent his free time writing letters to New York City restaurants. He had been dreaming of a cooking career in America ever since a home economics teacher, sensing talent, suggested he consider attending the Culinary Institute of America. At 15, Mr. Carmichael sent away for a Zagat Guide and began writing to the top-rated restaurants, asking for work. (Lespinasse was the only one to reply.)

title: Players to Watch at the Australian Open
snippet: Grigor Dimitrov, Karolina Pliskova and Johanna Konta are on a roll heading into the tennis season’s first Grand Slam tournament.
lead_paragraph: The Australian Open, the first Grand Slam tennis tournament of the year, begins on Monday in Melbourne. While the spotlight may be on the return of Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams, and the rivalry between Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, other players have the potential to make a splash over the next two weeks.

title: Australia’s Little Guantánamos
snippet: The international community has been critical of Canberra’s decision to close its borders to travelers from Ebola-affected nations — but it’s only the most recent debacle in a series of anti-immigration policy moves.
lead_paragraph: “Australia has temporarily closed its border to people from Ebola-affected West African nations,” reports Dan Harrison for The Sydney Morning Herald — an effort he says is meant to bolster the nation’s “defenses against the virus.”

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Westpac Profit Jumps
snippet: Growth in home loans and credit card lending contributes to rise in 2001 earnings for Westpac Banking, one of Australia's largest banks; net profit rises 11 percent to 1.90 billion Australian dollars; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: Growth in home loans and credit card lending contributed to a rise in 2001 earnings for Westpac Banking, one of Australia's largest banks. Net profit rose 11 percent to 1.90 billion Australian dollars ($964 million) for the year ended Sept. 30. Westpac lent 14 percent more to homebuyers in the most recent year, aided by five interest rate cuts from Australia's central bank in 2001 and a government bonus for first-time homebuyers. Credit card loans rose 20 percent. Bad debt more than doubled, however, and totaled 433 million Australian dollars ($219 million). The bank's chief executive, David Morgan, predicted a double-digit increase in per-share earnings growth in 2002. The bank's stock price closed at 14.92 Australian dollars ($7.57), just below a record high. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Australian Cafes Arrive in New York
snippet: Cafes you’d find in Melbourne are proliferating in New York, serving simple, fresh, satisfying food.
lead_paragraph: New York is a city of immigrants and their unofficial embassies offering a taste of home: the French bistro, the English pub, the California juice bar.

title: Australian Zucchini Slice
lead_paragraph: A beloved Australian staple, a zucchini slice is an eggy, frittatalike lunchbox staple that’s baked until it’s firm enough to slice and eat out of hand. Most versions include bacon, but in his book, “Snacks for Dinner” (Harper Wave, 2022), Lukas Volger substitutes a combination of olives and pickled peppers for a deeply salty bite without any meat. You can serve this hot, warm or at room temperature. Or make it a day or two ahead, store it covered in the fridge, then let it come to room temperature before serving so the texture is supple and soft.

title: Cahill Scores … for Australia
snippet: Tim Cahill and Brett Holman scored goals in the second half as Australia salvaged a 2-2 tie Tuesday against Oman in an Asia World Cup qualifying match.
lead_paragraph: In his 15-game career (so far) in Major League Soccer, Tim Cahill has scored only one goal.

title: Australia Warns on Budget
snippet: Australia can expect a “tough budget” as natural disasters, slower consumer spending and a strong currency take their toll on the nation’s economy, the Australian finance minister said.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Australia can expect a “tough budget” this year as natural disasters, slower consumer spending and a strong currency take their toll on the nation’s economy, the Australian finance minister, Penny Wong, said Sunday.

title: The Baked Pleasures of Australia Delivered
snippet: Bourke Street Bakery in Manhattan has added savory pies to its pickup and delivery menu.
lead_paragraph: Bourke Street Bakery, the New York branch of a family-run group of bakeries in Sydney, Australia, is open for pickup, as well as delivery to all five boroughs, nearby suburbs, and, weekly, to the Hamptons. Along with its original sourdough breads and well-burnished croissants and pastries, the bakery has added a new line of individual Aussie-style savory pies and filled pastry rolls ($15 to $18 for two). Among them are flaky chicken curry, ratatouille and beef pies, and delicious lamb rolls seasoned with harissa, to serve whole or to slice as hors d’oeuvres. The pies and rolls are sold frozen for home baking. The bakery also offers grocery staples, including bread and pastry flours, and boxes of local produce.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telephone Profit Up
snippet: Australia's Telstra Corp says full-year net income increased 10 percent, to 4.06 billion Australian dollars ($2.15 billion); sales rose 12 percent, to 23.1 billion Australian dollars ($12.25 billion); company says results will be flat for next six...
lead_paragraph: A leading Australian telephone company, the Telstra Corporation, said full-year profit from operations rose 4.6 percent but sales growth was likely to slow as competition intensified. Net income increased 10 percent, to 4.06 billion Australian dollars ($2.15 billion), from 3.7 billion ($1.96 billion) a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, the company's income rose to 3.71 billion Australian dollars, from 3.54 billion Australian dollars. Sales in the year, which ended June 30, rose 12 percent, to 23.1 billion Australian dollars ($12.25 billion). But Telstra's chairman, Ziggy Switkowski, said results would be flat for the next six months as competition increased from Cable and Wireless Optus Ltd. and the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand.

title: Australia Stays In Contention
snippet: Australia beats Zimbabwe by 44 runs in World Cup Super Six cricket match (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia beat Zimbabwe by 44 runs in a World Cup Super Six match at Lord's to stay in contention for a place in the semifinals.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Phone Company Slowdown
snippet: Australia's Telstra Corp cuts its forecast of profit growth for year in half, citing drop in market share and price cuts; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: The Telstra Corporation, Australia's biggest phone company, cut its forecast of profit growth for the year in half, citing a drop in market share and price cuts. The company's stock fell 9 percent, the largest decline since it began trading in 1997. The company expects pretax profit to increase 5 percent in the year ending June 30, compared with a March forecast of 10 percent growth. It forecast fiscal second-half pretax profit to be little changed from a year ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Media Bid Likely
snippet: Ireland's Independent News and Media is expected to revive its attempt to buy Fairfax, Australia's main newspaper group, once changes in Australia's regulations on foreign ownership of media companies are completed; any new attempt would go throug...
lead_paragraph: The Irish media conglomerate Independent News and Media is expected to revive its attempt to buy Fairfax, Australia's main newspaper group, once changes to Australia's regulations on foreign ownership of media companies are completed. A group led by Independent failed in an earlier bid for Fairfax, which has a market capitalization of 3 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion). Any new attempt would go through Independent's 41 percent stake in APN News and Media or its Wilson & Horton subsidiary.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Wireless Job Cuts
snippet: Vodafone Australia will lay off 12 percent of its work force, about 365 people (S)
lead_paragraph: Vodafone Australia, the country's third-largest telecommunications company, will lay off 12 percent of its work force, about 365 people, according to the managing director, John Rohan. The cutbacks are a response to intense competition in the domestic market, which is crowded by six carriers, and slowing customer growth. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Horse Betting Surges
lead_paragraph: Despite global economic uncertainty, bets flowed into gambling companies nationwide for the 2001 Melbourne Cup horse race, which is celebrated with a state holiday in Victoria and afternoons off by many Australians in the rest of the country. TAB Ltd. took in record bets worth 43 million Australian dollars, or $21.9 million, an increase of 4.6 percent from last year, according to a spokesman, Peter Fletcher. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Trebelhorn to Australia
lead_paragraph: TOM TREBELHORN, the Cubs' bench coach, has signed a one-year contract to manage the Perth Heat in the 1993-94 Australian Baseball League season.

title: Australia: The Lucky Country
snippet: Help us examine and explore the diverse and dynamic country that’s also a continent.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to an experiment in journalism and community — a newsletter that will help shape The New York Times’ expansion in Australia. Follow along by signing up to receive it by email, and tell us what you think at nytaustralia@nytimes.com.

title: In Australia, Diving Right Into Summer
snippet: With just a few stops left on a yearlong trip, the 52 Places Traveler reveled in the sunny days in Perth and the Northern Rivers region, but there were ominous signs as well.
lead_paragraph: Our columnist, Sebastian Modak, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2019 list. His stops in Australia were his 45th and 46th locations, following a visit to Danang, in Vietnam.

title: United States to Australia: Get Lost
snippet: It is grotesque for Trump to dismiss Australia’s stranded refugees as the next “Boston bombers.”
lead_paragraph: Let’s imagine for a moment Rex Tillerson, the newly installed secretary of state, awakening to this tweet from President Trump about an important American ally:

title: Swimming With the Whales in Australia
snippet: Sunreef in Australia is offering a trip in which participants swim with humpback whales.
lead_paragraph: As swimming with dolphins, sharks and even whale sharks becomes an increasingly common tourist attraction, Australia’s Sunreef dive company is thinking bigger – 80,000 pounds bigger, to be exact.

title: Bushire blazes in Australia
snippet: Australian authorities urge residents in parts of the Blue Mountains region to consider evacuation as a bushfire is burning out of control. Rough cut, no reporter narration.

title: A Shot to Remember for Australia
snippet: Belinda Snell of Australia hit a 50-foot shot to send a game into overtime.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – With Australia trailing late in women’s basketball against France on Monday, Belinda Snell took an outlet pass from a teammate who had rebounded a missed free throw. Snell turned up court, took several quick steps and launched a shot, which looked almost like a chest pass, from more than 50 feet away behind the half-court line.

title: Can Australia Regulate Intra-Office Sex?

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australian politics these days feels like a story in People magazine. Political journalism, indeed Parliament itself, has been reduced to a forum for rumors about sex.

title: Investment in Australia
lead_paragraph: Australia was the third-largest recipient of Japanese investment, after the United States and Britain, in the last year, with Australia's auto industry attracting most of the cash, according to figures released last week. The Australia-Japan Economic Institute said Japanese investors put $3.67 billion into Australia, a 14 percent drop from $4.26 billion in the previous year, when investment was unusually high because of a boom in real estate and financial services.

title: A Match Made in Australia
snippet: The tasting panel found that Australian cabernet sauvignon-shiraz blends are juicy wines that may offer a lot of pleasure but have little character or individuality.
lead_paragraph: YOU have to hand it to the Australians. By virtue of their geographical isolation, they were liberated from the ironclad wine rules of the Old World. Unlike the Americans, who have largely operated within the confines of European winemaking custom and tradition (though you can't always tell that from what's in the bottle), the Australians have freely tossed aside convention.

title: The Far Out Freestyle Fashion of Byron Bay, Australia
snippet: Playful looks abound in this beach community where the waves become a runway — hiding out as far east as you can go in Australia.
lead_paragraph: When dressing, comfort is always my top priority. It’s got to be effortless, ready to go. I'm not into buying the newest, latest and greatest — every now and then I’ll buy a staple piece. I love my bikinis to have a bit more coverage. This one is from a local designer, Saint Helena, and I love them because they are feminine and offer that coverage. I don’t want to be coming off a wave and worrying about where my bottoms and tops are. The girls surfing here at The Pass are pretty stylish. The wave can be a bit of a runway, there are lots of girls in high cut bikinis and jewelry. I’m not into it as much but I can appreciate the beauty of it. It’s fun. There are so many female surfers here, it is a female-dominated line up now, hence why I think fashion and surfing is popular here. The waves are relaxed and mellow, everyone is happy to share. Party waves!

title: Pope arrives in Australia

And a day earlier, Serena Williams won her fifth Australian Open championship in a three set thriller over Justine Henin, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2.

title: Architect Embraces Indigenous Worldview in Australian Designs

lead_paragraph: Jefa Greenaway will never forget the first time he heard his father’s voice. It was in 2017, when he was watching a documentary about Indigenous Australians’ fight to be recognized in the country’s Constitution.

title: Looking Toward a New Era of Australian Cuisine
snippet: After two years of exploring the country’s food scene, our critic wonders what will increase its mark on the world.
lead_paragraph: What is Australian food? It’s a question that sends me into fits of frustrated rage, as if there could be one simple explanation, one way to distill the taste and creativity and history of a country as large and diverse as Australia. But it is also the line of inquiry that has been the foundation of my assignment for the past two years, as critic and columnist for The New York Times in Australia: to explore and explain the food and restaurants for a global readership.

title: Australian Open
lead_paragraph: At the Australian Open, the three top seeded players in both the men's and women's singles draws advanced to the round of 16 in Melbourne. Stefan Edberg, seeded first, needed nearly three hours to beat a rejuvenated Pat Cash in four sets, to join Boris Becker (No. 2) and Ivan Lendl (No. 3). In the surprise of the day, Mats Wilander upset Brad Gilbert and will play Jaime Yzaga of Peru in the fourth round.

title: Draw in Australia
lead_paragraph: The defending champions, Mats Wilander and Steffi Graf, were matched against relatively easy first-round opponents yesterday for the $1.5 million Australian Open Championships, the year's first Grand Slam tournament. Wilander, ranked No. 1 in the world and seeded first, will open against a fellow Swede, Tobias Svantesson, who is ranked 95th in the world.

title: Webber and Australian drivers
lead_paragraph: Drivers always face more pressure at their home races, but today in Melbourne, as the teams prepared for the Australian Grand Prix on Sunday, Mark Webber, an Australian driver, said something a little surprising and perhaps revealing, for one of the most intelligent, articulate and fastest drivers.

title: Australian Bidding War
lead_paragraph: The Marmon Group of Chicago raised its bid yesterday for Atlas Steels Ltd. of Australia, topping an offer from the Australian appliance and building materials company Email Ltd. Marmon raised its offer to 1.75 Australian dollars a share from 1.62; Email's latest bid was 1.70. The latest Marmon bid values Atlas at 126 million Australian dollars, or $95 million. Atlas Steels advised shareholders to stand pat. The company produces stainless steel, steel alloy wire and bars and distributes machine tools in Australia and New Zealand. Marmon, controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, is a diversified manufacturing and services company. (Bloomberg Business News)

''We didn't just want to take from the city of Newport, we wanted to give something in return,'' said Daniel Wilkins, a syndicate spokesman who confirmed the gift to the Dr. Martin Luther King Center of Newport.

Somehow we manage to cram into it a microwave, a radio, a fishbowl (containing Stripe, the indomitable diamond tetra), six salt shakers, about 72 bottles of extra-virgin olive oil, my fifth of Ardbeg, a toolbox and other assorted paraphernalia of family living. As a storage unit, the kitchen is great. For cooking, forget about it.

title: While Australia burns
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA — This summer, Australia feels like a war zone. Cities and towns across the country are enveloped in a perpetual smoke haze, and the braying of fire sirens is as commonplace as birdsong. Every evening television commentators deliver grim-faced reports from the front lines.

title: Australia’s Bohemian Heart
snippet: With a bohemian heritage going back to the 1920s, Potts Point is Sydney’s answer to Paris’s Left Bank or London’s Notting Hill.
lead_paragraph: WITH a bohemian heritage going back to the 1920s, Potts Point is Sydney's answer to Paris's Left Bank or London's Notting Hill — coffee shops, galleries, bookshops — though much smaller in area. At one end is Darlinghurst Road, lined with tattoo parlors, adult book shops, massage parlors, strip joints — an area popularly called Kings Cross. At the El Alamein Fountain, erected in 1961, the street curves left, becoming Macleay Street, which is the heart of Potts Point and where seedy gives way to sophistication.

title: Australian Marsupials
lead_paragraph: The remarkable photography that distinguishes public broadcasting's nature shows, intruding into every animal lair and hideout, is present in abundance in ''The Nature of Australia,'' six one-hour documentaries that begin Sunday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Burgers, the Australian Way
snippet: It's an Australian specialty, and a riot of flavors: a burger with pickled beets, a grilled pineapple ring, chili mayo and an egg fried sunny-side up on top.
lead_paragraph: I am burger lover, so when I met the members of the BoTM (Burger of the Month) club a week ago -- I was putting together the multimedia that appeared online with Jodi Rudoren's article -- we talked burgers for a few minutes as they were leaving. I suspect that a lot of people give them suggestions about burgers to try, and I did too. My favorite burger in New York City, I told them, is at Diner in Brooklyn, a restaurant in an old dining car that sits right near the Williamsburg Bridge. It's a good size, salty and juicy with a nice crust, and when you ask the kitchen to cook it medium-rare, it's a true, red medium-rare.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Government To Sell Phone Stake
lead_paragraph: The Australian government has decided, in principle, to sell its 50.1 percent stake in Telstra, the national telephone network. The government said it would invest an additional 180 million Australian dollars in Telstra's Internet and cellphone services in rural areas to improve the company's commercial value, and began the legislative process but gave no sale date. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Australia: Muslims Rein in a Cleric
snippet: With its largely homogeneous population -- 92 percent Caucasian; 65 percent Christian; fewer Muslims than Buddhists -- Australia would seem an unlikely place for Islamic extremists. But after the London bombings, Australia's prime minister, John H...
lead_paragraph: With its largely homogeneous population -- 92 percent Caucasian; 65 percent Christian; fewer Muslims than Buddhists -- Australia would seem an unlikely place for Islamic extremists. But after the London bombings, Australia's prime minister, John Howard, has joined Britain in suggesting that new laws might be needed to deal with Islamic extremists, including deportation of clerics who preach violence.

title: Wine : The Australian powerhouse

lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Australia's wine exports were a mere drop in the ocean of European wine: 8.4 million liters, only 3 percent of the country's total production. Today, 51 percent of Australia's wine is exported around the world and the country is the sixth largest wine producer in the world.

title: Australian Floral Designs That, at Long Last, Embrace Australian Flora
snippet: In a land where unique species thrive, local florists are developing a gloriously twisted aesthetic all their own.
lead_paragraph: For a floral designer, Australia’s geographic isolation is a complicated legacy. The country’s native plants, like its fauna, are unique in their often outlandish beauty but, traditionally, arrangements here have tended toward the staid and vasebound, reflecting European cultures that shaped the continent’s contemporary identity. Floristry has been largely influenced by old-school British style, with roses, carnations and tulips flown in from Holland.
