lead_paragraph: Virgin Blue Airlines, Australia's second-largest airline, may buy as many as 50 aircraft from the Boeing Company in a purchase worth 5.4 billion Australian dollars ($3.1 billion).

title: Australia Has a Serious Gambling Problem
snippet: Can anything be done to rein in an industry that sucks millions of dollars out of Australians’ pockets?
lead_paragraph: Australia tops its fair share of lists, including hosting the deadliest animals on earth and, perhaps paradoxically, some of the world’s most livable cities. But the country also tops the charts on an indicator that is far more insidious: gambling losses. Last year, Australians lost $17.5 billion, or about $949 per adult. These per capita losses are among the highest in the world.

title: The Price of Australia’s Real Estate Boom

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — One hundred twenty-five years ago, the suburb of Balmain, which juts into Sydney Harbor, represented the aspirations of a young Australia: a society that wanted to be free of the class structure of its mother nation, Britain, with a safety net that would make it one of the most egalitarian countries on earth.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bank Declines Offer For Branches
snippet: National Australia Bank declines bid from rival, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, to buy 56 regional bank branches being closed by National Australia to cut costs (S)
lead_paragraph: National Australia Bank, the country's biggest lender, has declined a bid from a rival, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, to buy 56 regional bank branches being closed by National Australia to cut costs. National Australia, which is based in Melbourne, said the offer, which included branch buildings, staff and customers, was ''unrealistic.''

title: Starting Over in Australia
lead_paragraph: Philip Bertino, 40, is fed up with crime in America and is disgusted by what he sees as a plummeting standard of living. Instaead of complaining, he's moving to Australia with his wife, Jeanette, 41, and their 3-year-old son, Philip Louis. In Australia, he says, his family will find a better life, a place where hiking or surfing is more important than cable TV, where families still gather for big Sunday dinners, where schools are good and where the crime rate is low.

At least three prime ministers from the last decade have had their tenure buried there: John Howard, Kevin Rudd and Julia Gillard all lost their jobs, at least in part, for trying and failing to deliver polices to combat climate change.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Higher Bid For Gold Miner

lead_paragraph: AngloGold added a cash component to its initial stock-based takeover offer for Normandy Mining Ltd., Australia's largest gold producer, lifting the price by $231 million and topping the offer of the Newmont Mining Corporation. AngloGold said it identified an additional $15 million a year in savings it could reap by acquiring Normandy. The revised $1.9 billion bid comes after AngloGold's proposal won approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board of Australia. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: A U.S. Sportswriter’s ‘Glimpse of the Future’ in Near-Normal Australia
snippet: He was curious to know how it felt to cover a global event that is giving us a glimpse into a post-pandemic world.
lead_paragraph: For the many Australians who have spent the past year at home, surrounded by oceans and slammed-shut borders, the pandemic hasn’t exactly been a pleasant experience. But it is a world away from the crisis in the United States, where more than 3,000 people are still dying each day and life remains far from normal.

title: Australian Recovery
lead_paragraph: Australia's economy is on the threshold of recovery after two years with a deteriorating balance of payments, pressure on the Australian dollar and high interest rates, an economic forecasting company, BIS-Shrapnel Pty. Ltd., said today. Growth in the real gross domestic product should recover to 3.9 percent in the 1987-88 fiscal year, from an expected 1.4 percent in the year ending June 30, and compared with 3.6 percent in 1985-86, the private firm said. The recovery will be led by a moderate rally in consumer demand, with a 2.8 percent rise in exports and a further decline in imports, it said.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Wine Maker To Miss Dividend
snippet: Australia's largest wine maker, Southcorp, will miss dividend for first time; grapy (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's largest wine producer and exporter, Southcorp, will miss a dividend for the first time. After several recent profit warnings, the chairman, Brian Finn, told shareholders on Wednesday that with no recovery from a 97 percent decline in first-half profit it would be impractical to pay a final 2002-2003 dividend. Analysts expect a loss for the year of 12.8 million Australian dollars. The company, whose main brands are Penfolds, Lindemans and Rosemount, has admitted marketing errors in Britain, once its biggest buyer, as well as excessive promotional costs. Its market valuation has dropped 80 percent in 18 months and 40 percent in the last six months to 2.1 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion) currently.

title: Navigating a Virtual Australia in Postapocalyptic Ruins

lead_paragraph: The language barrier is just one of the obstacles that players will face in Broken Roads, a postapocalyptic role-playing game filled with thorny moral choices. With a distinctive nasal twang, the locals pepper their conversations with “crikey,” “sprog,” “yobbo,” “tinny,” “chunder,” “togs” and “hard yakka.” Early in the game, a cocky mercenary is called “a legend in his own lunchbox.”

title: Why Isn’t Blackface Taboo for Australians?

title: Australia Shoe Offering
snippet: Venator Group is selling shares of its Colorado Group unit in Australia to public so it can focus on its Foot Locker, Champs and other chains (S)
lead_paragraph: The Venator Group, the biggest United States athletic shoe retailer, is selling shares of its Colorado Group unit in Australia to the public so that it can focus on its Foot Locker, Champs and other chains. Venator, formerly the Woolworth Corportation, expects to raise about $75 million from the offering. The Colorado Group is Australia's largest specialty footwear retailer, with more than 300 stores.

title: Australians to Honor Winners
snippet: Australia announces that likeness of Australians winning gold medal at Sydney Games will appear on postage stamps throughout nation (S)
lead_paragraph: Within hours of receiving Olympic gold medals, the likenesses of victorious Australians will appear on postage stamps throughout Australia.

title: Afghans Are Mistreated in Australia

lead_paragraph: The centennial of Australia's nationhood this year is an occasion not only to celebrate its achievements but also to give thought to those areas where the record is blemished. One such area concerns the mandatory detention of people who arrive without permission in the country.

title: Threats in Australia's Neighborhood
snippet: Beneath Australia's characteristically optimistic exterior is a deep sense of insecurity. For the first time since the Vietnam War, defense concerns are intruding onto the domestic political agenda..Australians have lately become aware of the secu...
lead_paragraph: Beneath Australia's characteristically optimistic exterior is a deep sense of insecurity. For the first time since the Vietnam War, defense concerns are intruding onto the domestic political agenda.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Miner Expects a Higher Bid
snippet: Directors of Normandy Mining Ltd, Australia's largest gold producer and target of bidding war between Anglo-Gold and Newmont Mining Corp, expect to get better offer from Newmont soon (S)
lead_paragraph: The directors of Normandy Mining Ltd., Australia's largest gold producer and the target of a bidding war between AngloGold and the Newmont Mining Corporation, expect to get a better offer from Newmont soon. AngloGold added a cash component to its previously all-stock proposal for Normandy last week, topping Newmont's earlier bid. Normandy's board told the Australian Stock Exchange it ''considers there is potential for further developments.'' For now, the directors are waiting to advise shareholders, but they expect to respond within the next 10 days. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Woods Skips Australia Event
snippet: Tiger Woods confirms he will skip Andersen Consulting Match Play Championship, set for Jan in Australia (S)
lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods confirmed today that he will not play in next year's Andersen Consulting Match Play Championship, which will be held Jan. 3-7 in Australia. The event, which is limited to the top 64 players in the world ranking, has been held in California the past two years, but many players are reluctant to make the long journey to Australia right after New Year's Day.

title: A Drone Saves Two Swimmers in Australia
snippet: Lifeguards at a beach in New South Wales were testing a new drone when swimmers in distress were spotted and then saved.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A practice session for Australian lifeguards who were testing a new drone turned into a real rescue when the drone helped save two swimmers at a beach in New South Wales.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Profit Slips At BHP Billiton
snippet: BHP Billiton says profit fell 19 percent, to $931 million, in second half of 2002; chief executive Charles W Goodyear comments; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The mining and energy company BHP Billiton said its profit fell 19 percent, to $931 million, in the second half of 2002 compared with the period in 2001. The chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, left, said the profit was ''a solid result in difficult economic and geopolitical conditions.'' Mr. Goodyear, an American, replaced Brian P. Gilbertson, a South African who resigned last month after six months on the job. Mr. Goodyear warned of tough times ahead, with weak equity markets, high oil prices and lower consumer demand. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Media Company Reports Loss
snippet: Australia's Publishing and Broadcasting reports net loss of 84.6 million Australian dollars ($45.4 million) in last fiscal year (S)
lead_paragraph: Publishing and Broadcasting, a large media and entertainment company, reported a net loss of 84.6 million Australian dollars ($45.4 million) in the last fiscal year. The result for the year ended June 30 reflected 397 million Australian dollars ($212 million) in write-offs, mostly from investments in the failed telecommunications company One.Tel. Publishing and Broadcasting also made provisions for soured investments in India and losses associated with a venture in Australia with Charles Schwab. Rising paper costs and a slowdown in advertising also lowered earnings, executives said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Macquarie Acquires a Leading Australian Auto Finance Business
snippet: The $5.9 billion purchase of Esanda Dealer Finance from the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group will nearly double Macquarie’s auto loan operation.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s biggest investment bank, the Macquarie Group, said on Thursday that it would buy the second-biggest auto finance company in its home market, Esanda Dealer Finance, from the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group for 8.2 billion Australian dollars, or $5.9 billion.

title: Stock Issue In Australia
lead_paragraph: Investors bid up shares in Woolworths Ltd., Australia's largest food retailer, by 15 percent when the company's stock was traded today for the first time after being heavily oversubscribed at the issue price of 2.45 Australian dollars.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Audit Clears Bank Executives
snippet: National Australia Bank chairman Charles Allen says independent review by Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz of bank's write-down of $2 billion related to its mortgage unit, HomeSide Lending, has cleared directors and executives of bank; bank disclose...
lead_paragraph: An independent review of National Australia Bank's write-down of $2 billion related to its mortgage unit, HomeSide Lending, has cleared the directors and executives of the bank, the chairman, Charles Allen, said. The bank, the largest in Australia, disclosed only a summary of the findings, prepared by the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz in conjunction with a regulatory consultant, the Promontory Financial Group, because of legal action involving three HomeSide executives who were fired when the write-downs were disclosed. Last month, National Australia Bank said that it would sell HomeSide's operating assets to Washington Mutual for $1.9 billion. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: A Night for All of Australia
snippet: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 15 — The 27th Summer Games opened tonight with a spirit of inclusiveness and reconciliation in a ceremony that addressed Australia's discriminatory treatment of its indigenous people, celebrated the unprecedented number of...
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 15 — The 27th Summer Games opened tonight with a spirit of inclusiveness and reconciliation in a ceremony that addressed Australia's discriminatory treatment of its indigenous people, celebrated the unprecedented number of female Olympians and applauded a march of unity between North Korea and South Korea.

title: Australian Media Group
lead_paragraph: The Canadian publisher Conrad Black today won a battle for control of the John Fairfax Group, Australia's oldest and second-largest media group.

title: He Set Off Across Australia on a Toy Scooter. Then Australia Got on Board.
snippet: An improbable journey by a Japanese visitor chronicling his adventures on social media has captured the country’s imagination.
lead_paragraph: At a gas station near Bethungra, three people squabbled over who would buy him lunch. At a train station in Junee, a bearded man offered him shelter. And in small towns along Australia’s back roads, encounters with strangers have led to offers of hot showers and warm beds; beer and burgers; and heartfelt, even tearful, conversations, conducted mostly via Google Translate.

title: Australia Splits Davis Opener
snippet: Lleyton Hewitt and Patrick Rafter tie in first day of Davis Cup final (S)
lead_paragraph: First, Lleyton Hewitt was flat on his back with delight. Then Patrick Rafter was flat on his in pain. The result was a 1-1 tie after the first day of the Davis Cup final between Australia and Spain.

title: Plenty of Sting at the Tail End of Australia's Order

lead_paragraph: NOTTINGHAM, England — Ashton Agar fell a single blow short of complete cricketing immortality, but the mark he left on the second day of the Ashes series of five-day test matches between England and Australia on Thursday could hardly have been deeper.

lead_paragraph: ATHENS:—  For the second straight day, the cat devoured the mouse in the finishing straight of the Olympic cycling road race.

title: Cuba Challenges Australian Tobacco Rules
snippet: Cuba is seeking to overturn Australia's tough tobacco-labeling rules at the World Trade Organization, the trade body said Monday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Cuba is seeking to overturn Australia’s tough tobacco-labeling rules at the World Trade Organization, the trade body said Monday, the first time that Havana has used the forum to directly confront another nation over its commercial laws.

title: A Sparkler From Australia
snippet: Howard Goldberg reviews Australia's 1999 Seaview brut sparkling wine (S)
lead_paragraph: Fans of robust California sparkling wines can find similar pleasures more cheaply in 1999 Seaview brut, a white from Australia that's popular there. This wine, made from pinot noir, muscadelle, chenin blanc and sémillon grapes, is nifty for buffets and big parties. It offers a toasty aroma with rich fruit, nut and raisin flavors. Mr. Wright, 1593 Third Avenue (89th Street), Manhattan, asks $8. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Murdoch Expects Flat Year
snippet: News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch says immediate effects of Sept 11 terrorist attacks cost company at least $100 million in advertising bookings, address to annual meeting; predicts results in this fiscal year will be flat against prior year; adds...
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, said the immediate effects of the Sept. 11 attacks cost the company at least $100 million. In the two weeks after the tragedy, advertising bookings were virtually nonexistent, Mr. Murdoch told the annual general meeting in Adelaide. However, despite the global economic downturn and an uncertain advertising market, results this fiscal year will be flat against the prior year, he predicted. But promising signs have emerged, he said. Television revenue bookings are higher than in recent months. Also, the company is in talks with the Hughes Electronics Corporation over its satellite unit, DirecTV. There is a 50-50 chance a deal will be struck, Mr. Murdoch said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Teenager Fatally Shot by Australian Police After He Stabs a Man
snippet: The episode occurred just weeks after two major stabbing attacks in the country. The youth had been under monitoring for having extremist tendencies.
lead_paragraph: The police in Perth, Australia, fatally shot a 16-year-old who had stabbed a man in a parking lot and who officials said had been on their radar for suspicion of having extremist tendencies.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Profit Up At Mining Company
snippet: BHP Billiton, world's largest mining company, says profit rose 3.2 percent in fiscal first quarter ended Sept 30; net income rose to $608 million from $589 million year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, said profit rose 3.2 percent in the first quarter of its fiscal year because of higher prices for iron ore and coal in Asia. Net income rose to $608 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, from $589 million, or 10 cents a year earlier. The result beat most analysts' expectations for the period, the first full quarter since BHP's $11.6 billion takeover of Billiton. The deputy chief executive, Brian Gilbertson, said a protracted slowdown might hurt future earnings.

title: Australia Abandons Refugee Swap Plan
snippet: The decision to end plans to ship asylum seekers to Malaysia as part of a refugee swap leaves Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s immigration policy in turmoil.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Prime Minister Julia Gillard of Australia announced Thursday that she was abandoning her government’s controversial plans to ship asylum seekers to Malaysia as part of a refugee swap deal — a humiliating about-face for the beleaguered leader that leaves her immigration policy in turmoil.

title: U.S. Ready to Face Wounded Australia
snippet: The United States has put up a strong showing in the Rugby World Cup, but its match Friday against Australia will not be easy after the Wallabies were upset by Ireland in their last game.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Playing one of rugby’s superpowers was never going to be easy for the United States Eagles, and their task Friday might have become a lot tougher when Australia lost to Ireland last weekend in the Rugby World Cup.

title: Adding ‘Breadth’ to Specialist Degrees in Australia

lead_paragraph: Since Sophie Brough has her sights set on becoming a doctor, it is no surprise that science subjects like biology and chemistry feature prominently in her university timetable.

title: History of Australia After Red- Blooded Contest
snippet: Australia against Croatia was a tumultuous, at times bitterly fought, encounter despite - or possibly because of - the links between the Croatians, who never go down without a fight, and the Australians, several of whose players are of Croatian he...
lead_paragraph: One of the beauties of the modern age, where television bridges the gaps of time and distance in an instant, is that you can be travelling in a train from Hamburg to Berlin, and be totally informed about what is happening elsewhere in this World Cup of simultaneous matches played across hundreds of kilometers.

title: Australia and India Raise Interest Rates
snippet: Australia and India raised interest rates on Tuesday, in separate moves that highlighted the growing contrast between the Asia-Pacific region’s rapid growth and the still-fragile recovery in other parts of the world.
lead_paragraph: Australia and India raised interest rates on Tuesday, highlighting the contrast between the Asia-Pacific region’s rapid growth and the fragile recovery in other parts of the world.

title: BEING AUSTRALIA
lead_paragraph: AUSTRALIA ALWAYS SEEMED SO FAR away and perhaps not so important. Suddenly, there was Secretary of State George P. Shultz flying off to Canberra, the Australian capital, to listen more carefully to what the folks down under had to say about global defense strategy. At parties in Manhattan, the learned were talking about great Australian films and applauding the Aussies' delightful bravado in snatching the America's Cup from the stuffy New York Yacht Club. Business executives were going off eagerly to vibrant Sydney following the Labor Government's unexpected decision to open the Australian economy to foreign banks. At home, my kids were rattling around to Men at Work and other Australian rock groups.

title: No Australian Has Won an Australian Open Singles Title Since the ’70s. Can Barty?
snippet: Ashleigh Barty is two wins away from winning a Grand Slam title in her home country, as the top-ranked player left in a draw without Serena Williams, Naomi Osaka and other big names.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — In downtown Melbourne, Ashleigh Barty is nearly impossible to avoid. Her image adorns posters not just for tennis apparel but also for things like sunblock, watches and even Vegemite, the savory spread that is an Australian classic.

title: Australian Leader Wins Support From Greens
snippet: Prime Minister Julia Gillard won a formal assurance from the Greens Party that it will support her bid for a further three-year term.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Julia Gillard scored the first victory in the contest to end Australia’s parliamentary deadlock on Wednesday, winning a formal assurance from the Greens Party that it would support her bid for a further three-year term.

title: Australia Steel
lead_paragraph: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company said it would spend $71 million overhauling and updating equipment at the coated products division at its Port Kembla steelworks in New South Wales. The program will make the company's Springhill Works one of the three most modern steelmaking mills in the world, Broken Hill said. The program is in addition to $500 million already being spent on improvements at the Port Kembla works.

title: Sinochem Said to Approach Australia's Nufarm
snippet: China's Sinochem has made a conditional takeover bid for Australia's Nufarm, according to media reports. The deal could be worth $1.64 billion, The Wall Street Journal said.
lead_paragraph: China's Sinochem has made a conditional takeover bid for Australia's Nufarm, according to media reports. The deal for one of the world's largest off-patent agricultural chemical manufacturers could be worth $1.64 billion, The Wall Street Journal said.

title: Australian Officials Call for Changes
lead_paragraph: Australian Olympic officials, under pressure at home and abroad after revelations of questionable payments during Sydney's successful bid for the 2000 Summer Games, today called for change in a selection process that allows aspiring host cities to offer substantial aid to national Olympic committees.

title: Australia: Retail Sales Rose in May
snippet: Australian retail sales rose in May at the fastest rate in six months. Sales increased 0.7 percent from April, the Bureau of Statistics said.
lead_paragraph: Australian retail sales rose in May at the fastest rate in six months. Sales increased 0.7 percent from April, the Bureau of Statistics said.

title: Shell Joins PetroChina in an Offer in Australia
snippet: The joint venture offered $4.04 a share for the Australian energy company, which produces natural gas from coal beds.
lead_paragraph: Arrow Energy of Australia said Monday that it had received a takeover offer worth about $3 billion from a company owned by Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina, the government-run gas and oil giant.

title: AUSTRALIAN GOTHIC
snippet: RINGARRA By Coral Lansbury. 220 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. GOTHIC fiction's appeal is rooted in the fear of -and attraction to - the irrational. Relying upon exaggeration and the macabre, the genre slips easily into self-parody (the plot ...
lead_paragraph: RINGARRA By Coral Lansbury. 220 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. GOTHIC fiction's appeal is rooted in the fear of -and attraction to - the irrational. Relying upon exaggeration and the macabre, the genre slips easily into self-parody (the plot of the first Gothic novel, Horace Walpole's 1764 ''Castle of Otranto,'' all but defies rational summation) and has long inspired such deliberate spoofs as Austen's ''Northanger Abbey'' and Peacock's ''Nightmare Abbey.'' In ''Ringarra,'' Coral Lansbury (Australian-born, now a professor of English at Rutgers University) has attempted to write a straight Gothic novel, undiluted by levity, but leavened by a strong infusion of literary and psychological self-consciousness.

title: Floods Take Toll on Australia Economy
snippet: The floods in Australia have affected 200,000 people and caused several billion dollars worth of economic losses.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia  Churning floodwaters continued to rise across a vast stretch of northeastern Australia on Tuesday as the authorities worked to grapple with the multibillion-dollar economic toll from record inundations that have killed at least nine people.

title: Australian on Top
lead_paragraph: Geoff Case, a 32-year-old Australian who won his way into the race, scaled 80 flights of stairs yesterday in the 14th annual Empire State Run-Up in the fastest time of the 107 men entered, 10 minutes 13 seconds.

title: MUSIC: OF AN BY AUSTRALIANS
lead_paragraph: THE Australian performers and composers who joined forces for a concert Tuesday at Symphony Space styled their program, with some justification, ''terra australis incognita.'' That is the description given the vast southerly continent by its earliest European explorers, and though Australia's musicians have long since taken their numerous places on the international scene, her composers have been at best vaguely known in the world beyond.

title: Australian Output
lead_paragraph: Australia's major areas of production declined in April from March but were up from a year earlier, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said today. April production in 18 of 24 categories was lower than March's level, but 19 of 24 improved from a year earlier. Production of beer and bricks rose from both the previous month and a year earlier, as production of cars, trucks, iron, steel and cement fell from March but rose from a year earlier.

title: Australia Seeks Doctor’s Arrest for Operations
snippet: Australia is seeking the arrest of an American surgeon, charging him with manslaughter and inflicting grievous bodily harm.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 22 — A court in Australia issued warrants on Wednesday for the arrest of an American surgeon, charging him with three counts of manslaughter and five counts of inflicting grievous bodily harm, the chief prosecutor in the case announced.

title: Tepid Start for Myer's I.P.O. in Australia
snippet: Myer Holdings shares fell 5.4 percent in their debut Monday in Australia's biggest public float in two years, a negative sign for other retailers with initial public offerings waiting in the wings.
lead_paragraph: Shares in the Australian department store chain Myer Holdings fell 5.4 percent in their debut Monday in Australia's biggest public float in two years, a negative sign for other retailers with initial public offerings waiting in the wings.

title: An Australian’s Successful Quest, Inspired by Woods
snippet: At 36, Scott Gardiner is the oldest rookie on the PGA Tour and he is also the first indigenous Australian to earn his full-time playing privileges.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Torrey Pines’s beauty can be entrancing, especially to a first-time visitor. But its stately trees, sweeping views of the Pacific Ocean and craggy cliffs were not why Scott Gardiner needed to be reminded once or twice that it was his turn to hit during the first round of the Farmers Insurance Open.

title: A Gloomy Forecast for Australian Economy in 2009
snippet: Once considered a relatively save haven, Australia’s mining-led economy “will unwind scarily fast” in part because of slower-than-expected growth in China.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian economy, once considered a relatively save haven, is headed for a steep downturn in 2009, in part because of slower-than-expected growth in China, a leading forecaster said Monday.

title: A Gloomy Forecast for Australian Economy in 2009

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian economy, once considered a relatively save haven, is headed for a steep downturn in 2009, in part because of slower-than-expected growth in China, a leading forecaster said Monday.

title: Jackson Glove Gets $49,000 in Australia
snippet: Forty-nine thousand dollars is a lot to pay for a single glove, unless, of course, it was worn by the King of Pop.
lead_paragraph: Forty-nine thousand dollars is a lot to pay for a single glove, unless, of course, it was worn by the King of Pop. The Australian auction house Bonhams & Goodman told Reuters that a glove worn by Michael Jackson sold for $49,000 in Melbourne on Sunday, nearly twice the price auctioneers expected. A bidder on behalf of the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas won a bidding war with collectors in Australia and the United States for the Swarovski-crystal-covered white glove, inset above, which Mr. Jackson gave to a fan and memorabilia collector, Bill Hibble, in 1996, after the Sydney premiere of his short film “Ghosts.”

title: Studios Lose a Downloading Case in Australia
lead_paragraph: Hollywood studios lost a copyright court case against an Australia Internet service provider on Thursday, Reuters reported, when a court ruled that the provider, iiNet, could not be held responsible for unauthorized downloads of movies using its service. The suit was filed by a group of studios including Universal Pictures, Warner Brothers, Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures Entertainment, 20th Century Fox and Disney. A federal court in Sydney ruled that it was impossible to hold iiNet responsible for users who might infringe copyright. iiNet contended that it was not required by law to act on allegations of copyright infringement; that customers were innocent until proven guilty; and that the case was comparable to suing a power company for the activities clients use electricity to engage in.

title: Australian Incentives
lead_paragraph: The Australian Government plans to encourage high-risk technological ventures with federal tax incentives, the Industry and Commerce Minister, John Button, said today.

title: Australian Deficit
lead_paragraph: Australia must reduce its worrisome budget deficit, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. More borrowing by the Government could spark inflation, the O.E.C.D. warned.

title: Firefighters Battle Blazes in Australia

lead_paragraph: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the nation’s biggest provider of mortgages, agreed to buy Australian units from HBOS, the British bank, for 2.1 billion Australian dollars ($1.5 billion) as HBOS sells assets amid the global credit crisis.

title: Australian Paintings
lead_paragraph: The Institute for Art and Urban Resources is showing ''An Australian Accent,'' an exhibition of paintings by Mike Parr, Imants Tillers and Ken Unsworth of Australia, Sunday through June 10 in the main exhibition center at Project Studios 1, 46-01 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Australian Fashion Week Roundup
snippet: With the Global Financial Crisis prompting the closure of one of its three venues, Australian Fashion Week was only a two-ring circus this season. But that didn't stop a wave of new faces, and others who have tend...
lead_paragraph: With the Global Financial Crisis prompting the closure of one of its three venues, Australian Fashion Week was only a two-ring circus this season. But that didn't stop a wave of new faces, and others who have tended to be conspicuous by their absence from making an appearance this time around. New York Fashion Week refugees Sass & Bide, Willow and Aurelio Costarella opted for low-key presentations instead of shows, with Willow designer Kit Podgornik presenting her embellished cocktail dresses suspended over Sydney Harbour from the swings on an old fig tree on the grounds of Carthona, a gothic mansion in Darling Point.

title: Australia: Job Creation Tops Forecasts
snippet: Employers hired almost three times as many workers in August as economists had forecast, adding to evidence that an Australian mining boom is offsetting weaker domestic demand.
lead_paragraph: Employers hired almost three times as many workers in August as economists had forecast, adding to evidence that an Australian mining boom is offsetting weaker domestic demand. The number of people employed rose 14,600 last month, the Australian Statistics Bureau said. Economists had forecast an increase of 5,000. The jobless rate fell to 4.1 percent, from 4.3 percent. The number of full-time jobs rose about 7,500 in August and part-time jobs increased roughly 7,200. The August employment gain followed a revised increase of 18,700 jobs in July. Demand for skilled labor at companies including BHP Billiton is helping generate new jobs.

title: Astonishing Admission of Cheating Rocks Australian Cricket
snippet: Senior players schemed to tamper with the ball during a series in South Africa, a revelation that has stunned a sport that prides itself on fair play.
lead_paragraph: It is commonly said in Australia that the captain of the national cricket team is the second most important job in the land. The role goes beyond sports; it bequeaths a certain moral authority, too. In the last 30 years, three Australian captains have won the Australian of the Year Award.

title: N.F.L. Protests Draw Attention – and Comparisons – in Australia

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — With more and more N.F.L. players kneeling during the national anthem in protest of police killings of African-Americans, a familiar cry has resurfaced: Politics has no place in sport.

title: Australian Trade Deficit
lead_paragraph: Despite a rise in exports, Australia had a trade deficit of 1.2 billion Australian dollars, or $924 million (United States), in April, the Government reported last week. Although the current account deficit was lower than the gap of 1.63 billion Australian dollars in March, it was still more than double the deficit of 558 million Australian dollars a year earlier. The current account measures trade in goods and services.

title: Earthquake in Australia Forces Hospitals and Residents to Evacuate
snippet: The 5.9-magnitude quake damaged buildings in Melbourne, but there were no immediate reports of serious injuries or deaths.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A magnitude 5.9 earthquake hit southeast Australia on Wednesday morning, damaging buildings and forcing hospitals to evacuate staff members and patients. It was an unusually large quake in a country less susceptible to major temblors than neighboring countries.

title: 4 Dead in Helicopter Collision in Australia
snippet: The two craft crashed in midair in a tourist area on the Gold Coast, near a theme park. An investigation is underway, with a report expected to take weeks.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Four people died and eight others were injured in a midair collision of two helicopters on Monday in a tourist area in Queensland on the Gold Coast.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Another Bank Bidder
snippet: Wesl
lead_paragraph: The Westpac Banking Corporation is in talks to buy the New Zealand banking unit of Lloyds TSB Group, pitting it against its main Australian rivals in bidding for New Zealand's biggest bank, which analysts have valued at about $4 billion. Westpac sought approval from New Zealand's competition regulator to buy the Lloyds unit, the National Bank. Westpac, based in Sydney, is the second bidder for the New Zealand unit to approach the regulator after the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group applied last week. In addition, the chief executive of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, David Murray, has said that he may also be interested in bidding for the National Bank as well.

title: Australian Detective on Stabbing Deaths
snippet: Bruno Asnicar, the detective inspector of the Queensland state police, discussed the stabbing deaths of eight children in the northern Australian city of Cairns.
lead_paragraph: Bruno Asnicar, the detective inspector of the Queensland state police, discussed the stabbing deaths of eight children in the northern Australian city of Cairns.

title: Deputy Premier of Australia Is Questioned on Kickbacks
snippet: The deputy prime minister was asked whether he knew about kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government under the United Nations oil-for-food program.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, April 10 — The high-profile hearings into accusations that an Australian wheat company, AWB Ltd., paid $200 million in kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government under the United Nations oil-for-food program became even more dramatic on Monday with the appearance of the deputy prime minister, Mark Vaile.

title: Australia condemns journalist jailing
snippet: Australia's foreign minister hits out as an Egyptian court jails an Australian journalist and two colleages for seven years each. Paul Chapman reports.
lead_paragraph: Australia's foreign minister hits out as an Egyptian court jails an Australian journalist and two colleages for seven years each. Paul Chapman reports.

title: Australia Negotiating to Send Refugees to Philippines
snippet: An Australian official declined to provide details of the possible plan.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Australia is in talks with the Philippines about the possibility of that country’s accepting asylum seekers, currently being held on remote Pacific islands, who had tried to reach Australia by boat, the immigration minister said Friday.

title: Japan and Australia Take Steps to Revive Economies
snippet: Japan’s central bank unveiled steps to spur lending, while Australia cut rates to their lowest in nearly half a century.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s central bank took new steps to encourage lending and Australia cut its benchmark interest rate to the lowest level in nearly half a century Tuesday, highlighting concerns about the global economy despite signs of a pickup in China and elsewhere.

title: Australia’s Anti-interference Laws
snippet: China takes offense at the country’s newest legislation.
lead_paragraph: The Australian government has passed far-reaching new laws that ban foreign interference in politics and mete out harsher punishments for the divulging of classified information. Officials contend the laws aren’t targeting any specific countries, but China has reacted unfavorably. China is Australia’s most significant trading partner.

title: Robin Hood in Australia
snippet: Brooke Allen reviews book The Conversations at Curlow Creek by David Malouf; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: THE CONVERSATIONS

title: Previewing a Spring of Culture in Australia
snippet: Offerings in art, culture, design, music and theater across the country.
lead_paragraph: Balmy temperatures have set in across much of Australia. It won’t last — the forecast is back to cooler weather early next week — but the dose of warmth is a good reminder that summer, with its plethora of cultural attractions, is not too far away.

title: Australia Scraps Coronavirus Vaccine
snippet: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.

title: Raytheon-Australia Deal
lead_paragraph: The Raytheon Company said today that it had received a contract valued at more than $100 million to provide air traffic control equipment to the Royal Australian Air Force. The shares of Raytheon rose 37.5 cents, to $81.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Raytheon, which is based here, sells electronic equipment, aircraft parts and other products in 39 countries.

title: COMPUTERSHARE OF AUSTRALIA TO ACQUIRE EQUISERVE
snippet: Computershare Ltd, Australia's largest share registrar, acquires DST Systems' EquiServe business for $307 million in cash and stock, to add share registration services in US (S)
lead_paragraph: Computershare Ltd., Australia's largest share registrar, has agreed to buy DST Systems' EquiServe business for $307 million in cash and stock, to add share registration services in the United States. Computershare will pay $216 million in cash and 29.6 million shares, valued at about $91 million, DST Systems said yesterday. EquiServe provides share registry and employee plan administration services to 1,300 clients, including more than half of the 30 companies in the Dow Jones industrial average. Computershare is based in Melbourne and DST Systems in Kansas City, Mo.

title: The Future of Australian Children’s TV
snippet: It might make more economic sense for all English-language programming to be made in Los Angeles, but that would come at a different cost.
lead_paragraph: On one of my earliest visits to Australia, as a small child in the 1990s, I couldn’t believe the extraordinary wealth of kids’ programming on terrestrial television. (We were not a cable family, and had strict limits on “screen time” at home.)

title: Foremost Stake To Australians
lead_paragraph: An investment group led by the FAI Traders Insurance Company, an insurance concern based in Sydney, Australia, has acquired 5.1 percent of the Foremost Corporation of America. Foremost, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., insures mobile homes and recreational vehicles.

title: How to Rethink Australia Day
snippet: Our national holiday is built on the dispossession of Aboriginal Australians. It’s time to change the date.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — When pollsters asked Australians a year ago to list three words associated with Australia Day — the country’s Jan. 26 national day — the most popular responses were barbecue, celebration and holiday. But among Indigenous Australians, the most popular words were invasion, survival and murder. That, in miniature, is why the country finds itself in the throes of an intense debate over the timing of Australia Day.

title: Australian Deal by Dana
lead_paragraph: The Dana Corporation has acquired the Australian filter maker James N. Kirby for undisclosed terms. Kirby, which is closely held, makes air filters for cars and trucks. Dana, based in Toledo, makes automotive components and industrial products.

title: How to Say Fish in Australian
snippet: Availability to home cooks in New York of fish native to Australia discussed; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Fish with Australian accents are making their way to our shores. The mulloway-suzuki, a meaty creature that resembles striped bass, is $18 a pound at Dorian's Seafood, 1580 York Avenue (83rd Street). A whole side, filleted, weighs nearly two pounds but can be cut to order. Another Australian import, the succulent barramundi, is farmed at Australis, an American-Australian aquaculture facility in Turners Falls, Mass. The fish, raised in tanks filled with well water, are harvested at about two pounds, smaller than the imported version. Red Cat in Chelsea has an occasional special of barramundi, sautéed and served with greens, calamata olives and roasted red pepper relish ($22), below. For home cooks it is available at Grace's Marketplace, Balducci's, Citarella and Pescatore for about $12 a pound.

title: The Biggest, Darkest Sky in Australia
snippet: Looking for darkness in Australia’s biggest state.
lead_paragraph: This week, I went looking for darkness.

title: A Battle to Contain Australia’s Fires
snippet: Firefighters in Australia are trying to take advantage of cooler and damper weather to slow the spread of the devastating fires.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters in Australia are trying to take advantage of cooler and damper weather to slow the spread of the devastating fires.

title: Will Australia Rise Above Xenophobia?
snippet: Leaders from the main political parties profess to abhor racism. But this cherished bipartisanship is in danger of fracturing.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — As Australia faces the global virus of xenophobia, the country’s early history provides a warning of the social and economic costs of isolation.

title: Dutch Team Dominates the Finals in Australia
snippet: The final of the Yeh Bros Cup team event in the Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia, last weekend was between the defending champions from Sweden and the team from the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: The final of the Yeh Bros Cup team event in the Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia, last weekend was between the defending champions from Sweden, Peter Bertheau, Fredrik Nystrom, Bjorn Fallenius and Peter Fredin, and the team from the Netherlands, Sjoert Brink, Bas Drijver, Ton Bakkeren and Huub Bertens.

title: Mime With Attitude by 2 Australian Zanies
snippet: The Umbilical Brothers (David Collins and Shane Dundas) frantically mock a traditionally silent art in “Thwak!,” at Hartford Stage.
lead_paragraph: Watch out. Jokes fly thick and fast at Hartford Stage, where those Australian zanies the Umbilical Brothers are busy giving mime a good name. Loudly.

title: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
snippet: Australia and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Australia and More — Pictures of the Day

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand/Australia: Australia: Bid For Property Trust
snippet: Australian pú
lead_paragraph: An Australian property trust, Stockland, agreed to pay 1.6 billion Australian dollars ($1.05 billion) for AMP Diversified Property Trust. Stockland will gain industrial, office and retail property, mostly in New South Wales, Australia's most populous state. Stockland, based in Sydney, said it would offer one share plus 80 cents for every 1.9 AMP units. The bid was the third in the real estate fund industry in a week.

title: Letter From an Australian Jail
snippet: An Iranian Kurdish writer, detained for six years on a remote island for seeking asylum in Australia, proves that words are more powerful than fences.
lead_paragraph: Behrouz Boochani could not be in Melbourne to receive Australia’s most prestigious literary award on Thursday. He was on a small Pacific island 2,500 miles away, near the Equator, where he, along with hundreds of other refugees and asylum seekers, has been locked up by Australia for nearly six years now.

title: Australian Dance, With No Hint of Kangaroos
snippet: Profile of Sydney Dance Company; its current American tour, first in nearly decade, could prove to be Australian troupe's rite of passage; artistic director Graeme Murphy commens; photo (L)
lead_paragraph: AT 21, THE SYDNEY DANCE COMPANY is ''on the verge of adulthood,'' says its artistic director, Graeme Murphy. And its current American tour, the first in nearly a decade, may indeed prove to be the Australian troupe's rite of passage.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia And New Zealand: Australia: Retailer's Profit Rises
snippet: Harvey Norman Holdings says full-year profit rose 18 percent; net income for year ended June 30 rose to 151 million Australian dollars ($100 million) from 128 million Australian dollars year earlier; sales rose 21 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: Harvey Norman Holdings, Australia's largest furniture and electronics retailer, said its full-year profit rose 18 percent, helped by demand for plasma televisions and DVD players. Sales in July and August rose 21 percent. Net income for the year ended June 30 climbed to 151 million Australian dollars ($100 million), or 14 cents a diluted share, from 128 million Australian dollars, or 12 cents a diluted share, the previous year. During the latest year, Harvey Norman opened 15 stores in Australia and New Zealand as well as one store in Slovenia.

title: Indigenous Australians Use Tech to Expose Police Abuse
snippet: Copwatch teaches Australia’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples how to use their mobile phones’ cameras to battle police brutality.
lead_paragraph: PERTH, Australia — In one video, a black prisoner screams “I can’t breathe” 12 times as he is pinned down by a group of guards. In another, a police car swerves to run down a black teenager. As the young man has a seizure in the street, the officers handcuff him rather than offer first aid.

title: For Australians, Too, It’s the End of an Era
snippet: “I don’t think we’ll ever have the security again that we had with her,” said one Australian about the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: The death of Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s longest-reigning monarch, has reverberated around the world. Amid the outpouring of grief on social media and in news coverage, her passing inevitably renewed questions about the monarchy’s role, including in Commonwealth countries, like Australia, where she was the head of state.

title: Facebook Strikes Deal to Restore News Sharing in Australia
snippet: The agreement means users and publishers in Australia can once again share links to news articles, after Facebook had blocked the practice last week.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Monday that it would restore the sharing and viewing of news links in Australia after gaining more time to negotiate over a proposed law that would require it to pay for news content that appeared on its site.

title: Australian Minister on Nauru Incident
snippet: Peter Dutton, the Australian immigration minister, said an Iranian man was in serious condition after setting himself on fire on the island of Nauru on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dutton, the Australian immigration minister, said an Iranian man was in serious condition after setting himself on fire on the island of Nauru on Wednesday.

title: Review: Gauge in Brisbane, Australia
snippet: In a post-Ben Shewry dining scene, this modern Australian restaurant is putting customers before ego.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — The restaurant’s name will be a single word: stark, vaguely industrial, somewhat meaningless. There will be some sort of sculptural tartare on the menu, and probably a kingfish ceviche. Saltbush and kangaroo and finger lime will all make appearances. The format is a tasting menu or shared plates or a combination of both; the wines are natural. Ben Shewry has a lot to answer for.

title: Australia braces for double cyclone
snippet: Residents warned to take shelter as two tropical cyclones bear down on northeastern Australia. Rough cut (no reporter narration).
lead_paragraph: Residents warned to take shelter as two tropical cyclones bear down on northeastern Australia. Rough cut (no reporter narration).

title: Can Australia Escape a Recession?
snippet: “Whether it’s a technical recession or not, we certainly are going to be in for difficult times,” one economist said.
lead_paragraph: In September 2020, as the effects of the coronavirus pandemic hit all over the world, Australia dipped briefly into a recession — then bounced straight back out again the following year.

title: Review: Kisumé in Melbourne, Australia
snippet: This Japanese restaurant offers an extravagant omakase on its top floor, a less expensive omakase on the ground floor and more casual fare below that.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — There is a certain sector of Australian dining that relies on trickle-down reputation — the idea that the prowess of one chef or flagship restaurant confers immediate status on every other related project. But rarely have I seen this concept contained within one restaurant, in one building.

title: AUSTRALIAN 'KITTY'
snippet: Tangy, stylish Australian send-up of Hollywood gangster fare.
lead_paragraph: DONALD CROMBIE'S ''Kitty and the Bagman'' takes place in a very odd part of Australia: the part that adjoins the old Warner Bros. back lot, or so it seems. That, at least, is the feeling of this colorful gangster movie, with its unlikely Australian air.

title: Australia Vows to Bolster Navy
snippet: Malcolm Turnbull, the prime minister of Australia, said on Thursday that his country would bolster its naval strength as part of a long-term military build-up.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Turnbull, the prime minister of Australia, said on Thursday that his country would bolster its naval strength as part of a long-term military build-up.

title: A Two-Wheeled Australian Adventure
snippet: Tara and Steve Howell believe that the nation’s true beauty lies off the beaten path. Follow their journey into the wild.
lead_paragraph: Tara and Steve Howell believe that the nation’s true beauty lies off the beaten path. Follow their journey into the wild.

title: Australia Official Welcomes Resettlement
snippet: Peter Dutton, Australia’s immigration minister, said on Friday that Papua New Guinea would begin resettling asylum seekers from an Australian camp on Manus Island.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dutton, Australia’s immigration minister, said on Friday that Papua New Guinea would begin resettling asylum seekers from an Australian camp on Manus Island.

title: Fire Season in Australia Starts, Early and Ominous
snippet: Though experts do not think that this season will be the worst yet, they also warn that the past is no longer a reliable guide to the future.
lead_paragraph: The warmest winter on record, followed by an unusually warm and dry spring. Hundreds of fires along Australia’s east coast, including one that razed 53 homes in Queensland. And last week, on the west coast, a raging blaze just over a dozen miles from the Perth city center was fueled by an unseasonably early heat wave and strong winds.

title: Australia condemns executions in Indonesia
snippet: An Indonesian firing squad executes eight convicted drug-traffickers from several countries, prompting Australia to recall its envoy to Jakarta. Yiming Woo reports.
lead_paragraph: An Indonesian firing squad executes eight convicted drug-traffickers from several countries, prompting Australia to recall its envoy to Jakarta. Yiming Woo reports.

title: Gender Progress in Macho Australia?
snippet: The director of The New York Times Gender Initiative shares her impressions and questions after a busy visit to Sydney and Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: Want the Australia Letter by email? Sign up and forward to your friends for heaps of global coverage and provocative Australia insight.

title: Australians React to Leadership Change
snippet: Australians have mixed views on news of Malcolm Turnbull toppling Tony Abbott as prime minister to become the country’s fifth leader in eight years.
lead_paragraph: Australians have mixed views on news of Malcolm Turnbull toppling Tony Abbott as prime minister to become the country’s fifth leader in eight years.

title: Minimalist Swimsuits, From Australia
snippet: A look at Tuyen Nguyen and Michael Lim’s new line of one-pieces and bikinis for their label, Her.
lead_paragraph: A look at Tuyen Nguyen and Michael Lim’s new line of one-pieces and bikinis for their label, Her.

title: A Vegan Macadamia Milk With Roots in Australia
snippet: Milkadamia comes in four varieties and is made from macadamia nuts grown in Australia.
lead_paragraph: Add macadamia to the growing parade of vegan nut milks. A line of four is showing up in dairy cases and online. The milk is pressed from raw nuts grown on a family farm in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, Australia, the macadamia’s native habitat. The farm cultivates the trees in a manner said to promote healthy soil. There are four varieties, all nicely creamy: original (lightly sweetened), unsweetened and unsweetened vanilla (both pleasant), and latte de barista (designed for coffee shops, fairly sweet, foams well): Milkadamia, $4 to $5.50 per quart, depending on the store, milkadamia.com.

title: Endorsing Australia’s Ties to Indonesia
snippet: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia said he was optimistic about the prospect of economic cooperation with Indonesia after meeting with its president, Joko Widodo, in Jakarta.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia said he was optimistic about the prospect of economic cooperation with Indonesia after meeting with its president, Joko Widodo, in Jakarta.

title: Australia Discusses Asylum Policy
snippet: Australia is negotiating a deal with the Philippines to transfer asylum seekers currently held in detention centers on remote islands, the immigration minister, Peter Dutton, said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Australia is negotiating a deal with the Philippines to transfer asylum seekers currently held in detention centers on remote islands, the immigration minister, Peter Dutton, said on Friday.

title: Australia vs. Canada. The Results Are In.
snippet: This week’s newsletter revisits our friendly little contest with the frozen maple-leaf-lovers.
lead_paragraph: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on Australia, news of the world, and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Want to receive it by email? Sign up here.

title: An Official Role for David Hallberg at Australian Ballet
snippet: Mr. Hallberg is to be a resident international guest artist at the company, which he says gave him new artistic life.
lead_paragraph: David Hallberg, the American Ballet Theater principal dancer, will be the Australian Ballet’s first international resident guest artist, a spokeswoman for the company confirmed on Thursday. Mr. Hallberg, who recently returned to the stage after two and a half years sidelined by injury, will perform in two seasons in Australia this year, including upcoming performances of “The Sleeping Beauty” in Brisbane on Saturday and on Tuesday.

title: Australian Officials on Cafe Siege
snippet: The police commissioner and the premier of New South Wales discussed the situation at a cafe in Sydney, Australia, where an assailant was holding an unknown number of hostages Monday.
lead_paragraph: The police commissioner and the premier of New South Wales discussed the situation at a cafe in Sydney, Australia, where an assailant was holding an unknown number of hostages Monday.

title: Australia’s ‘Unbreakable,’ and Worrisome, Alliance
snippet: Mike Pompeo, the United States secretary of state, came to Sydney a few days ago. Here’s what it means.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Australia Letter is written by Damien Cave, the Australia bureau chief.Sign up to get it by email.

title: Little Sisters in Final in Australia
snippet: The Australian Open women’s final will be a match between Serena Williams and Dinara Safina for the trophy and the No. 1 ranking in the world.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia  The Australian Open women’s final will be a match between Serena Williams and Dinara Safina for the trophy and the No. 1 ranking in the world.

title: Fossils of a Prehistoric Rainforest Hide in Australia’s Rusted Rocks
snippet: The find suggests overlooked rocks across the continent may contain more fossilized surprises.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s Central Tablelands, hundreds of miles northwest of Sydney, are dominated today by grasses and spindly trees. But scientists recently discovered that some of the area’s rusted rocks conceal traces of the lush rainforests that covered the area 15 million years ago during the Miocene Epoch.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Mall Businesses Merge
snippet: Shareholders of Westfield Holdings, Australia's largest listed retail property developer, approve plan to acquire Westfield Trust and Westfield America Trust and create what will be world's largest publicly traded manager of shopping malls; combin...
lead_paragraph: Shareholders of Westfield Holdings, Australia's largest listed retail property developer, approved a plan to acquire Westfield Trust and Westfield America Trust, and create what will be the world's largest publicly traded manager of shopping malls. The combined company, to be called the Westfield Group, will have a market value of $27 billion. John Shaw (NYT)

title: AUSTRALIA AND THE ASIA GAME
snippet: AUSTRALIA AND THE ASIA GAME.By Michael Byrnes. 272 pages. $20. Allen and Unwin.. Reviewed by Philip Bowring. THE sympathetic observer of Australia's relations with its Asian neighbors is often hard put to decide which of two widespread attitudes i...
lead_paragraph: AUSTRALIA AND THE ASIA GAME

title: Learning to Swim: An Australian Birthright
snippet: In my 20s, I decided to finally learn to swim — properly.
lead_paragraph: Recently, in my 20s, I decided to finally learn to swim.

title: Australia slows on sliding prices
snippet: With weaker-than-expected economic growth, Australia posted third quarter figures as the country tries to shake its dependency on commodity exports amid global price declines. Meg Teckman reports.
lead_paragraph: With weaker-than-expected economic growth, Australia posted third quarter figures as the country tries to shake its dependency on commodity exports amid global price declines. Meg Teckman reports.

title: Australia’s Other Great (and Threatened) Coral Reefs
snippet: Every one of Australia’s coral reefs is threatened by climate change, potentially devastating not just the country’s ecosystems but its economy as well.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The United Nations issued a dire alert on Monday, warning that many of the world’s coral reefs could die as soon as 2040 as a result of climate change.

title: Australia: Relaxed, Sunny and Secretive?
snippet: Australia has a global reputation for being a sunny, relaxed democracy. But it also has a deep preference for government secrecy.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up to get it by email. This week’s issue is written by Isabella Kwai, a reporter with the bureau.

title: Spalding’s Australian Baseball Tour
snippet: Some 125 years ago, in October 1888, Albert Spalding, a former player and part owner of the Chicago White Stockings arranged for two teams to embark on a round-the-world tour.
lead_paragraph: Some 125 years ago, in October 1888, Albert Spalding, a former player and part owner of the Chicago White Stockings arranged for two teams to embark on a round-the-world tour.

title: Alcoa Australia
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser said today that Alcoa of Australia Ltd. was likely to freeze development of its $1 billion smelter project at Portland, Victoria, because of financing problems. In addition, the company today reported a 35 percent drop in net first-half profit to $36.90 million, from $57 million a year ago, and said earnings for the second half of the calendar year 1982 would be substantially worse. Alcoa said the project's future was under review and a decision was expected in the very near future.

title: A Sweet Combination of Belgium and Australia
snippet: Australian Homemade is new confectionary shop in East Village; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The name of the new East Village confectionery shop, Australian Homemade, takes some explaining. To be sure, swirling aboriginal-style patterns cover the floor of this bright, industrial-looking glass, stainless steel and wood place at 115 St. Marks Place (between First Avenue and Avenue A). And the ice cream that is made fresh on the premises in small batches, not just daily, but every few hours, is from an Australian recipe. But the shop is the first American branch of a European chain with stores mostly in Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: The Future Is Knocking on Australia’s Door
snippet: With Covid, global security and climate change, the status quo has started to shift.
lead_paragraph: When I sat down to write my essay about Australia’s bifurcated approach to containing the Delta variant, I knew there would be scenes and insightful conversations that never made it into the article. I’d spoken to dozens of Australians across the country, seeking a mix of nuance and contemplation, and there are always moments you wish could be included. But one discussion came back to me this morning because it seemed to cover a range of the issues that Australia now finds itself confronting on the world stage.

title: Australia Doubles Down on Cruel Refugee Policy
snippet: A proposed lifetime ban on migrants who attempt to reach Australia by boat is absurd, shortsighted and cruel.
lead_paragraph: The government of Australia has come under withering criticism for its harsh anywhere-but-here approach to refugees and other migrants who attempt to reach the country by boat. But instead of revisiting a cruel and costly policy — which involves sending everyone intercepted at sea to offshore prisons — Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has decided to double down.

title: Australia bushfire threatens homes
snippet: A bushfire fuelled by strong winds is threatening homes in Australia's Blue Mountains. Rough cut (no reporter narration).
lead_paragraph: A bushfire fuelled by strong winds is threatening homes in Australia's Blue Mountains. Rough cut (no reporter narration).

title: Williams Reaches Finals in Australia
snippet: Serena Williams defeated the 17-year-old Czech Nicole Vaidisova in the semifinals of the Australian Open, and will face the U.S. Open champion Maria Sharapova in the final.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 25 — After two years of waiting and not much playing, Serena Williams is back in a final, and it happens to be in a Grand Slam tournament.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Jobless Rate Falls
snippet: Australia's economy unexpectedly added 111,000 jobs in January, most in more than decade, and unemployment rate fell to 6.1 percent from 6.2 percent in December (S)
lead_paragraph: Australia's economy unexpectedly added 111,000 jobs in January, the most in more than a decade, and the unemployment rate fell to 6.1 percent from 6.2 percent in December, the government announced. Officials said the figures underscored the economy's resilience at a time of global weakness, but some analysts said they might be the last good news for a while, as the worst drought in a century erodes growth. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Netanyahu’s Planned Visit to Australia Is Met With Opposition
snippet: Benjamin Netanyahu’s trip, a first by an Israeli prime minister, has generated a bit of pushback because of his government’s policies toward the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The first visit to Australia by an Israeli prime minister was intended to be a warm meeting between the leaders of two countries with strong trade ties, giving Benjamin Netanyahu some positive coverage as his nation faces broad condemnation for pushing to expand settlements on the West Bank.

title: Australia vs. Warner Bros.?
snippet: The newest A.F.L. team will be in Tasmania. Can the club can be named after the island’s resident marsupial, the Tasmanian devil?
lead_paragraph: It was a story that made for splashy, even sensational, headlines in the Australian press this week: The notion that Warner Bros., the American film and entertainment studio, could legally prevent Tasmania’s new Australian rules football team from being called the Tasmanian Devils.

title: Australia Police Comment on Arrests
snippet: The police said on Thursday that several people, including a 15-year-old boy, were charged in Sydney with terrorism-related offenses.
lead_paragraph: The police said on Thursday that several people, including a 15-year-old boy, were charged in Sydney with terrorism-related offenses.

title: Sinkhole Opens in Australian Backyard
snippet: Mayor Paul Pisasale of Ipswich said an old mine shaft is the suspected cause of a sinkhole that swallowed part of a backyard on Tuesday, and that experts will investigate it.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Paul Pisasale of Ipswich said an old mine shaft is the suspected cause of a sinkhole that swallowed part of a backyard on Tuesday, and that experts will investigate it.

title: Australia's Feral Cat Problem
snippet: Culling the wild cat population is a necessary step in reducing the threat to other native species.
lead_paragraph: To Brigitte Bardot, it is nothing less than “animal genocide.” To the singer Morrissey, it is “taking idiocy just too far.” Indeed, Australia’s plan to kill two million stray cats — “two million smaller versions of Cecil the Lion,” in Morrissey’s poignant formulation — is a jaw dropper. In a fast urbanizing world, the only cats most people come in contact with are the family pet, an animal to be pampered and scratched, not fed poisoned carrion.

title: Sampras and Chang Master the Australians
snippet: Michael Chang defeats Patrick Rafter and Pete Sampras defeats Mark Philippoussis to give United States 2-0 lead over Australia in tennis's Davis Cup semifinal; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: The yellow jackets menaced, the horns honked, the sirens wailed, and some out-of-towners way up in the crammed bleachers kept waving Australian flags. But Pete Sampras and Michael Chang, the two hired guns who signed on with the United States Davis Cup team for this weekend's semifinal against Australia, were impervious to distractions today.

title: What Was Australia Doing in Vietnam?
snippet: The country contributed some 60,000 soldiers to the American war effort.
lead_paragraph: In July 1967 President Lyndon B. Johnson sent two of his principal advisers, Clark Clifford and Gen. Maxwell Taylor, to Australia and New Zealand with an urgent mission. Protests were raging in American streets and on university campuses. Hawks and doves were battling in Washington. Defense Secretary Robert McNamara was heading toward resignation, an admission that his Vietnam policy had failed.

title: AUSTRALIAN AFFAIR
snippet: Dreadful, distasteful domestic comedy from Australia.
lead_paragraph: INTO the annals of really rotten movie ideas comes ''Norman Loves Rose,'' an Australian Jewish domestic comedy about an infertile young couple and the wife's unusual solution to their problem. After taunting her husband about his inadequacy for a while, she begins an affair with his smarmy, unctuous, 13-year-old brother. A lighthearted theme song attributes the virility of little Norman, who's still in kneepants, to chicken soup.

title: Voter Snapshots: Australians Weigh in

title: 1939: Australian Flyers Arrive
snippet: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Australian airmen arrived as a reinforcement to the Royal Air Force in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The vanguard of a formidable contribution from the far flung Dominions of the British Empire to the Mother Country’s effort with France to secure overwhelming air supremacy arrived at a south coast port this morning [Dec. 26] in the form of a fully organized squadron of the Royal Australian Air Force. This contingent, composed of about two hundred well-trained, sun-browned men from the Antipodes, is the first to reach Britain from any section of the imperial realm of King George VI. The squadron, which was schooled in Australia and is operating four-engine Sunderland flying boats, will be attached to the coastal command in the Royal Air Force after the completion of a course of advanced training at a British air base. Though operating under direction of the Royal Air Force, the squadron will retain identity as an Australian unit. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 27, 1939

title: Australia Day’s Multicultural Significance
snippet: Is the holiday a time when people of all backgrounds feel they belong or a day that celebrates colonization without regard for the colonized?

title: Australia Failed to Protect Asylum Seekers, Report Says
snippet: The government failed to protect asylum seekers locked up in Papua New Guinea during riots that left one man dead and others seriously wounded, a parliamentary inquiry concluded.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian government failed to protect asylum seekers locked up in Papua New Guinea during two days of riots in February that left one man dead and others seriously wounded, a parliamentary inquiry has concluded.

title: The Alarming Allure of Australia’s Brumbies
snippet: The environment is being sacrificed for a national myth.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Since this country’s founding in the early 20th century, the packs of untamed horses that roam freely through our beautiful and hostile alpine landscape have captured the public’s imagination. The savage grace and freedom of the horses — known here as brumbies — have made them into a popular symbol of the national spirit.

title: Gunman Kills 4 in Darwin, Australia
snippet: The police said a 45-year-old man was arrested. The motive for the shooting spree was unclear, but the authorities ruled out terrorism.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The police said four people were shot and killed on Tuesday in Darwin, the capital of Australia’s Northern Territory, when a gunman went on a shooting spree in the city’s main business district.

lead_paragraph: As news of the death of Tina Turner hit Australia’s shores, people all over the country stopped what they were doing and started to dance.

title: Review: Shik in Melbourne, Australia

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Peter Jo has made some bold choices in opening his first restaurant.  Shik, in Melbourne’s Central Business District, is not an easy place to find. Neither is it an easy place to define. Mr. Jo’s cooking represents such a significant leap forward for Korean food in Australia that it’s in danger of missing its audience entirely.

title: An Electoral Brush Fire in Australia
snippet: Once again, analysts overestimated the resonance of climate change and underestimated the power of economic populism.
lead_paragraph: It was another election that couldn’t be lost until it was. Rived by years of infighting, Australia’s conservative governing coalition was trailing in the polls. The opposition Labor Party’s polls showed it all but certain of ousting Prime Minister Scott Morrison, and its action platform on climate change seemed bound to resonate in a country devastated by drought, heat waves, brush fires and the loss of its magnificent Great Barrier Reef to warming seas.

title: Australia to Pay $53 Million Settlement to Detainees Held Offshore

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia has tentatively agreed to a $53 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of asylum seekers housed in one of the country’s contentious offshore detention centers, lawyers for the detainees said on Wednesday.

title: Australia Deal

The shares were purchased from the Bond Corporation, a diversified energy company based in Perth. Bond still holds 2.1 million shares, or 1.4 percent, of Santos.

title: Australia Is Committing Climate Suicide
snippet: As record fires rage, the country’s leaders seem intent on sending it to its doom.
lead_paragraph: BRUNY ISLAND, Australia — Australia today is ground zero for the climate catastrophe. Its glorious Great Barrier Reef is dying, its world-heritage rain forests are burning, its giant kelp forests have largely vanished, numerous towns have run out of water or are about to, and now the vast continent is burning on a scale never before seen.

title: Is This the End of the Line for Nationalism in Australia?
snippet: If this political moment lasts, the country’s conservative movement could be transformed.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Just two months ago, Australia seemed destined for what the country’s commentariat calls a “Tampa” election. That’s local shorthand for a campaign characterized by race baiting and scare tactics about refugees — a term derived from the 2001 election a few months after the government of Prime Minister John Howard ordered special forces to board a Norwegian freight ship called the MV Tampa, carrying more than 400 rescued refugees, to prevent it from reaching Australia.

title: Review: Saba’s in Melbourne, Australia
snippet: Lovingly prepared home cooking in a hip Melbourne neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Brunswick Street in Fitzroy is known as Melbourne’s epicenter of hipsterdom, a stretch of boutiques and bars and cafes catering to the young and fashionable. In many ways, Saba’s, a restaurant that sits smack in the middle of it all, adheres to the neighborhood’s trendy reputation. The design is sleek and simple, with bright pops of color on the wall in the form of vibrant woven plates. The customers are youthful, as expected, but the crowd is far more diverse than it is elsewhere in the area.

title: It's High Noon in the Australian Outback
snippet: An outback western, in which Heath Ledger, his prettiness hidden behind a heavy beard and a stiff, balky manner, plays the legendary 19th-century Australian bandit Ned Kelly. The film's idea of Kelly as an unwitting social revolutionary — somewher...
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century Australian outlaw Ned Kelly may be obscure to many Americans -- at least compared with homegrown folk heroes like Jesse James or Billy the Kid -- but the new movie that bears his name has a familiar rhythm and shape. Though the flora, the fauna and the accents may be exotic ''Ned Kelly,'' directed by Gregor Jordan and drawn from the novel ''Our Sunshine'' by Robert Drewe (rather than on Peter Carey's more recent, revisionist version of the story), has the look and feel of a classic western, as well as some of the genre's limitations.

lead_paragraph: Adam Ferguson, an Australian photographer, has covered geopolitical issues the world over, from India and Greece to Afghanistan and, more recently, Niger. Earlier this year he returned to his home country and embarked on a three-month, 12,000-mile odyssey across Australia’s vast interior. His resulting report, “Through the Outback,” explores the land and its people — and the complicated, evolving relationship that binds them.

title: Review: Joomak in Melbourne, Australia

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Victoria — It is hard to argue with barbecue and fried chicken. Those two foods have snaked their way into the Australian restaurant zeitgeist like no other in recent years, as edible Americana has become ubiquitous here. But these two giants of Southern cookery are also culinary emissaries of Korean culture. And as ambassadors go, you can’t get much more charming and irresistible than sizzling meats and crispy chicken served with plenty of beer.
