title: Push to Empower Police in Australia
snippet: Prime Minister John Howard proposed tough new counterterrorism laws, including allowing the police to use tracking devices to monitor suspected terrorists, and expanding police powers to ''stop, question and search.'' Mr. Howard said the measures ...
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister John Howard proposed tough new counterterrorism laws, including allowing the police to use tracking devices to monitor suspected terrorists, and expanding police powers to "stop, question and search." Mr. Howard said the measures were a response to the London bombings. The program would also give more power to the country's domestic intelligence agency to search houses and intercept mail; would give the police and intelligence agency access to airline passenger information; and would make it a crime to leave baggage unattended at an airport. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Early Humans in Australia
lead_paragraph: Evidence has been found that humans reached Australia 5,000 years earlier than previously found materials, according to the Australian Government's Science Newsletter. The evidence, stone tools found along the Nepean River near Sydney, is 43,000 to 47,000 years old, scientists say.

title: Thousands Flee Australia Floods
snippet: The police are forcing residents in northeast Australia to evacuate their homes, as flood waters continue to inundate the coastal region.
lead_paragraph: The police are forcing residents in northeast Australia to evacuate their homes, as flood waters continue to inundate the coastal region.

title: Lorde Postpones Australian Tour
snippet: The singer said on Twitter that her parents and support team told her she had to take a break to recover.
lead_paragraph: Lorde, the teenage pop star, has had to postpone her scheduled concert tour of Australia because of a chest infection, Billboard magazine reported.

title: Cyclone Strikes North Australia
snippet: A cyclone strikes the north Australian city of Darwin, bringing with it lashing winds and record levels of rainfall.
lead_paragraph: A cyclone strikes the north Australian city of Darwin, bringing with it lashing winds and record levels of rainfall.

title: Australians Unite Amid floods
snippet: Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard visits flood affected areas, and describes a 'fantastic Australian spirit' amid the crisis.
lead_paragraph: Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard visits flood affected areas, and describes a 'fantastic Australian spirit' amid the crisis.

title: Australia Braces for More Floods
snippet: Floods in Australia have inundated an area the size of France plus Germany, and levels are yet to peak in some towns.
lead_paragraph: Floods in Australia have inundated an area the size of France plus Germany, and levels are yet to peak in some towns.

title: Australia Rejects Exchange Deal
snippet: Australia rejected Singapore Exchange’s attempt to merge with the country’s bourse, saying it “would not be in the national interest.”
lead_paragraph: Australia announced its final decision Friday on the Singapore Exchange’s attempt to merge with the country’s bourse, rejecting the proposal because it “would not be in the national interest.”

title: Hostage Standoff in Sydney, Australia
snippet: The man who took hostages in the city’s business district was described by the prime minister as “an armed person claiming political motivation.”
lead_paragraph: The man who took hostages in the city’s business district was described by the prime minister as “an armed person claiming political motivation.”

title: But It's 108 in Australia
snippet: Temp at record 108 degrees, Perth

title: Guantánamo Conviction of Australian Is Overturned
snippet: The decision in the case of David Hicks, an Australian who trained with Al Qaeda, was another setback for the tribunal system set up after the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A military appeals court on Wednesday overturned the terrorism conviction of an Australian whose guilty plea was once hailed as a sign that the tribunal system at the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, prison would be swift and effective.

title: For Australian Wine, a Reversal of Fortune
snippet: A wine critic argues that Australian wine has lost its momentum, thanks to problems at both the low and higih ends of the market.
lead_paragraph: In her weekly column in The Financial Times, Jancis Robinson offers a thoughtful analysis of the problems besetting the Australian wine industry.

title: Australians at Odds Over Rules for Refugees
snippet: Australia is debating whether the relaxation of Australia’s asylum program has emboldened a new wave of illegal immigrants.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — The Australian government, under criticism from the United Nations and others because of its harsh immigration laws, has been quietly rolling back a number of measures that kept refugees locked in prison-like detention centers, sometimes for years.

title: The Original Australians, on Their Creative Turf
snippet: Grace Glueck reviews exhibit of contemporary Aboriginal art from Ramingining, Australia, on view at Asia Society and Museum in New York; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: When the Australian government changed its currency from the Australian pound to the dollar in the 1960's, it used a design made from a bark painting by an Aboriginal artist, David Daymirringu, on the back of the new dollar note. But it neglected to ask the artist's permission, or even to notify him of its interest in his work.

title: Australia to protect natural resources
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE — Australia said it would increase its scrutiny of investment from China and other foreign countries in mining companies, particularly when the investor was also a major customer or government entity seeking a majority stake.

title: Australian Prime Minister on the Fires
snippet: Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd on Tuesday (February 10) reiterated his government's willingness to rebuild communities devastated by deadly bushfires.
lead_paragraph: Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd on Tuesday (February 10) reiterated his government's willingness to rebuild communities devastated by deadly bushfires.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Oil Company Sales
snippet: Australia's Woodside Petroleum Ltd says sales in second quarter rose 9.7 percent; revenue increased to 552.3 million Australian dollars ($283.3 million), from 503.5 million Australian dollars ($259 million) year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: The country's second-largest oil company, Woodside Petroleum Ltd., said sales in the second quarter rose 9.7 percent, helped in part by the lower Australian dollar. Revenue increased to 552.3 million dollars ($283.3 million) in the three months ended June 30, from 503.5 million dollars ($259 million) a year earlier. Domestic gas production was higher than planned because of strong demand, the company said. Oil production fell over all last quarter. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: New Australian Coin
lead_paragraph: Australia introduced a gold coin today weighing a kilogram, or 2.2 pounds, which it says is the largest coin in the world. The Nugget, made of 99.99 percent gold, has a face value of 10,000 Australian dollars (about $7,700).

title: Low Australia Inflation
lead_paragraph: Australia has achieved the lowest inflation rate in the developed world, according to figures released last week. Australia's consumer price index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in the final quarter of 1992, for an annual inflation rate of three-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Reversal on Immigration Policy in Australia
snippet: Australia’s lower house of Parliament on Wednesday passed sweeping immigration reform aimed at deterring asylum seekers by reopening remote offshore detention centers.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The lower house of Australia’s Parliament passed sweeping changes in immigration policy on Wednesday that are meant to deter asylum seekers who try to reach the country by the thousands each year on rickety, overcrowded ships and boats.

title: The End of Australia’s ‘Ambien Slam’
snippet: A wee-hours post from our man Down Under as the tennis ends and he looks forward to adjusting his circadian rhythms.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Covering the Australian Open, which ended later than usual this year, means going through two major time changes.

title: Divided Parliament Opens in Australia
snippet: Australia’s most bitterly divided Parliament in recent history convened for the first time on Tuesday as Prime Minister Julia Gillard urged legislators to engage in “consensus, not confrontation.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia’s most bitterly divided Parliament in recent history convened for the first time on Tuesday as Prime Minister Julia Gillard urged legislators to engage in “consensus, not confrontation.”

title: Risking It All to Reach Australia
snippet: The number of Iranians seeking asylum has been rising around the world, and Australia is no exception. But in a country where immigration is a highly political issue, leaders have struggled to find a response.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Three days after being released from a week’s detention for attending a pro-democracy rally last March in his native Iran, Ahmad made up his mind to flee. A close friend who had taken part in the same demonstration had disappeared into Tehran’s notorious Evin prison, and a phone call from someone claiming to be from the security services led Ahmad to believe he might be next.

title: Grey Expands In Australia
lead_paragraph: Grey Advertising in Sydney has moved from being the 21st largest to 14th largest in Australia by the simple expedient of buying Murray Evans Advertising, the 22d largest.

title: More Bad News for Australia
snippet: More on the travails of the Australian wine industry.
lead_paragraph: In a recent post, I linked to a Jancis Robinson column  analyzing the troubles facing the Australian wine industry, which is experiencing sharply reduced sales in the United States and Europe. Now, Mike Steinberger has chimed in with a fine column  on Slate that makes essentially the same points, with a little more detail and a little less opinion. Very much worth reading.

title: Australia Bauxite
lead_paragraph: The Tipperary Corporation said it had received final approval from the Australian Government for the sale of its interest in the Aurukun bauxite project in Queensland to the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann S.A. for $27 million in cash. Tipperary said it would also receive a deferred payment of 50 cents a ton on an estimated 252 million tons of Bauxite as it is mined.

title: Australian Director Is Thinking Globally
lead_paragraph: Australian baseball has a long way to go to reach the level of play in this country, but it has something major league baseball doesn't have: a commissioner.

title: Obama to Travel to Indonesia, Australia
snippet: President Obama will visit Indonesia and Australia this spring, the White House announced today, a trip that will take Mr. Obama back to a part of the world where he spent several years of his childhood.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will visit Indonesia and Australia this spring, the White House announced today, a trip that will take Mr. Obama back to the area of the world where he spent several years of his childhood.

title: A Cosmopolitan Horse Comes to Australia
snippet: Dandino and his trainer, Marco Botti, are the embodiment of the international nature of the 153rd Melbourne Cup race in Australia.
lead_paragraph: There are few better examples of the cosmopolitan makeup of this 153rd Melbourne Cup field than Dandino. The 6-year-old horse, who started his career in England and has at times left Europe for challenges in Japan, Hong Kong, Canada and the United States, is owned by dozens of Australians, ridden by an English jockey, and conditioned by an Italian trainer based in England. What matters is that he will be one of the favorites.

title: Australia, Baseball’s Diamond in Rough
snippet: The Diamondbacks and the Dodgers will play two exhibition games and a two-game, season-opening series in Sydney, but it is not the first time professional American baseball journeyed to Australia.
lead_paragraph: When Albert Spalding arranged a world tour for his Chicago White Stockings and a team of all-stars that included stops in Australia in December 1888, the baseball writer Henry Chadwick hailed it as “the great event in the modern history of athletic sports.”

title: Singapore Exchange to Buy Australia Counterpart
snippet: The $8.3 billion deal is the first major consolidation of Asia-Pacific exchanges and will result in $30 million in cost savings.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  The Singapore stock exchange on Monday offered to buy its Australian counterpart for $8.3 billion, a purchase that would create a leading player in a region that has not yet experienced the major consolidation that has taken place in other parts of the world.

title: Australia wildfire suspects are freed
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Two people detained for questioning in the fatal wildfires that killed 181 people in southern Australia last week have been released without charge, police said Thursday.

title: Australian Given O.K.
lead_paragraph: CORY READER, a 7-foot, 280-pound center from Brisbane, Australia, will be allowed to play for Brigham Young after all, just not this season.

snippet: Mr. Musk’s defiance over removing content is testing the boundaries of international legal systems.
lead_paragraph: An Australian court on Wednesday extended an injunction ordering the social media platform X to remove videos depicting the recent stabbing of a bishop, setting the country’s judicial system up for a clash with the company’s owner, Elon Musk, who has denounced the court’s order as censorship.

title: Australia's Politics of Global Warming
snippet: Why trust poll-driven lawmakers more than data-driven scientists?
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Huge clumps of strange, pink-stringed jellyfish drifted into the protected bay near my home in Sydney last year. Thousands swarmed under the surface, stinging indiscriminately. I swam through them in a full-body wet suit for several long months with my swimming group, wondering if warmer currents had changed the habitat patterns. Scientists are now talking about a peculiar “jellification” of the sea, prompted by climate change. We smeared ointments on our faces and packed antihistamines and creams for the red welts on our exposed skin.

lead_paragraph: When the Australian Open began today, women's tennis entered the third year of the Monica Seles era, which came fast on the heels of the Steffi Graf era, which came fast on the heels of the Martina Navratilova era.

lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan  Fans wanting to know which Australian pitcher retired the side to start a recent World Baseball Classic tuneup against Japan had to be resourceful to find out. While the Japanese players wore their names on the backs of their uniforms, each member of Australia’s team had an advertisement for sports undergarments sewn above his number.

title: Race's Future in Australia Unclear

title: Australia’s Healthscope Bids for Symbion
lead_paragraph: Healthscope, a private hospital operator in Australia, said Tuesday it had offered 2.86 billion Australian dollars ($2.34 billion) for Symbion Health, an acquisition that would make it the country’s largest pathology services provider.

title: Billions in Stimulus Are Proposed for Australia
snippet: Australia’s prime minister promised the equivalent of $26 billion in spending that will send the national budget into the red for the first time in nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Australia announced another major stimulus plan and its central bank delivered a deep cut in interest rates on Tuesday as the country sought to prop up growth.

title: Asian Cup: Redemption for Australia?
snippet: Australia, a relative newcomer to the Asian confederation, faces Japan in Saturday’s final of the Asian Cup in Japan.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Australia Day was special this year because the Socceroos have made it to the championship game of the Asian Cup, after trouncing Uzbekistan, 6-0. Australia will play Japan for the title on Saturday.

title: Australia’s Former Prime Minister to Challenge Successor
snippet: Former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd said he was “sick and tired” of being blamed for the failures of Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s government.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia announced on Friday that he would challenge his successor, Julia Gillard, for the leadership of the Labor Party and the country in a vote set for Monday morning. The move sets up a showdown to end an acrimonious public leadership battle that analysts warn has begun to paralyze the Australian government.

title: Australian wine exports dropping
lead_paragraph: MURRUMBATEMAN, Australia — From a picturesque hill overlooking the hazy, distant foothills of Australia's eastern ranges, Bruce March can see with crushing clarity a crisis facing the Australian wine export industry.

lead_paragraph: Champ, an Australian private equity firm, has begun looking for buyers for Healthcare Australia, the nation’s largest nursing and aged care staffing business, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

title: Turning Australia Into a Hub for Designers?

One is a traditional boatyard, another is a reclaimed timber mill, a third deals in marble and a fourth is an old shipping container that the product designer Henry Wilson has converted into an office and studio.

title: Australia learns that winning is not everything
lead_paragraph: So much for winning's being the only thing. Australia, which might be thought the society likeliest to accept that peculiarly limited view of sporting endeavor, has spent the last few days finding out quite how misguided it is.

lead_paragraph: Here is the choice: a bottle of brown HP sauce, with London’s Houses of Parliament in sky blue on the label and a secret recipe (tomatoes, tamarind, dates, molasses, malt vinegar, mysterious spices) dating from the late 19th century, or a ramekin of mayonnaise laced with a house-made sambal of bird’s-eye chiles, fish sauce and palm sugar.

title: Football, Australian Style, Meets Basketball
snippet: Professional teams in Australian rules football, enamored of the skills of American big men, are trying to persuade ex-collegians to switch sports.
lead_paragraph: After four seasons as a solid contributor for North Dakota’s basketball team, Patrick Mitchell graduated last year with one professional option: a contract with a low-level club in Portugal.

title: A cautious outlook from Australia
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Major Australian banks are expected to post slower growth in first-half profit, and in some cases a drop in earnings, as lenders battle higher financing costs and rising bad debts stemming from the global credit crisis.

title: Australia's Gillard Retains Power
snippet: Australia's long process of selecting new leadership is over, as Labor's Julia Gillard is able to secure a wafer thin parliamentary majority.
lead_paragraph: Australia's long process of selecting new leadership is over, as Labor's Julia Gillard is able to secure a wafer thin parliamentary majority.

title: Australia facing housing slump
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Australia may be headed for a housing recession similar to those roiling the United States and Britain.

lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON — It is hard to see Robbie Deans remaining coach of Australia beyond the Rugby Championship unless his team’s performances improve dramatically.

title: A U.S. Marine Base for Australia Irritates China

lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — President Obama announced Wednesday that the United States planned to deploy 2,500 Marines in Australia to shore up alliances in Asia, but the move prompted a sharp response from Beijing, which accused Mr. Obama of escalating military tensions in the region.

title: Australia Floods Show No Signs of Retreating
snippet: More than 200,000 people in northeast Australia have been affected by rising flood waters that have knocked out roads and marooned entire towns.
lead_paragraph: Rising waters have knocked out roads and several highways in northeastern Australia, trapping motorists, marooning entire towns and driving thousands from their homes as flooding stretched into its second week on Saturday. More than 200,000 people have been affected so far by the floods, local news media reported.

title: Australia Faces Hung Parliament
snippet: Australia's two major parties started wooing independent lawmakers on Saturday after an inconclusive election left the nation facing its first hung parliament since 1940.
lead_paragraph: Australia's two major parties started wooing independent lawmakers on Saturday after an inconclusive election left the nation facing its first hung parliament since 1940.

title: On the Ground: Kurt Campbell in Australia
Removing the ‘Stain’ on Australia’s Soul
lead_paragraph: Bravo to Australia’s new Prime Minister Kevin Rudd for boldly leading the effort to ease ancient tensions by organizing an official apology to his country’s indigenous people, the Aborigines.

title: Australian wine exports dropping
lead_paragraph: MURRUMBATEMAN, Australia — From a picturesque hill overlooking the hazy, distant foothills of Australia's eastern ranges, Bruce March can see with crushing clarity a crisis facing the Australian wine export industry.

title: Sunset at an Australian Outpost
snippet: I arrived in Port Douglas in time to catch the sunset on the dramatic rain forest range. The two-hour drive north of Cairns on a winding road along virgin coastline had been promising. On the map, Port Douglas looked like the perfect small beach a...
lead_paragraph: I arrived in Port Douglas in time to catch the sunset on the dramatic rain forest range. The two-hour drive north of Cairns on a winding road along virgin coastline had been promising. On the map, Port Douglas looked like the perfect small beach and resort to get away from it all without having to head offshore to the Great Barrier Reef: It was, literally, the end of the road. And this made it irresistible to any misanthropic traveler.

title: Series win looms for Australia
lead_paragraph: ADELAIDE, Australia — Ricky Ponting reached a higher place in cricket's batting elite and Adam Gilchrist made a farewell cameo Sunday as Australia moved closer to a series victory on the fourth day of the fourth cricket test against India.

title: Pleasant Surprise For an Australian
lead_paragraph: The United States Open has been very good to Mark Woodforde of Australia. He made it through the qualifying rounds, now spends every other day advancing through the main draw, enjoys a few giggles during mixed doubles play, and occasionally has an opportunity to practice against Steffi Graf of West Germany, the top-ranked woman.

title: Australian Prime Minister Calls Leadership Vote
snippet: Australia’s embattled prime minister, Julia Gillard, on Thursday slated a vote to determine if her party wishes her to continue as its leader, and therefore as head of the government.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s embattled prime minister, Julia Gillard, on Thursday slated a vote to determine if her party wishes her to continue as its leader, and therefore as head of the government. Analysts saw the move as Ms. Gillard’s attempt to try to end a simmering political crisis that peaked this week when her foreign minister, Kevin Rudd, resigned.

title: An Australian Import Speaks to Brooklyn
snippet: The first United States outpost of the popular Australian coffee company Toby’s Estate instantly attracted all the neighborhood’s types in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: When Toby’s Estate arrived in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in January, it did not take long for the buzz to be heard. And that was not just because of its Rwandan espresso. The first United States outpost of the popular Australian coffee company, this cafe and roastery, housed in a bright, airy former meatpacking factory, instantly attracted all the neighborhood’s types: the entrepreneurial set convening at communal tables for late power breakfasts as well as the stroller-rolling families nestling into the long navy couch.

title: How Azarenka Won Australia
snippet: Victoria Azarenka broke down Maria Sharapova’s game with her superior reception of the ball, allowing her to apply enough topspin to control it while maintaining pace and length.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Azarenka thoroughly outplayed Maria Sharapova in Saturday’s Australian Open final. The spirited Azarkena had superior hands, better footwork and near-perfect shot selection as she withstood Sharapova’s blistering pace with astonishing ease. How did Azarenka handle Sharapova’s big game? And why did Sharapova struggle when Azarenka attacked?

title: For Kudla, a Quick Qualification in Australia
snippet: Before he could battle his own way through the qualifying draw of the 2012 Australian Open, the 19-year-old Denis Kudla needed some help from the rest of the field.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Before he could battle his own way through the qualifying draw of the 2012 Australian Open, the 19-year-old Denis Kudla needed some help from the rest of the field.

title: 36 Hours in Melbourne, Australia
snippet: Often overlooked by travelers as they sprint their way through Australia’s Big Three tourist attractions, visitors should take some time to appreciate this laid-back city.
lead_paragraph: IT’S hard not to feel some sympathy for Melbourne. Often overlooked by travelers as they sprint their way through Australia’s Big Three tourist attractions — the dazzling metropolis of Sydney, the startlingly beautiful Great Barrier Reef and the historic Aboriginal site of Uluru — this laid-back city is a place that takes some time to appreciate. But Melbourne slowly grows on you as you stroll around the immaculately preserved Victorian-era downtown or along the revitalized Yarra waterfront, or linger over a cup of “flat white” in one of trendy cafes on Chapel Street (where the very mention of the name Starbucks is greeted with horror). And in January, at least, it has something that Sydney and those other places don’t: the Australian Open. This is a country that loves its tennis, and for two weeks, this city feels like a nonstop party, one in which the chances that a local hero may finally take the title are debated each night in the pubs and where even a doubles match played on an outside court and featuring unranked players from the former Eastern Bloc will draw a capacity crowd. Who needs the Opera House?

title: WikiLeaks Founder Speaks Australian
snippet: Leaving a police station on Friday, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, proved that despite his nomadic lifestyle in recent years, he is, at heart, an Australian.
lead_paragraph: Updated | 6:33 p.m. As a crowd of reporters and bystanders watched, and filmed, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, visited a police station in the English town of Beccles on Friday, where he is obliged to check in each day as a condition of his release on bail.

title: The Vatican: Australian Saint Approved
snippet: Pope Benedict XVI approved sainthood on Friday for Mary Helen MacKillop, who will become Australia’s first Roman Catholic saint.
lead_paragraph: Pope Benedict XVI approved sainthood on Friday for Mary Helen MacKillop, who will become Australia’s first Roman Catholic saint. Sister Mary of the Cross, as she was known, founded the Congregation of the Sisters of Saint Joseph of the Sacred Heart in Australia. Since 1866, the order has built schools, orphanages and centers for the homeless and the needy in Australia and New Zealand.

title: South Sudanese, Seeking to Fit In, Stand Out in Australian Basketball
snippet: A program meant for fun now has to protect its young players from something it never expected: the interest of American recruiters.
lead_paragraph: BLACKTOWN, Australia — The teenage boys rush the ball down the court, knowing that the losing team will face another round of the lung-crushing wind sprints that make their borrowed gym at a police athletic center here even more confining.

title: Australia Drifts, With No Guiding Star
snippet: Australia faces a host of international problems, but its top candidates for leadership are hopelessly beyond their depth.
lead_paragraph: In easygoing Australia, the overwhelming focus on pedestrian domestic issues at election time is excusable. But the absence of genuine debate on foreign policy, trade or regional security has been alarming. With less than two weeks before election day, the Labor leader Julia Gillard, who became prime minister in June, and the conservative opposition leader, Tony Abbott, have set Australia on course for the foreign policy doldrums.

title: Australian Open Begins With Eye on Henin and Clijsters
snippet: At the Australian Open, Roger Federer is the 3-1 favorite on the men’s side over the defending champion Rafael Nadal. On the women’s side, Serena Williams is a slim favorite over Kim Clijsters.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia  Like politics, all sports are local, and the passions of Australians have been on full display the past 72 hours. Virtually every television and car radio has been tuned to the cricket test between Australia and Pakistan under way in Hobart  between lunch and tea, of course. Horse racing has been off and running day and night, too, from one rugged coast to another.

title: The Aftermath of Australia’s Worst Fires
snippet: The police said Monday that at least 131 people had died in wildfires over the weekend, making the firestorm the country’s deadliest natural disaster on record.
lead_paragraph: The police said Monday that at least 131 people had died in wildfires over the weekend, making the firestorm the country’s deadliest natural disaster on record.

title: A caution issued on the Australian economy
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Breakneck economic growth in Australia will have to slow if inflation is to be contained, a senior central banker said Tuesday, while noting that significant uncertainties surrounded the economic outlook.

title: Fernandez Is Out Of Australian Open
snippet: Mary Joe Fernandez withdraws from Australian Open (S)
lead_paragraph: Mary Joe Fernandez withdrew from next month's Australian Open and a warm-up tournament because of a recurring wrist injury, the WTA Tour said.

title: Japan Defies Australia on Whaling
snippet: Australia said it will argue in the International Court of Justice in The Hague that Japanese whaling expeditions violate international obligations.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan rebuffed a threat by Australia to take Tokyo to court over its whaling in the Antarctic, saying on Friday that the annual hunts were permitted under international law and accusing the Australian government of exploiting the issue for political gain.

title: Sheep Curb In Australia
lead_paragraph: The Australian Government approved tough new curbs today on farmers aimed at forcing them to trim the country's sheep population of 180 million.

title: Final: Germany Dominates Australia
snippet: Entrenched reliability meets newfound uncertainty meets glowing potential as Germany alights on South Africa’s east coast in Durban to begin another bid.
lead_paragraph: With the most comprehensively excellent performance of any team thus far in the World Cup, Germany made a proud Australian side look hopeless on Sunday night in Durban and cast itself as perhaps more of a contender than observers thought.

title: Entergy Is Selling Australian Unit
snippet: American Electric Power Co to buy Entergy Corp's electric distribution unit in Australia for $1.1 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: The American Electric Power Company agreed today to buy the Entergy Corporation's electric distribution unit in Australia for $1.1 billion, continuing its push to expand in that nation.

title: Back to the Drawing Board for Australia
snippet: Australia was thrashed in the opening match of the Rugby Championship, 47-29, by New Zealand, wrecking the coaching debut of Ewen McKenzie.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON — Ewen McKenzie’s honeymoon period as Australia’s coach lasted all of 80 minutes as his side was thrashed, 47-29, by New Zealand in the opening match of the Rugby Championship.

title: 'CACTUS,' AUSTRALIAN ROMANCE
lead_paragraph: DIALOGUE is to the movie ''Cactus'' what rain is to the plant; seasons pass without much of it. But the director, Paul Cox, who helped write the screenplay, keeps the theater filled with sound. There are the attention-exciting bird calls of the Australian bush, particularly a cry like whiiiiip that whips out to startling effect the first couple of times, and lovely church music for soprano and countertenor. When the dialogue does start up, we miss them. ''It's not goodbye, it's a new kind of hello,'' says the hero to the heroine. Bring on the birds.

title: Australian Men Sentenced for Terrorism Plot
snippet: Prosecutors said the men had stockpiled dangerous chemicals, firearms and ammunition as part of a plan to wage Islamist jihad against the Australian government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  An Australian court on Monday sentenced five Muslim men to prison terms of 23 to 28 years for conspiracy to commit acts of terror, according to reports from ABC Radio and news agencies.

title: The Next ‘Better Place’ Is Australia
snippet: Shai Agassi, the former SAP software technologist turned electric vehicle crusader, announced Wednesday that he was adding Australia to the “island” nations planning to deploy his Better Place electric vehicle network.
